fields.headline: No: 1679 Tesco
fields.body:
What's the trouble, old bean? Finally somebody has had the nerve to stand up and tell those euro- johnnies in Brussels just where to shove their sprouts. Jolly good show!

You've been reading the Sun again, haven't you? I've had it up to here with lily-livered, namby-pamby, Guardian-reading liberals throwing away our nation's heritage. I'm going to do my shopping at Tesco from now on.

What are you on about? Tesco has announced that it is going to display the weight of all its goods in pounds and ounces at all 658 of its British stores. Suppliers will be told to change labels to imperial and metric on pre-packed foods.

Are Tesco's shoppers thicker than, say, Sainsbury's? Quite possibly. A Tesco survey found that more than threequarters of its shoppers wanted to buy goods in pounds and ounces, and said they found metric weights confusing. Its home shopping service has had bungled orders - one asked for three kilos of broccoli instead of three pounds.

But they don't have that problem at Tesco service stations. True. Petrol will still be sold only in litres.

Isn't all this illegal? Under EC regulations introduced in January, metric measurements are meant to take precedence over imperial ones. Tesco could be fined £2,000 for every price sign which fails to use metric, but says it will still display them. Unfortunately, it has no plans to revive those marvellous traditional imperial measures - the thirdenmel, the ell, not to mention the scruple.

What's the Sun's view of all this? Under the heading "KO for the kilo", the Sun says: "Tesco bosses are taking a huge commercial and legal risk. We applaud them for it."

Any response from across the Channel? Yes indeed. Le Monde Diplomatique has launched a campaign with full-page ads to appear in the British press from tomorrow, which state: "Hey, rosbifs! Not arnly do your ladiez all fancy us sexy Frenchmen, but no-one across La Manche gives a mornkey's about your laughable pounds and arnces. You are pathetique at le football, you can't beat Ecuador at le tennis, and now you can't even weigh your sperds properly. Ha!"

You made that last bit up, didn't you? Yes.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 Just when he needs a period of feud-less tranquility to recover strength for the election ahead, Mr Tony Blair will rejoice to hear that the next major embarrassment may be delayed until the autumn when two interesting books will appear. The Independent's Don McIntyre is updating his O'Mandy Mandelson biography, while - also in time for conference - the Observer's Andrew Rawnsley will publish a tome concentrating on the Brown-Blair relationship. Speculation begins to grow as to whether one or both will name the source of the home loan story that removed O'Mandy from cabinet - one that appeared first in this newspaper and later in Paul Routledge's book. God only knows who, if anyone, these commentators have in mind, but pray with us that the person unknown does not prove to be a close associate of Gordon Brown's, let alone a member of the government (or even, God forbid, the cabinet). The reopening of that old wound could make election strategy meetings between O'Mandy and the weirdo chancellor almost too spicy to bear.

 Speaking of sources for internecine briefings, it was great to see Alastair Campbell denying the "psychologically flawed" briefing in Michael Cockerell's documentary with such darting-eyed assurance. Even if you didn't quite have to be Desmond Morris to read the body language, the next time anyone films Ali (in whatever his new career might be?) it would seem a shame to leave the polygraph at home.

 Home office minister Charles Clarke is quite a charmer. The man who explained that Mr T's use of cash point was "a metaphor" was at a party recently when a fellow guest reminded him that the two knew each other at university. For whatever reason - possibly antihistamines prescribed for hayfever - Charles didn't seem quite himself, and became a little brusque as a debate developed over law and order until it became too much for him. "You say we knew each other at Cambridge," said the silver-tongued sweetheart. "Did we sleep together?" Ah, but you just can't beat a bit of old world courtesy...

 This summer's search for a musical legend, in succession to Kenny Ball, his Jazzmen and others, concerns a particular favourite. She's been to Nice and the Isle of Greece and any place she could run... but does anyone know where Charlene is now? While the only white artist on the Motown label and running a sweetshop in Essex (I'm not making this up; at least I don't think I am) Charlene had a 1982 number one with the unforgettable I've Never Been To Me. All information gratefully received.

 David Carter writes with a suggestion as to how to spend our August weekend with the £250,000 Rolls-Royce Corniche (RR1). He invites the Diary to drive to Middlesbrough, where our extracts from local MP Stuart Bell's Paris, 69, went down well. With Boris the Jackal Johnson in mind, he says that a candidate will be required "to replace our current MP when he stands down just before the next election to take his well deserved seat in the Lords," (Stuart, you never mentioned a word to us) "and you could gain a head start on any of your so-called rivals..." I had been intending to stand for Henley, but this is most enticing. Let me sleep on it.

 A clerk at Chicago's city hall wages war on the misconception about bureaucrats being unfeeling. Concerned not to discriminate against citizens simply for being deceased, this genius wrote to Abby Frene advising her that she could still sue the city over an employment claim. "You died May 2 2000, and you have no survivors," the letter explains, before telling her to call the office should she have any questions.

fields.headline: PM's thoughts mirrored Mail editorial
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair faced renewed embarrassment last night when it emerged that his leaked memo mirrored an editorial published in the Daily Mail on the day that he put pen to paper.
fields.body:
Tony Blair faced renewed embarrassment last night when it emerged that his leaked memo mirrored an editorial published in the Daily Mail on the day that he put pen to paper.

In a powerful sign of the hold that middle market tabloids have over the prime minister, all but one of his five "thoughts" were raised in the editorial which lambasted Mr Blair for being "openly contemptuous of public opinion".

The editorial rounded on the government in the wake of a series of ministerial attacks on William Hague for defending the Norfolk farmer Tony Martin who was jailed for the murder of a teenage burglar.

The Mail asked its readers: "Feel queasy about how the law dealt with Tony Martin? A 'progressive' legal establishment that has presided over an explosion in crime since the war will mark you down as an ignorant vigilante."

Mr Blair's first "thought" in his memo was about the Martin case.

The editorial said that the Martin case highlighted the need for tougher sentencing of the teenagers who hounded Martin - Mr Blair's third "thought" in which he wrote of the need to highlight "tough measures".

After its defence of Martin the Mail turned its fire on the government's handling of asylum seekers - Mr Blair's second "thought".

The paper then condemned the government for opposing section 28, and its decision to abolish the married couple's tax allowance - Mr Blair's fifth "thought".

The government last night denied that the prime minister had been influenced by the Mail.

The Scottish secretary, John Reid, told Channel 4 News: "Finding one [editorial] on one particular day where some of the themes coincide with some of the themes the prime minister wants to mention within one of hundreds of memos, isn't exactly Sherlock Holmes, it's more like Inspector Clouseau."

fields.headline: Inside Mr Tony Blair. And what a sight it proves to be
fields.standfirst:
The Blair leak: Hugo Young inspects the saddening contents of the prime minister's mind
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The Blair leak: Hugo Young inspects the saddening contents of the prime minister's mind
fields.body:
All prime ministers communicate their political alarms. All comment on performance, chivvy colleagues, stagger towards a strategy, circulate private missives, worry about the future, commit to paper or email thoughts that aren't meant to be widely seen. These are necessarily secret, and often reckless, and they would always be dynamite if leaked at the time.

"He accused me of lying and I wasn't having that... He got up in the most abusive way and I told him to sit down... He was shouting resignation threats, attacking the decision taken, and he came round the table to leer at me and said we had made a great blunder tonight - 'Not the first you have made', he said." Thus wrote Harold Wilson, of George Brown, on March 18 1968. If it had got out, it would have spoiled Wilson's holiday. Like Tony Blair, he was living on his nerve-ends.

The political scene was in fact more neuralgic in those days than it is now. Less than three years into power, the Wilson government was always in a state of panic, as the diarists inside the cabinet recorded. "Number 10 lives in an atmosphere of intrigue," noted Tony Benn on August 5 1966, "encouraged by George Wigg who is completely crazy, Marcia [Falkender] who gets a bit hysterical and Gerald Kaufman who just sits wisely and nods." There are no demented analogues in residence in 2000 yet, not even Alastair Campbell.

Wilson's preoccupations, though, were different from Blair's. The diaries open up a world that is barely recognisable today, in which the media featured little and the public not at all. The talk is all of speeches to be made, cabinets to be squared, parliament to be won, and the party to be stitched up. That is how politics used to be. Richard Crossman and Barbara Castle chronicle incessant anti-Wilson plotting that was second nature to the Labour party of the 1960s, but against a background of bloody argument about principle and policy that hardly exists at all in the 2000s.

Arguably, Mr Blair's April memo, baring his anxieties about what voters will think of him, is updating the Wilson era, simply identifying a new set of enemies. Modern leaders may be obliged to see the media as the new conspirators to be schemed against day and night. The public, not parliament, are the agents whose opinion will decide. The memo, so nakedly concerned with impression over substance, might be called benign in its search for a direct connection with the people. Perhaps a prime minister obsessed with pleasing the electorate is preferable to one obsessed with balancing five fractions of the Tribune group of MPs.

There is something in this. Mr Blair is demonstrably a leader who cares about his programme. He is not, deep at heart, a cynic. His concern for appearances can be explained by his perception that, unless the government tries to control them, these will be determined by people who have no interest in creating a mood of national optimism or even vague approval for what is going on. Though Wilson had many run-ins with the newspapers, he didn't have to live with the power of the media to drown every version of the truth except their own.

All the same, the tenor of the memo is terribly depressing. It shows the lengths to which a desperate man has been driven, away from the steady path of purposeful reform into the dead end of instant wheezes and bogus responses. Private though it was meant to be, it is one of those papers whose secrecy enhances rather than distorts its ghastly veracity. It lines up in black and white the government's two most crippling tendencies.

First, we learn how little policy in the field of law and order is sane, rational or orderly. It is not substance-based but initiative-based. Do anything as long as it looks harsh. The words from the top are there for all to study. It's all about being seen to do "something tough, with immediate bite". This is already the policy, an aggrieved prime minister writes. But because people don't understand that, harder things must be invented to make sure they get the message. Jack up the figures, rush in the laws, hammer home the asylum-removals. And then increase the defence budget for no better reason than to be seen "standing up for Britain".

Running through these law and order attitudes is Mr Blair's own most consistent defect as a progressive politician: his indifference to, almost his contempt for, civil liberties. I've never heard him giving them priority. At the last party conference he spat on the very concept. In this field he's been the crudest populist, masquerading behind the smile of a man of reason. More generally, in obeisance to family and patriotism alike, he seems prepared to reduce all policy-making to the service of his next mandate. Ask not how you can lead the people, but how you decipher their instincts and then gratify them. Very regrettably, this, defiling much that has been well done, is what it has come to.

But it may not be the most ominous defect that now comes into full focus. The second theme running through the not-for-your-eyes message is the leader's concentration on himself. When he emphasises that "I personally should be associated with as much of this as possible", he reflects the way the politics of New Labour have been conducted for six years. He did, after all, believe the only way to guarantee victory in 1997 was by ensuring that his alone was the voice the country heard. And he has done much with power by his personal qualities: think of Ireland, education, parts of Europe. But presidentialism now aspires to go further. It can be a dangerously counter-productive style.

For one thing it has weakened Labour's greatest source of strength, the colossal parliamentary majority. This is a startling perversity. The government is now tossing about as if it were living on a parliamentary knife-edge, a direct result of Blairite arrogance and mismanagement. If you weaken parliament's importance, you cannot mobilise its strength. We entirely forget that this government is the strongest in living memory, for the unhappy reason that its leader behaves like one whose strength resides almost entirely within himself. His colleagues barely count. Not only parliament but the cabinet will be missing from any ministerial diaries of the power-struggles in the first Blair term.

In place of the collective, one man has ruled the zeitgeist. One man, unfortunately, is a frail performer. He cannot do it all, and if he falters, who takes up the slack? So strong a year ago, he is capable of weakening, and has not placed much of a safety-net below. We begin to get intimations of a style that needs drastically to change, yet one that may already have made too many enemies, especially in his own party, to enable this easily to be done. The leak is a vile blow, against the right of leaders to ruminate and direct. But it's a savage caution, and it does not tell a lie.

hugoyoung@compuserve.com

webTitle: Matthew Engel: Vice-presidential candidates have a great tradition to uphold

fields.headline: Where first prize is to come second
fields.standfirst: Vice-presidential candidates have a great tradition to uphold
fields.trailText: Matthew Engel: Vice-presidential candidates have a great tradition to uphold
fields.body:
In 1931 there was a hit Broadway musical called Of Thee I Sing (written by George S Kaufman, music by the Gershwins) which included a character called Alexander Throttlebottom, vice president of the United States. He agrees to take the job only when he is persuaded that his mother is never likely to find out. Throttlebottom then spends most of his time in office feeding pigeons in the park. He can't get a library card (no one will give him a reference), and his only way into the White House is by joining the conducted tour.

It is widely believed in America that there actually was a vice president called Throttlebottom. Since there were real ones called Hannibal Hamlin, Schuyler Colfax and William Rufus de Vane King, not to mention Hubert Horatio Humphrey, this is an understandable mistake.

It is also widely believed that Franklin Roosevelt's first vice president, John Nance Garner, said the office was "not worth a pitcher of warm spit". However, Garner was a grizzled old Texas pol (known as Cactus Jack); he was addressing the equally grizzled Lyndon Johnson at the time; and the quote was then filtered through the famously puritanical American press. So you can take it that "spit" was not the original word.

Now, for the true connoisseur of such arcana, a double treat is in store. For the first time since the most dramatic of American political seasons, 1968, both parties are approaching the convention season with the vice-presidential position up for grabs. Throttlebottoms all over America are stirring on the off-chance of a call from the candidates: Gush and Bore.

The vice-presidency was a constitutional afterthought, and has caused institutionalised amusement since the first incumbent, John Adams, complained that the job was "utterly insignificant". The vice president has only ever had two roles: to take over if anything happens to the president, and to fill in his days by presiding over the senate.

That's one job more than the heir to the British throne has, and Adams could have made more of his position: he could have spent his days complaining about new-fangled architecture, for instance. Instead, after a period of unsuccessfully trying to tell the senate what to do, he did as little as possible. President Washington could not have cared less what his deputy did, but Adams was held back by a mixture of pique (until 1804 the vice president was the runner-up rather than a running-mate), diffidence and a stern constructionist view of the constitution.

And so the tradition of uselessness and eccentricity began. The vice presidents have included Aaron Burr, the murderer, Elbridge Gerry, inventor of the gerrymander, Daniel D Tompkins, a hopeless drunk, Richard M Johnson, who spent more time presiding over his tavern than the senate, and James Schoolcraft Sherman, who weighed 20 stone, making him slightly slimmer than the president, William H Taft.

The dandy William R de V King was widely presumed to be the gay lover of his president, James Buchanan. In contrast, when William Wheeler was chosen to run with Rutherford Hayes in 1876, Hayes wrote: "I am ashamed to say, who is Wheeler?"

Fortunately, not every vice president was wholly insignificant because, as the Americans acquired the taste for murdering their presidents (especially those elected in years ending in zero), the possibility of succession could not be treated lightly. But for much of the 19th century, the presidency itself was overshadowed by congressional power, and it was not until the Franklin Roosevelt era that the balance changed irreversibly.

Cactus Jack quit in 1940, and the vice-president for Roosevelt's third term was Henry Wallace. This was as near as America ever got to having a genuinely leftwing president because Wallace was a seriously radical thinker, interested in mystic religion and world poverty. Roosevelt broke vice- presidential tradition by giving him a proper job, running the board of economic warfare, but Wallace lost that when the House committee of un-American activities reported that he employed "pinkos, nudists, Communists and world-savers". Roosevelt kicked him off the ticket in 1944, and replaced him with an obscure Missouri politician called Harry Truman. There but for fortune: if Roosevelt had died just before his fourth term began instead of just afterwards, post-war history might have been very different.

And since then the job has gained a much higher profile. Seven of the last 10 vice presidents, counting Gore, have gone on to get their party's nomination for No 1. Even so, there has still been time for the ineffable and crooked Spiro Agnew ("If you've seen one slum, you've seen 'em all"), the bone-headed J Danforth Quayle (who corrected a schoolboy's spelling of potato to add a final e) and Nelson Rockefeller (a substantial politician in his time but famous now mainly for his enviable death, aged 71 - in flagrante with a 25-year-old). One trusts that this year's nominees will uphold a great American tradition.

fields.bodyText: In 1931 there was a hit Broadway musical called Of Thee I Sing (written by George S Kaufman, music by the Gershwins) which included a character called Alexander Throttlebottom, vice president of the United States. He agrees to take the job only when he is persuaded that his mother is never likely to find out. Throttlebottom then spends most of his time in office feeding pigeons in the park. He can't get a library card (no one will give him a reference), and his only way into the White House is by joining the conducted tour. It is widely believed in America that there actually was a vice president called Throttlebottom. Since there were real ones called Hannibal Hamlin, Schuyler Colfax and William Rufus de Vane King, not to mention Hubert Horatio Humphrey, this is an understandable mistake. It is also widely believed that Franklin Roosevelt's first vice president, John Nance Garner, said the office was "not worth a pitcher of warm spit". However, Garner was a grizzled old Texas pol (known as Cactus Jack); he was addressing the equally grizzled Lyndon Johnson at the time; and the quote was then filtered through the famously puritanical American press. So you can take it that "spit" was not the original word. Now, for the true connoisseur of such arcana, a double treat is in store. For the first time since the most dramatic of American political seasons, 1968, both parties are approaching the convention season with the vice-presidential position up for grabs. Throttlebottoms all over America are stirring on the off-chance of a call from the candidates: Gush and Bore. The vice-presidency was a constitutional afterthought, and has caused institutionalised amusement since the first incumbent, John Adams, complained that the job was "utterly insignificant". The vice president has only ever had two roles: to take over if anything happens to the president, and to fill in his days by presiding over the senate. That's one job more than the heir to the British throne has, and Adams could have made more of his position: he could have spent his days complaining about new-fangled architecture, for instance. Instead, after a period of unsuccessfully trying to tell the senate what to do, he did as little as possible. President Washington could not have cared less what his deputy did, but Adams was held back by a mixture of pique (until 1804 the vice president was the runner-up rather than a running-mate), diffidence and a stern constructionist view of the constitution. And so the tradition of uselessness and eccentricity began. The vice presidents have included Aaron Burr, the murderer, Elbridge Gerry, inventor of the gerrymander, Daniel D Tompkins, a hopeless drunk, Richard M Johnson, who spent more time presiding over his tavern than the senate, and James Schoolcraft Sherman, who weighed 20 stone, making him slightly slimmer than the president, William H Taft. The dandy William R de V King was widely presumed to be the gay lover of his president, James Buchanan. In contrast, when William Wheeler was chosen to run with Rutherford Hayes in 1876, Hayes wrote: "I am ashamed to say, who is Wheeler?" Fortunately, not every vice president was wholly insignificant because, as the Americans acquired the taste for murdering their presidents (especially those elected in years ending in zero), the possibility of succession could not be treated lightly. But for much of the 19th century, the presidency itself was overshadowed by congressional power, and it was not until the Franklin Roosevelt era that the balance changed irreversibly. Cactus Jack quit in 1940, and the vice-president for Roosevelt's third term was Henry Wallace. This was as near as America ever got to having a genuinely leftwing president because Wallace was a seriously radical thinker, interested in mystic religion and world poverty. Roosevelt broke vice- presidential tradition by giving him a proper job, running the board of economic warfare, but Wallace lost that when the House committee of un-American activities reported that he employed "pinkos, nudists, Communists and world-savers". Roosevelt kicked him off the ticket in 1944, and replaced him with an obscure Missouri politician called Harry Truman. There but for fortune: if Roosevelt had died just before his fourth term began instead of just afterwards, post-war history might have been very different. And since then the job has gained a much higher profile. Seven of the last 10 vice presidents, counting Gore, have gone on to get their party's nomination for No 1. Even so, there has still been time for the ineffable and crooked Spiro Agnew ("If you've seen one slum, you've seen 'em all"), the bone-headed J Danforth Quayle (who corrected a schoolboy's spelling of potato to add a final e) and Nelson Rockefeller (a substantial politician in his time but famous now mainly for his enviable death, aged 71 - in flagrante with a 25-year-old). One trusts that this year's nominees will uphold a great American tradition. matthewengel@ndirect.co.uk

fields.headline: Unsafe texts
fields.standfirst:
New Labour in power: special report
Privacy on the net: special report
fields.trailText: Richard Adams: One evening last week someone from Surinam tried to break into my computer. I was sitting in south London surfing the internet, and a person on another continent thousands of miles away was attempting to hack into my PC, right in front of my nose.
fields.body:
One evening last week someone from Surinam tried to break into my computer. I was sitting in south London surfing the internet, and a person on another continent thousands of miles away was attempting to hack into my PC, right in front of my nose.

All my anonymous friend in Surinam did was the computer equivalent of trying a door to see if it was open. He or she rattled the handle a couple of times, couldn't get in, and left. So while it was disconcerting - like hearing someone try your front door in the middle of the night - it's no reason to rush out and get security guards.

Cyber-crime now worries a lot of people. As Tony Blair's emails leak, the government's Regulation of Investigatory Powers bill is going through the Lords. Not only is this one of the most sustained attacks on civil liberties in recent history - allowing for powers of surveillance that Stalin would have been delighted with - the bill will also fail in its aim of tightening computer security. It would be powerless against my Surinam visitor, as Jack Straw's writ does not run to South America just yet. Flawed computer software and inadequate management are the biggest contributors to cyber-crime in this country - not the Russian Mafia or spotty teenage hackers.

Imagine if cars were sold with just a standard key, which started every car of that model. That, in effect, is how most commercial software is released. Had I left my computer exactly as it was when I took it out of its box, my potential hacker from Surinam would have been able to get in. By rushing out new products, with little regard for security or time to check for dangerous flaws, software makers actually allow hackers to flourish. The majority of successful attacks on computers over the internet can be traced to the exploitation of one of a small number of security flaws. Microsoft is one of the worst offenders: it has just announced an update for its new Windows 2000 operating system that patches up 35 "access violation errors", and 65,000 bugs in total.

A Welsh teenager, Raphael Gray, was arrested this year for breaking into commercial websites and publishing details of customers' credit cards. Gray said: "You could teach your grandmother how to do what I was doing." That suggests Gray isn't really a hacker, but a "script kiddie" - the pejorative name proper hackers use for those who simply download free programs from the internet, and use them to exploit the well-publicised weaknesses in commercial software.

Gray says he first warned companies their sites were insecure. When they didn't respond, he posted thousands of credit card details on the internet until someone took notice. The FBI sent an agent, in regulation trench-coat, to the small village where Gray lives to be present at the bust. But something must be going wrong if an 18-year-old, with just a home computer and basic skills, can operate out of a bedroom in Wales and find confidential information.

Any shop that allowed a teenager to walk in off the street and scoop up pages of customers' bank details and credit cards would be guilty of lax security. Why should websites be any different? They are the ones with the IT departments and professional systems administrators who should be able to lock out the script kiddies. But enough of them aren't able to, because the most common mistake made by companies is to assign untrained people to maintain security.

While it's annoying to have sites defaced by snot-nosed punks, it does at least mean that systems are being tested in a relatively benign manner. The good news is that the majority of hackers aren't interested in stealing credit cards, and most of them don't break the law. They are curious about how computers work, and are more interested in the challenges involved in hacking than anything else. That's a small price, a sort of survival-of-the-smartest computer Darwinism, for exposing the hidden entrances and rickety defences of modern software.

richard.adams@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Dollars for peace
fields.standfirst:
As the Camp David talks reach their most delicate stage, a settlement might depend on promises of cash and security guarantees

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: As the Camp David talks reach their most delicate stage, a settlement might depend on promises of cash and security guarantees
fields.body:
As Palestinians and Israelis wrangle at Camp David, Bill Clinton may be reminded of a dispute that wise King Solomon, builder of the temple in Jerusalem, settled 3,000 years ago. Confronted by two women, both of whom claimed the same baby, Solomon suggested cutting the child in half. At that, one of the women offered to let the other take the child, if only the king would spare its life. Seeing her concern, Solomon knew instantly that she was the true mother.

The problem for Clinton over the fate of Jerusalem is that neither claimant gives the required response. One would happily split the child in two; one insists on keeping it while allowing the other to look after parts. The solution - both for Jerusalem and the Occupied Territories - is simple in theory. It means resolving rival claims of sovereignty and control so that granting ownership to one side is balanced by granting rights to the other. The difficult part is how to do this fairly.

A deal can be worked out over the West Bank, creating a Palestinian state while allowing the Israelis to retain some settlements. But the Palestinians are worried at the control this would mean ceding to the Israelis. How to give access to settlers from Israel proper without making a mockery of a Palestinian state? Jerusalem involves matters of principle, since both sides want it as their capital. Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak proposed extending the city's boundaries to accommodate a Palestinian seat of government but insists on having sovereignty, even though he might not object to Palestinian flags flying in parts of it.

On the Palestinian side Yasser Arafat cannot afford to concede sovereignty of East Jerusalem to the Israelis. Apart from finishing him politically, it would cause fury in the rest of the Arab and Muslim world. President Clinton may therefore have to propose a third way which might, for instance, involve internationalising or "Vaticanising" the old (religious) part of the city. Some Israelis would certainly reject that, so if he can come up with a solution which is acceptable to both sides it will be nothing short of a triumph. The failings of his presidency could deservedly be forgiven, if not forgotten.

Despite the news blackout at Camp David, it is clear from leaks to the Arab and Is raeli press that the talks have now moved from the first phase - establishing the bottom line on each side - to the stage where the Americans seek to close the gaps. This is the most delicate part because Mr Clinton not only has to demonstrate to both sides that he has workable proposals and earnestly wants to strike a deal, but must also secure the confidence of the Palestinians who, up to now, have regarded his administration as more concerned with Mr Barak's problems than their own.

Apart from ideas, the main things the Americans can bring to the table are money and security guarantees. Money can lubricate a deal by making minor concessions easier to accept. Mr Clinton will almost certainly make an attractive "unrepeatable" offer of aid to a Palestinian state, and more money would help towards solving the refugee problem.

Money would also be needed for construction work to provide sensible and secure movement within Jerusalem, between the West Bank and Gaza, and between Israel and any remaining settlements. The Israelis, in addition, will want money to resettle displaced settlers behind the 1967 borders, and money for weapons - essential, they will say - to guarantee their security. The cost would certainly run into tens of billions of dollars. Both sides will be looking for firm promises from the Americans but Mr Clinton cannot be sure how the Congress will respond to what is perceived by some as his personal "legacy project".

After 50 years of conflict it would scarcely be surprising if the talks failed - though barring a dramatic walk-out, a failure would more likely be described officially as an adjournment, if only to hold off Mr Arafat's threatened unilateral declaration of a Palestinian state. Whatever happens on other issues, the refugee question cannot be totally resolved at Camp David because it involves other countries who are not represented - notably Jordan, Lebanon and Syria - but a framework for a solution could be established.

The most easily achievable outcome, an incomplete deal creating a Palestinian state in the West Bank and Gaza but postponing the question of Jerusalem, seems the least likely. At this stage, neither side regards such a deal, on its own, as worth having. The Palestinians remain suspicious of Mr Clinton's assumed role as an honest broker, and some suggest it would be better to wait for the next president.

Mr Barak's problem, apart from his enemies at home, is the opposite. Future American administrations can scarcely be more sympathetic to Israel - and will probably be less so. Israel has already served its strategic cold war purpose for the US and is now simply one among several American allies in the Middle East. That change has not yet filtered through into American public opinion, but it will do eventually - as Mr Barak is well aware. A deal now, even with some painful concessions, could be a lot better for Israel than a deal later.

Mr Clinton's incentive is no less than Mr Barak's, and even more personal. Success now would not only give a huge boost to the Democrats in their election campaign but redeem his presidency for the history books.

webTitle: Tycoon resigns from duma as relations with Kremlin cool

fields.headline: Tycoon resigns from duma as relations with Kremlin cool
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Russia's most prominent business tycoon, Boris Berezovsky, announced yesterday that he plans to resign from parliament in protest at the "authoritarian" trends in Vladimir Putin's government.
fields.body:
Russia's most prominent business tycoon, Boris Berezovsky, announced yesterday that he plans to resign from parliament in protest at the "authoritarian" trends in Vladimir Putin's government.

But another motive for his decision emerged later when he admitted that he believed he could be the next target in the government's drive to tackle corruption. Observers believe the real motive may only become clear in time.

Mr Berezovsky, once an impoverished mathematician, transformed himself into a multi-billionaire in the 1990s and soon became the most notorious of Russia's oligarchs - the well-connected businessmen who made their fortunes buying up state assets cheap in the chaotic post-Soviet period.

In the past week the government has begun prosecuting some of the country's most powerful business figures, and the president has warned that he will not tolerate "shadowy" business groups operating in the economy.

As a member of parliament, Mr Berezovsky is theoretically immune from prosecution, but yesterday he described this guarantee as worthless, and added that he had decided to renounce his parliamentary immunity in any case, so that he was on an "equal footing" with those businessmen already facing prosecution.

In a strong indication that Mr Berezovsky's warm relations with the Kremlin have cooled in the months since Mr Putin became president, he said he believed that ultimately all the oligarchs would be affected by the drive, which he called "an orchestrated campaign, directed at destroying major independent businesses".

He called for an amnesty, arguing that anybody recently involved in business in in Russia must at some point have acted illegally, because of the chaotic laws governing business transactions.

"Only those people who have been asleep for the past 10 years have avoided willingly or unwillingly breaking the law," he said, adding: "And those sitting in the Kremlin are in the same situation."

Mr Berezovsky was an intimate associate of Mr Putin's predecessor, Boris Yeltsin, and for years served as the linchpin of the group of backroom advisers who wielded immense influence over the president.

He has frequently boasted of the role he played in securing Mr Putin's rapid rise to power by ensuring positive coverage on the television channels he controls. In this context, Mr Berezovsky has long been thought of as untouchable.

But in recent weeks his relationship with the president has seemed strained. He has vehemently criticised the central platform of Mr Putin's political programme: the attempt to reclaim power from the unruly regional leaders.

Mr Putin has repeatedly argued that strengthening the Russian state is essential for development; Mr Berezovsky responded yesterday by declaring that he wanted to have no part in the "dismantling of Russia and the imposition of authoritarian rule".

At a packed press conference in Moscow, he added that dissatisfaction with Mr Putin's campaign against the Chechen rebels was another reason for his leaving the duma.

Once his resignation was processed, Mr Berezovsky said, he intended to set about organising a "constructive opposition" political movement. At the weekend he announced his intention to use the media outlets he controls to create a powerful group, which he admitted would become a politically influential force.

On Friday Mr Berezovsky was questioned as a witness by state prosecutors investigating whether large sums of money were stolen from the state airline Aeroflot, which he used to be associated with.

He denied that this his decision to quit was connected to this inquiry.

webTitle: Opec joins drive to cut oil prices

fields.headline: Opec joins drive to cut oil prices
fields.trailText: Opec, the oil producers' cartel, yesterday announced it was willing to pump an extra 500,000 barrels of crude a day in an attempt to bring down world prices and prevent a split in its ranks.
fields.body:
Opec, the oil producers' cartel, yesterday announced it was willing to pump an extra 500,000 barrels of crude a day in an attempt to bring down world prices and prevent a split in its ranks.

Ali Rodriguez, the Venezuelan oil minister and cartel president, said 10 member countries would increase output before the end of the month unless global prices started to fall.

Opec's move was a direct response to the decision by Saudi Arabia, the world's biggest producer, to bow to pressure from an increasingly concerned US government to produce an extra 500,000 barrels a day in order to push prices down to $25 a barrel.

Faced with the prospect that unilateral Saudi action could prompt disintegration of the cartel and lead to an even sharper drop in prices, Opec members agreed to the third production increase this year. Mr Rodriguez did not give details but Opec delegates said ministers agreed to lift output if prices stayed above $28 for 20 business days from July 1.

Dealers said the share-out of higher production among Opec members represented a watering down of the Saudi plan and would mean oil prices might not fall sharply in the near term. London Brent blend futures traded 64 cents (2%) lower at $28.59 a barrel, with US light crude off 64 cents at $30.76.

Oil prices fell to $10 a barrel at the start of 1999 following the global financial crisis, but higher demand and tight production curbs by Opec led to a sharp increase in costs for producers and consumers in the west. Petrol prices are up by 25% in the US since February, while airline fares have risen by 18% this year.

In Britain, a grassroots consumer campaign, Boycott the Pumps, is calling on motorists to abstain from buying petrol on August 1 and to repeat the action every Monday until prices come down.

BP Amoco said British pump prices were being cut by 1p a litre and would fall further if international prices were sustained or fell further. Royal Dutch/Shell said it had already cut its pump prices "on at least a couple of occasions" over the past couple of weeks.

webTitle: US regulators accuse day trading firm of violating rules

fields.headline: US regulators accuse day trading firm of violating rules
fields.trailText: American regulators yesterday accused All-Tech, one of the biggest day trading firms in the US, and its flamboyant founder, Harvey Houtkin, of serious violations of market rules which could lead to a fine or suspension.
fields.body:
American regulators yesterday accused All-Tech, one of the biggest day trading firms in the US, and its flamboyant founder, Harvey Houtkin, of serious violations of market rules which could lead to a fine or suspension.

The charges levelled by the regulatory arm of the National Association of Securities Dealers come after a year-long investigation into the day trading industry by both the NASD and the securities and exchange commission.

The investigation gained national prominence when Mark Barton, a former day trader, killed 16 people, including some at an All-Tech branch in Atlanta, last year.

The two most serious allegations filed yesterday are that All-Tech failed to supervise loans between customers to cover margin calls and employed a disqualified person to work at the firm.

Margin calls are made when an investor borrows money from a firm using their portfolio as collateral. To prevent the firm from selling off their shares at a loss, many traders borrowed money - mainly from each other - to meet the margin call.

The NASD investigation found that All-Tech, which has more than 20 branches, organised loans between customer accounts worth more than $130m (£81m) in 1998. The activity, known as journaling, allows individual traders to go deeper into debt in order to carry on trading and therefore continue to pay the day trading firm's commissions.

The NASD said that many loans were arranged by unregistered employees at "sometimes usurious rates" and without the traders being given adequate information. It found that customers were told that the loans were risk-free, for example. One customer allegedly lost $40,000 on a "risk-free" loan.

Mr Houtkin, referred to as the St Paul of day traders because of his evangelism, was directly accused of making "misleading, exaggerated and unsupported statements" in advertisements and during television appearances as well as in his first book. These statements included saying that most of his customers "have enjoyed successes virtually unheard of in the trading community".

The NASD also disputed a company statement that three in 10 trained day traders would be successful.

fields.headline: O'Reilly can buy Belfast Telegraph
fields.trailText: Fears that political concerns could block the sale of the Belfast Telegraph to Tony O'Reilly's Independent News & Media proved unfounded yesterday when the deal was waved through by Stephen Byers.
fields.body:
Fears that political concerns could block the sale of the Belfast Telegraph to Tony O'Reilly's Independent News & Media proved unfounded yesterday when the deal was waved through by Stephen Byers.

The sale of the paper by Trinity Mirror in March attracted strong criticism that a paper with a moderate Unionist editorial line should pass to Mr O'Reilly's Dublin-based group.

The trade and industry secretary said he had been "mindful of the particular importance of the accurate presentation of news and free expression of opinion in Northern Ireland" but concluded the change of ownership would not work against public interest. The competition commission had found no reason to doubt Mr O'Reilly's commitment to maintaining the editorial freedom of the Telegraph and it made no commercial sense to alter this stance.

John Taylor, deputy leader of the Ulster Unionists, said yesterday he was "pleased that almost all of the concerns which we had expressed appear to have been addressed".

Regional newspaper group Trinity was forced to sell the Telegraph as a condition of its acquisition of Mirror Group. Mr O'Reilly's business, which owns the Irish Independent and the Independent titles in London, is paying £300m.

webTitle: P&O pulls plug on Greek merger

fields.headline: P&O pulls plug on Greek merger
fields.trailText: Shipping company P&O yesterday pulled out of the planned merger of its cruise business with Greece's Festival Cruises because of the collapse of market sentiment towards cruise companies in the US.
fields.body:
Shipping company P&O yesterday pulled out of the planned merger of its cruise business with Greece's Festival Cruises because of the collapse of market sentiment towards cruise companies in the US.

Despite its decision, just weeks after it dropped the planned £125m float of Associated Bulk Carriers in Oslo because of Norwegian stock market volatility, P&O will go ahead with plans to demerge its shipping and ports business in the autumn.

Cruise companies have been among the darlings of stock markets, and US investors in particular, because of the expanding appetite for seaborne tourism among the west's affluent citizens. But that has changed in recent months.

In May, P&O and privately owned Festival said they planned to surf this wave and the trend towards global consolidation in the business by merging their cruise operations in a £400m-plus deal. P&O owns Princess Cruises in the US, Aida Cruises in Ger many and an eponymous business in Britain but warned last month of a fall in the cruise market.

Lord Sterling, P&O chairman, said: "Taking everything into account we both arrived at the conclusion that this was probably not the best time to take the step of joining forces."

Carnival, the US-based market leader which, with Malaysia's Star Cruises, bought Norwegian cruise group NCL earlier this year, has seen its shares fall 60% this year and warned that second-half revenues would be less than last year's. Royal Caribbean Cruises, its nearest rival, has suffered from a similar drop in valuation, while Star has fallen 50%.

Analysts welcomed P&O's decision as indicating a breath of realism about capacity in the global cruise market, with Festival alone planning to introduce two new ships over the next two years.

The market endorsed P&O's decision, pushing its shares up 20p to close at 570p.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: RBS opts for insurance pact
fields.body:
RBS opts for insurance pact

Royal Bank of Scotland yesterday announced a bancassurance partnership with insurer CGNU.

The move, mooted at the time of Royal Bank's hostile bid for NatWest late last year, will see CGNU buy 50% of Royal Scottish Assurance and National Westminster Life Assurance for £600m.

The new insurance business would combine the life assurance expertise of CGNU with Royal Bank's branch network and retail market strength, CGNU said. Royal Bank said the joint venture offered a better arrangement for providing bancassurance than a strategic tie or a full merger, as pursued by competitors such as Lloyds TSB in purchasing Scottish Widows.

Brown wins on watchdogs

Britain appeared to win a victory yesterday in resisting French plans that some claimed could lead to a pan-European financial services regulator.

EU finance ministers said the committee of "wise men" considering convergence in regulation would have to stick to terms of reference set by the ministers. Gordon Brown argued that French calls for a detailed review of stock market regulation could lead to extinction of national safeguards. The "wise men" will present an initial report in November.

G7 pressed to act on debt

Western leaders have been told they must speed up their efforts to forgive the debts of the world's poorest countries, which have run into the sand since Tony Blair and other G7 leaders promised $100bn in debt relief last year in Cologne.

As G7 leaders prepare for their annual summit this weekend in Okinawa, Japan, the president of the World Bank, James Wolfensohn, warns that a "business as usual" approach will not do. "We need speed and flexibility in delivering debt relief and other assistance as quickly possible to countries able to use it effectively," he wrote in a letter to G7 leaders, warning that the international targets for halving poverty by the year 2015 will not be met without more progress on debt relief and other measures.

"It will take more efforts by developing countries themselves, and also by the advanced countries through increased aid, debt relief, sharing experience and access to markets."

Concern is growing among aid agencies and debt campaigners that the Okinawa summit will fail to break the logjam on debt. The G7's original target was for 25 countries to embark on the process by the end of 2000. This has been scaled down to 20, and with five months to go just nine have received interim debt relief, totalling $15bn (£10bn).

Hovercraft replaced

Sea Containers is replacing two hovercraft on the Dover-Calais route with Sea-Cat vessels because of a boom in people taking vehicles across the Channel to buy French goods. The company said it was "reluctantly" withdrawing the 32-year-old Hoverspeed vessels, because they did not have enough car capacity to cope with a jump in traffic since abolition of on-board duty free last July.

webTitle: Market forces: Tech love affair is rekindled

fields.headline: Tech love affair is rekindled
fields.trailText: The feeling that the Federal Reserve has done enough to achieve a soft landing for the US economy was the cue for institutional investors to rediscover the attractions of technology shares yesterday.
fields.body:
The feeling that the Federal Reserve has done enough to achieve a soft landing for the US economy was the cue for institutional investors to rediscover the attractions of technology shares yesterday.

No fewer than five of the six top performing blue chip shares came from various sectors of the technology universes, as institutions swapped holdings in the old economy for those in the new.

Freeserve, aided by revived bid speculation, was the best of the pack, rising 49p to 381p, closely followed by Anglo-Dutch software group CMG, up 80p at £10.80, Logica, 124p better at £18.22, and Sema, 60p stronger at 988p.

Dealers noted that the re-emergence of the tech love affair came after a quarter in which investors had targeted stocks which would still display earnings growth in the event of a global economic slowdown. Such fears had been triggered by expectations of an aggressive series of rate increases by the Fed.

With these fears now largely discounted and the Nasdaq comfortably back above the 4,000 level, investors once again seem prepared to take risks with tech stocks.

The tech surge combined with some strong gains for key telecoms stocks enabled the FTSE 100 to end the session with a gain of 50.1 points to 6,525.5. The Techmark 100 index of technology stocks also closed up, 111.37 points higher at 3,683.22.

In the telecoms sector, Cable & Wireless shot up 50p to £12.60, after analysts at Schroder Salomon Smith Barney set a new target price of £20 for the stock. They reckon the sale of C&W HKT on August 17 will close the valuation gap of £8 per share.

FTSE heavyweight Vodafone AirTouch pushed on 9.75p to 315.75p on news that it is increasing its stake in AirTel, the Spanish mobile phone operator.

On the downside, drinks group Allied Domecq tumbled 16.5p to 342p, unsettled by news of the restructuring at rival Diageo, up 13p at 310p. Yesterday, Diageo unveiled the merger of its food business with US group General Mills and moved to combine its UDV wines and spirits business with its Guinness brewing arm.

Analysts fear a more focused Diageo will thwart Allied's plans to acquire the drinks business of Seagram or at the very least cause it to overpay.

Elsewhere, oil majors BP Amoco , down 20.5p to 580p, and Shell, off 4.5p at 542, were knocked by comments from Opec which suggested that further output increases could be on the way before the end of the month.

Drugs group AstraZeneca surrendered 74p to £29.45p hit by broker comment. Deutsche Bank was the most negative, cutting its rating on the stock to "underperform".

Deutsche feels the stock's recent strong run - it has outperformed the FTSE 100 by 10% in the last month - has left it overvalued and the market is underestimating the risks associated with impending patent expiries.

The story in the FTSE 250 was much the same as the FTSE 100 with technology stocks motoring forward.

Infobank, the e-commerce software provider, extended Friday's gains, rising 115p to 870p with the help of a bullish note from Lehman Brothers. The broker rates the stock a "buy" and has a 12-18 month target price of £15.

Meanwhile, Kewill Systems leapt 125p to 895p helped by the sales of its logistics software division, London Bridge Software rose 87.5p to 682.5p and QXL gained 14.75p to 107p.

Airtours advanced 18p to 280p on reports that German group C&N Tourisitc has appointed an investment bank to look at making a takeover approach.

Shares in Manchester United, down 19p at 345p, were seemingly unsettled by the news that chief executive Martin Edwards was stepping down.

Women's fashion retail New Look dropped 13.5p to 97.5p after reported a 3.9% fall in like-for-like sales in the first 15 weeks of the financial year.

webTitle: Watch out, you've just been Bingleyed

fields.headline: Watch out, you've just been Bingleyed
fields.standfirst: The windfall scramble
fields.trailText: "You'll be better off if we stay a building society" said Mr Bradford, raising his bowler hat. "Oh yes, if we became a bank, we would have to raise mortgage rates and lower savings rates," agreed Mr Bingley.
fields.body:
"You'll be better off if we stay a building society" said Mr Bradford, raising his bowler hat. "Oh yes, if we became a bank, we would have to raise mortgage rates and lower savings rates," agreed Mr Bingley.

Not our words. They are taken from the defence documents issued by Bradford & Bingley in March last year when it was fighting off a carpetbagging resolution. And not words that the members found very persuasive, voting yesterday nine to one in favour of demutualising and windfalls that may average about £730.

Messrs Bradford & Bingley ate their hats immediately after they lost to the carpetbaggers resolution last year, with the board switching sides with almost unseemly haste. Ahead of yesterday's vote, the documents sang a different tune, saying that conversion would mean little change for customers.

The truth perhaps lies more in the original defence documents than in the conversion proposal. Last year B&B's standard variable mortgage rate was only a smidgen above mutual benchmark-setter Nationwide. Now, as it prepares to float, the rate nearly matches the Halifax rate of 7.74%. Expect to see the converse happen with savings rates.

Handing profits to shareholders cannot happen without widening margins. The surprise in yesterday's result was not the huge majority of savers in favour of conversion (£100 in the account for a £730 return), but the number of pro-demutualisation mortgage holders, who will be hit by higher interest rates. One can only guess that either they have not worked out the sums properly - higher rates will wipe out the windfall gain in about three to four years - or that they are also savers who will be doubling or tripling up on windfalls.

A wave of "it's the end of mutuality" comment will follow the vote, but do not read too much into this. The suspicion remains that the B&B board was never truly committed, in the style of Standard Life and Nationwide, to mutuality. It left its doors open to carpetbaggers for so long that come the vote, almost a third of its members were new £100 account holders who were never going to do anything other than vote for conversion.

One of the biggest windfalls has already been handed out; chief executive Christopher Rodrigues saw his pay leap 48% last year to a bank-style £654,048.

Diageoland

If you believe Diageo, consumers no longer distinguish between the separate worlds of beer, wine and spirits drinking.

In Diageoland, we slug Gordon's Space (an unlikely combination of Gordon's gin, lemon juice and ginseng) plus pints of Guinness and shots of J&B whisky as the setting demands.

This future was mapped out by the chief executive-designate, Paul Walsh. But aside from his determination to tap into things like "high value adult drinking occasions," there is plenty of sense in the (belated) plan to amalgamate its two drinks arms, Guinness and UDV.

Merging its Minneapolis-based Pillsbury food subsidiary with General Mills also sounds reasonable enough. This will create the third biggest food group in the US and will send the shivers up Nestlé, which has failed to join the restructuring binge.

Critics were peeved that Diageo will still hold a 33% interest in General Mills as a term of the £7bn merger deal. They wanted a clean exit. But that was curmudgeonly. The overall price was good and Diageo will run down its General Mills stake as soon as practicable.

Sunrise scenario

You are a Japanese policymaker. It is the turn of your country to host the annual summit and Bill, Tony, Gerhard and the rest of the chaps are about to jet in ...

Do you a) Admit that the past decade has been pretty awful for the economy and that there is no real evidence of a pick-up outside of the export sector?

Or b) Search the works of Norman Lamont and announce that you can spot the green shoots of recovery?

No prizes for guessing which way Tokyo has jumped. The Japanese are heartily sick of the Americans telling them how to run a vibrant modern economy, and the prospect of another dressing down at Okinawa this weekend would be too much to bear. So the talk from the Bank of Japan yesterday was that the corner has at last been turned and that the days of zero interest rates are numbered.

But Japan, according to its politicians, has been about to turn the corner for the best part of a decade. Unemployment is at a post-war high and consumer confidence is weak. Export-led growth is at the mercy of a rise in the value of the yen that would accompany a fall in the dollar. The real reason that the Bank of Japan did not raise rates yesterday was that it remains unsure whether there really is a recovery. But, thankfully, by the time anybody finds out, the summit will be over and the Americans will have left.

webTitle: Dust-up Dyson takes Hoover to high court

fields.headline: Dust-up Dyson takes Hoover to high court
fields.trailText: Battles between Dyson and Hoover have moved from the showrooms to the courtrooms.
fields.body:
Battles between Dyson and Hoover have moved from the showrooms to the courtrooms.

For decades Hoover was the leading brand name in household cleaning. Then along came design student James Dyson to steal the headlines and a huge chunk of the market with a bagless cleaner.

Yesterday, Dyson Appliances and Hoover squared up to each other in a London court.

In a patent battle, privately owned Dyson has accused Hoover of infringing one of its patents with the Hoover Vortex, a new machine that boasts of dispensing with the traditional vacuum cleaner bag.

David Kitchen QC, for Dyson, told the high court that James Dyson's cleaner, which uses centrifugal force to separate dirt from air, "turned the industry on its head". Mr Dyson had broken the mould established by Hoover in 1908.

Mr Dyson took his invention to various companies including Electrolux, Philips, and Black & Decker but none was interested in moving away from vacuum cleaners using bags. "Mr Dyson found that getting the industry interested was like extracting teeth."

Eventually Mr Dyson borrowed £600,000 to set up his own company.

Mr Kitchen told the court that Hoover's argument would be that the technology behind the Dyson Dual Cyclone involved nothing that was not generally known within the industry.

He said Hoover had offered no explanation as to why it had waited until now to come up with its bagless product.

Mr Kitchen said: "Their profit came from bags, therefore they had a vested interested in bag sales being maintained. The industry had a mind-set and that mind-set was vacuums and bags."

All vacuum cleaners prior to Dyson's had worked on the principle that dirt was vacuumed up and separated by passing the stream of dirty air through a bag or a filter or both. "That was the industry to which this patent was addressed. It seems Hoover knew little or nothing about centrifugal vacuums in 1980."

On the opening day of the action, Mr Kitchen said Hoover's claim that Mr Dyson was not the first person to have the idea of a bagless vacuum did not stand up to scrutiny.

Hoover denies any infringement. The hearing was adjourned until today.

A Dyson spokeswoman said the action was being brought against the Italian owner of the Hoover brand in Europe, Candy, and did not affect Maytag, the American company which markets the brand in the United States.

webTitle: Bank of Japan holds rates at zero

fields.headline: Bank of Japan holds rates at zero
fields.trailText: Japan yesterday surprised the markets by keeping its zero interest rate policy on hold despite earlier preparing dealers for an increase.
fields.body:
Japan yesterday surprised the markets by keeping its zero interest rate policy on hold despite earlier preparing dealers for an increase.

However, the Bank of Japan signalled that a long period of deflation had come to an end and rates would begin to rise in coming months. The central bank said the economy was beginning to show signs of inflation as economic activity picked up in recent months.

But the positive note struck by the BoJ will be disputed today by McKinsey, the American management consultant, which has published a highly critical assessment of the Japanese economy, describing the past decade as a journey from "model to muddle".

In a report published three days before the country hosts the annual economic summit of the Group of Seven leading industrialised nations on the island of Okinawa, Mckinsey said the only way Japan could turn itself around was by adopting a systematic programme of reform aimed at increasing competition.

The hectoring tone of the report is likely to irritate the Japanese government, which will see it as another attempt to bully it into rebuilding the economy in the image of the US. But the thrust of its message will be welcomed by progressive policymakers at the Japanese finance ministry who believe politicians have been too slow to grasp the nettle of economic reform.

"The Japanese system does have to change to more like the US economy," one said. "We need more competition and originality but at the same time US economic success can't go on forever and when it stops the social strains will show. Stability oriented policies are needed."

Despite more than a year of interest rates at zero and eight different fiscal packages worth nearly $800bn (£500bn), gross domestic product per head of the population had grown by a meagre 0.6% since 1990, compared with 1.7% in the US, said McKinsey

Meanwhile, the unemployment rate has risen from just over 2% to around 5% and public debt to GDP ratio has doubled to nearly 120%, twice that of the US and Germany.

"In short, the past decade has seen the Japanese economy go from model to muddle," said McKinsey.

The company said that Japan had a "dual economy" with a world-beating portion, comprising cars, steel, machine tools and consumer electronics, which was exposed to international competition, and a remaining 90% which was not.

"Save for their national origin, these [poor performing] companies share nothing with Toyota," said the report.

"They are subscale, poorly managed, antiquated, insulated from competition, and woefully unproductive.

"The productivity of this portion of the Japanese economy stands at a mere 63% of US levels.

"It is the source of Japan's ills, and the Japanese economy will not rebound until the performance of these companies begins to turn around."

fields.headline: At this price?  Ramco
fields.trailText: British oil explorer, Ramco Energy, saw its shares rise 33% yesterday after selling out interests in Azerbaijan for $150m (£94m) cash. Nine-year high oil prices and renewed interest in the Caspian region oiled the wheels of a neat deal by founder and main shareholder Steve Remp.
fields.body:
British oil explorer, Ramco Energy, saw its shares rise 33% yesterday after selling out interests in Azerbaijan for $150m (£94m) cash. Nine-year high oil prices and renewed interest in the Caspian region oiled the wheels of a neat deal by founder and main shareholder Steve Remp.

The question for investors is whether there is anything much left in the Ramco locker after this deal, or whether this is just an exit route for the swashbuckling Mr Remp.

Amerada Hess is the buyer, in four instalments, of Ramco's 2.08% stake in the Azeri Chirag Guneshi (ACG) production sharing agreement which undoubtedly represents Ramco's crown jewel.

The deal brings a big injection of cash into the Aberdeen-based company whose shares have been through a rollercoaster ride from highs of £12.00 three years ago to lows since Christmas of 275p.

Oil prices might be flying high but Ramco has little in the way of producing fields. Its oil services business is still suffering from spending shyness by the oil majors.

Most of Ramco's interests are in future development projects. These eat up cash and produce little until the crude starts flowing. The ACG agreement covers three fields being developed by Azerbaijan's biggest foreign oil group, AIOC, led by BP Amoco.

The ACG area overall is estimated to have recoverable reserves of 4bn barrels of oil. But Ramco says it does not want to become a big oil producer.

Remp said yesterday: "Our concept is to redefine the role of a small exploration and production company and add value to a project."

Ramco is also involved in two other projects in Azerbaijan and Mr Remp is looking at farming out those interests, too, if they prove commercial.

But what else has Ramco got in its portfolio? Today it will outline plans for drilling its first well in Georgia and it has potentially interesting gas developments off the Irish coast.

Ramco is in many ways like a dot.com venture, except management has a proven track record. Last night it was trading at 470p, up 117.5p, a rather more realistic level.

If you are convinced Ramco can come up with more company-making deals and Mr Remp is enjoying himself too much to bail out, then it's a buy. If you are made of more sober stuff, steer clear.

fields.headline: ITE exhibits bid signs
fields.trailText: Is something up at ITE Group, the international trade show and conference group that specialises in emerging markets?
fields.body:
Is something up at ITE Group, the international trade show and conference group that specialises in emerging markets? Dealers have been watching turnover in the company, chaired by Lawrie Lewis of Blenheim fame, over the past couple of sessions and have concluded that something could be up.

The shares, which have been on a roll-coaster ride this year, ticked up 2p to 70p yesterday as further 774,000 changed hands.

According to speculation, the company has received an informal approach and a bid at around the 100p per share is expected any day. Names in the frame include Euromoney Institutional investor, dealers say.

ITE's position as a leading exhibition organiser certainly makes it an attractive target. The group now arranges over 350 trade exhibitions a year.

Hugh Bidwell, deputy chief chairman of ITE, told the Guardian he was not aware of any formal approach, however.

webTitle: Enterprise Oil buys into the US Gulf

fields.headline: Enterprise Oil buys into the US Gulf
fields.trailText: Enterprise Oil, Britain's biggest exploration and production company, yesterday celebrated the continuation of high oil prices by splashing out £127m for interests in the US Gulf of Mexico.
fields.body:
Enterprise Oil, Britain's biggest exploration and production company, yesterday celebrated the continuation of high oil prices by splashing out £127m for interests in the US Gulf of Mexico.

Chief executive Pierre Jungels said the deal with US drilling company R&B Falcon offered exciting exploration opportunities and important stakes in producing fields.

Oil companies have enjoyed strong prices around $30 per barrel for 18 months but have avoided spending.

Last week two integrated oil majors, BP Amoco and Royal Dutch/Shell, said that they would be increasing capital expenditure and were on the look out for the right kind of acquisitions.

The new Enterprise assets would complement its assets in the deep water area such as the Llano field and allow the company to make the US Gulf a core area along with the North Sea and Italy. The British company will acquire a 50% stake in the Boomvang field which comes on stream in 2002, 100% of the Gyrfalcon project which is already producing gas, plus interests in 19 other US Gulf exploration blocks.

The exploration and production sector has been particularly shy about openly spending much more money after their shares were hit following the previous oil price downturn.

They have recovered on the back of promises of financial prudence, and there was little enthusiasm around the City for Mr Jungels new investments. The Enterprise shares were marked down ending the day at 509p, a slide of 13p.

Analysts questioned whether this was the time to buy into a mature oil province. One said: "I seem to remember it was a former Enterprise chairman who once said: 'there is nothing worse than a British oilman desperately looking for assets to buy in the US Gulf'. "

webTitle: The anti-EU backlash amongst Poland's farmers

fields.headline: Yesterday Moscow, today Brussels
fields.trailText: Nut-brown under the summer sun, Romuald Lempicki is worrying about the future as he surveys the old wooden mill and the traditional Polish storks' nest above his modest home,  writes Ian Black in Chiechanwiec.
fields.body:
Nut-brown under the summer sun, Romuald Lempicki is worrying about the future as he surveys the old wooden mill and the traditional Polish storks' nest above his modest home, writes Ian Black in Chiechanwiec.

Mr Lempicki, a healthy 70-something, has nine milk cows in his breeze-block shed, and grows potatoes, maize and wheat on the 13-hectare smallholding he shares with two other generations of his family.

But costs are rising and his country's attempt to join the EU has created new and frightening uncertainties.

"We do have a lot of fears, but you need to look at this historically," he explains. "I remember the war and the occupation and collectivisation. We can't separate ourselves from the rest of the world any more. We did that for 50 years. We owe it to our children and grandchildren."

Yet with 20% of Poland's population dependent on farming and producing only 5% of the country's wealth, the crisis is already all too real.

According to some estimates more than 1m people could be driven off the land in coming years. And those who stay cannot all expect the subsidies received by farmers elsewhere under the EU's common agricultural policy.

Mr Lempicki's circumstances are fairly typical. But they are misleading: some larger Polish farms are capable of competing in the EU's single market.

The image of traditional horse and cart sits uneasily with the gleaming Swedish-made stainless steel equipment in the nearby dairy cooperative.

But the flat Polish countryside shows signs of painful transition: on the main road between Warsaw and Bialystock - the turn-off for Treblinka, a chilling reminder of recent history - Lithuanian trucks trundle past scantily-clad prostitutes and old women selling berries.

With demands for milk quotas and cereal set aside on the agenda, Warsaw officials worry about an anti-EU backlash among farmers. Slogans like "Yesterday Moscow, Brussels today", are a real concern to the minority government.

Poles are angry at the way that during the Russian financial crisis two years ago the EU sent subsidised pork to Moscow, undercutting Polish prices.

Many are sceptical about pledges to create new alternative jobs, while there are complaints about exacting and expensive EU food hygiene and animal health standards.

Bozena Jaros-Jelska, president of the regional pig farmers' association, is clear. "We feel that we are supposed to become consumers, not producers. We do want to join the EU, but quickly, and with subsidies, like everyone."

Stefan Brzozowski, another farmer, is blunter.

"The EU is a very rich and selfish club," he says.

"We find that our supermarkets are full of their products, but it's not the other way round."

webTitle: Poland fears joining EU will take for ever

fields.headline: Poland fears joining EU will take for ever
fields.standfirst: Support for extending the union eastwards slips as members foresee threat to jobs and borders
fields.trailText: High above the Warsaw skyline the Palace of Culture and Science, a massive and unlovely model of 1950s Stalinist baroque, is being prepared for its most grandiose addition: a giant clock.
fields.body:
High above the Warsaw skyline the Palace of Culture and Science, a massive and unlovely model of 1950s Stalinist baroque, is being prepared for its most grandiose addition: a giant clock.

It will start ticking at midnight on December 31. But the capital's Big Ben, millennial brainchild of the mayor, Pawel Pikorski, will be measuring out an even more momentous timetable for Poland - the race to join the European Union.

"Timing is important for us, but it is not as important as concrete achievements," says Mr Pikorski, a dynamic 33-year-old credited with transforming Warsaw into Europe's fastest-growing city after Berlin.

"But if we are not a member of the EU in 2003," he warns, "things could be very difficult."

Poles are getting impatient. It is now more than 20 years since Lech Walesa's Solidarity movement launched the strikes that first challenged and finally brought down the entire communist system.

Eleven years have elapsed since Poland's first free elections, yet its 39m people still linger in a political and economic no man's land as the EU's 15 members lose enthusiasm for taking newcomers into their club.

In theory, all is well. EU communiques routinely declare that Poland can join from January 2003. But no one now believes that is going to happen. On the Brussels rumour mill, 2004 and 2005 are more often heard

Poland's chief negotiator with the EU, Jan Kulakowski, is blunt, even undiplomatic, about the slipping date. "We are starting to wonder if they are serious," he says.

Efforts to ensure that there are no excuses for further delay continue apace: last week the sejm, Poland's parliament, formed a special committee to fast-track the passage of the 180-odd laws needed to comply with the EU rule book.

Yet the mood is depressed, even angry. "There is waiting fatigue syndrome here," warns Jacek Saryusz-Wolski, the widely admired minister for European affairs. "We want to be ready just in time, not just in case."

Understandably enough the Poles see their country as a victim: first of Hitler then, after the west accepted the division of Europe into two warring camps at Yalta in 1945, of Stalin.

Substantive talks have yet to begin. The biggest and most expensive worries are agriculture, the environment, and borders: a Poland in the EU will control the union's external border with Ukraine, Belarus and Russia.

But among the 15, according to Eurobarometer polls, support for the historic post-cold-war mission of enlargement is only about 44%, and dropping.

In Germany in particular there are fears of Polish workers flooding the market, and in Austria Jörg Haider played heavily on similar anxieties. "Stereotypes and cliches are stronger than reality," complains President Alexander Kwaskniewski.

Poles are also unhappy with the recent revival of debate about the future of the EU, in which Jacques Chirac of France and Joschka Fischer of Germany are soul-searching about hard cores and two speeds while Warsaw feels excluded.

And many officials complain that for Polish membership of the union the standards are being set higher than hitherto.

"When they were talking to the Austrians, Swedes and Finns it was like they were talking to members of the family," Mr Kulakowski says. "We feel like very very distant cousins."

Record aid from Brussels is already helping prepare Poland for accession. But uncertainty about the timing could create real difficulties for the prime minister, Jerzy Buzek, who is now governing with a minority coalition. And crucial foreign investment, Mr Pikorski suggests, could also be affected.

Yet in the end, as Poles freely admit, they have nowhere else to go but the EU. And so, despite frustration at the pace, this is still about mutual confidence, and not a crisis. Not yet, anyway.

"Crisis is what we lived through for 50 years, Mr Saryusz-Wolski says with a bitter laugh. "This is just delay."
