fields.headline: 3,000 jobs may go at Diageo
fields.trailText: Up to 3,000 jobs could be spilled by Diageo after the drinks group's decision to merge its UDV spirits business with Guinness and hive off its US food arm, Pillsbury, to General Mills in a £7bn deal, analysts predict.
fields.body:
Up to 3,000 jobs could be spilled by Diageo after the drinks group's decision to merge its UDV spirits business with Guinness and hive off its US food arm, Pillsbury, to General Mills in a £7bn deal, analysts predict.

Cash from the Pillsbury deal is expected to fund a spending spree, with Seagram's liquor assets likely to top the list. A share buyback is in prospect.

Paul Walsh, Diageo's chief executive-designate, yesterday refused to put a number on the redundancies but said the London head offices of UDV and Guinness would be combined under plans to secure savings of £130m a year.

Analysts predicted that 10% of the combined UDV and Guinness staffs of 30,000 worldwide could go (17,000 are employed by UDV).

Mr Walsh played down the magnitude of the cuts but admitted senior and middle management would not be spared as sales, marketing and consumer research functions were merged.

"Our objective is to streamline but we do not have the scope on absolute numbers yet," said Mr Walsh. He ex pected to give an outline of staffing levels to employees, possibly within the week.

The integration of Diageo's spirits business, which produces Johnnie Walker, Baileys and Smirnoff, will cost £170m in exceptional charges but secure savings of £100m by year three and the full £130m by year five.

Diageo's goal is to achieve a winning share of "high value adult drinking occasions" within a global market estimated by the company to be worth £5bn a year.

The Pillsbury-General Mills deal was agreed during weekend talks between the boards of the two firms in Minneapolis, where both are based.

Mr Walsh said the "dream deal" needed the approval of US regulators and shareholders but expected the deal to be completed by the year end. Some small sales might be demanded as the price of the regulatory go-ahead.

General Mills, the maker of Cheerios cereals, will pay 141m shares valued at $5.4m (£3.6m) and take on $5.1bn of debt for Pillsbury, producer of Old El Paso corn chips and Haagen-Dazs ice cream.

This will leave Diageo with 33% of the combined General Mills-Pillsbury and two board seats. Diageo intends to sell down at least 75% of this stake over 10 years.

This is the latest restructuring of the US food sector where Unilever recently paid $24.3bn to buy Bestfoods and Philip Morris spent $18.9bn on Nabisco Holdings.

The Pillsbury sale would enhance Diageo's earnings per share by as much as 6% on a pro forma basis before goodwill and exceptional items during fiscal 2001, said finance director Nick Rose.

The stock market liked the deal and pushed up Diageo shares 13p to 610p. The company hopes for its shares to be rerated once it is perceived as a pure drinks company.

Diageo next year will float 20% of Burger King with the rest going by 2003. The company made clear it was interested in the assets being disposed of by Seagram due to its merger with Vivendi of France.

webTitle: New light thrown on treating acne

fields.headline: New light thrown on treating acne
fields.trailText: Shy teenagers with acne are being encouraged to step out of their bedrooms and into the spotlight under a new treatment programme to clear up spots, health researchers said yesterday.
fields.body:
Shy teenagers with acne are being encouraged to step out of their bedrooms and into the spotlight under a new treatment programme to clear up spots, health researchers said yesterday.

Dermatologists at Hammersmith hospital in west London said regular sessions under blue and red light has been shown "radically" to help clear acne in moderate and less severe cases.

In preliminary trials, the consultant dermatologist Tony Chu sent 120 patients home with specially designed red and blue lamps to be used for 15 minutes each day.

The results, published in the British Journal of Dermatology, show a 76% drop in visible spots over 12 weeks. Many of those who saw a marked improvement had tried other treatments with poor results.

Dr Chu said the blue light killed off the bacteria that causes spots and the red light helped the skin heal.

While it has long been known that exposure to ultraviolet rays, present in sunlight, can help acne, it can also damage the skin and is discouraged as a form of treatment.

Dr Chu said the red and blue light treatment involved higher wavelengths than ultraviolet rays and was safer.

All but the most severe acne is at present treated by a course of antibiotics. This can produce varied results and takes several months to work.

"As more people become antibiotic-resistant, this new treatment looks set to help thousands of acne sufferers across the world," Dr Chu said. "The combination of red and blue light attacks the acne and heals the skin, through their anti-bacterial and anti-inflammatory actions, and without any significant side effects. Our challenge now lies in extending this finding to other, more severe, cases."

Those with severe acne are at present treated with the vitamin A derivative isotretinoin, which can be effective but can also make the skin dry.

Mr Chu said he hoped that the new treatment would help the 90% of adolescents, 5% of women and 1% of men who suffer from acne.

"It is a condition that is often mocked but in reality it can scar people physically and scar people psychologically," he said. "It can have an impact on relationships, employment opportunities, and can even lead to suicide in some cases."

In 1986 researchers at Leeds general infirmary found that 16.2% of 18- to 30-year-olds with acne were unemployed, compared with an average among the age group of 9.2%.

fields.headline: Baby death findings 'wrong'
fields.trailText: Sally Clark, the solicitor jailed for life for the murder of her two baby sons, was convicted on the basis of crucial medical evidence that was at best unconfirmed and at worst "plain wrong", the court of appeal in London heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Sally Clark, the solicitor jailed for life for the murder of her two baby sons, was convicted on the basis of crucial medical evidence that was at best unconfirmed and at worst "plain wrong", the court of appeal in London heard yesterday.

Clark, 35, received two life sentences at Chester crown court last November for the murder of Christopher, 11 weeks, in December 1996 and Harry, eight weeks, in January 1998. She maintained that they were cot death victims.

At the opening of her appeal against the convictions, Julian Bevan QC, for Clark, said the findings of the pathologist who examined the bodies of both children were doubtful.

He also described as "highly prejudicial" and "dangerous" statistical evidence at the trial that the chances of two cot deaths in a family such as the Clarks was 73m to one.

Christopher died when Clark's husband, Stephen, was away from the family's home in Wilmslow, Cheshire.

At the time, the pathologist, Alan Williams, found nothing suspicious, and the cause of death was given as a lung infection.

When Harry died, Mr Clark was downstairs while his wife was in the bedroom with the child. Dr Williams detected injuries which made him suspicious, and Christopher's death was re-examined.

Mr Bevan said Dr Williams's findings in relation to both deaths would be disputed by new expert witnesses.

The reliability of Dr Williams lay at the very heart of the case, Mr Bevan said.

The appeal continues today.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.body:
Hillsborough jury out today

The jury in the trial of two police officers charged with manslaughter relating to the 1989 Hillsborough stadium disaster will be sent out to consider their verdict today.

Mr Justice Hooper, at the Leeds crown court trial of former chief superintendent David Duckenfield and former superintendent Bernard Murray, told the jury that everyone had sympathy for the families of the 96 victims but that they must decide on evidence.

RSPCA plea for porpoises

Thousands of porpoises are being killed in fishing nets around Britain despite a government commitment to cut the death toll, the RSPCA says today as it launches an ad campaign to highlight their suffering.

In a report titled Haul of Shame, the charity calls for action to save harbour porpoises, a smaller cousin of the dolphin, from gill nets.

Dublin grant for Ulster

The Irish government has awarded a £IR120,000 grant to a fund to aid victims of violence in Northern Ireland.

The Belfast-based Survivors of Trauma group is one of 10 organisations to receive cash from the reconciliation fund.

Horse trainer arrested

Racehorse trainer Henry Cecil, 57, has been arrested on suspicion of drink-driving after an elderly couple were injured in a road accident. Retired carpenter Len Hurrell, 77, and his wife Joan, 78, were hit by a car at Newmarket, Suffolk.

fields.headline: Dealers to outlaw 'conflict diamonds'
fields.trailText: The illicit trade in "conflict diamonds" - which is known to be funding at least three African wars - is likely to be regulated out of existence by the diamond industry which signalled its readiness yesterday to introduce tough new rules later this year.
fields.body:
The illicit trade in "conflict diamonds" - which is known to be funding at least three African wars - is likely to be regulated out of existence by the diamond industry which signalled its readiness yesterday to introduce tough new rules later this year.

The industry admitted that the time had come to clean up its act, a resolve which is likely to cut off one of the biggest sources of funding for the Revolutionary United Front in Sierra Leone and the Unita rebels in Angola.

The notoriously secretive industry, which is holdings its biannual congress in the Belgian city of Antwerp, is expected to endorse a new set of rules tomorrow. The impetus for change is a radical set of proposals from the International Diamond Manufacturers' Association, which represents the world's 10 biggest manufacturing centres.

The proposals envisage every parcel of diamonds being accompanied by a detailed certificate of origin, and anyone caught dealing in conflict diamonds being banned from trading for life.

The industry has been under enormous pressure from non-governmental organisations and governments such as Britain's to end the trade in diamonds from rebel groups to help restore peace and human rights in Africa.

The threat of a possible consumer boycott of diamonds and a media campaign against the trade has persuaded the industry that it is now in its in terests to tackle the problem.

Robert Fowler, the Canadian ambassador to the United Nations, who supports sanctions against Unita, hailed the industry's change of heart. "What is so exciting for all of us today is that this is the first time we're talking about a comprehensive approach," he said.

Peter Hain, the Foreign Office minister with responsibility for Africa, warned that the change would come too late for hundreds of thousands of Angolans and Sierra Leoneans who have suffered in wars financed by diamonds, but said that industry action was exactly what was needed.

"We now have the basis to form an international accreditation system and all diamonds exported will have to have a proper certificate. We've now got consensus on that within the industry and we'll have to work very hard to implement it," he said.

He urged diamond buyers not to buy any stones from Sierra Leone, Angola or the Democratic Republic of Congo since the situation was, he argued, too confused.

Peter Meeus, general manager of Antwerp's Diamond High Council, which oversees the world's biggest trading centre, stressed that the industry should not be made a scapegoat for Africa's ills, adding that only 4% of diamonds came from conflict areas.

"It is unfair and dishonest to put the blame on the industry, because it's small and employs a small number of people" he said.

"We are ethical people and we want to help, but the diamond industry should not stand alone in taking the blame for all that goes wrong in Africa."

"We have a responsibility, but at a certain moment our responsibility ends and we are not the international police.

He was optimistic that an industry-wide agreement was close and that an upbeat resolution was likely to be adopted on the final day of the congress tomorrow.

Gary Ralfe, managing director of South African diamond giants De Beers, said: "It's a question of self-policing leading to the ostracisation of those who debase our trade."

The diamond industry produces £4.5bn-worth of diamonds each year, which feed into a jewellery market worth £37bn.

fields.headline: On message
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: • Popular Supreme in software but an internet laggard for several years, Microsoft yesterday proclaimed it had the world's most popular website with 201m unique users last month. The figures, helped by Microsoft's number one slot in the British market as well as elsewhere around the world, beat those published by Yahoo! , the internet portal, for the same period. Yahoo!, which announced 156m unique users in the same period, refused to comment on the Microsoft results. However, it has also described itself as the "leading, global branded web network".

The figures, helped by Microsoft's number one slot in the British market as well as elsewhere around the world, beat those published by Yahoo! , the internet portal, for the same period. Yahoo!, which announced 156m unique users in the same period, refused to comment on the Microsoft results. However, it has also described itself as the "leading, global branded web network".

 Oversubscribed The institutional tranche of Wanadoo 's initial public offering has been 16 times oversubscribed and the retail tranche more than 4.5 times oversubscribed, said a source close to the float. Demand for the institutional tranche came 40% from France, 40% from other European countries and 20% from the United States and the rest of the world. France Telecom, Wanadoo's parent, declined to comment.

 Expanding The American business-to-business marketplace company, Internet Capital Group, said it would expand its European holdings and has plans for a future spinoff. ICG also said it had appointed Doug Alexander, ICG's managing director and chairman of VerticalNet, as chief executive officer of ICG Europe. The company is planning to open an office in Paris and expand its Munich offices.

 Developing Internet content software developer NetCentric Systems said it will raise £390,000 from a private placing to finance expansion plans. The cash will also be used to invest in development of the company's flagship technology, Lychee. The technology enables corporate website owners to update their websites by using a browser, eliminating the need for technical knowledge of complex web languages such as HTML.

webTitle: Sketch: Giving the government the headlines it wants

fields.headline: Unvarnished, positively Downing Street
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Watching the documentary about Alastair Campbell and his colleagues in Downing Street, and reading the plangent memo from Tony Blair about the need for lots of spiffy headlines,  I realised that we in the news media have a stern duty, not just to our readers but to the nation
fields.body:
As I understand things, it's all the fault of the press. Watching the documentary about Alastair Campbell and his colleagues in Downing Street, and reading the plangent memo from Tony Blair about the need for lots of spiffy headlines ("I should be personally associated with as much of this as possible") I realised that we in the news media have a stern duty, not just to our readers but to the nation.

The gist of the documentary was that the prime minister needs to spend more time working on his wise and beneficent policies, but is constantly distracted by the media. He issues rational and objective reports about what he and his team are doing and what they have achieved, but these are distorted by the press, consuming yet more time which should be devoted to his acting as the father of his people.

So I arrived at the Commons yesterday anxious to do my bit. First up was Alistair Darling, the social services secretary. I shall write up what he said in positive headlines, which are what Mr Blair wants to see more of.

"Not all that many more pensioners are living in poverty these days," he told us. (This is because there are more pensioners altogether, so naturally more of them are living in poverty, though the proportion of people living off tinned cat food hasn't changed - more good news!)

"Labour government to spend more than six and a half billion pounds on supporting pensioner incomes!" was another marvellous piece of news. So was, "expect to see a year-on-year improvement as we reduce the number of pensioners living in poverty!"

Distinctly off-message Tories such as Anne McIntosh claimed that the government had "insulted" pensioners by giving them a smaller percentage rise than the hike in the cost of petrol. (And, Anne, please resume sending the Guardian office those faxes that detail every moment of your working day. We haven't had one since late May - "MP lends a helping hand in Thirsk" - another cheery headline of the type Mr Blair would like to see.)

Mr Darling wasted little time on this kind of negative thinking. "Frankly, when it comes to pensions, when it comes to fairness, when it comes to doing the right thing for today's pensioners and for tomorrow's pensioners, then the Conservatives have got nothing to say - whatsoever!" Who needs journalists when you have got ministers who tell the truth in such an honest, straightforward manner?

The problem is that it's not just us hacks who keep twisting the government's words. Take Michael Connarty, the rebellious Labour MP for Falkirk East. He called the cold weather payments for pensioners a "gimmick" that damaged "the credibility of this government".

Pshaw! Mr Darling rapped back that more than 130,000 more claims for minimum income guarantee had been received.

"Its availability is now being extended beyond the 1.5m pensioners already receiving it!" he said. That is laying it on the line; that is telling the unvarnished truth to the people!

But then it's not just Labour MPs who are causing trouble. The high court the other day had the temerity to stop David Blunkett's plan for performance-related pay for teachers on the pathetic, whingeing, feeble-minded grounds that the scheme was "illegal". Since when has it been up to judges to decide what is illegal?

Estelle Morris, the schools minister, slammed them back. "The government's pay reforms are the best opportunity teachers have had in a generation," she said.

And who could argue with that? Not me! I hope I have been of service to you.

fields.headline: Falling Carphone locks in investors
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Retail investors in Carphone Warehouse watched as the value of their shares dropped yesterday - but were unable to act because of the three-month contracts shareholders signed with the company not to sell.
fields.body:
Retail investors in Carphone Warehouse watched as the value of their shares dropped yesterday - but were unable to act because of the three-month contracts shareholders signed with the company not to sell.

The shares fell to a low of 190p, ending only slightly firmer at 190.5p, compared with Friday's close of 201.5p. The stock made its debut at 225p on Friday, capitalising the company at £1.8bn, while more than two-thirds of the shares issued in the float changed hands that day.

To gain priority share allocations in the company's public offer, retail investors were given an optional three-month lock-in period, which was designed to deter speculators and encourage long-term holders of Carphone Warehouse stock.

At least 90% of the 11,500 retail investors who applied for shares took up the option, with a minimum application of 500 shares at 200p apiece.

Retail investors who did not agree to those restrictions on share selling only got 60% of the shares for which they applied.

The allocation of stock set aside for institutional shareholders was 8.5 times oversubscribed.

An analyst said yesterday: "I think all those retail investors who locked in for three months possibly won't be thrilled about it right now. Though perhaps not all see it as a short-term investment."

One private investor on the Interactive Investor International website said of Carphone Warehouse: "It could be a slippery slope all the way down to a pound. Let's face it, no retailer, however sexy and innovative, is worth a price-earnings ratio over 50. The price needs to halve at the very least."

Charles Dunstone, the founder of Carphone Warehouse founder who has retained a stake of about 38% in the company, also saw his fortunes fall. The directors have been barred from selling any shares for the next 12 months, other than those they cashed in at the float.

The quick slide in Carphone Warehouse's shares since listing has been blamed on the aggressive issue price, which was at the top end of the float's indicative range of 170p-220p a share.

At 200p a share, and with earnings per share forecasts of 3.6p for 2001, Carphone Warehouse was trading at almost 55 times its potential earnings.

Analysts said on that ratio the share price was already factoring in the company's growth prospects for the next two years.

About one-third of the £185m raised by the float will be used to reduce debt and a further third will be used to fund Carphone Warehouse's European expansion, targeting mainly the German market where it has recently acquired a further 97 retail locations.

The company has 450 stores in Britain and a further 430 or so trading under the Phone House name throughout continental Europe.

The remainder of the funds raised will be used to develop other services, including Value Telecom, which repackages One2One airtime under the Carphone-owned brand, and Mviva the group's wireless internet portal.

fields.headline: 'M25 three' are freed
fields.standfirst: The issue explained
fields.trailText: Three men who spent more than 10 years in prison for murder and a series of armed robberies around the M25 were freed yesterday after the court of appeal ruled that there had been a "profoundly disturbing" conspiracy between the police and a key informant before their trial.
fields.body:
Three men who spent more than 10 years in prison for murder and a series of armed robberies around the M25 were freed yesterday after the court of appeal ruled that there had been a "profoundly disturbing" conspiracy between the police and a key informant before their trial.

Quashing the convictions of Raphael Rowe, 32, Michael Davis, 33, and Randolph Johnson, 37, at the end of a tense two-hour hearing, three appeal judges said the collusion was one of three "material irregularities" that made the jury's verdict unsafe.

The judgment was greeted by jubilation among relatives and friends of the three men, who were sentenced to life imprisonment at the Old Bailey 10 years ago, and left their lawyers demanding an inquiry into police conduct.

Mr Rowe said: "The system allowed them to lock up innocent men. I was 19 years old when they put me in prison and I'm 32 now - 12 years of my life lost for ever. I will never ever get those years back."

The judgment handed down by Lord Justice Mantell, Mr Justice Blofeld and Mrs Justice Rafferty, did not, however, clear the men of involvement in the crimes. The judges said the case against all three was "formidable" and the evidence against Rowe for the robbery charges was "overwhelming".

They added: "For the better understanding of those who have listened to this judgment and of those who may report it hereafter this is not a finding of innocence, far from it."

Rowe, Davis and Johnson, from Sydenham, south London, were jailed for three violent robberies committed in the early hours of December 16, 1988. One led to the death of a hairdresser, Peter Hurburgh, who was dragged at gunpoint from his car, tied up, beaten and doused with petrol. He had a heart attack.

Timothy Napier, 40, was stabbed when three men broke into his father's house in Oxted, Surrey. Later, three men also broke into a house in Fetcham, Surrey, and demanded jewellery, cash and car keys. Their weapons included a machete and a gun.

There was no forensic evidence against any of the defendants. Some of the victims also told the police that at least one of the attackers was probably white. The case against the three was based almost entirely on the evidence of a suspect turned prosecution witness, Norman Duncan, and Rowe's girlfriend, Kate Williamson, who claimed he returned home on December 16 with jewellery taken from the raids.

The three men lost an appeal against their convictions in 1993 but the criminal cases review commission referred it back to the court of appeal last year after a new police investigation. This uncovered that Duncan was a police informer who had originally told detectives the robberies were the work of Rowe, Davis and a man called Jason - not Johnson. Duncan later changed his mind and received a £10,000 reward.

When he gave evidence, Duncan did not tell the jury he was an informer or that he had spent two days in protective police custody giving evidence. The court of appeal ruled that Surrey police should have disclosed that Duncan had not named Johnson during an initial interview.

The judges called it a "material irregularity" that also breached the European convention on human rights.

"Because [Duncan] was concealing his status as an informant, he was also forced to lie about what had taken place," said Lord Justice Mantell. "That could only have been in collusion with the police. It amounts to no less than a conspiracy to give perjured evidence. We find the fact profoundly disturbing. It must dent the credibility of both Duncan and the police officers directly involved."

After the ruling, Mr Rowe said: "The only reason I am standing here is because my sister, family, supporters and friends have fought long and hard to prove we are innocent.

"Today they have done that. The victims said from the outset it was two whites and one black. They weren't listened to."

A statement read out on Mr Davis's behalf said: "We are innocent, regardless of what this court said. The judges said there was a conspiracy by the police and witnesses. I want those policemen brought to book."

Surrey police said: "We will be seeking clarification of the suggestion of collusion between Duncan and police officers. This has now been investigated twice and leaves us bemused as no evidence of such collusion has been found."

webTitle: Poll slide adds to Blair gloom

fields.headline: Poll slide adds to Blair gloom
fields.standfirst: Inquiry into leak of damaging memo
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's hopes of a summer recovery are dashed today by the latest Guardian/ICM opinion poll, which shows that Labour's lead has slipped to just seven points ahead of the Tories - the narrowest gap between the two parties since the landslide 13-point general election victory in May 1997.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's hopes of a summer recovery are dashed today by the latest Guardian/ICM opinion poll, which shows that Labour's lead has slipped to just seven points ahead of the Tories - the narrowest gap between the two parties since the landslide 13-point general election victory in May 1997.

The ICM survey was taken at the weekend before the leak of Tony Blair's own confidential memo admitting that his government was widely perceived to be "somehow out of touch with gut British instincts" on key populist issues such as crime and asylum seekers.

The leak was the subject of a high-level inquiry by the cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson, last night amid Labour hints that it had been orchestrated by the Tories after someone, inside Downing Street or an outside hacker, had intercepted Mr Blair's private communications.

The timing, on the eve of Gordon Brown's long-awaited unveiling of his £40bn comprehensive spending review and today's bad crime figures, is damaging. The Guardian's ICM poll will also dampen Labour's confidence, although Blair aides remain adamant that they are already on course to bounce back from mid-term difficulties.

The poll shows that last month's 11-point lead has been cut by four points in the face of a recovering Tory party. This is only the second time since the election that Labour's poll lead has fallen below 10 points to reach such a low point. The last time was in May.

It represents a sharp decline in popularity in the past year. The Tories have reached 35%, their highest poll rating since the election, suggesting that their "flatlining" days around the 30% mark may be in the past.

Last night delighted senior Tories claimed the leaked memo would encourage voters to believe that Labour is "all spin and no substance" - a belief that Downing Street is keen to kill.

"Now we know where all the spin and the gimmicks come from in this government. It comes from the very top," William Hague told reporters. Labour loyalists see the memo as unsurprising at worst and impressively lacking in complacency at best.

Some senior officials speculated that the same person who intercepted the private pollster Philip Gould's recent memo reporting allegations that Mr Blair is "all spin and no substance" is behind the latest leak - and might be using a trusted Tory as a go-between. Some MPs called for tighter electronic security for No 10.

Today's ICM poll confirms that the prime minister's anxiety in his leaked memo - handwritten at Chequers on April 29 and faxed to key advisers - that the party was being seen as "soft on crime" is still widely believed by the voters. It helps explain Mr Blair's tough remarks since then, including his ill-fated plan to impose on-the-spot cashpoint fines on lager louts.

Some 69% of the electorate, including 48% of Labour voters, say that the prime minister, despite his promise, has not been "tough on crime and tough on the causes of crime". But 42% of Labour voters believe he has delivered tough crime policies.

The government will try again today to dispel the perception by announcing extra cash to recruit more police officers as part of Mr Brown's package.

The shift comes as the latest crime figures are published, revealing a 16% rise in violent crime, the largest for more than 10 years, and a more modest 3.8% rise in the overall headline crime rate.

The accuracy of the prime minister's identification of crime as the party's weak spot is confirmed when the pollsters asked the voters which party they thought had the best policies on a series of policy areas. Labour still retains a strong lead over the Conservatives on its core issues of health (+19 points) and education (+18 points). It also retains a lead over the Tories on the economy (+8 points).

But there is growing and widespread scepticism over its performance on roads, railways and bus services (49% say none of the parties have the best policy or don't know) and crime (55% say none of the parties or don't know).

Labour retains a slim lead over the Tories on crime (22% to 18%) but the massive ab stention implies that the disillusioned Labour voter is not yet ready to vote Conservative.

The only issue on which the Tories actually have a lead over Labour is on tax (28% to 25%), despite last week's furore over Mr Hague's u-turn, ditching the opposition's "minimum tax guarantee".

 ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,056 adults aged 18-plus by telephone between July 14 and 15. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

webTitle: Third tribunal payout gags MSF allegations

fields.headline: Third tribunal payout gags MSF allegations
fields.standfirst: Union official drops victimisation case for £200,000 retirement deal
fields.trailText: MSF, the manufacturing, science and finance union, yesterday paid out nearly £200,000 and handed over a free company car to a senior union official in order to halt a fresh employment tribunal airing allegations of misconduct and expenses fiddles.
fields.body:
MSF, the manufacturing, science and finance union, yesterday paid out nearly £200,000 and handed over a free company car to a senior union official in order to halt a fresh employment tribunal airing allegations of misconduct and expenses fiddles.

Howell John, the union's north Thames regional officer, was yesterday given £108,000 tax free, had £84,000 added to his pension fund, and was given a Ford Mondeo, in a deal done hours before he was due to bring allegations of victimisation against Roger Lyons, the general secretary, at a central London tribunal.

Lawyers for the union made Mr John sign a "gagging clause" to keep secret allegations about MSF's internal affairs that would have been made public in the case.

The settlement comes 10 days after a tribunal case against the "whistleblower" Marcia Solomon for gross misconduct collapsed. Ms Solomon, a former secretarial assistant to Nelson Mendes, the union's head of finance, received £50,000 tax free in a £140,000 out of court settlement. She had accused Mr Mendes and Mr Lyons of fiddling thousands of pounds of expenses, and claimed to have seen copies of cheques totalling £35,000 paid to them from defunct union accounts. Both officials strongly denied the allegations.

Mr John's case arose out of a report by John Chowcat, the union's former assistant general secretary, on the allegations about the cheques and the expense account lifestyle of Mr Lyons. Mr Chowcat detailed Mr Lyons's expenses, suggesting he bought two briefcases, a luggage trolley, two radios, a video recorder and an expensive connection to the internet at home - all out of his claims. It also suggested he regularly had take-aways at home on expenses, and made "sustenance" claims for between £4.50 and £20 every time he met Tony Blair or Gordon Brown and attended internal union management meetings.

Mr Chowcat was initially dismissed for gross misconduct, but later won a £250,000 out of court settlement. Ms Solomon, who had first made the expenses allegations, then won her "whistleblower" case. Mr John was originally accused of leaking the information about the general secretary's life style - and his case was settled yesterday.

Altogether the union has spent around £750,000, including legal costs, to settle these three cases.

The general secretary is, however, facing a fourth claim for unfair dismissal, from his former chauffeur, Bryan Keegan; he alleges he was fired after claiming £7,000 owed in overtime, and he has also made further allegations about Mr Lyons's expenses.

Yesterday the union and Mr John agreed a joint statement saying he would take early retirment on grounds of ill health. Mr John, 58, was not due to go until 65. The statement praised his work for the union, and said he agreed "to withdraw allegations he had made" as part of the deal. His barrister, Damain McCarthy, said yesterday: "Mr Howell is very happy with the settlement and relieved he can now get on with the rest of his life."

The union did not want to comment on the settlement, but a spokesman emphasised that Mr John was retiring on grounds of ill health.

The settlement came after two MSF regional councils met over the weekend and called for Mr Lyons and Mr Mendes to resign, and demanded an independent inquiry by forensic auditors. The resolutions cited the findings of Ms Solomon's tribunal. Her hearing for unfair dismissal under "whistleblower" legislation was halted by the tribunal when it became clear the union was unable to sustain its assertion she had been malicious in making her claims of wrongdoing.

webTitle: New fight to save Nissan car jobs

fields.headline: New fight to save Nissan car jobs
fields.standfirst: Company chief in No 10 talks over threat to switch Micra to France
fields.trailText: The prime minister is to intervene in an increasingly desperate government effort to prevent Nissan, the Japanese car maker, from switching production of its new Micra from Sunderland to a French plant in the heart of the eurozone.
fields.body:
The prime minister is to intervene in an increasingly desperate government effort to prevent Nissan, the Japanese car maker, from switching production of its new Micra from Sunderland to a French plant in the heart of the eurozone.

Tony Blair and Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, are to hold talks with Carlos Ghosn, Nissan president, at Downing Street later this month amid mounting ministerial and union fears that the new car will be built at Renault's Flins plant near Paris.

Mr Ghosn is a former executive at Renault where he earned a fearsome reputation as a cost cutter. He is expected to press the case for an early decision on UK entry to the euro to offset the financial damage caused by the strong pound. Nissan, in which Renault owns a 36.8% controlling stake, has already asked for UK state aid towards the £150m investment it would have to make at Sunderland for the new Micra assembly line.

This intervention by Mr Blair comes when anxiety is growing over the overall fate of the UK car industry. Sir Ken Jackson, leader of the AEEU engineering union, last night called for talks with Jac Nasser, Ford president, to discuss alternatives to the planned closure of the assembly line at Dagenham, and ministers are openly worried about Rover's future under the Phoenix consortium.

Sunderland is Europe's most productive car plant but makes losses, largely because the bulk of its output, around 350,000 cars including the current Micra, is for export to mainland Europe. It employs 5,000 in a region represented by several cabinet ministers, including Mr Blair and Mr Byers. Senior ministers fear that Nissan could bow to the wishes of its French part-owners, Renault, and build the new Micra at Flins, to the north-west of Paris, which employs 6,654.

The Micra's "platform" or basic structure is to be combined with that of the new Clio, making it feasible to produce the two cars at the same plant. The new Micra is due to enter production in 2002, before any likely UK membership of the euro.

Mr Ghosn warned last month that, though Sunderland was the "logical" place to build the new Micra, its case was damaged by the strong pound and he called for "guarantees" for its future.

Even if they stump up money for Sunderland, ministers fear Nissan may follow the example of Toyota and go to France. The Japanese car maker, whose main European base is in Derbyshire, is building a new plant in Valenciennes, northern France, with substantial state aid.

Sir Ken, meanwhile, released a letter to Mr Nasser urging Ford to transfer production of a new Volvo from its Ghent plant in Belgium to Dagenham, where 1,900 jobs are to go when the assembly line closes in 2002. He said: "Ford wants to build new Volvos at Ghent but Ghent is too small, has no stamping facility and too few skilled workers. Dagenham can do the work."

He added that Volvo, now owned by Ford, would have to take on 1,800 new staff in Belgium and build a new 50,000 square metre facility at Ghent's assembly line to double output to 325,000 cars by 2004. Tony Blair and Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, are to hold talks with Carlos Ghosn, Nissan president, at Downing Street later this month amid mounting ministerial and union fears that the new car will be built at Renault's Flins plant near Paris. Mr Ghosn is a former executive at Renault where he earned a fearsome reputation as a cost cutter. He is expected to press the case for an early decision on UK entry to the euro to offset the financial damage caused by the strong pound. Nissan, in which Renault owns a 36.8% controlling stake, has already asked for UK state aid towards the £150m investment it would have to make at Sunderland for the new Micra assembly line. This intervention by Mr Blair comes when anxiety is growing over the overall fate of the UK car industry. Sir Ken Jackson, leader of the AEEU engineering union, last night called for talks with Jac Nasser, Ford president, to discuss alternatives to the planned closure of the assembly line at Dagenham, and ministers are openly worried about Rover's future under the Phoenix consortium. Sunderland is Europe's most productive car plant but makes losses, largely because the bulk of its output, around 350,000 cars including the current Micra, is for export to mainland Europe. It employs 5,000 in a region represented by several cabinet ministers, including Mr Blair and Mr Byers. webTitle: Germany signs £3.3bn pact for Nazi victims

fields.headline: Germany signs £3.3bn pact for Nazi victims
fields.trailText: Men and women forced to labour for the Nazis during the second world war are expected to receive initial compensation payments before the end of this year, following the signing yesterday of an historic deal to compensate them for their suffering.
fields.body:
Men and women forced to labour for the Nazis during the second world war are expected to receive initial compensation payments before the end of this year, following the signing yesterday of an historic deal to compensate them for their suffering.

The agreement to set up a fund of 10bn marks (£3.3bn) for former forced and slave labourers will almost certainly be Germany's last formal reparation for the horrors inflicted on Europe under Hitler's rule. Up to 10m men and women were used as labourers by the Third Reich.

Yesterday's long-delayed settlement was greeted with contradictory sentiments by the victims - the satisfaction of some contrasting with the disillusion of others. Almost a fifth of the fund will cover property losses and projects connected with reparation. The remainder will be disbursed among more than half a million survivors. Slave labourers - most of them Jews were were intended to be worked to death - will get up to 15,000 marks. Forced labourers - mainly east Europeans -will receive about 5,000 marks.

Dissatisfaction was most notable yesterday among representatives of the east European victims. Markiyan Demidov, head of the Ukrainian victims' union said: "The amounts are a joke, an insult from Ger many." His Polish counterpart, Marian Nawrocki, said: "This is not so much, considering the scale of our suffering, the bestial treatment we were subjected to and the wounds that stayed for life."

But Ben Helfgott of Britain, who was born a Polish Jew and toiled in a string of labour camps, said: "We have achieved something that we never thought would ever be possible."

The deal was welcomed by the Conference on Jewish Material Claims against Germany. Its president, Rabbi Israel Miller, urged that payments be made as soon as possible. "Slave labourers are dying every day," he said. "Our obligation is to reach them quickly."

Germany's former chancellor, Helmut Kohl, had ruled out any form of settlement. It was only after his 1998 election defeat by Gerhard Schröder's centre-left coalition that voluntary compensation became thinkable. Mr Schröder said yesterday: "This closes one of the last open chapters of the Nazi past. We are setting down a durable marker of historic and moral responsibility."

German companies, however, were already under pressure from the threat of legal action in the United States. A key element in the agreement is a guarantee for them of immunity from US law suits.

The pact was signed at a ceremony in Berlin by representatives from Germany, the US, Israel and eastern Europe as well as American lawyers for the victims. It provides for the Germany government and German firms to split the cost 50:50.

But while the number of companies involved has risen to some 3,000, the total pledged by industry falls well short of what is needed. It has so far committed only 3.2bn marks of the 5bn marks required by the deal and, as a result of recent legislation in Germany, the law.

The reluctance of firms to commit shareholders' money to the fund was the key reason for successive delays. The talks missed an initial August 1999 deadline and appeared close to failure last October.

webTitle: Taliban send off footballers in shorts

fields.headline: Taliban send off footballers in shorts
fields.trailText: A team of Pakistani footballers on a rare tour to Afghanistan were arrested and had their heads shaved as a punishment for wearing shorts, a violation of the Islamic code laid down by the Taliban government.
fields.body:
A team of Pakistani footballers on a rare tour to Afghanistan were arrested and had their heads shaved as a punishment for wearing shorts, a violation of the Islamic code laid down by the Taliban government.

The players from the Young Afghan Club, based in the border town of Chaman, in western Pakistan, were dressed in a red strip and shorts for the invitation tour, the first visit by a Pakistani team since the Taliban took power four years ago.

Halfway through their third and final game against a local team in Kandahar on Saturday, armed Taliban religious police burst into the sports stadium and stopped the match.

The team manager and some of the reserves fled but 12 players were arrested. The raid started a stampede among the hundreds of spectators and several were injured.

After a night in the city jail, the players had their heads shaved, a mark of shame usually reserved for petty thieves, and the men were sent home.

Mohammed Hasan, the Taliban's Kandahar governor and one of the regime's most senior leaders, admitted the police had over-reacted. "They were our guests and should not be treated like this," he said.

Under Taliban rules and despite the burning summer heat, the players should have been more modestly dressed in the traditional shalwar kameez, baggy trousers and long-sleeved shirt.

All Afghan men must also wear turbans and uncut beards or risk a public beating from the religious police. Women are rarely allowed out of their homes and when they venture on to the streets they must wear all-covering cloaks, burqas. Western-style clothes and haircuts are forbidden.

More than 20 years of war and four years of Taliban rule have put pay to most organised sport in Afghanistan, one of the few countries not to put forward a team for the Olympics or the next World Cup.

The Taliban have taken to using the crumbling brick football stadiums of Kabul and Kandahar for public executions and mutilations.

fields.headline: Police smoke out Greek hospitals
fields.trailText: Greek police began patrolling hospitals yesterday to arrest any staff, patients or visitors caught smoking as they enforced a long-ignored cigarette ban.
fields.body:
Greek police began patrolling hospitals yesterday to arrest any staff, patients or visitors caught smoking as they enforced a long-ignored cigarette ban.

Angry at persistent smoking in hospitals, the health ministry issued a decree saying anyone caught doing it would be arrested and taken straight to court for summary trial.

Television showed uniformed police walking through the large Athens Evangelismos hospital corridors on the first day of the decree's enforcement. Offenders face fines at the discretion of the judge.

Evangelismos is the first hospital in the country to enforce the ban following complaints from patients that hospitals were uniquely unhygenic places.

Patients, tired of bringing in their own sheets and food to state hospitals, called for better health standards.

After Cuba, Greece tops the international league table of smokers, and has the highest per capita cigarette consumption of any country in the European Union.

The medical profession are among the greatest offenders. Cigarette-puffing doctors and nurses are a common sight on the wards in Greece, often cramming hospital hallways and corridors for a post-operative smoke.

The ban is seen as a long-overdue attempt to bring Greece in line with its EU counterparts. The Greek government announced the measure after saying that it would also stop all non-EU foreigners from being treated for non-life-saving operations.

There have been mounting complaints recently after it was discovered that thousands of immigrants from eastern Europe and developing countries were checking in to hospital for expensive treatments that they could not obtain at home.

webTitle: The best of it, the worst of it... a tale of two cities

fields.headline: The best of it, the worst of it... a tale of two cities
fields.standfirst: Policing crime: special report
fields.trailText: Manchester, which emerges as the scariest city in England and Wales on today's crime figures, has eight times more robberies than Sheffield.
fields.body:
Manchester, which emerges as the scariest city in England and Wales on today's crime figures, has eight times more robberies than Sheffield.

The number of crimes involving violence is five times greater and the number of sexual offences four times greater than in the south Yorkshire city across the Pennines. Manchester can also claim double the number of burglaries and thefts of and from vehicles.

The statistics will be seen as bad news by a city building up its conference trade and preparing to host the Commonwealth Games in 2002.

There will be little comfort for a police force which has worked with communities such as that of Moss Side to stamp out the gun and gang culture that disfigured its reputation in the 1990s.

While Sheffield yesterday fell over itself to talk of policing styles and anti-crime strategies, Manchester complained that like was not being compared with like.

"The nature of Manchester is considerably different from Sheffield," said a spokesman for Greater Manchester police. "More people travel to Manchester on a daily basis. The city also has a more transient population, which makes offences against the person such as robbery more likely to happen. We have the largest student campus in Europe and vast numbers of people coming into the centre to shop and enjoy its social life."

That social life erupts on to the streets on Friday and Saturday nights when revellers head for the city's bars and clubs, and it can turn nasty when such establishments close their doors in the early hours.

Manchester city council responded to gangland intimidation by introducing a registration scheme for bouncers, and plans to follow Liverpool in seeking a bylaw allowing police to seize opened bottles of alcohol and glasses carried on the street. Many city centre streets are now watched by closed circuit TV cameras.

"I'm shocked by these figures, which are unacceptable," said Kath Robinson, deputy leader of the council. "We shall be seeking an urgent meeting with the chief constable to get to the bottom of the figures."

She said the city had sought 10 anti-social orders and set up 23 local action partnerships in an attempt to reduce crime. "You have to remember that 43% of people in the city are on housing benefit and 73% of council tax payers are in the A band," she added.

Police in Sheffield - England's fifth largest city - were quick to claim credit for reduced levels of crime, including lower rates of violent crime, sex offences and robbery than in any comparable city.

"We're targeting known criminals, building up evidence about them, sometimes using surveillance techniques," said Mike Hedges, chief constable of South Yorkshire.

"Only last week, a group of drug dealers appeared before Sheffield crown court and were sentenced to almost 50 years between them following lengthy surveillance.

"Intelligence-led policing is all over the news at the moment, but I can tell you: it works."

But high-profile detective work is only part of the strategy: the flipside involves mopping up after the customers of the city's 900 licensed premises, 301 off-licences, and 150 registered clubs. "The things that bug people in Sheffield city centre are what people do when they are drunk: urinating in doorways, vomiting, even making love in doorways, and we are now prepared to arrest people in those cases," said a spokesman for the force.

"You might ask whether it's worth catching somebody who's urinating in a doorway, but that person is contributing to the rundown of the city centre."

The city's Prolific Offenders Project, one of only a handful in the UK, borrows from Dutch techniques of crime prevention in bringing together police, probation officers and the health service in a streamlined initiative to target the tiny minority of offenders who commit the vast majority of crimes.

It provides medical support for the 80% who are users of heroin or crack cocaine and gives staff access to police intelligence.

fields.headline: Business users expect free 3G phones
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Almost a third of business users expect to receive a free upgrade of their mobile handsets to next-generation internet phones, according to a survey by the consultancy CMG.
fields.body:
Almost a third of business users expect to receive a free upgrade of their mobile handsets to next-generation internet phones, according to a survey by the consultancy CMG.

CMG said the prospect of phone operators having to subsidise upgrades threatens their ability to recoup costs.

Third-generation technology will allow mobile handsets to perform simple computing tasks and promise high-speed internet connections and video conferencing.

The costs next-generation operators face already are massive. Vodafone, One2One, Orange, BT Cellnet and TIW paid a total of £22.5bn to the government for the licences to deliver third-generation mobile phone technology from 2002.

Analysts have estimated those five operators might have to spend a further £10bn upgrading their networks to deliver the technology.

The survey of 300 business users in Britain, the Netherlands and Germany found many mobile were dissatisfied with the performance of functions on their present handsets such as email and internet access.

"[They] aren't yet attractive enough for business managers to want to pay extra to upgrade their mobile phones," the survey concluded.

"Surprisingly, 28% expect their service provider to provide the upgrade for nothing. This is bad news for the network providers as it looks as if customers are not yet prepared to help them recoup their costs."

The survey also found only 11% of those interviewed were happy with their current mobile phone operators and only 10% owned handsets capable of sending and receiving emails.

Even so, more than two-thirds of those respondents expect to be using their mobile phones for email by 2003.

webTitle: Louise Woodward's parents defrauded her appeal fund of thousands, court told

fields.headline: Louise Woodward's parents defrauded her appeal fund of thousands, court told
fields.trailText: The parents of Louise Woodward, the au pair who was convicted of killing an American baby, got richer and richer while they defrauded their daughter's appeal fund, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
The parents of Louise Woodward, the au pair who was convicted of killing an American baby, got richer and richer while they defrauded their daughter's appeal fund, a court heard yesterday.

Gary and Susan Woodward, who are now estranged, have pleaded not guilty to submitting a false invoice for accommodation expenses incurred while Mrs Woodward was staying free of charge at the home of Louise's American lawyer Elaine Whitfield Sharp.

The couple, both 44, of Elton, Cheshire, submitted a $15,400 (£9,100) invoice for seven months' accommodation while Mrs Woodward was a guest at the lawyer's home. She claimed it cost her $2,200 a month. The couple also deny furnishing false information.

Bernard Lever, prosecuting, told Chester crown court: "Far from getting poorer and poorer and poorer, they were getting richer and richer and richer. They were getting their full salaries from their employers, they were getting free air fares back and forth across the Atlantic and they were getting free accommodation from Mr and Mrs Whitfield Sharp. Everyone was doing their best to help them."

He said there was evidence of Mr Woodward's dishonesty when he claimed to the appeal fund's lawyer in 1998: "We're skint, we're wiped out. We need this money urgently."

Furthermore the Woodwards were meticulous about making expenses claims. "Among the receipts submitted at the same time of the bogus rent invoice was $6.80 for guinea pig food for Louise's hamster and 50 cents for bubblegum for Louise," said Mr Lever. "Unbeknown to anybody they did a deal with the Mail newspaper. To people all around the world this poor couple never got a penny, but they had £80,000 in assets -including £50,000 they had not told anybody about," said Mr Lever. "Does that assist you as to whether they were dishonest?"

The forged invoice came to light when the couple submitted a claim for £30,000 expenses incurred while they were in the United States. The biggest part of the bill was for accommodation that had been free.

But Mr Lever said that whoever forged the invoice had got the Whitfield Sharp postcode wrong and had mistakenly added a hyphen to the surname. He said: "The invoice is a forged document and the envelope it was in is genuine Sharp stationery, but the Woodwards stayed in their home and had the run of the house for months so the stationery was easy to get hold of. They thought they would get paid on the nod and not be questioned."

Louise was arrested in Boston, Massachusetts in February 1997 for assault and battery after Matthew Eappen, who was in her care, became ill. She was charged with murder after he died and it was alleged that she had shaken him to death, which she strongly denies.

Her parents regularly flew out to America to visit their daughter before her trial. Mrs Woodward moved into a spare room at the Whitfield Sharps' home in April 1997 and she stayed until October. Shortly before the trial began, the couple moved into an apartment near the court paid for by Louise's au pair agency.

The agency also footed bills for lawyers, air fares, hotel rooms and car rental. Louise was eventually freed after serving 279 days in prison when her conviction was reduced for involuntary manslaughter.

Mr Lever said: "They were guests of the Sharps and apart from taking them out for the odd meal or buying them a carton of milk or the like at no charge whatsoever, accommodation was completely free out of the goodness of Mr and Mrs Sharp's heart."

He said Mr Woodward told police that they kept a wedge of cash in a bedside table or sock which they then handed over the Sharps.

An appeal fund was originally set up in Elton after Louise was arrested. It raised £20,000 which was used to pay off the couple's credit card bills while they were in the US. A proper trust was set up after more than £250,000 of public donations poured in.

"All the trustees took the view that as they were dealing with substantial sums from the public, payments to the Woodwards had to be carefully examined against documents produced by them for their expenditure," said Mr Lever. He said previous payments had gone through on the nod so the defendants did not expect to be scrutinised.

He said Mrs Woodward claimed Mrs Whitfield Sharp was angry at not being allowed to make money by writing a book on the family. Mrs Woodward has said she paid the lawyer for accommodation and it had been Mrs Whitfield Sharp's idea to submit the invoice. Her husband said he was surprised by the invoice because he had never asked for it.

Mrs Whitfield Sharp told the court she had nothing to do with the invoice. She said Mrs Woodward had paid no rent but would occasionally pay for meals out.

The trial, expected to last for three weeks, continues today.

Some of the alleged expense claims

$6.80 for hamster food

50 cents for bubblegum

$1,600 for car rental (paid for by the British Charitable Society)

$250 for reading materials (paid for by the British Charitable Society)

$1,492 for clothing, parking and petrol (paid for by the EF au pair agency, which had employed Louise Woodward)

"Among the receipts submitted at the same time of the bogus rent invoice was $6.80 for guinea pig food for Louise's hamster and 50 cents for bubblegum for Louise," said Mr Lever. "Unbeknown to anybody they did a deal with the Mail newspaper. To people all around the world this poor couple never got a penny, but they had £80,000 in assets -including £50,000 they had not told anybody about," said Mr Lever. "Does that assist you as to whether they were dishonest?" The forged invoice came to light when the couple submitted a claim for £30,000 expenses incurred while they were in the United States. The biggest part of the bill was for accommodation that had been free. But Mr Lever said that whoever forged the invoice had got the Whitfield Sharp postcode wrong and had mistakenly added a hyphen to the surname. He said: "The invoice is a forged document and the envelope it was in is genuine Sharp stationery, but the Woodwards stayed in their home and had the run of the house for months so the stationery was easy to get hold of. They thought they would get paid on the nod and not be questioned." Louise was arrested in Boston, Massachusetts in February 1997 for assault and battery after Matthew Eappen, who was in her care, became ill. She was charged with murder after he died and it was alleged that she had shaken him to death, which she strongly denies. Her parents regularly flew out to America to visit their daughter before her trial. Mrs Woodward moved into a spare room at the Whitfield Sharps' home in April 1997 and she stayed until October. Shortly before the trial began, the couple moved into an apartment near the court paid for by Louise's au pair agency. The agency also footed bills for lawyers, air fares, hotel rooms and car rental. Louise was eventually freed after serving 279 days in prison when her conviction was reduced for involuntary manslaughter. Mr Lever said: "They were guests of the Sharps and apart from taking them out for the odd meal or buying them a carton of milk or the like at no charge whatsoever, accommodation was completely free out of the goodness of Mr and Mrs Sharp's heart." He said Mr Woodward told police that they kept a wedge of cash in a bedside table or sock which they then handed over the Sharps. An appeal fund was originally set up in Elton after Louise was arrested. It raised £20,000 which was used to pay off the couple's credit card bills while they were in the US. A proper trust was set up after more than £250,000 of public donations poured in. "All the trustees took the view that as they were dealing with substantial sums from the public, payments to the Woodwards had to be carefully examined against documents produced by them for their expenditure," said Mr Lever. He said previous payments had gone through on the nod so the defendants did not expect to be scrutinised. He said Mrs Woodward claimed Mrs Whitfield Sharp was angry at not being allowed to make money by writing a book on the family. Mrs Woodward has said she paid the lawyer for accommodation and it had been Mrs Whitfield Sharp's idea to submit the invoice. Her husband said he was surprised by the invoice because he had never asked for it. Mrs Whitfield Sharp told the court she had nothing to do with the invoice. She said Mrs Woodward had paid no rent but would occasionally pay for meals out. The trial, expected to last for three weeks, continues today. Some of the alleged expense claims $6.80 for hamster food 50 cents for bubblegum $1,600 for car rental (paid for by the British Charitable Society) $250 for reading materials (paid for by the British Charitable Society) $1,492 for clothing, parking and petrol (paid for by the EF au pair agency, which had employed Louise Woodward)

webTitle: Missing Sarah: girl's body found in field

fields.headline: Missing Sarah: girl's body found in field
fields.standfirst:
Timetable: Sarah's disappearance
More about the case
6pm, audio: Sad details emerge
fields.trailText: Detectives yesterday informed the anguished parents of Sarah Payne they had found the body of a young girl in undergrowth 10 miles from where the eight-year-old vanished.
fields.body:
Detectives yesterday informed the anguished parents of Sarah Payne they had found the body of a young girl in undergrowth 10 miles from where the eight-year-old vanished.

Police said they were keeping an open mind as to whether the body was that of the missing schoolgirl until formal identification had taken place, but were unaware of any other missing girls from the area whom it could be.

The discovery, 17 days after Sarah went missing from a country lane in Kingston Gorse, West Sussex, was made by a young farmworker as he walked in a field alongside the A29 between Pulborough and Billingshurst.

Assistant Chief Constable Nigel Yeo, of Sussex police, said that a Home Office pathologist was at the scene examining the body, which was found 25 yards from a hedge separating the field from the busy main road which runs north through the West Sussex countryside from the coast.

The body was believed to have lain undiscovered for some time, hidden from the main road by 6ft high ferns and dense undergrowth.

Mr Yeo said parts of the body were covered up, including the face.

"There is some concealment. Whether it was concealed when the body was left there or subsequently is something we can't answer."

Identification was likely to take some time, he said, as scientists and officers carried out detailed investigations across an area which would extend to acres.

He said: "It's a very very slow process particularly as you bring in the experts. You don't uncover the body, the face particularly - that being one of the parts that was covered - until later on."

White-suited scenes of crime officers were yesterday seen scouring the sealed-off area near Brinsbury agricultural college, wading through waist-high grasses and weeds in the shadow of a police helicopter which hovered above.

From the road, the only sign of the grim find behind the bushes and trees screening the field was the top of the white police tent erected over the site.

Mr Yeo described the mood of the officers involved in the hunt for Sarah as "fairly grim". He said: "There is a lot of sadness.

"Whatever has happened down the road represents a human tragedy no matter who it is."

The Payne family were being kept informed of developments, he said, adding: "Even if there is no connection with the discovery, the sheer circumstances represent another trauma for the family."

The discovery of the body came just hours after police released the latest available photograph of Sarah in another attempt to jog people's memories.

Investigations were still focusing on the white van seen by Sarah's brothers in a lane near Kingston Gorse on July 1, at the time she vanished.

Police revealed yesterday they had received crucial information regarding the van after a person who had just returned from holiday contacted them.

fields.headline: Straw to target drink-related crime
fields.standfirst:
As latest figures reveal surge in violence, home secretary claims government is getting to grips with real causes

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Affluent young men getting involved in late night fights and targeting of mobile phones by robbers are among key factors driving the 16% rise in violent crime in the last year revealed by the statistics published today by the Home Office.
fields.body:
Affluent young men getting involved in late night fights and targeting of mobile phones by robbers are among key factors driving the 16% rise in violent crime in the last year revealed by the statistics published today by the Home Office.

The police figures show a further modest rise in the headline crime rate to 3.8% in the 12 months to March but also reveal one of the sharpest ever increases in violent crime - particularly robbery, which jumped 26%.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, last night insisted that the figures, which also showed continuing falls in domestic burglary (down 6%) and car crime (down 4%), proved the government was "bucking the long-term trend of rising crime" by tackling the issue. Despite Mr Straw's denial that the prime minister was panicking over the crime figures, a further significant boost to police recruitment will be announced today and a package of measures to tackle alcohol-related crime is to be unveiled next month.

Mr Straw yesterday blamed youngsters with more money in their pockets spending more than ever on drink, and then getting involved in violence and disorder when they left clubs and pubs, for fuelling the rise in violence.

"Some 40% of violent crimes are committed when the offender is under the influence of alcohol, as are 78% of assaults and 88% of criminal damage incidents," said the home secretary. Comparative tables published for the first time, grouping local authority areas into "families" weighted by 20 social factors such as unemployment, show clear discrepancies between the crime figures of similar areas.

They show, for example, that Hull has the highest burglary rate in Britain and Caerphilly in Gwent the highest violent crime rate. But they confirm that it is inner London boroughs, such as Lambeth and Hackney, and some of the big cities, such as Manchester, which have the worst crime problems.

They also reveal a clear north-south divide, with the largest increases taking place in London, the home counties and East Anglia.

A new package of measures for tackling alcohol-related crime is to be unveiled. Proposals include a "proof of age" ID scheme, state licensing of pub and club "doorkeepers", barring "habitual drunks" from pubs, and forging tighter relationships between hospitals' accident departments and the police.

Ministers' hopes of tackling the rise in robberies, which is fuelled by mobile phone thefts, are even more long term, with attempts being made to persuade mobile phone companies to adopt a more expensive new "chip" which would incapacitate stolen phones and even indicate their location.

Home Office statisticians said that 86% of the robberies were street attacks with the rest being on businesses. Two-thirds of all robberies happened in London, Manchester and Birmingham. The sharp rise in violent crime was preceded by an unexpected fall last year, and Home Office officials said part of the reason may be the "bedding in" of new counting rules - but there was a clear upward trend.

The vast majority of the 581,000 offences recorded for violence against the person, which now includes everything from murder through harassment down to non-injury common assaults, was for less serious crimes. But the total for "life threatening" offences rose by 12% to 30,400.

The upward increases in sex crimes (up 4%), racially aggravated offences - of which 22,000 were recorded - and domestic violence (not separately counted) are officially explained as reflecting a growing intolerance of such offences and a greater willingness to report them to the police. Drug offences fell by 10% to 122,000 offences, mainly possession.

But it is the burglary and car crime figures which ministers will take the most comfort from.

Burglaries fell for the seventh year running to 906,000 offences, and thefts of and from vehicles also fell for the seventh year running, by 3% on the previous year.

But the continuing fall in detection rates, down from 29% to 25% will continue to cause anxiety. Officials said the fall was partly the result of tightening up the rules, so that offences cleared up during prison visits and those where no further action is taken were not counted as detections.

webTitle: We must cover up our knees to get off them

fields.headline: We must cover up our knees to get off them
fields.trailText: Our decline as a footballing power can be traced back to that moment in 1953 when Nandor Hidegkuti and his chums ushered in a new era of mid-to-upper-leg exposure.
fields.body:
Perhaps more than even Sunday's debacle against Ecuador, it says something about the parlous state of British tennis that the only book I could find on the sport in my local library yesterday was on the bottom shelf, between Go Fishing For Bass and Tales Of A Rat-Hunting Man.

The fact that Agassi And Ecstasy had attracted considerably less interest from borrowers than The Jackie Stewart Book Of Shooting, and had been trounced in the ratings war by Sir Walter Gilbey's Hounds In Old Days, is surely something even the Lawn Tennis Association's doughty performance director Patrice Hagelauer will struggle to redress.

The problem is indeed a deep one. A nation can only excel at a sport when the conditions are right. Take last weekend's beach football event at sunny Richmond-on-Sea: how could our native players be expected to defeat the French in a contest so clearly slanted in the latter's favour?

Where were the elements of beach football with which British players would have felt familiar: the howling wind, the driving rain, the piebald mongrel with the mad, feral mien of a WWF corner man, which runs off with the ball and snarls menacingly at anyone who attempts to retrieve it? Where were the ice-cream wrappers, the sandcastles and the group of spotty youths in baggy drawers dive-bombing the players with a nylon kite the size of a boxing ring?

You may wonder what this has to do with Britain's failure on the famous lawns of SW19 to overcome Ecuador, a country with only one grass court. The answer is simple: shorts. This pernicious and frankly continental garment has created an environment in which no Briton can possibly succeed.

Bluntly, our country has failed dismally down the years in any sport requiring the exposure of knees to pub lic scrutiny. The masculine British knee is a sensitive beast that does not take kindly to the harsh light of day. If it must see sunshine, it prefers to peep cautiously from the narrow aperture between the top of a stout woollen sock and the hem of a voluminous pair of nether garments, preferably canvas with the colour and texture of a ship's biscuit. It is surely no coincidence that the last British man to triumph on centre court was modestly attired in trousers.

Our decline as a footballing power, meanwhile, can be traced back to that moment in 1953 when Nandor Hidegkuti and his chums ushered in a new era of mid-to-upper-leg exposure. Much is made of the Magnificent Magyars' skills yet Billy Wright's moral and physical collapse during the Wembley fixture owed as much to the unabashed display of Hungarian shank-joints as to Puskas's drag-back.

Since then football shorts have crept ever more groin-wards (the amount of coccyx on display nowadays would have made poor Billy faint dead away, I suspect) and countries more comfortable with public nudity than us - such as Germany, France and Brazil - have consequently dominated the game. The only underachievers who stand comparison with England are Spain, a nation that for years laboured under the prudish moral codes of General Franco.

Rest assured that any progress the Spanish national team make over the next decade will have more to do with the liberating influence of Pedro Almodovar than the fire of Hector Camacho or the skill of Raul.

England, meanwhile, must pin its hopes on Howard Wilkinson. Admittedly the Yorkshireman is not the sort you can imagine creating Live Flesh or Women On The Verge Of A Nervous Breakdown (in fact, Lads On The Verge Of Carrying A Telegraph Pole Up A Mountain would be more his style) but he is said to be open to ideas. It is therefore entirely possible he will revitalise the English game by insisting that henceforth our youth academies hold at least one naked training session a week, while he himself turns up at the occasional under-19 tournament wearing nothing but a cautious smile.

The Davis Cup defeat will bring predictable appeals for more coaching and better facilities. That is facile. Britain has proved it can still excel at sport. We have leading competitors in motor racing, snooker and darts, all of which are played in the sporting equivalent of purdah. What our tennis plainly needs is not more courts but bigger shorts.
