webTitle: What the memo tells us about Tony Blair's style of leadership

fields.headline: What the memo tells us about Tony Blair's style of leadership
fields.standfirst:
Patrick Wintour explains the PM's preoccupation with presentation

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: TB's memo: There are a clutch of issues - seemingly disparate - that are in fact linked. We need a strategy that is almost discrete, focussed (sic) on them.
fields.body:
TB's memo: There are a clutch of issues - seemingly disparate - that are in fact linked. We need a strategy that is almost discrete, focussed (sic) on them.

Tony Blair fires off such memos to disparate groups of people at regular interviews. They are often staccato and dictatorial, and never complacent. "He reads more like Thatcher than Major," says one cabinet source. "He is intensely hands on and if he does not like the strategy on the health plan, for instance, he will say so." One cabinet minister said he recently received a memo setting out the prime minister's views on Hague's abandonment of the Tory tax guarantee, written within 48 hours of the Tory U-turn. The memos, sometimes dictated, often concentrate on trying to set new political dividing lines between Labour and the Conservatives.

TB They are roughly combining "on your side" issues with toughness and standing up for Britain.

This is drawn from the vocabulary of focus groups, largely conducted by Philip Gould, the party's obsessive pollster since 1985. Regarded with suspicion on the left and with reverence by party modernisers, Gould has a predilection for lists, pithy phrases and conjuring up new dividing lines. "On your side issues" may sound vacuous, but is intended to convey a government in touch with voters' instincts, needs and values. The phrase was originally developed in Mr Blair's first party conference speech as leader in 1994, when he told the country that Labour was "on your side" on education, crime and tax. Subsequently William Hague has used the same phrase in his speeches.

TB They range from: the family - where, partly due to MCA [married couple allowance] and gay issues, we are perceived as weak; asylum and crime, where we are perceived as soft; and asserting the nation's interests where, because of the unpopularity of Europe, a constant barrage of small stories beginning to add up on defence and even issues like Zimbabwe, we are seen as insufficiently assertive.

The memo was written on the eve of the local goverment elections when Mr Blair had been receiving poll reports showing asylum pushing up the agenda. The married couple allowance had been scrapped in April 2000, saving the government £2bn, but Mr Blair has been uneasy about the political signal the move sent out. The reference to gay issues confirms that he has been lukewarm about reforms such as the abolition of section 28, or the potentially far reaching review of the law on sexual offences. He was also struggling in his relations with Europe, where he did not want to be seen to be wielding the British veto, but also could not afford to be soft. Even a relatively obscure foreign policy issue - Zimbabwe and the treatment of white farmers - was related back to its impact on Labour's stance on defence. Many of the anxieties raised by Mr Blair in his memo, dated April 29, were later reflected back to him from a focus group conducted by Mr Gould on May 16 in the wake of the local elections and subsequently leaked to the Sunday Times. Mr Gould concluded: "The basis of the Conservative recovery is concern over asylum seekers where the Conservatives are occupying the ground the electorate think we have vacated. We are believed to be soft on crime (and to) have lost our sense of mainstream values."

TB All this, of course, is perception. It is bizarre that any government I lead should be seen as anti-family. We are, in fact, taking very tough measures on asylum and crime. Kosovo should have laid to rest any doubts about our strength in defence. But all of these things add up to a sense that the government -and this even applies to me --are somehow out of touch with gut British instincts.

Mr Blair always championed family values, even if some of his ministers, including Gordon Brown and Harriet Harman, were willing to send out warmer tax messages to less conventional families. Mr Blair assumed that his tough stance on Kosovo, the Gulf and Sierra Leone, would ensure his government would always be seen as sound on defence. References to himself reveal a presidential tone, but also some hurt at suggestions he would do anything to undermine the family.

TB The Martin case - and the lack of any response from us that appeared to empathise with public concern and then channel it into the correct course -has only heightened this problem.

In a sign of his acute political antennae, Blair wrote this memo within three days of William Hague suddenly proposing that the balance of the law should be shifted to give greater protection to those defending their home or property. In public, the home secretary, Jack Straw, dismissed the Conservative scheme as a kneejerk reaction. However, by May 17, Mr Gould was privately writing to the prime minister warning that , judging from his focus group findings, "neither the 'opportunism' or the 'extremism' attack worked ... Hague is speaking for the mainstream majority".

TB Each of these issues should be analysed and the correct policy response drawn up. Then each should be dealt with, but with a message which ties it all together. This is precisely the sort of thing AC (Alastair Campbell, Tony Blair's press secretary) and CF (Lord Charles Falconer, Cabinet Office minister) should do if a new system is put in place which frees up their time.

The first definitive confirmation that Mr Blair had been intent for some time on releasing Mr Campbell from the time consuming lobby briefings to allow him space to think more strategically. There had been rumours that Mr Campbell felt his relations with the lobby had collapsed, or that he wanted to resign his post altogether.

TB My thoughts are: (i) Possibly on the Martin case, asking a senior judge to look at changing the sentencing law, ie to allow lesser sentences than life. We also need a far tougher rebuttal or alternatively action, re the allegations that jurors were intimidated.

This does not tally with ministers' remarks. In the Commons on May 9, the Home Office minister, Charles Clarke, praised the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, for initially responding to the Martin case by saying 'I have yet to be persauded the law is at fault because the law says you can use reasonable force'. Mr Blair, by contrast, was considered asking a High Court judge to review the law. Later in the month, John Halliday, former Home Office director general of criminal justice policy, was asked to conduct a general review of sentencing policy, including repeat offending. The police examined but rejected allegations of juror tampering.

TB On asylum, we need to be highlighting removals and decisions plus if the April figures show a reduction, then a downward trend. If the benefits bill really starts to fall, that should be highlighted also. Plus some of the genuine asylum claims being given some publicity.

Mr Blair was in luck. Asylum applications fell to 5,890 in April, a drop of nearly 800 on the previous year. Moreover, decisions processed in April rose to the second highest for 12 months. However, the asylum benefit bill is set to rise to £590m this year. The issue of desperate, if not necessarily genuine, asylum claims received tragic publicity with the death of over 50 migrants hidden in a lorry in Dover.

TB On crime, we need to highlight the tough measures: compulsory tests for drugs before bail; the PIU [performance innovation unit] report on the confiscation of assets; the extra number of burglars jailed under the "three strikes and you're out".

The performance and innovation unit report published a month ago proposing confiscation of assets from criminals was indeed given wide publicity. The 1997 Crime Sentences Act imposed minimum three year sentences for repeat burglars, but only came into force in December 1999, partly for fear it would flood overcrowded prisons.

TB Above all, we must deal now with street crime, especially in London. When the figures are published for the six months to April, they will show a small -4% -rise in crime. But this will almost certainly be due to the rise in levels of street crime. This will be worst in London. webTitle: Scientists warn of 30% rise in human BSE

fields.headline: Scientists warn of 30% rise in human BSE
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: Government scientists yesterday warned of a sharply accelerating trend in the incidence of human BSE after studying the pattern of the disease so far.
fields.body:
Government scientists yesterday warned of a sharply accelerating trend in the incidence of human BSE after studying the pattern of the disease so far.

They said the number of reported cases may in fact be rising at between 20% and 30% a year despite the apparently varied annual death rates over the past five years.

The prediction came as it was revealed that the death toll from the incurable condition officially known as vCJD had risen by a further two in the past fortnight to a total of 69, and 14 so far this year.

The scientists said that there was now a "statistically significant rising trend" in the number of victims since the first casualties first displayed signs of the disease in 1994, although it was still too early to forecast the ultimate number of deaths caused by vCJD.

This year's toll is already equal to that for the whole of last year when the number dropped. A further seven people still alive are thought to be suffering from the condition. The scientists have come to their conclusion about the progress of the disease after analyses of monthly figures, including studying the dates at which friends, relatives or doctors first noted symptoms.

The period between this and eventual death has varied between seven and 38 months, with an average of 14 months, although the incubation period before symptoms become evident is believed to be several years longer.

Stephen Churchill was the first known death from the disease in May 1995, although it was not formally identified or officially linked to the eating of beef in the late 1980s until March 1996. Three people died in 1995, 10 in 1996, 10 in 1997, 18 in 1998 and 14 last year.

Members of the government's spongiform encephalopathy advisory committee took the unusual step of publishing the figure immediately after their meeting in London yesterday because of the recent interest in a cluster of five cases around Queniborough in Leicestershire.

These included three victims dying within a few of months in 1998, a fourth who died in May and another patient, still alive, who is thought to be suffering from the same disease.

The scientists said this was "unlikely to have occurred by chance but this cannot be completely ruled out" and they would be closely informed about local investigations.

The Department of Health last night said it could not elaborate on the significance of the new analysis until ministers and officials had considered the scientists' new advice.

The figures came amid reports that sheep imported by the US from Europe were showing signs of a disease which could be linked to BSE in cattle. Government scientists are to hold talks with their US counterparts after the US agriculture department ordered the destruction of three flocks of sheep which were in quarantine in the state of Vermont.

fields.headline: Timed for maximum damage
fields.standfirst:
The source: Whoever leaked the memo knew how to get the most out of it

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The mole at the heart of the government's spectacular leak timed his or her actions to inflict maximum damage on Tony Blair.
fields.body:
The mole at the heart of the government's spectacular leak timed his or her actions to inflict maximum damage on Tony Blair.

Secret meetings on Saturday were organised with senior journalists on the Sun and the Times to give the two Rupert Murdoch newspapers most of the weekend to prepare the bombshells that rocked Downing Street yesterday.

Trevor Kavanagh, the Sun's political editor, gave up the golf course to drive from his Epsom, Surrey home to London for a meeting.

Andrew Pierce, an assistant editor on the Times, caught a cab to get across the capital for his separate meeting.

The mole, who first made contact around Thursday last week, was "known" to both and told each that the other was also on the delivery list.

Faxed copies of the letter were handed over, though it is unknown whether it was by the mole or a go-between.

Some in the Labour party last night pointed the finger at the Tories, who - while delighted at the chaos - denied any involvement.

No money changed hands, a senior figure at News International, which owns the papers, maintained. One Wapping executive closely involved in publication said: "The motive was clearly to harm Blair. There is a traitor in the camp who in some ways is more treacherous than anyone John Major faced."

One of the priorities of the leak inquiry set up under Sir Richard Wilson, the cabinet secretary, will be to discover if the mole still works in Whitehall.

Mr Kavanagh and Mr Pierce yesterday declined to comment on where the leak came from.

Mr Kavanagh said: "I trusted my source immediately. I received a paper copy of what I was convinced were the actual words of the prime minister and I had no hesitation in writing the story."

Ministers, special advisers, civil servants and contractors are all under suspicion.

Was it a minister with a grudge, personal or political, against the prime minister? Was it a permanent or temporary employee? Political or civil service? An insider copying paper or an outside computer hacker? Or was it from Millbank or an outside office rather than Downing Street or elsewhere in Whitehall?

A list of recipients is believed to have been blanked out by the source, although a covering page left those picking up the scoop in no doubt that it was genuine.

The Sun speculated that those it had been sent to included Mr Blair's press secretary, Alastair Campbell, chief of staff Jonathan Powell and policy unit head David Miliband, while the Times claimed it went to Mr Campbell, party pollster Philip Gould and fixer Lord Falconer, "among others".

Mr Gould has recently seen two of his memos about Mr Blair appear in public and it has not been ruled out - along with many other possibilities - that this might be a third.

Leak inquiries have a poor success record but special branch could be called in if Sir Richard suspects he has discovered the culprit.

The Sun and the Times co-ordinated their check-and-reaction calls to Downing Street for 3.30pm on Sunday, the first Mr Campbell knew of what was about to be made public. He is thought to have immediately recognised the phrases used, alerted Mr Blair and prepared a damage limitation plan.

webTitle: Glints of jealousy are kindled in the cradle

fields.headline: Glints of jealousy are kindled in the cradle
fields.trailText: Babies are not as full of unconditional love and innocence as we might think, according to research revealed yesterday. In fact, they get as jealous as the rest of us when their loved ones display affection to others.
fields.body:
Babies are not as full of unconditional love and innocence as we might think, according to research revealed yesterday. In fact, they get as jealous as the rest of us when their loved ones display affection to others.

Ricardo Draghi-Lorenz, of the University of Surrey, who has studied the emotional development of infants in their first 12 months, told the international conference of infant studies in Brighton that babies as young as four months old were extremely aware of their environment and the relationships of people around them.

He said that many parents reported observing the first discernible acts of jealousy in their children at about seven to eight months old, and some after just four months.

"Video recordings of babies showed that soon after they can control their bodies they may, for example, squeeze in between the mother and another person, pushing away and sometimes even hitting the latter," he said.

Dr Draghi-Lorenz asked mothers of five-month-olds to show affection towards another baby in front of their own child.

"This was usually watched intently," he said. "Within five minutes more than half of their babies were so upset that they cried.

"This did not happen when the mother simply spent five minutes chatting to another adult."

He added that the results suggested young babies could be as jealous of their peers as many adults.

 Another presentation at the conference revealed why crying babies were soothed by music and tired infants drifted into sleep when they heard a lullaby.

Laurel Trainor, of McMaster University in Canada, studied how long different tunes held the attention of babies. The songs would play when the infants looked at an illuminated toy and stopped when they looked away.

She said: "Infants prefer higher-pitched over lower-pitched singing and loving over less loving tones.

"They prefer lullabies over play songs such as Five Little Piggies Go to Market."

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Radio
fields.body:
David Beresford used to produce thousands of words to meet The Guardian's ever-pressing news deadlines. Now, as he tells Peter White in No Triumph, No Tragedy (9.0am, Radio 4), Parkinson's disease has slowed him down to 800 words over three days. He became aware of a problem during the Gulf War, when his handwriting suddenly became oddly cramped. He now faces the dilemma that the drug which stops him shaking and allows him to write has serious side effects on his mental capacity.

Colleagues who shared a remarkable 50-year acting career are marshalled by Douglas Adams for Peter Jones: A Celebration (11.30am, Radio 4). Adams, of course, owed Jones an enormous debt for his deadpan rendering of The Book in The Hitchhiker's Guide To The Galaxy. Miriam Carlin and Nicholas Parsons will also be on hand to recall virtuoso performances in sitcoms like The Rag Trade and in the panel game Just A Minute.

fields.headline: Heart of darkness
fields.trailText: Boss Women | 100 Per Cent White | Natural World
fields.body:
They call Anna Wintour "Nuclear Wintour", and judging from the profile of her in Boss Women (BBC1), she could easily slaughter everything within a thousand-yard radius. Tight-lipped, stick thin, bereft of anything resembling charm and more ferociously driven than Josef Stalin, Wintour controls her empire at American Vogue through a combination of fear and ruthless efficiency.

Still, you have to give her credit for a single-minded commitment that could bore through armour plate. Wintour has decided that Vogue, and the awesome influence it gives her, is her life. Although she has two children aged 12 and 14, it was difficult to work out when she sees them, since she gets up at 5.45am to play tennis and get her hair and make-up done in time to reach her office by 8am. After a hard day of ringing the opening bell on Wall Street, putting Hillary Clinton on the cover and shaping fashion's next wave, she's in bed by 10.30. Alone, as far as anyone knows.

And here was the problem. Nobody knows anything about Wintour's private life and inner thought-processes, and by the end of the film they still didn't. Her feature writer, the delightfully dizzy Plum Sykes, described with gurgling adulation her boss's mastery of the media, giving interviews but controlling the process so thoroughly that she gives nothing away. This was illustrated at some length.

It was Wintour's elusiveness that left the strongest impression. We saw her hosting a Vogue party surrounded by Liz Hurley, Iman and Lauren Hutton, but as Puff Daddy arrived, Wintour left, since she never stays at parties for longer than 20 minutes. She keeps editorial meetings to a crisp 15 minutes, commenting that "even if I don't know what the hell I'm doing, I try to be decisive". She makes Margaret Thatcher seem timid and wishy-washy.

In 100 Per Cent White (Channel 4), Leo Regan revisited three of the neo-Nazis he wrote a book about 10 years ago, and made you wonder how he could bear to spend so much time with these depressing, screwed-up losers. At least Nick and Neil had made some kind of progress. Their desire to engage in arson, bombing and racist thuggery had decreased, and Nick had even become close friends with Jamie, a black man. In fact, Nick has mellowed so much that he believes he's "the same kind of racist as your average Englishman in the street".

Neil has become addicted to going to raves, because he thinks the communal vibes help him avoid violence, but he's still prone to aggressive outbursts, and is now attending anger management courses. As for Colin, Regan confessed he couldn't understand him at all, though his wife Carla seems to have figured him out perfectly. She reckons everything he does is a form of role-playing, and until he can approach relationships honestly he can never change. She still loves him, even though he throws her through windows and down the stairs.

But what do we make of Leo Regan? There was a mounting sense of queasy futility in his obsessive desire to keep quizzing these people about their feelings and motivations, since he could have made his points and drawn his conclusions in a film half the length. The phrase "no platform for fascists" seemed increasingly apt - the more Regan invited them to talk about themselves, the more the programme wallowed in rambling self-pity.

BBC2's Natural World films can be beautiful yet pointless, but Top Cat worked brilliantly because it had a strong narrative to shape its location footage. A family of caracal lynxes were shipped from a sanctuary in Britain to a new, wild life on the Hoedspruit airbase in South Africa, the plan being that they would control the bird population which flies into air-intakes or aircraft windscreens.

Could the caracals learn to fend for themselves? The first promising sign was when they began making calling noises to each other, which they'd never done in captivity. Then Bold, the most enterprising of the kittens, chalked up the first kill by bagging a guinea fowl. fields.bodyText: They call Anna Wintour "Nuclear Wintour", and judging from the profile of her in Boss Women (BBC1), she could easily slaughter everything within a thousand-yard radius. Tight-lipped, stick thin, bereft of anything resembling charm and more ferociously driven than Josef Stalin, Wintour controls her empire at American Vogue through a combination of fear and ruthless efficiency. Still, you have to give her credit for a single-minded commitment that could bore through armour plate. Wintour has decided that Vogue, and the awesome influence it gives her, is her life. Although she has two children aged 12 and 14, it was difficult to work out when she sees them, since she gets up at 5.45am to play tennis and get her hair and make-up done in time to reach her office by 8am. After a hard day of ringing the opening bell on Wall Street, putting Hillary Clinton on the cover and shaping fashion's next wave, she's in bed by 10.30. Alone, as far as anyone knows. And here was the problem. Nobody knows anything about Wintour's private life and inner thought-processes, and by the end of the film they still didn't. Her feature writer, the delightfully dizzy Plum Sykes, described with gurgling adulation her boss's mastery of the media, giving interviews but controlling the process so thoroughly that she gives nothing away. This was illustrated at some length. It was Wintour's elusiveness that left the strongest impression. We saw her hosting a Vogue party surrounded by Liz Hurley, Iman and Lauren Hutton, but as Puff Daddy arrived, Wintour left, since she never stays at parties for longer than 20 minutes. She keeps editorial meetings to a crisp 15 minutes, commenting that "even if I don't know what the hell I'm doing, I try to be decisive". She makes Margaret Thatcher seem timid and wishy-washy. In 100 Per Cent White (Channel 4), Leo Regan revisited three of the neo-Nazis he wrote a book about 10 years ago, and made you wonder how he could bear to spend so much time with these depressing, screwed-up losers. At least Nick and Neil had made some kind of progress. Their desire to engage in arson, bombing and racist thuggery had decreased, and Nick had even become close friends with Jamie, a black man. In fact, Nick has mellowed so much that he believes he's "the same kind of racist as your average Englishman in the street". Neil has become addicted to going to raves, because he thinks the communal vibes help him avoid violence, but he's still prone to aggressive outbursts, and is now attending anger management courses. As for Colin, Regan confessed he couldn't understand him at all, though his wife Carla seems to have figured him out perfectly. She reckons everything he does is a form of role-playing, and until he can approach relationships honestly he can never change. She still loves him, even though he throws her through windows and down the stairs. But what do we make of Leo Regan? There was a mounting sense of queasy futility in his obsessive desire to keep quizzing these people about their feelings and motivations, since he could have made his points and drawn his conclusions in a film half the length. The phrase "no platform for fascists" seemed increasingly apt - the more Regan invited them to talk about themselves, the more the programme wallowed in rambling self-pity. BBC2's Natural World films can be beautiful yet pointless, but Top Cat worked brilliantly because it had a strong narrative to shape its location footage. A family of caracal lynxes were shipped from a sanctuary in Britain to a new, wild life on the Hoedspruit airbase in South Africa, the plan being that they would control the bird population which flies into air-intakes or aircraft windscreens. Could the caracals learn to fend for themselves? The first promising sign was when they began making calling noises to each other, which they'd never done in captivity. Then Bold, the most enterprising of the kittens, chalked up the first kill by bagging a guinea fowl. When Dougal, father of the clan, finally stirred himself to pounce on a fowl of his own, here was proof that old cats can learn new tricks.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Satellite, cable and digital
fields.body:
El Cid
(Anthony Mann, 1961) 2pm, Carlton Cinema
Charlton Heston at his noblest as Rodrigo Diaz de Bivar, aka El Cid, 11th-century scourge of the Moors in Spain. At three hours long, progress is stately but it's intelligent, ablaze with colour and conflict, and heads towards a truly heroic climax. Sophia Loren plays the Cid's proud wife, Chimene, and Herbert Lom is the fundamentalist, Ben Yussef.

Resurrection
(David Petrie, 1980) 9pm, Carlton Cinema
After almost dying in the car crash which kills her husband, a southern-States woman finds herself endowed with mystical healing powers. She refuses to believe that they are divine in origin; others aren't so sure. And neitherare we. Ellen Burstyn does a fine job of seeming both beatific and secular, but Sam Shepard must have scratched his head reading through the part of her patient/lover/attempted murderer. So that's the secret behind making a movie about someone with healing hands: fail to reveal what on earth you're getting at.

Pulp Fiction
(Quentin Tarantino, 1994) 10pm, FilmFour
Tarantino's follow-up to his stunning debut, Reservoir Dogs, is just as savagely amoral, but funnier. It takes three staples of the thriller genre - the gangster and the boss's wife; the pug's One Last Chance; the lovers' doomed heist - and interweaves them with giddy pace and complexity: Uma Thurman's icy femme, Mia; Harvey Keitel's Mr Wolf; Tim Roth's Pumpkin; and John Travolta, rescued from acting with babies, a revelation as gunman Vincent Vega, talking burgers and toe-jobs on the way to the hit with cool partner Samuel L Jackson.

Buffalo 66
(Vincent Gallo, 1997) 1.30am, Sky Premier
Gallo's Billy, straight from jail, goes home to Buffalo, NY, and kidnaps Christina Ricci's Layla so she can pretend to be his wife in a meeting with his parents (Ben Gazzara, Anjelica Huston). And so one of the most touching of screen romances is born. Gallo's directorial debut is fresh, funny and utterly individual: don't miss it.

webTitle: Getting personal with Tom de Ville

fields.headline: Getting personal with Tom de Ville
fields.trailText: Full Name: Tom Nicholson de Ville.
fields.body:
Full Name: Tom Nicholson de Ville.

Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why? Yes. Occasionally when I get bored of the Cruella jokes, I change it to The Wicked Witch of the West.

Have you ever lied about your age and, if so, why? Continually. I'm actually five. Growth hormones are a frightening thing.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad? Mid-20s, tall, dark, bendy male, GSOH, OA, BA, S+M. Likes reading, walks in the country. May bite small animals.

What was the last illegal thing you did? I sold alcohol to Tony Blair's son.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did? I refer you to my previous answer.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with? John Price for the occasional lessons in how to chin someone, and Steve Matthews for his general raffish behaviour.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've ever worked with? BBFC.

Has a critic ever made you cry? Yes, I always feel sorry for critics.

What would you advertise without a fee? The goodness of all of nature's herbs.

What would you never advertise? Monkey torture units. I have been approached.

What wakes you up screaming at four in the morning? Wet dreams about Jamie Oliver's Cockney ways.

What takes you to a "happy place"? Jackie Chan movies. "Tube bunnies" - the little mice that run around on the Underground. The sea.

 Tom de Ville wrote Urban Gothic, currently on Channel 5.

webTitle: New deal for jobless gets cash to carry on

fields.headline: New deal for jobless gets cash to carry on
fields.standfirst: More about welfare reform
fields.trailText: The new deal for the unemployed, so far funded largely from a windfall tax on the profits of utility companies, is to become a permanent deal funded from general taxation.
fields.body:
The new deal for the unemployed, so far funded largely from a windfall tax on the profits of utility companies, is to become a permanent deal funded from general taxation.

The announcement, to be made today, is a centrepiece of the comprehensive spending review and follows negotiations between the chancellor, Gordon Brown, the education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, and the employment minister, Tessa Jowell.

Mr Brown raised £5.2bn over two years from the utility companies, but by the end of the next financial year he will have spent all but £900m of it. Without new channels of funding he will run out of funds for the unemployed from 2002-03.

The programme is to be expanded and reshaped to meet what ministers describe as new labour market challenges.

One minister involved in the spending review said: "The new challenge is the degree and severity of the problem facing the long term unemployed as we gradually reduce [those] easy to place. We are now getting down to very hard people to tackle, either because of structural problems in the community or their personal health or drug abuse.

"We also face a second challenge of trying to reach out to those who are part of the unemployed in the labour force survey figures but who do not figure in the claimant count."

Ministers say this group extends beyond lone parents to individuals who have seen no point in seeking work. In Easington, Co Durham, for instance, the claimant count stands at 9.2%, but the proportion of the population of working age in work is only 58.2%. Much of this discrepancy can be attributed to older people not seeking work due to ill health or disabilty.

The government believes there are vacancies - as many as 1m - but the jobless lack the motivation, the job readiness, the travel subsidies or the right work transition benefit package to find permanent work. Some have simply disconnected from the world of work after being put on incapacity benefit in the late eighties.

The new action team for jobs, led by the employment service and directed at the poorest communities, is starting to target some of these hardcore unemployed and is likely to receive extra funding in the coming spending round.

Labour hopes to challenge the Tories hard on jobless schemes, claiming that William Hague's planned US-style initiative, Britain Works, is predicated on asking private sector companies to force the jobless into work - removing the child care and the personal adviser service and simply giving the companies subsidies.

The bulk of the windfall levy has been set aside for the new deal for young people (£1.48bn) - those aged 18-24 - and a new deal for school capital projects (£1.5bn).

Mr Brown has also set up new deals for those over 25 and unemployed more than 18 months, for lone parents, for the over-50s, for lone parents, for the disabled, and for partners of unemployed people.

Not all these projects have been exclusively funded from the windfall levy. Ministers have been emphasising the One project, which requires claimants to the job seeker's allowance and lone parents with children over five to attend interviews with a personal adviser.

Since spring 1997 more than 1m extra people have been put into employment. Mr Brown claims that the economy is on the verge of once again creating a full employment society. But he recognises that joblessness is less a north-south divide problem than one of stark disparities within regions.

webTitle: Note to inner circle typical of PM

fields.headline: Note to inner circle typical of PM
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: There is a distinctly Blairite air of informality to the leaked memo. The prime minister was at Chequers, read his Saturday newspaper clippings - including the day's editorial in the Daily Mail - and dashed off a memo to his inner circle.
fields.body:
There is a distinctly Blairite air of informality to the leaked memo. The prime minister was at Chequers, read his Saturday newspaper clippings - including the day's editorial in the Daily Mail - and dashed off a memo to his inner circle.

BBC2 viewers who watched Michael Cockerell's Downing Street documentary last Saturday will recognise how it works: first name terms, rapid reaction to breaking news, awareness of the need to get the government's "message" across.

Mr Blair is famously sensitive to the Daily Mail as a voice of middle England. On April 29, under the headline The shadow of a new intolerance, the paper accused him of trying to dismiss his critics as "antediluvian reactionaries" and homophobic bigots.

Contrary to some speculation yesterday, Mr Blair did not knock out an email, complete with colloquialisms and a spelling error ("focussed" with a double s). He hand-wrote a memo which was typed and almost certainly faxed to his intimates.

The loyalty of its recipients is beyond question: almost certainly chief of staff, Jonathan Powell; press secretary, Alastair Campbell; David Milliband, head of the policy unit; and Cabinet Office ministers Mo Mowlam and Lord Falconer QC.

Downing Street yesterday stressed that Mr Blair sends many such memos, and only this weekend scribbled notes on the transport plan, on today's comprehensive spending review, and on the NHS reforms.

For Labour's critics the memo appears to show Mr Blair as a media-obsessed lightweight - exactly as William Hague is keen to show him. That is one aspect of the truth. New Labour is image-conscious and right to be so. In some ways the memo shows Mr Blair to be on the ball, keen to show he is in charge and in touch - not indifferent to "gut British instincts".

We have seen him acting upon that notion in the intervening weeks - with mixed results.

fields.headline: Putting the boot in
fields.standfirst: Why have a group of famous men chosen to go on television and boast about violent assaults they've committed in the past? Because they're footballers.  Roy Hattersley, for one, is appalled
fields.trailText: Why have a group of famous men chosen to go on television and boast about violent assaults they've committed in the past? Because they're footballers. Roy Hattersley, for one, is appalled
fields.body:
About half-way through tonight's episode of Bad Boys - the first of four Football Stories to be broadcast on Channel 4 - I decided to find out the present whereabouts of Norman Hunter and advise him to sue the programme makers. Mr Hunter - made famous in glory days with Leeds United by the slogan "Norman bites yer legs" - was being represented as a soccer thug, a player from what the advance publicity called the dark side of football.

Yet I remembered him in the words of the Corinthian cliché as "hard but fair". Just as I reached my indignation climax Hunter himself appeared on screen and I abandoned all thought of litigation. He described his tackling technique as "fair means or foul". Asked how he would adjust his game to the modern referees' more stringent application of the rules, he replied "If I could get away with it I would".

More disillusion followed. The strong emphasis was on foul. I had never regarded Chelsea's Ron "Chopper" Harris as one of football's artists, although I was mildly surprised to hear Peter Osgood, his own teammate, describe him as "an animal". But the programme went on to prove his point. During the 1982 Cup Final replay against Leeds, Eddie Gray was running rings round the Chelsea defence. Then Harris "caught him" with a "tackle". Or, to be more exact, kicked him behind the knee. Harris, asked to justify his behaviour, boasted "he limped through the rest of the game". Jack Charlton (the Leeds centre half) claimed that "he never intended to get the ball". When Harris was asked about the incident he replied with obvious satisfaction, "ninety per cent won the cup with that tackle on Eddie Gray".

Viewers will wonder why apparently respectable men want to appear on television to boast about their history of criminal assault - offences which these days might well lead to prosecution. It would be comforting to think that it was no more than pub talk. But they were all hideously sincere. In the full hour programme, during which a whole "bad boys" team was selected, only Harold Schumacher (the German goalkeeper who cynically flattened a French forward during the 1982 World Cup semi-final) protested his innocence. The rest seemed enthusiastic to bring the game into disrepute.

However, why 10 once distinguished footballers should want to plead guilty to grievous bodily harm is not the most important question to be asked about Bad Boys. The real mystery is why at a time when the nation is rightly concerned by football violence off the field Channel 4 should want to make a film which, in the warped minds of some viewers, will be seen as a celebration of football brutality. Of course there were pious voices interspersed with the boasts of the men who kicked, tripped and punched.

Brian Moore, true to his reputation, was critical. Jack Charlton expressed genuine disapproval of Graham Souness, "a bit of a bad lad at times". But the general impression was very different. The spirit of the programme was epitomised by Stuart Hall - comparing Roy Keane to a Roman centurion (he probably meant a gladiator) and describing a Ron Harris tackle like being engulfed in a haystack. The inadequacy of his images was less important than the tone of his contribution. He found the violence amusing.

The programme began on a note of positive approval. Roy Keane of Manchester United was exalted as both "the best in the game today" and the only contemporary player to win a place in the "all-time bad boys' XI". And it ended with a positive encomium: "There will always be a place for hard men in the game". Danny Kelly ("journalist and broadcaster") actually explained that supporters find it easier to identify with a player who brutalises opponents than with one who dazzles with his skill. Stuart Hall, in one of the passages of purple prose which are his trademark, spoke of the man on the production line being liberated by the sight of a hard tackle.

There was much implied criticism of newspapers which report bad behaviour on and off the field. But the programme is far more prurient than most of the exposés about which it complained. It makes viewers voyeurs of violence. And must, in consequence, take responsibility for the baser emotions which it arouses. It was also lowest common denominator television - reminiscent of the dead but not mourned Sunday Empire News. This is the sort of behaviour we deplore, that paper would say - before describing some sexual misdemeanour. And it always did its best to make the sex sound exciting. The next time a youth club player's leg is broken in a match played in the local park, remember Bad Boys.

 Football Stories: Bad Boys, tonight, 10pm, C4

webTitle: MPs worry about leak rather than message

fields.headline: MPs worry about leak rather than message
fields.standfirst:
Special report: New Labour in power

The fallout: Tories jeer, but others say note shows firm and reasoned PM
fields.trailText: William Hague yesterday proclaimed that Tony Blair's leaked Chequers memo showed the prime minister to be spin-obsessed and shallow.
fields.body:
William Hague yesterday proclaimed that Tony Blair's leaked Chequers memo showed the prime minister to be spin-obsessed and shallow.

"Now we know where all the spin and the gimmicks come from in this government. It comes from the very top. It comes from the prime minister himself. It shows that the government gets very rattled that we are now setting the agenda, " Mr Hague said.

Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, took a similar view of Mr Blair's apparent preoccupation with "spin, not substance".

The Daily Mail claimed to be running Mr Blair's agenda. This was dismissed as fantasy by the Scottish secretary, John Reid, in radio and TV interviews. He rejected, too, claims that Labour's fundamental problem is an obsession with short-termism instead of long-term vision.

Some MPs were dismayed the memo did not seem to address heartland issues - manufacturing jobs at risk from the high pound, for instance, or the rising price of petrol.

Others conceded that crime and limiting asylum-seekers - mentioned in Mr Blair's memo to advisers as issues where the government was seen as soft - were also heartland issues.

Loyal ministers said that the chancellor's statement on government spending plans this afternoon would show that Labour had a powerful long-term strategy. Discrediting the government on the eve of the spending statement is the ob jective of opponents, evidently including the memo's leakers.

Tony Wright, the liberal academic turned Labour MP for Cannock, last night asked: "Would I have written that memo after watching Hague press all those populist buttons and seeing the tabloids join in ? Yes, I think I would."

Other loyalist MPs who did not want to be named argued that Mr Blair was being "a bit harsh" on himself and his government in the note he wrote back in April. "I don't think things were quite as bad as he suggested."

But there was criticism in Labour ranks. Leftwing MP Diane Abbott said: "The thing that the prime minister appears to forget is that it is possible actually to try to lead public opinion on some issues rather than just to follow it."

The home secretary, Jack Straw, denied suggestions that Mr Blair was panicking: "Certainly not, the prime minister is the least complacent politician I have ever met."

Martin O'Neill, chairman of the trade and industry select committee, regretted the leak, but said: "It shows he is sensible in discussing the issues."

Later, the former Welsh first secretary, Alun Michael, suggested Mr Blair had an internal problem: "There is malevolence right at the heart of government, otherwise this memo would not have been leaked."

That is a minority view. But he argued the memo was not damaging to Mr Blair because it showed "a prime minister who is in charge, who is issuing a wake-up call to ministers, who is making it very clear that there are two things that matter," Mr Michael told BBC Radio 4's PM programme.

fields.headline: Pilgrims' progress
fields.standfirst: Choral music - in the form of two Bach cantatas and a little-known Mendelssohn work - dominated the opening Proms
fields.trailText: Choral music - in the form of two Bach cantatas and a little-known Mendelssohn work - dominated the opening Proms
fields.body:
John Eliot Gardiner began this concert with a tribute to Sir William Glock, the ex-BBC controller of music who died last month aged 92. It was a fitting speech, as this concert couldn't have taken place without Glock, credited with introducing early music to the Proms. Once, it would have been unthinkable to put on a period-instrument concert in the Albert Hall of works by just one composer - but times change.

One of the ensembles that have brought about that change is the English Baroque Soloists, a group that, at its best, can make the listener wonder why anyone ever thought of modernising orchestral instruments. For them, and for the Monteverdi Choir, this was another step of Gardiner's massive Bach Cantata Pilgrimage project, which will see all 198 of Bach's sacred cantatas performed worldwide.

Cantatas number 24 and 185 were being crossed off the list on this occasion, framed by two instrumental works - the Fourth Suite and the First Brandenburg Concerto - and dwarfed by the D Major Magnificat with which the concert closed. The precise, disciplined choir sang for the most part with clarity, but tenor Paul Agnew tended to overdo the phrasing in his arias, meaning that some of his notes disappeared into the vast enclosure of thin air above the platform. He was nonetheless a communicative soloist, as was Magdalena Kozena, his duet partner in Cantata 185, whose bright mezzo-soprano rang easily out over the orchestra.

Yet despite the presence of three other promising young soloists - soprano Miah Persson, contralto Nathalie Stutzmann and full-bodied bass Nicolas Testé - it was the orchestra's night. The obbligato soloists in the arias of the Magnificat assumed as much importance as their vocal counterparts. Xenia Loffler's oboe d'amore solo in the Quia respexit was beautifully warm, inspiring Persson to relish each word she sang.

Each movement brought another finely coloured accompaniment - the flute duet in Esurientes, the feather bed of muted strings in Et misericordia. The entire violin section stood as Agnew sang Deposuit potentes, playing with soloistic flourish and a fierce attack on every note. Cutting through the texture were the three excellent brass players, who made trills on the natural trumpet seem easy (they're not). For a thrilling sound, only the heroic crescendo from the basses in the choir in the closing bars of the Magnificat came even close.

 Erica Jeal

It's extraordinary that Mendelssohn's oratorio St Paul has had to wait until the cusp of the third millennium for its first Proms performance. St Paul is precisely the kind of rousing-but-reverent choral spectacular that has historically been at the core of Proms programming. Yet the piece is almost completely neglected in this country in favour of Mendelssohn's other oratorio, Elijah. The performance by the BBC National Orchestra of Wales under Richard Hickox, who is shortly to become their principal conductor, was an evangelical attempt to kick-start the popularity of St Paul - even if a thinly attended Royal Albert Hall pointed to an uphill struggle.

Hickox eschewed any notions of historical correctness. This was a grand account, situated firmly in the tradition of massed choirs and the British lineage of choral conducting at the Proms. At the heart of the performance was a superabundant chorus, an exotic combination of the BBC National Chorus of Wales, the London Symphony Chorus and the Houston Symphony Chorus. They achieved a remarkable clarity and focus - as well as brute power - in the unrelenting counterpoint of Mendelssohn's choral writing.

The problems with St Paul are to do with its narrative. Part I tells the dramatic story of Saul's conversion. Mendelssohn depicts the moment of divine intervention with extrovert orchestral colour, in an enormous crescendo before a blazing choral entry. But in the second half, St Paul's preaching and martyrdom present fewer opportunities for vivid illustration. Instead, Mendelssohn's music is more like a series of attractive, but static, tableaux.

However, Hickox's conducting never let the music subside into laborious penance. In fact, combined with the eloquent St Paul of Peter Coleman-Wright, the enthusiasm of tenor Robert Tear - a luxurious last-minute replacement for John Mark Ainsley - and the expressive range of soprano Susan Gritton, this St Paul was a fervent, inspiring pilgrimage.

 Tom Service

fields.headline: Drum machine
fields.standfirst: She was the first solo percussionist ever to play at the Proms. Now Evelyn Glennie's back with another groundbreaker.  Charlotte Higgins  meets a musical tour de force
fields.trailText: She was the first solo percussionist ever to play at the Proms. Now Evelyn Glennie's back with another groundbreaker. Charlotte Higgins meets a musical tour de force
fields.body:
It must be exhausting being Evelyn Glennie. More, much more than just a musician, she is the percussionist who has welcomed the readers of Hello! magazine into her home; she endorses Rolex watches; she even has her own tartan, named the Rhythms of Evelyn Glennie. Click on to her first-name terms website - www.evelyn.co.uk - and you can buy Evelyn-designed percussion practice pads and Evelyn T-shirts, not to mention Evelyn CDs. She is the first percussionist to forge a career as a soloist, and - as well as the scores she and her husband write for TV - she is also working on a book about percussion instrument maintenance, and developing a series of children's storybooks.

Glennie lives in a village in Cambridgeshire with a duck pond and lots of executive homes. Next to her house is parked a lorry emblazoned with her personal logo. Inside the house there is bustle a-plenty: the Glennie operation employs two office staff, a web designer and a technician to deal with the practicalities of looking after and transporting her percussion instruments - of which she owns about 2,000.

Tomorrow, on her 35th birthday, Glennie will perform the world premiere of Mark-Anthony Turnage's Fractured Lines at the Proms with the BBC Symphony Orchestra. The piece is a double percussion con certo, and she will share the limelight with US jazz drummer Peter Erskine. "It is quite discordant and agitated and, as the title suggests, fractured," she said on Thursday. "It is hard to see a line through the piece. I'm unsure how the piece will be. A lot will be revealed when we start rehearsals. My part is a sort of skeleton that will need colouring in. Mark is used to players making suggestions - he is a very open composer."

To many, Glennie is still the "deaf percussionist". But she doesn't make a big deal of it. It is pointedly not mentioned on any of her publicity material. She lip-reads with ease; "the hearing aspect", as she calls it, seems irrelevant as you talk with her.

Not that Glennie didn't have to be iron-willed to get where she is. She was born on a farm near Aberdeen. Her father owned an accordion he played once a year; there was a piano in the house her mother played. It was not until she was eight that Glennie learned the piano formally, though she had already started picking out tunes by ear. Then her hearing started to go. By the age of 12, she was 95% deaf.

The same year, she badgered the head of music at Ellon Academy, the comprehensive school she attended, to let her learn percussion as well as piano. As she played more and more, she eventually discarded her hearing aids, having found she could pick up the music's vibrations through her feet and lower body. Far from being a child prodigy propelled by pushy parents, she was unusually self-motivated. "I didn't have to practise," she explains. "There was no pressure on me. There wasn't even any competition, even though my friends and I were going in for the same piano exams."

This freedom engendered an extraordinary fearlessness: "I used to treat piano exams as literally a chance to play. They were almost performances as opposed to tests. I had conversations with the examiners. One time, I said to the examiner, 'I haven't decided how I want to play this yet, but this is how I am going to play it today.' So he asked how else I was thinking of doing it, and then I demonstrated; suddenly we were talking about music."

When she was 16, Glennie left school and, after a few episodes of high drama surrounding her deafness, was finally accepted into the Royal Academy of Music to study percussion and piano. Her years there were not untroubled. She was determinedly hatching her scheme of becoming a solo percussionist - pretty much unheard of at the time - but receiving little encouragement. "It boggles me," she says now, "that you can give a solo percussion recital, the first percussion recital in the history of the Royal Academy of Music, and your teacher is not there. I had to get over a lot of things psychologically while I was at the Academy. But it was a great learning experience. I knew if I ever wanted to be a teacher, I would have to really concentrate on that - because you have people's lives in front of you. That's why I don't teach."

She was not desperately popular among her fellow students, either. There were even sour-grapes rumours that her deafness was exaggerated. Her stringent practice regime (she often practised in corridors because of the Academy's then insufficient facilities) allowed little time for friendships. She found playing in the Academy's orchestras boring, and would irritate others by learning the whole score of whatever they were playing. "If something is essential," she says now, "I'll do it. Other people have to sort their own thoughts out." She spent a lot of time in the library, squirrelling out solo percussion works. She was also by now making TV appearances - with Harry Secombe on Highway - and was the subject of a BBC documentary, The Will to Win.

She left the Academy at 19 ("I'm not good within institutions. I work very well with myself"). By the end of the 80s, still barely in her 20s, the goal she had so obsessively striven towards was achieved. She had established herself as the first ever full-time solo percussionist. In 1988 she won a Grammy; in 1989 she gave a solo recital at the Proms.

Since then, the furious rate of her achievements has slowed - or at least her ambitions have changed emphasis. One of Glennie's lasting legacies will be that she has created a solo percussion repertoire, by dint of commissioning about 90 works: "I will continue doing that for as long as I function as a player. I have got over the stage of proving myself as a musician. Now I am simply being a musician. We need to bring music to percussion, rather than percussion to music. I'm not trying to push percussion any more. People know what a marimba is now." (If news hasn't reached you, the marimba looks like an oversize xylophone and has a particularly sonorous tone.)

Glennie's forthcoming projects include pieces for her by Harrison Birtwistle and Steve Reich; past collaborations have involved works by James MacMillan and Jonathan Harvey. "My biggest regret," she says, "is just missing out on Leonard Bernstein. He died just as we were in communication. He was the one composer I wanted to work with."

Not surprisingly, Glennie is acutely aware of her own place in musical history. Percussion today is very different from where it was 23 years ago when she first picked up a pair of sticks: "My biggest aim is for a research centre, that will include a performing-arts school for percussion, like the Menuhin School, a museum and a library. There's nowhere like that in the world. I'd like it to be completely adaptable to the general public, players, students. I need a home for all this_" She gestures at dozens of instruments. "I'm not going to go on forever. I want to have a home for everything that has been dealt with or achieved or whatever."

You sense that this aim will be fulfilled with the same fearless efficiency as her youthful ambitions to become a solo percussionist. As a musician, according to Glennie: "You are basically a businessperson and your product is music." Or, in her case, her product is also Evelyn Glennie.

 Evelyn Glennie performs Mark-Anthony Turnage's Fractured Lines at the Proms, Albert Hall, London SW7, tomorrow. Box office: 020-7581 9311.

webTitle: May the force be with you

fields.headline: May the force be with you
fields.standfirst: The new exhibition at the Hayward Gallery is all about art that moves.  Adrian Searle finds that he has windmills in his mind
fields.trailText: The new exhibition at the Hayward Gallery is all about art that moves. Adrian Searle finds that he has windmills in his mind
fields.body:
Force Fields: Phases of the Kinetic is a strange exhibition. Now at the Hayward Gallery, London, having travelled from the Museum of Contemporary Art (Macba) in Barcelona, Force Fields comes on the heels of Sonic Boom, one of the Hayward's dreariest ever exhibitions. The two shows have something in common, in their attention to works which twang, boing, whoop and dazzle with pretty coloured lights. But Sonic Boom was merely modish, where Force Fields attempts to trace a path through history.

Curated by Guy Brett, whose interest in things kinetic is matched only by his championing of art from Latin and South America, the exhibition is fascinating, disparate, and, at times oddly affecting. It also presents us with kinetic art as an expanded field, an open terrain, rather than anything we can call a consolidated movement.

Brett's show seems to me to be brave. In part, this is due to the inclusion of artists one would not necessarily associate with the "kinetic", whatever that is. One expects Takis , Marcel Duchamp, Laszlo Moholy-Nagy, whose mechanical sculptures and objects are canonical objects of kinetic art. But not necessarily the great Lygia Clark, although her sculptures and objects require interaction and manipulation, or Maria Schendel's ropes and worm-casts of rolled and knotted rice-paper, or Agnes Denes's peculiar ink drawing of tiny human figures, in a snail-like vortex. I'd never have thought, either, that the work of Robert Smithson or Gordon Matta-Clark had much in common with Pol Bury's furtive, twitching nests of nylon fishing line, or Jean Tinguely's absurd clattering machines, but of course there is a link, even if it is more to do with the artist's sense of the mutability of the world than anything else.

The artist Wols was, towards the end of his life, almost entirely immobilised. Confined to his bed in Paris in the early 50s, he drew mad, obsessive little drawings, spidery networks of lines, horrifying exploding testicle shapes, intricate wounds - all visions of his own decay. Henri Michaux (whose resuscitation is also in part due to a renewed interest in the informalist and tachist artists of the 40s and 50s) is included with a number of his seismic, automatist, mescaline drawings. With their seizures and repetitions, their fields of psychic tremors, one wonders what was due to his quaking hand, what to his juddering brain.

Wols, Michaux and Georges Vantongerloo - who made crazily cosmological drawings, as well as odd, jewellery-like sculptures and paintings (looking back to theosophist drawings of psychic auras at the beginning of the 20th century) - are artists for whom movement is a matter of the firing of the brain's synapses, of involuntary palpitations and convulsions. Their visions may have more to do with Einsteinian relativism rather than Newton's mechanical laws of the universe. Equally, they were driven by some apprehension of the inherent instability of the world, of their own imminent collapse, and temporary confusions between inner and external experience. We may all have such moments of madness, but they were able to keep a grip on that part of themselves which could record their subjective crises. What we might call their kinaesthesia is as much the subject of the show as is the mechanical.

Although the exhibition begins, historically, with the optical experiments of Duchamp and Man Ray of the 20s, and the shimmering, rota-ting mechanical apparatus of Moholy-Nagy, it may as well have begun with cubism's essentially kinetic idea of the world fragmenting into multiple simultaneous viewpoints. Cubism, futurism and vorticism represent art's early attempts to come to terms with the 20th century - that is, with the advances of Freudianism and theoretical physics as much as the machine age itself. We are still trying to do much the same thing, and while Brett alludes to very recent art, the exhibition does not take on board the electronic revolution of the past 20 years. That, though, is probably for another show - of art anxious about its disappearance, suspicious of technology (yet always willing to use it), apocalyptic in its study of the effects of new technology on human consciousness.

In the small film section of this show, curated by Mark Nash, the revelations, for me, are the two hand-drawn animations by the American James Whitney. Whitney, who died in 1982, drew the most astonishing abstract animated films. Brownian-motion fields of corpuscular dots slew into tantric mandalas and rhythmic ejaculations of shooting stars - vertiginous free-falls of writhing squiggles. Not surprisingly, Whitney hung out with Aldous Huxley and Christopher Isherwood, and lived in California. Uncharitably, one might view his films as pre-computer screen-savers, or pre cursors to Timothy Leary and horrible psychedelic album covers, yet their effects are all the more compelling for their alarming hand-drawn intensity. And anyhow, there is something redeemable, even in the so-called psychedelic.

Brett says in his introduction to the show that he would have liked to present these works "without interpretive text or didactic material". He doesn't, of course, and the catalogue goes a long way towards locating and drawing parallels between more than 40 artists, who occupy different historical, geographic and aesthetic positions and moments. Cosmological fantasists and conceptualists, taoists and phenomenologists, mescaline-eaters and alcoholics, a Benedictine monk who updated the illuminated manuscript and recast it as concrete poetry all find a home here.

Brett's proposed silence is a good place to start. But it is a silence already loud with clatterings, screeches, metal machine music. Things twitch, vibrate, attract and repel one another. The minimal glass cube weeps and drizzles inside, as though the weather had leaked in. Waves flow along a ruffling length of white cotton, driven by the wind of an electric fan. A white, helium-filled balloon, which should stay suspended above a jet of air drifted away, as though it had lost concentration. It is a silence, too, in which I hear the lines, "Like a circle in a spiral, like a wheel within a wheel, like the circles that you find in the windmills of your mind", going round in my head. I wish it would stop.

Standing on one of the Hayward's open-air decks, watching the shredded clouds of detergent bubbles spew from David Medalla's Cloud Gates, that awful song came back to me, along with Little Fluffy Clouds, by the Orb. Hell, why not? It is nice to stand here and watch the soapy blobs bounce into people as they drift down, to see people on the street pause and look up for a moment.

Force Fields made me think, and to confront certain of my own prejudices, for which I am grateful. It was also, on the first day the show was open to the public, almost empty. Most London galleries are suffering a lowering of attendance figures at present, because everyone is at Tate Modern. But numbers aren't everything. And if you're going to hum embarrassing songs, it's best to do it alone.

webTitle: Leader: Alex Salmond leaves the SNP puzzling

fields.headline: Salmond leaps
fields.standfirst:
He leaves the SNP puzzling

Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: Quit while you are ahead, they say, and Alex Salmond has. The Nationalists stand tall in the polls. They have done well in Scottish and Westminster by-elections. Some of their Edinburgh parliamentarians have started to shine - at last showing the SNP's mettle as a potential party of government. So why, then, the wave still cresting, has Mr Salmond bailed out?
fields.body:
Quit while you are ahead, they say, and Alex Salmond has. The Nationalists stand tall in the polls. They have done well in Scottish and Westminster by-elections. Some of their Edinburgh parliamentarians have started to shine - at last showing the SNP's mettle as a potential party of government. So why, then, the wave still cresting, has Mr Salmond bailed out? Yesterday, he said seeking to win the next (Holyrood) election would lock him into politics for another decade - a non-sequitur. His reluctance to spend more time with his family is shown by his desire to continue as MSP for Banff.

Nationalism is faction-ridden and there has lately been a nasty outbreak of strife involving the party treasurer. And yet, credit to Mr Salmond, the party has achieved a fair degree of policy stability. The right-wingers who were once a feature of Scottish nationalism (some downright fascist) are nowhere to be seen. The SNP these days is more Old Labour in its beliefs than anything.

But for all its buoyancy in the polls, the party has not entirely enjoyed the experiment in self-government that began last year. Scots have, so far, shown little interest in the blame-the-UK game the SNP loves. Labour's difficulties have had to do with the nitty-gritty of office, spending and spin - the SNP won backing as the main opposition party not because it stands for separation. Brian Souter's campaign against repeal of Clause 28 (Section 2a) skewered the SNP as well as the parliament's Lib-Lab coalition. Does it want independence for bigots?

Mr Salmond has shown no appetite for solving a puzzle his successor (left or further left, by the looks of it) must now address. Making a success of the Scottish parliament entails a commitment to Scottish welfare in the here and now, not some utopian, independent future. The alternative is conniving at the parliament's failure - and good riddance to good government north of the border.

fields.headline: Vocal discord
fields.standfirst: Scientists are trying to prove the existence of a "chatterbox" gene.  Anita Chaudhuri  asks, are we born to blab?
fields.trailText: Scientists are trying to prove the existence of a "chatterbox" gene.  Anita Chaudhuri  asks, are we born to blab?
fields.body:
When I grow up, I want to be a genetic scientist. No, really. What a brilliant life they must lead, lounging around all day isolating chromosomes to explain away our irritating personality traits. Out-of-control drinking, eating, sex and shopping have all been attributed to compulsive behaviour genes. Now researchers at the Institute of Psychiatry are attempting to prove the existence of a "chatterbox" gene which - surprise, surprise - they expect to be more dominant in females.

The scientists conducting the study have already looked at 3,000 twins and say that two-year-old girls consistently outperform boys. Parents were asked to make notes of which of 100 set words their children used around their second birthday. Boys aged two used an average of 44 words while girls used a more impressive 52.

"The research shows there are sex-specific influences on early language development. It seems the ways genes work is different in boys and girls. It could be that this trigger is hormonal," says Michael Galsworthy, one of the researchers. Although psychologists have previously suggested that sex differences in verbal ability occur because parents talk to girls more than boys, Galsworthy and his team believe that it has more to do with differences in genetic make-up.

Another theory might be that in evolutionary terms, women were the ones setting up camp and nurturing communities while the men were off in the woods killing dangerous beasts and lugging them home. However, one thing is clear: despite the fact that ours is an increasingly talk-driven culture, chatting is not a highly valued talent.

The Collins dictionary definition of the word chatterbox sums it up nicely: "A person who talks constantly about trivial matters". Note, it doesn't say "a woman" but it might as well, for when did anyone ever hear of a male being referred to as a chatterbox? Popular culture thrives on the notion of girl talk - from Lorraine Kelly and her sofa-bound sisters on daytime TV to Sex and the City, the apotheosis of female bonding through chat.

Whatever the context, there is this lingering idea that women talk about inconsequential things, therefore it's a facility that goes unrewarded. Nowhere is this more marked than in the arena of broadcasting. Inexplicably, in the very medium where chat is king, women fail to shine. Men do the talking and women are forever doomed to aimless chit-chat. For every Parkinson, Clives James and Anderson, Jonathan Ross and David Frost, there are precious few girls.

Ruby Wax is the exception rather than the rule; Esther Rantzen and Denise Van Outen, we'd rather forget about. Patsy Rodenburg, director of voice at the National Theatre, believes that women have been discriminated against because of their voices and she has written an essay on the issue for Well-Tuned Women, an anthology about women's voices.

"It seems that after the initial intellectual awareness of the feminist movement, the physical manifestations surfaced in the mid-70s. Women seeking my help either felt that their voices were denied, not heard or, if they had good strong voices, they were mocked or called unfeminine, their vocal power deemed inappropriate."

Rodenburg has been called in to provide voice coaching for a number of corporations and observes how difficult it is for women to express opinions in arenas of power. "Gossiping, giggling and flirting, yes, but an intelligent woman speaking with freedom, clarity and power was too much and these women were constantly punished. No wonder voice specialists are sought by professional women."

Linguistic theorists have long suspected that men and women spend half their lives talking at cross-purposes. In her best-selling book You Just Don't Understand, Deborah Tannen examined the differences in the way we talk. She concluded that men see conversations as a forum for male power games with domination as their goal and noted that where women use language to seek confirmation, make connections and reinforce intimacies, men use it to protect their independence and negotiate status.

It will be interesting to see what the gene team at the Institute of Psychiatry come up with after they've analysed the DNA samples of all the participants. Who knows, maybe they will isolate other useful genes - a commitment gene, perhaps, or a gene that indicates a predisposition towards buying girlfriends presents from Tiffany. That would indeed be a valuable contribution to science.

fields.headline: New crack at benefit fraud
fields.standfirst: More about welfare reform
fields.trailText: Benefit fraud investigators are to be given powers to check bank accounts and telephone records as part of a government clampdown on fraudsters who cost the taxpayer up to £4bn a year.
fields.body:
Benefit fraud investigators are to be given powers to check bank accounts and telephone records as part of a government clampdown on fraudsters who cost the taxpayer up to £4bn a year.

Under the proposals, which were unveiled yesterday by the social security secretary, Alistair Darling, benefit staff will be able to examine bank accounts without the permission of claimants to see if they have undeclared income or savings. Telephone numbers on small ads, offering services such as window cleaning or building work, could be checked to see if anyone is supplementing their earnings with benefits.

At the moment, fraud investigators have to obtain permission from banks and telephone companies to carry out checks on personal details.

Gordon Brown, the chancellor, will today unveil a multi-million pound package to update antiquated computer systems in benefit offices to allow staff to carry out the checks on the personal details of suspicious claimants.

Mr Darling said the initiative, which implements some of the key recommendations of the recent Grabiner report into Britain's "informal economy", marked a renewed attempt to crack down on fraud. "We need tougher powers to cross-check claims," Mr Darling said. "Only those with something to hide need worry."

Ministers have been regularly criticised for announcing tough anti-fraud measures. "Much has been done to make the benefits system more secure and we are determined to do all we can to drive fraud out of the system," Mr Darling said.

David Willetts, the shadow social security secretary, said: "With nine crackdowns in as many months, it is little wonder that this government is cracking up. No amount of spin will cover up the extent of their past failures. We can tell them why their previous initiatives have failed - there is too much tinkering and not enough action."

The government's proposals have been put out to consultation until October 21.

fields.headline: BSkyB takes control of Open
fields.trailText: BSkyB yesterday took control of Open, the interactive television and home shopping business, in a deal valuing the operation at more than £1.1bn.
fields.body:
BSkyB yesterday took control of Open, the interactive television and home shopping business, in a deal valuing the operation at more than £1.1bn.

The company increased its shareholding in Open from 32.5% to 80.1% in two widely anticipated agreements. It is paying £225m in BSkyB shares for the 20% held by HSBC bank and £169m, also in paper, for the 15% stake owned by Matsushita, the Japanese electronics group.

The pair of deals satisfy the stated ambitions of BSkyB's chief executive, Tony Ball, to gain control of Open, which has been a surprise success story.

Crucially, the deal also removes a no-competition clause which was hampering BSkyB from offering interactive services such as shopping or online betting on its other channels.

Industry analysts suggested that BSkyB had brokered a good deal.

Neil Blackley at Merrill Lynch said he still valued the business at £2.75bn.

"The evidence coming from Open is tremendous. They are quoting buy rates that QVC [the shopping channel] would die for," he said.

ABN Amro took an even more bullish view and valued Open at £4bn.

British Telecom will see its shareholding in Open diluted from 32.5% to 19.9% as part of a commitment from BSkyB to meet the operation's future funding requirements.

British Interactive Broadcasting, the holding company for Open, was primarily set up to subsidise the cost of producing digital set-top boxes. It launched Open last October on the SkyDigital platform and in the 12 months to June had revenues of £22m and losses of £330m.

BSkyB estimates that a further £250m will need to be ploughed into the business, including the set-top box subsidies, until break-even which it has forecast will happen in 24 months.
