fields.headline: The mile-high club
fields.standfirst: Once upon a time, every little girl dreamed of being an air hostess - but that was before the days of cheap air travel for all, lager louts and air rage.  Caroline Sullivan  on the changing face of a feminine icon
fields.trailText: Once upon a time, every little girl dreamed of being an air hostess - but that was before the days of cheap air travel for all, lager louts and air rage.  Caroline Sullivan  on the changing face of a feminine icon
fields.body:
Coffee, Tea or Me: The Uninhibited Memoirs of Two Airline Stewardesses. The title says it all. When this "naughty, authentic" best seller was published in 1967, stewardesses were renowned as the good-time girls of the skies. Women wanted to be them, men wanted to have them - and plenty did, if you believe the American authors, Trudy Baker and Rachel Jones. Their long-deleted tome is worth searching out for the sexual revelations on almost every page, such as: "From what we've heard, some of the gayest, hottest and most unusual bedroom scenes have resulted from a stewardess accepting the stiff and proper advance of a Britisher."

Well, it was the 60s. These days, airborne Britishers are more likely to be complaining about lack of leg-room than instigating bedroom scenes, while stewardesses are too busy maintaining order on zoo-like planes to entertain amorous advances. But, as deglamourised as the air hostess has become in the easyJet era, she is still a key feminine icon. Almost every little girl has dreamed of wearing that chic uniform (or its modern polyester equivalent), and though the mystique may have tarnished, it has never quite faded. This week, BBC2's new series on the changing status of women, The Lipstick Years, kicks off with the documentary Fly Me, which traces the profession through its many permutations, from the 30s (when the job included fuelling the plane) to the age of Ibiza charter flights.

Being an air hostess has always been "top of the female fantasy league", in presenter Lowri Turner's words. But the downsides are enough to put off all but the most determined. The job is a peculiar combination of servility and power, with women rigorously trained in health and safety, yet relegated to serving meals. They're expected to tolerate rude and boorish passengers without complaint, and attempts to respond in kind result in reprimands. Worse, the uniform makes them fair game for some men. "Uniforms are sexy. The British Airways uniform is quite militaristic, like the RAF," says Philip Kerr, an ex-advertising copywriter who worked on a BA campaign. "Some airlines create images that lend themselves to the idea of mid-air shagging."

In the 60s, airlines woke up to the fact that hostesses could be employed as bait to attract their core passenger, the travelling businessman. Fly Me (which is named after an infamous advertising slogan, "I'm Mandy, Fly Me") has fascinating archive footage of ads that stopped just short of pimping. A TWA commercial shows a minxy young thing blowing the froth off a pint of beer as a male voice intones: "We have old English pub flights, complete with serving wench." Eastern Airlines' ad boasts that they don't hire girls who wear glasses.

Moreover, the girls who made the grade had to be under 32, unmarried and were subjected to compulsory public weigh-ins, where an extra pound meant suspension without pay.

"They made me turn around and looked at me," recalls Isabel McIlwraith, who flew for BOAC between 1966 and 1974. "At my [job] interview, I'd just been nursing in Beirut, and the first question they asked was, 'Why is it so many girls come back from Beirut pregnant?' What can you say? I think I said 'Because they can't resist the attention of Arab men'. I answered all their questions. I didn't care, because I was 22 and reasonably attractive, and it was so exciting."

The Sex Discrimination Act of 1975 did away with the under-32 rule, and sleazy advertising was gradually replaced by campaigns emphasising safety and reliability. But the hostess's job hasn't changed all that much: it's still about cleaning up after 300 strangers a day in exchange for the chance to see the world. Yet women still queue to do it.

"When I was growing up," says Amanda Drake of United Airlines, "it was either marry Donny Osmond or join an airline. I wanted to get out and see the huge world and have 300 people to dinner every night. You can be on the beach in LA one week and shopping in New York the next. I can't picture myself doing anything else.

"The industry is so professional now, it's just not the case that you come across sexism. Customers don't get fresh - it's just groups of people out having a good time. I've certainly never been proposed to."

I grew up in the 70s, when air travel was something you did once a year at most, and stewardesses still commanded envious respect. The job hadn't yet been debased by having to control lagered-up blokes flying to Barcelona for £59 return. Air rage hadn't been invented, nor the concomitant attitude that flight attendants are acceptable vents for the stress of being cooped up for eight hours. When singer Ian Brown was convicted of threatening to cut a flight attendant's hands off in 1998, one of his band shrugged that she was "just a flying dinner lady".

It makes you wonder why so many people still aspire to a job that former Debonair flight attendant Samantha Parker remembers as "waitressing... and the smell of planes first thing in the morning". Another ex-stewardess interviewed on Fly Me managed just 12 months in the air before quitting to become a lap dancer. "You only earned £10,500 a year plus allowance for up to a six- day week. Now I entertain on the ground," she says from her new job at Stringfellow's Cabaret of Angels.

But Drake argues a persuasive case, maintaining that the modern flight attendant is less "trolley dolly" than valued professional in an industry geared towards "the product, service and technology". So does her colleague Loretta Burke, 78, the world's oldest working stewardess. Based in Washington, DC, she still does five overseas trips a month. "Honey, I work my wrinkles to my advantage," she laughs. Quite so. Airlines should think about this: who inspires more confidence, an old hand like Burke or a 19-year-old hired for the size of her duty-frees? I know who I'd rather fly with.

She managed to flout the rule about retiring at 32 - "I guess they couldn't fire me because I was doing a pretty good job" - but never married. "Most of the girls only flew for two years, because the fantasy was that you'd marry a rich man. If you were flying for five years, you were an old maid."

McIlwraith agrees. "It was assumed that after 10 years you'd be worn out," she says. "They wanted young, attractive girls. You had to be cheerful to cope with not just men but old ladies and mothers with children, which is very stressful. And everyone envied us and wanted to be us."

That's still true now, to an extent. The lure of free travel and freedom from the nine-to-five grind attracts thousands of applicants. But much of the lustre has gone since the time of Baker and Jones (who apparently finally got their men and quit flying in the late 60s). Perspicacious airlines should be aware that the job is no longer top of the female fantasy league. "You ask little girls what they want to be now," muses Turner, "and they all say TV presenters."

 The Lipstick Years: Fly Me is on BBC2 on Wednesday at 9pm.

webTitle: Hillary faces voters' wrath for alleged ethnic slur

fields.headline: Hillary faces voters' wrath for alleged ethnic slur
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Hillary Clinton is fighting a rearguard action to avoid further damage to her standing with the crucial Jewish vote in her campaign for a Senate seat after a claim that she once used an ethnic insult against one of Bill Clinton’s aides.
fields.body:
Hillary Clinton is fighting a rearguard action to avoid further damage to her standing with the crucial Jewish vote in her campaign for a Senate seat after a claim that she once used an ethnic insult against one of Bill Clinton's aides.

A book out today claims that 26 years ago she called Paul Fray, her husband's campaign manager at the time, a "fucking Jew bastard".

Mrs Clinton denied the allegation and pressed the president into supporting her, but the author, Jerry Oppenheimer, said: "Three witnesses have now publicly acknowledged that she said it."

The Jewish vote accounts for 14% of the New York state electorate and is being courted assiduously by Mrs Clinton and her Republican opponent, Rick Lazio.

Mr Clinton won 80% of the bloc - traditionally sympathetic to the Democrats - in the last presidential election, but recent polls show that his wife has the support of only about 50%.

"I have never said anything like that, ever," Mrs Clinton said. "I have in the past certainly, you know maybe, called somebody a name. But I have never used an ethnic, racial, anti-Semitic, bigoted, discriminatory, prejudiced, accusation against anybody. I've never done it. I've never thought it."

Mr Clinton, who is trying to bring about a Middle East peace deal at Camp David, backed her up. "I was there on election night in 1974 and the charge is simply not true," he said.

"She might have called him a bastard, I wouldn't rule that out. She's never claimed that she was pure on profanity. But I've never heard her tell a joke with an ethnic connotation. She's so fanatic about it. It's not in her."

Referring to a "vast rightwing conspiracy" in previous elections, he said: "This is part of a pattern. They couldn't defeat me politically and they can't defeat her politically so they go after us personally."

Accounts of the dispute on election night 1974, when Mr Clinton failed to win a congressional seat representing Arkansas, have appeared before without the ethnic insult.

Those present at the inquest into the defeat were Mr Clinton, his then-girlfriend Hillary, his campaign manager Paul Fray, and Mr Fray's wife, Mary Lee. Neill McDonald, a campaign worker, was just outside the room and claims to have heard everything.

The Frays and Mr McDonald are the three witnesses on whom Mr Oppenheimer, a former reporter on the National Inquirer tabloid, relies for the passage in his book State of a Union: Inside the Complex Marriage of Bill and Hillary Clinton.

Mr Fray, 57, said yesterday: "I was a little defensive about it. I looked to the floor thinking 'How do I respond?' I didn't mind being called a son-of-a-bitch, but when it came to attacking my culture, that's a whole 'nother ballgame.

"You've got to understand it was the heat of the moment. We knew we had lost. It was a case of people lashing out at one another and it just got to that point."

Mr Fray is actually a Southern Baptist but says that he is one-eighth Jewish through his great-grandfather.

Mrs Fray said that her husband's recollection of the meeting, which lasted about an hour, was accurate. Mr McDonald said: "I don't know what provoked it or what. I just remember that one little comment."

Polls consistently show that Mr Lazio, a previously obscure congressman from Long Island, is neck-and-neck with Mrs Clinton.

He entered the race in place of the much better known New York mayor Rudy Giuliani, who withdrew because of health and marital problems.

Mrs Clinton has already had trouble with the Jewish vote and was booed when she took part in an Israel Day parade in Manhattan.

She was criticised last year during a visit to the West Bank for failing to rebuke Yasser Arafat's wife immediately for saying that Israel was poisoning Palestinian children.

Instead, she and Suba Arafat exchanged kisses.

fields.headline: Dorino Serafini
fields.standfirst: From motorcycle ace to early Ferrari flyer
fields.trailText: Dorino Serafini, who has died aged 90, was a senior figure in Italian motor racing who became one of the first men invited to drive in Enzo Ferrari's fledgling Formula One team in the immediate post-war years.
fields.body:
Dorino Serafini, who has died aged 90, was a senior figure in Italian motor racing who became one of the first men invited to drive in Enzo Ferrari's fledgling Formula One team in the immediate post-war years.

Before the war he had earned renown as a racing motor- cyclist, but after the hostilities he switched to cars. He showed signs of achieving a similar level of success before a serious accident during the 1951 Mille Miglia - a race around a thousand miles of Italian public roads from Brescia to Rome and back again - inflicted injuries which ended his career in competition.

He raced in only one Formula One world championship event, the Italian Grand Prix of 1950 at Monza. After 34 laps he obeyed a request to hand over his Ferrari to team leader Alberto Ascari, whose car had failed some minutes earlier. The combined efforts of the two men earned them a finish in second place, behind the Alfa Romeo of Dr Giuseppe Farina, whose victory also made him the first world champion.

Teodoro Serafini was the oldest of the four sons of a carriage builder and beekeeper in San Pietro in Calibano, a village near Pesaro, on Italy's Adriatic coast. At that time the region between Pesaro and Modena was full of young men making machines with wheels and laying the foundations of the Italian motor industry. For many of them, racing was not just an enjoyable new sport but a way of proving the commercial value of their creations. Signor Serafini's passion for motorcycles was inherited by the young Dorino and further fuelled by the presence in Pesaro of the Benelli family. The five Benelli brothers - Tonino, Francesco, Giuseppe, Filippo and Mimo - were building formidable little 175cc bikes, which Tonino rode to a number of local victories.

It was on a Benelli 175 that Serafini made his racing debut in the 1928 Circuit of Rimini, a few kilometres up the coast from his home, recording the fastest time. He stayed faithful to his hometown manufacturer for the next four years But it was on MM machines, built by the Bolognese firm of Morini and Massetti, that he became Italian national champion in the 175cc category, racing in a white sweater with the company's initials embroidered on its chest.

In 1935 he moved up to the 500cc class, the motorcycling equivalent of Formula One, joining the Bianchi team, whose promotional department made the most of his victory in the Circuit of Lario by printing special literature to draw attention to the speed and efficiency of their machines - recognisable by the pale blue of their paintwork. In the saddle of Bianchi's freccia celeste (blue arrow), Serafini also won the 1936 Coppa Acerbo at Pescara and the 1937 Circuito del Giardini Margherita in Bologna.

Such was his reputation that in 1938 the two most successful teams in Italy, Guzzi and Gilera, competed for his services, the latter making the winning bid with the offer of a salary of 2,000 lire a month.

In his first season on the four-cylinder machines, Serafini's victories in the grands prix of Sweden, Germany and Ulster gave him the title of European champion ahead of his main rival, the BMW rider Georg Maier of Germany. At the victory ceremony after the race on the Saxtorp circuit in Malmo, he and the other class winners - two German riders on NSU and DKW machines - followed the contemporary custom of giving the fascist salute on the podium.

After the war Serafini moved immediately to the world of four-wheeled racing, competing against Tazio Nuvolari and others in the elegant little Cisitalia single-seaters built in large numbers by Piero Dusio to help speed the rebirth of Italian motor sport, starting with a race in the park around the Baths of Caracalla in Rome. But Serafini also competed in a Frazer-Nash and a four-seater Healey 2000, with which he and Count Johnny Lurani took second place in the Tour of Sicily in 1948, as well as in the pretty little OSCA sports cars built by the Maserati brothers in Bologna.

In 1949 and 1950 Serafini visited Argentina to participate in the Temporada series, driving for the Maserati and Ferrari factories and meeting President Juan Perón and his wife Evita, who were great motor sport fans. In 1950, at the wheel of one of Enzo Ferrari's early single-seaters, he came second in the Gran Premio Maria Eva Duarte Peron on the Palermo Park circuit in Buenos Aires. On his return he and the other Italian drivers who had made the trip - among them Ascari, Farina, Gigi Villoresi and Piero Taruffi - were received by Pope Pius XII in a special audience.

But Serafini's greatest result in a racing car was undoubtedly his second place in the 1950 Mille Miglia.That year it rained virtually throughout the race and Serafini got a 12-hour soaking in his little open Ferrari barchetta, finishing behind Giannino Marzotto in a closed Ferrari coupé.

By this time he was also making regular appearances in Ferrari's Formula Two single-seaters, although his performances were usually overshadowed by those of his team mates, Ascari and Villoresi. He was already 41 years old when he got his opportunity in Formula One at Monza in 1950, and even then he had to sacrifice his own chances to Ascari's benefit.

But in the 1951 Mille Miglia, while speeding through the Abruzzo region, his Ferrari left the road at Martinsicuro and somersaulted across a ploughed field. His leg and arm injuries necessitated major surgery and put an immediate end to a racing career which, given his age, was in any event almost certainly nearing its close.

In recent years he was a regular attender at commemorative events, notably taking his place with the younger men - Surtees, Regazzoni, Trintignant, Berger and many others - and alongside Enzo Ferrari at the 40th anniversary of the first appearances of the machines in which Serafini enjoyed his most memorable days as a racing driver.

His wife, Bruna, pre-deceased him.

 Teodoro 'Dorino' Serafini, racing driver, born July 22 1909; died July 5 2000

In recent years he was a regular attender at commemorative events, notably taking his place with the younger men - Surtees, Regazzoni, Trintignant, Berger and many others - and alongside Enzo Ferrari at the 40th anniversary of the first appearances of the machines in which Serafini enjoyed his most memorable days as a racing driver. fields.headline: Armed Kashmiris kidnap tourist
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Kashmir conflict
fields.trailText: There was growing fear last night for the safety of a German tourist who was apparently abducted by a group of militants in Kashmir who marched him into the mountains at gunpoint.
fields.body:
There was growing fear last night for the safety of a German tourist who was apparently abducted by a group of militants in Kashmir who marched him into the mountains at gunpoint.

The tourist, whose name is believed to be Harfurth Rolf, has not been seen for a week. The truck in which he had hitched a lift in the remote region of Zanskar, which is popular with backpackers, was hijacked by five militants, three of them armed.

When the truck was flagged down shortly afterwards by four Buddhist monks, the militants panicked. They shot three of the monks dead.

They then abandoned the vehicle 12 miles further up the valley towards the town of Kargil. The German was last seen being led away on foot.

Inspector general Ashok Bhaan of the Kashmir police said: "They told him, 'You come along.' The other passengers on the truck protested and said 'leave him'. It is very difficult to say whether he is still alive."

Mr Rolf's abduction appears to be the first in Kashmir since six trekkers, including the Britons Keith Mangan and Paul Wells, were kidnapped in July 1995.

They are presumed dead, although their bodies, and those of their fellow hostages, a German and an American, have never been found. One hostage, an American, escaped. Another, a Norwegian, was beheaded.

That kidnapping was carried out by al-Faran, a Muslim group fighting to end Indian rule in Kashmir. Mr Rolf's disappearance comes at a time of increased tension between Buddhist and Muslim communities in Ladakh, a previously tranquil region which is only accessible to tourists between June and October.

webTitle: Leader: Blair needs more policy and less hot air

fields.headline: Policy on the hoof
fields.standfirst:
Blair should take on the Tories' arguments

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Just when Tony Blair might have hoped his season of misfortune was at an end, another sharp punch has landed in his solar plexus. The leak of a private memo is a multiple embarrassment.
fields.body:
Just when Tony Blair might have hoped his season of misfortune was at an end, another sharp punch has landed in his solar plexus. The leak of a private memo is a multiple embarrassment. Least important is the matter Downing Street, predictably, embraced first: the security of the prime minister's communications. Written by him and dispatched only to his innermost circle, this missive somehow found its way into two newspapers historically hostile to Labour. At the weekend, emails from Mr Blair's gatekeeper, Anji Hunter, reached the Guardian. Philip Gould's polling data and advice has also surfaced in the public prints. If the problem is hackable technology, perhaps Jack Straw will take note: he hardly need introduce authoritarian new snooping legislation to read the nation's emails if eavesdropping on private correspondence is this easy.

Much more alarming is the light this latest text sheds on the thinking of our prime minister. What it confirms is what Mr Blair's critics have said for so long: that he has got himself into a contest he can never win, a Dutch auction with the Tories where each side bids to be more extreme than the other on crime and a clutch of other "values" issues. "We should think now of an initiative, eg locking up street muggers," suggests Mr Blair, confirming that he does indeed make up policy on the hoof. He goes on: "Something tough, with immediate bite that sends a message through the system." We now know, of course, where this musing led: to Mr Blair's absurd call for young louts to be frogmarched to cashpoint machines to pay on-the-spot fines of £100.

Even with the benefit of hindsight, for many Labour loyalists this text will come as a very nasty shock. Because what it reveals is that the government's critics have been right. Mr Blair never mentions the Tories by name in his memo, but it is clear from every word that he is reacting to their attacks on issues like crime, asylum and gay rights. Because the Conservatives had made the running with the case of the vigilante farmer, Tony Martin, for example, the PM suggests a senior judge be called in to review sentencing law, perhaps introducing lesser sentences than life for murder: the very idea championed by William Hague.

It is telling that Mr Blair wrote this memo the same bank holiday weekend he penned a 975-word, handwritten defence to the Sun. They used a single word headline to capture the PM's state of mind that day, which this latest leak wholly vindicates. It is the word that is fast defining Mr Blair's performance this whole year. The word is: rattled.

Worst of all, however, is the exposure of the prime minister as pure, 100% politician. For some leaders that would not matter. But Mr Blair has made much of his persona as ordinary guy, just doing what he really believes. On Saturday's documentary about Alastair Campbell, the PM was at it again, insistent that spin and positioning were never further from his mind. Yet here is a text, written in his own hand, which reads more like the work of a Gould or Campbell than a serving head of government. It reveals that the ultimate political strategist, thinking about polls and perception rather than policy, is not any of the "men in the dark". It is the prime minister himself. No wonder his memo never suggests taking on the Conservatives by confronting their arguments and defeating them: he does not consider making the positive case for immigration, for example, but prefers to boast of the high numbers of asylum seekers the government has kicked out. This document brings embarrassment on Tony Blair - and not a little shame.

fields.headline: Sir Mark Oliphant
fields.standfirst: Physicist who made wartime Britain and America wake up to the possibilities of atomic weapons, and then turned to peace
fields.trailText: Mark Oliphant, who has died aged 98, was one of the cluster of outstandingly creative physicists who, by shaping nuclear physics in its infancy, were assigned by fate to crucial roles in the second world war.
fields.body:
Mark Oliphant, who has died aged 98, was one of the cluster of outstandingly creative physicists who, by shaping nuclear physics in its infancy, were assigned by fate to crucial roles in the second world war. His particular achievement at the Cavendish laboratory in Cambridge in the 1930s was the first description of hydrogen fusion.

After a distinguished academic career following his return to his native Australia in 1950, he became governor of South Australia at the age of 70 - an indication of his vigour, as he was the only scientist of international stature to take on a political challenge at this level.

Vigour was of his essence. It was Oliphant who, in 1940, convinced the Whitehall defence scientific committee that atomic weapons were practical, a truth that had been spelt out in a short and highly perceptive paper by the refugee physicists Otto Frisch and Rudolf Peierls.

It was Oliphant who headed the Birmingham University team secretly seeking high-power oscillators for radar. Under his direction, Randall and Boot produced the cavity magnetron - the device which (when modified and stabilised by GEC) played a crucial role in winning the war in the air by making short-wave radar possible. This was probably Britain's greatest single technical contribution under the lease-lend arrangements with the United States. And in 1941 it was Oliphant again who, with his rival and friend Ernest Lawrence of the US Berkeley Laboratory, finally galvanised the US scientific community out of its indifference to the military significance of nuclear fission.

From then on the possibility that physicists in Nazi Germany were already working toward nuclear weapons concentrated minds in the US as decisively as they had already been in Britain. Teams came together rapidly. Within a year, Oliphant joined the Manhattan Project under Enrico Fermi and worked at Los Alamos on the electromagnetic separation of uranium-235.

But, like Lawrence, he was already dreaming of the giant particle accelerators that might be built after the war, to investigate the mysterious properties of fundamental matter at the deepest levels. This ambition was never quite fulfilled, although he spent years in the quest as head of the physical sciences research school at the Australian National University in Canberra.

After the atom bombs had been dropped on Japan in 1945, Oliphant declared that physics, a subject of great importance and beauty, had been destroyed for ever. To others this was an over-statement, although the open, energetic and friendly international world of physics of that era has never re-emerged from the long shadows of nuclear secrecy.

Oliphant, an ebullient outgoing man, was a great talker, and during the war he was regarded by some, quite wrongly, as a possible security risk. After the war, when Oppenheimer and Teller set out on the road to hydrogen weapons, he turned sharply away from defence work, playing instead a vigorous role in the promotion of peace. He was involved in the formative years of Pugwash, the powerful Einstein-Russell peace-seeking organisation, an involvement to which he returned in the last years of his life. For a while he advocated extensive use of nuclear power, which he believed might transform the human environment, and through desalination, for example, bring deserts back into agricultural use.

Born in Adelaide, where he studied at the university, Oliphant arrived in Cambridge as an exhibitioner in 1927. His greatest personal triumphs in science came in the 1930s, when his friendship with the New Zealander Ernest Rutherford was at its height and when, with the departure of James Chadwick, he became assistant director of the Cavendish laboratory - then the world's leading centre for experimental nuclear physics.

At this time Rutherford was arguing that the notion of useful energy from nuclear interactions was "moonshine", because the very high energy needed to initiate a reaction meant that you would always get back less than you put in. To avoid his displeasure, Oliphant therefore waited until Rutherford was away before attempting his next experiment.

Then, with hurriedly lashed-up equipment, he bombarded heavy water vapour with deuterons (heavy hydrogen nuclei) - the first experimental attempt to produce fusion energy. It was unsuccessful - and earned him a stinging reprimand from Rutherford which, perhaps, finally convinced Oliphant that it was time for him to run a laboratory of his own. In 1937, he infuriated Rutherford still further by accepting the chair at Birmingham.

Rutherford's uncharacteristic anger, although short-lived, is difficult to explain. However, in his biography of this period (Rutherford: Recollections of the Cambridge Days, 1972), Oliphant describes the great friendship which developed between his family and the Rutherfords: the shared holidays, precarious tree pruning in the Rutherfords' garden and long walks from the Rutherfords' holiday cottage in Nant Gwynant, north Wales.

Such close association suggests that, after Chadwick's departure in 1934, Ruther ford hoped that Oliphant would eventually take over the Cavendish. Sadly, when Rutherford died in October 1937, Oliphant had already gone, and the remaining "boys" scattered, bringing to an end this great period of experiment.

In 1946, still based in Britain, Oliphant became the first scientific adviser to the UN atomic energy commission. Later, with Howard Florey and Keith Hancock, he served on the council setting up the Australian National University (ANU). In 1950 each was invited to take over the relevant research school at the new university. Only Oliphant accepted. He knew that he might be sacrificing his career in research, and was dismayed to find that the house he had been promised did not exist.

It was almost a year before he and his family had a home, and two before he had a working laboratory. Then, armed with some grants and larger premises, he set about building "the most powerful accelerator in the southern hemisphere", but the project failed, becoming known, cruelly, as "the White Oliphant".

At this time, undismayed, Oliphant fought for and became a founding member of the Australian Academy of Sciences. After his retirement from the research school in 1970, he became governor of South Australia from 1971-76.

Still deeply involved in energy research, he became a powerful promoter of research into the links between energy use and ecology. He had to fight yet again for the ANU, this time against the federal government, which was seeking to peel off its successful school of medical research.

In retirement, Oliphant maintained an office at the ANU and, although shaky on his legs, continued to lecture, study, stimulate and disturb those he met, while still startling passers-by with his booming laugh. Like Rutherford, he was somehow larger than life, and he somehow managed to enjoy almost every moment of an extraordinarily full existence.

His wife Rosa died in 1987, and he is survived by his daughter, Vivian.

 Marcus (Mark) Laurence Elwin Oliphant, physicist, born October 8 1901; died July 14 2000

webTitle: Leader: Ministers are on the right course in fight against crime

fields.headline: False crime statistics
fields.standfirst:
Prevention is still better than prison

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Total crime up by 4%, violent crime by 16% and detection down by 4% to a mere 25% of the 5.3m recorded offences in a year. Should yesterday's crime statistics prompt a "Come back, John Major" call - remember the previous prime minister's election pledge to reduce crime by 10%? Of course not.
fields.body:
Total crime up by 4%, violent crime by 16% and detection down by 4% to a mere 25% of the 5.3m recorded offences in a year. Should yesterday's crime statistics prompt a "Come back, John Major" call - remember the previous prime minister's election pledge to reduce crime by 10%? Of course not. Remember the acerbic comment of Judge Tumim, former chief prison inspector, on that earlier pledge: a target is an aspiration, not a policy. But will yesterday's statistics reinforce the prime minister's big fear, that the public perceives Labour as soft on crime? Only if ministers - including the prime minister - fail to sell their excellent crime reduction policies.

Take burglaries - one of the most feared offences. They are down again: domestic burglaries by 6% and non-domestic by 3%. Surely that was because of the tough new mandatory sentences - minimum three years for third offences - introduced last December, which the prime minister wants accentuated. No. The statistical year ended in March. Burglars would have had to have committed and been tried for three separate offences by then. The fall is because of the government's evidence-based crime reduction plan, targeted on the highest crime areas with the poorest people, helping them make their homes more secure. Labour should be celebrating its "what works" approach.

But what about violent crime? This is serious. They may only represent 13% of all crimes, but this still involves 703,000 offences. Part of the rise is a new definition - two years ago the 194,000 common assaults would not have been included. Ministers should be congratulated for being honest enough to include them. Part of the problem is alcohol - more young men with money in their pockets, drinking too much. Researchers have suggested drink is involved in 40% of domestic violence, 65% of murders, and 75% of stabbings. Of course, most convictions for violence deserve a taste of prison, but prevention would be of even more help to victims. A new package will be unveiled next month, including stricter regulation of violent pubs, strengthened beer glasses to reduce the 5,000 broken glass attacks a year, stronger links between hospital emergency departments and the police. Ministers should ignore simplistic tabloid analysis. They are on the right course, except for their reluctance to sell it. They should trust people's common sense.

fields.headline: Zealots harry Israel's liberal Jews
fields.standfirst: Ultra-Orthodox blamed for attacks on synagogues
fields.trailText: Almost as soon as Aviad Nahum became a man, chanting a portion of the Torah scrolls in the traditional Jewish rite of passage, his rabbi was urging him to become a responsible adult.
fields.body:
Almost as soon as Aviad Nahum became a man, chanting a portion of the Torah scrolls in the traditional Jewish rite of passage, his rabbi was urging him to become a responsible adult.

Do not confuse machismo with masculinity, he told the chubby bespectacled teenager, and remember always to show tolerance to others.

To the congregation of Ya'ar Ramot synagogue, gazing out of seven metre high windows at a brilliant blue sky and an impressive sweep of the Jerusalem suburbs, the message of tolerance had a particular poignancy.

On June 24, three men in white skullcaps threw a chunk of golden Jerusalem stone through the windows, followed by a couple of rags doused in petrol. The scorch marks from the resulting fire are still visible on the high dome of the ceiling and a dozen blackened chairs on the patio outside. At one side members of the synagogue have made a sort of shrine of charred prayer books.

Two days later another synagogue in Jerusalem, used by adherents of the most contentious sect in Judaism, which accepts Jesus as the Messiah, was broken into. The burglars stole Torah scrolls, and left behind jerry cans of petrol.

On July 6 it was the turn of the Hebrew Union College in central Jerusalem, which trains rabbis in the Reform movement, the liberal mainstream of Jewish practice in North America. The great glass doors were smashed, and the word "Satan" spray-painted on the pavement in big black letters.

To the horror of the congregation at the Ramot synagogue, the vandals in all three cases were fellow Jews. But the police believe that, unlike the worshippers at Ya'ar Ramot, however, who are followers of a stream of Judaism known as Masorti in the UK and Conservative in North America, they were almost certainly ultra-Orthodox Jews.

"It seems there is a pattern of events, possibly pointing to the existence of some kind of underground - hopefully a very small one," Rabbi David Bateman told his congregation. "We truly hope and pray the police catch the individuals who carried out these unspeakable acts."

The rabbi sees the attackers as "God's Cossacks". He explained: "They have not succeeded in their yeshiva [religious seminary] studies, they have not succeeded in normal life, and they get some validation in trying to enforce their extreme views."

To ultra-Orthodox Jews, Aviad Nahum's bar mitzvah was an abomination. Men and women - arms bare, and heads uncovered - sat together as he chanted his passage from the Torah, and his beaming mother was called to the pulpit to say a blessing.

There were other tokens of the dreaded modernity: the synagogue was air-conditioned - albeit by a timer so as not to violate the sabbath - and a few of the men had mobile phones on their belts.

Such innovations would barely ruffle the majority of Israelis, who profess to be secular Jews or moderately religious, and they are in the mainstream of religious practice among Jews in North America and Europe.

But to ultra-Orthodox Jews the Ramot synagogue stands for heretical practices which must be stamped out. They are also anathema to the Israeli religious authorities, who refuse to recognise Masorti and Reform practice as authentic Judaism.

Although Israel's chief rabbi deplored the attack at Ramot, he could not bring himself to use the words synagogue and Jew.

In Jewish circles the attacks are seen as part of a battle raging for generations between traditionalists and modernisers. But in Israel the debate between orthodoxy and modern practice is defined by the disproportionate influence the ultra-Orthodox exercise over public life.

The peculiarities of Israel's coalition politics have turned ultra-Orthodox political parties into the kingmakers; in return for their support, religious politicians have sought to impress their stamp on public life.

So, while the ultra-Orthodox remain a minority in Israel, they dominate public life. According to Israeli law, only ultra-Orthodox rabbis can solemnise marriages, and their assent is necessary in divorces.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Death sentence on Aum cultist
fields.body:
Death sentence on Aum cultist

A Japanese court sentenced two former leaders of the Aum Shinryko doomsday cult to death yesterday for spraying nerve gas in the Tokyo subway in 1995.

The two were accused of taking a direct role in the assault, which killed 12 people and made thousands of others ill, the Tokyo district court said. They claimed that they had been brainwashed by the Aum Shinrikyo cult's guru, Shoko Asahara.
Reuters, Tokyo

Bomb destroys Serb church

An explosion tore through a medieval Serbian Orthodox church in Kosovo, UN police said yesterday.

The church of the Holy Prophet Elijah in the village of Pomazetin was levelled by Sunday's bomb, said Oleg Rubezhov, a UN police officer. Minority Serbs in Pomazetin have faced attacks from ethnic Albanian militants since Kosovo's war.
Reuters, Belgrade

Pipeline fire toll reaches 100

The death toll in the latest Nigerian oil pipeline blaze climbed to 100 as the local authorities prepared a mass grave for the victims, officials said yesterday.

The explosion on a ruptured pipeline near Warri on Sunday came less than a week after more than 250 people died in a similar disaster six miles away. In both cases the victims were stealing petrol.
Reuters, Warri

Journalist killed in Bangladesh

Shamsur Rahman, 43, a reporter for the daily Janakantha, was shot dead on Sunday evening in his office in Jessore, Bangladesh.

Three gunmen escaped after shooting him at point blank range, it was reported. Rahman was crusading against official corruption and terrorism.
Arshad Mahmud, Dhaka

Toxic threat by French strikers

Workers threatened to pour sulphuric acid into the sewers and drains of the French town of Givet on the Belgian border yesterday as their anger at the closure of their textile factory grew.

The workers who occupied the Cellatex viscose factory a week ago want the government to guarantee jobs and redundancy money when it closes.
Givet, France

Russians killed by mushrooms

Poisonous mushrooms have killed 95 people and put hundreds in hospital in Russia this summer, news agencies reported yesterday. Radio stations warned people not to pick mushrooms.
Reuters, Moscow

fields.headline: Sleaze allegations warning to MPs
fields.trailText: MPs were warned yesterday not to use the Commons standards watchdog to make "tit for tat" sleaze allegations against each other in the run-up to the general election.
fields.body:
MPs were warned yesterday not to use the Commons standards watchdog to make "tit for tat" sleaze allegations against each other in the run-up to the general election.

Robert Sheldon, chairman of the Commons standards and privileges committee, said that the committee would regard it as "a very serious matter" if MPs were to put in trivial allegations of rule-breaking in order to score party political points to further their party's election campaign.

He was giving evidence to Lord Neill's committee on standards in public life on the final day of its hearings into whether the House of Lords should have a compulsory register of interests and a code of conduct. Peers who oppose a register claim that it could lead to political point-scoring in the Lords.

Mr Sheldon said: "The tit for tat situation concerns me greatly, where people outside the Commons are willing to trip up others.

"This is getting quite serious because my task has been to improve the reputation of the house, and what we are seeing is that trivial matters are being put forward ... you get that particularly in the run-up to a general election."

Nobody in parliament "wants to be under suspicion when they have not done anything wrong," Mr Sheldon said.

The problem was the publicity that surrounded complaints made to the parliamentary commissioner: often complaints later proved groundless, yet this outcome was not reported subsequently in the newspapers.

Mr Sheldon said that he was concerned about a recent complaint about the former prime minister John Major having to disclose all the money he received from his lecture tours after signing an agency contract. Mr Major has still to agree the detail of the contract to be lodged with the register.

"John Major made a very sensible point that the agency didn't employ him, he employed the agency. I feel very strongly for him," Mr Sheldon said.

Mr Sheldon distinguished between trivial and serious complaints - an example of the latter leading to Teresa Gorman, Tory MP for Billericay, being suspended for a month, for covering up her investments and threatening those members of the public who provided the information. Two recent examples of trivial complaints - against Fabian Hamilton, Labour MP for Leeds north east, and Frank Cook, Labour MP for Stockton north - were thrown out by Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary commissioner for standards, and by the committee.

Later, Baroness Jay, leader of the Lords, told Lord Neill that the government wanted a compulsory register of inter ests for all peers similar to the wide-ranging one in the Commons.

"It is anomalous that the House of Lords alone does not have a standards and ethics framework at a time when the House of Commons, local government and other public institutions are developing their own frameworks," she said.

"There is extensive anecdotal evidence that peers are, albeit inadvertently, failing to declare interests - either at the beginning of what they say in the chamber or, in some cases, at all.

"The relevance of peers' non-parliamentary activity to their parliamentary activity appears not to be in the forefront of their minds."

webTitle: Top judge hits at mandatory sentences

fields.headline: Top judge hits at mandatory sentences
fields.trailText: Judges are being forced to pass wrong sentences because parliament has taken away their discretion in some cases by enacting mandatory sentences, one of England's most senior judge said yesterday.
fields.body:
Judges are being forced to pass wrong sentences because parliament has taken away their discretion in some cases by enacting mandatory sentences, one of England's most senior judge said yesterday.

Lord Woolf, master of the rolls, was protesting about new sentencing laws, such as the controversial "two strikes and you're out" regime, under which serious sexual and violent offenders must be sentenced to life for a third offence.

The removal of their discretion to fit the sentence to the offender and the circumstances is unpopular with the judges.

He used the platform of the American Bar Association conference in central London to air judicial disquiet, which has been building up in a series of cases, on mandatory sentences. He said it was an "area of tension" between the judges and the government.

"It is a subject on which the judiciary feel strongly," Lord Woolf told American lawyers and judges at Middle Temple Hall. The subject was controversial because, except for murder, which has a mandatory life sentence, and some minor offences such as traffic offences which have fixed penalties, "the judiciary say good policy requires judges to have a substantial degree of discretion as to what sentence is appropriate".

He said the judges would advise parliament that it was not wise to impose mandatory sentences "because almost inevitably cases will arise where a wrong sentence has to be given" and the policy of the reform would be defeated.

He did not specifically attack the mandatory life sentence for murder, although his last three predecessors made no secret of their opposition to it. Most senior judges believe it operates unfairly in treating mercy killers and serial murderers equally.

Tony Blair suggested in his memo, leaked yesterday, that a senior judge should look at whether the life sentence should remain mandatory in the aftermath of the conviction of the Norfolk farmer Tony Martin for killing a teenage burglar. Such a move would be welcomed by the judges, who might point out that a committee headed by Lord Lane, a former lord chief justice, recommended reform years ago.

Mr Blair told the conference yesterday that the Human Rights Act, which comes into force in October, would "transform judicial decision making". It would give the highest courts a radical new power to declare legislation incompatible with the European convention on human rights, and would transform British society from one of "negative" rights to one based on "positive" rights, which restrictions must not unreasonably reduce.

Lawyers predict many claims challenging laws and procedures as breaching human rights. Last week a crown court judge dismissed dangerous driving prosecutions against two men in Birmingham, ruling that police letters requiring them to name the driver breached safeguards against self-incrimination.

Lord Woolf said: "I predict that after a two to three year period of sometimes painful settling down, the system will accommodate the European convention." It would be absorbed comfortably into the system, with institutions being modified rather than abolished.

He said there was tension between judges and government over judicial review, and remarks had been made that judges were taking on more than they should. But the judiciary saw the sovereignty of parliament as an important protector of the public.

There were cases - such as asylum seekers being deprived of benefit - where the question was whether it had been the intention of parliament to allow rights to be taken away.

fields.headline: Saving the vole
fields.standfirst: Top secret operation under way
fields.trailText: Half a dozen water voles sporting radio collars and electronic transponder chips were released into the wild at a secret location in Oxfordshire yesterday in an attempt to avert the extinction of Britain's fastest declining mammal.
fields.body:
Half a dozen water voles sporting radio collars and electronic transponder chips were released into the wild at a secret location in Oxfordshire yesterday in an attempt to avert the extinction of Britain's fastest declining mammal.

Once a common sight swimming close to the banks of Britain's waterways, the reclusive rodent (above) has suffered a catastrophic population decline of 88% over the past 15 years. This is a result of habitat loss and of the flourishing of the American mink, for whom they are a key source of food.

Yesterday's initiative, co-ordinated by the environment agency in collaboration with the UK Water Vole Steering Group, is part of an attempt to build sustainable local populations across the country.

The precise location of the operation was being kept secret in order to prevent tampering with the cages in which the voles were left to burrow to freedom. More are due to be released into a canal in southern England during the next fortnight, an agency spokesman said.

Land drainage and changes in methods of river management have contributed to the species vanishing from up to 49% of the sites in which it once thrived, according to Britain's Wildlife Trusts network.

But it is the rampant success of the American mink, which began breeding in this country only in the late-1950s, that has finally helped put the species in danger of disappearing entirely.

If conditions permit, the replenished population could increase rapidly, but infant mortality is high, and many offspring do not make it through the winter.

webTitle: Quick look at what's happening at Westminster

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.trailText: Penthouse of day
fields.body:
Penthouse of day

MPs are to move into their £230m office block in September, it was announced yesterday. Portcullis House, which has been built above the refurbished Westminster tube station, will accommodate 210 MPs with separate rooms for secretaries and researchers. Committee rooms are to be named after Margaret Thatcher, Harold Macmillan, Harold Wilson, Clem Attlee, Betty Boothroyd and Jo Grimond.

Comeback of day

One of the country's richest landowners, the Duke of Devonshire, said he was considering standing as an MP despite being 80 years old. The duke, who stood unsuccessfully for the Tories in 1945 and 1950, said he might stand as an anti-euro independent in Tony Benn's Chesterfield seat.

Today

Commons: Questions to the foreign secretary. Chancellor's statement on comprehensive spending review. Finance bill, remaining stages. Backbench debate on compensation under compulsory purchase orders.

Lords: Learning and skills bill, Commons amendments. Care standards bill, Commons amendments.

webTitle: Government urged to give more cash to arts training

fields.headline: Government urged to give more cash to arts training
fields.trailText: The government is being urged to increase funding for training the next generation of actors and dancers - or suffer a disaster in the arts.
fields.body:
The government is being urged to increase funding for training the next generation of actors and dancers - or suffer a disaster in the arts.

A report published today by the National Council for Drama Training warned that a scholarship scheme introduced by the government was underfunded, limited in scope, and bureaucratic.

Although welcoming the dance and drama awards, the report said the scheme failed to meet ministers' objectives of enabling the maximum number of talented students to attend the best schools.

Winners of the awards get help with finding annual fees of up to £9,000, paying at most £1,050, in line with university students.

In the wake of recent spectacular failures in football and tennis, the report's author, Graham Marchant, an independent arts consultant, warned: "Britain is already seeing the results of failure to invest properly in training in sports activity; it would be a disaster if similar mistakes were made in one of the few other arenas where this country has an absolutely outstanding international reputation to defend."

He also suggested that the awards scheme was elitist because it had created a divisive two tier structure which distinguished between separating "talented" students on the accredited courses who had won scholarships from those who had also won places but not scholarships.

The report said that this implied that the latter were deemed "untalented".

The call for more funds comes days after details emerged of a last minute tussle between the chancellor, Gordon Brown, and the culture secretary, Chris Smith, over a £60m rescue package to save up to 50 regional theatres from closure over the next three years.

Mr Smith is said to be furious at having been put "last in the queue" for cash in today's spending review, because of the competing demands from big spending departments such as health, education and transport.

The Marchant report also highlighted anomalies which resulted from courses being split between the further and higher education sectors, leaving FE students worse off as they were unable to apply for student loans to cover living costs.

The government has increased the money from a special hardship fund to help students on FE courses - predominantly dancers.

Yet many on these physically demanding courses are forced to take part-time jobs, which made them even more exhausted.

Peter Cheeseman, chairman of the drama training council, acknowledged that introduction of the awards scheme was "a great milestone in the history of our state funding for the arts".

But he added: "By not investing properly in our young talent we are gradually diluting the source of great international triumphs and pride. Take the number of Oscars which Britain won for Shakespeare in Love. We must invest in the future, not the past, and the government should stop being so short sighted."

webTitle: Miners' long hours blamed as lung disease returns

fields.headline: Miners' long hours blamed as lung disease returns
fields.trailText: Miners at a Scottish colliery are suffering from a serious lung disease that health experts thought had been virtually eradicated.
fields.body:
Miners at a Scottish colliery are suffering from a serious lung disease that health experts thought had been virtually eradicated.

Routine tests have found that nine miners at the Longannet colliery in Fife have developed pneumoconiosis, or black lung, which is caused by inhaling coal dust. A further 11 have abnormalities in the lungs, an early stage of the condition.

The condition, which can lead to debilitating and sometimes fatal respiratory disease, was thought to have almost disappeared with the introduction of new safety and screening measures in the mid-1970s.

Last year a compensation scheme was agreed for miners affected by the disease after the biggest ever personal injury action in the UK.

A health and safety executive report on the Longannet findings is expected to blame excessive working hours and a failure to use protective equipment properly.

Dan Mitchell, HSE chief inspector of mines, said it was unusual to have found such an outbreak.

"But certainly in recent years the number of workers in mines attending for x-ray has been falling," he said. "It's not as good as it used to be and we only know about the prevalence of disease from the people who are x-rayed."

The re-emergence of the disease has also surprised medical authorities at the Scottish pulmonary vascular unit at the Western Infirmary in Glasgow.

"I am really quite surprised because we have known about this condition for years and screening measures have been in place for years," said the unit head, Andrew Peacock. "We know what causes it. We expect old cases from the past but new cases coming along now does surprise me."

Under regulations introduced in 1975 miners are only supposed to work 7-hour shifts, but many work overtime.

They are also expected to have lung x-rays every five years, but at Longannet only around 70% of men took part on the last occasion.

Representatives from the National Union of Mineworkers met HSE officials yesterday to discuss the situation.

Peter Neilsen, vice-president of the NUM in Scotland, said: "We thought that disease had disappeared. As a union we are concerned and it is our intention to take stock of the situation."

The Scottish Coal Deep Mine Company, which runs Longannet, issued a statement saying that health of employees was of the utmost concern.

More than 82,000 claims for compensation have been filed since the miners won their health case against the government and the nationalised coal industry.

They claimed it had been known for decades that dust produced in the coal mining process could cause diseases like emphysema and chronic bronchitis and that not enough was done to protect them.

fields.headline: WTO referees rum punch-up
fields.standfirst: Cuban refinery takes on Bacardi in latest bout of transatlantic trade war
fields.trailText: The grim Soviet-style apartment blocks of Santa Cruz del Norte and the millionaires' playground of the Bahamas have one thing in common: the brand name Havana Club rum. In the Cuban town, rum produced under a label made famous in the decades before Fidel Castro's revolution is a main export for the island's cash-strapped economy. Distributed worldwide by the French company Pernod Ricard, it is the fastest-growing spirits brand in the world.
fields.byline: Tom Gibbs in Santa Cruz del Norte and Charlotte Denny
fields.body:
The grim Soviet-style apartment blocks of Santa Cruz del Norte and the millionaires' playground of the Bahamas have one thing in common: the brand name Havana Club rum. In the Cuban town, rum produced under a label made famous in the decades before Fidel Castro's revolution is a main export for the island's cash-strapped economy. Distributed worldwide by the French company Pernod Ricard, it is the fastest-growing spirits brand in the world.

But Havana Club has joined beef and bananas in bringing the US and the European Union into conflict at the World Trade Organisation.

The problem is that not all rum found in Havana Club bottles comes from Santa Cruz del Norte. The American drinks group Bacardi also uses the brand on rum it produces in the Bahamas and sells in the US, where the Cuban version cannot be sold because of trade sanctions.

The origins of the battle over who owns the Havana Club trademark started 40 years ago when Fidel Castro's new government nationalised the plant built by Havana Club's founder, Don Jose Arechabala, at the start of the century, further along the coast in the port of Cardenas, today best known as the home of six-year-old Elian Gonzalez.

Trademark lapsed

"Cardenas and Santiago were always the best places to make rum because of the water which comes from fresh springs," said 90-year-old Juan Parquet, who started work in the distillery in 1937. He took a dim view of the revolutionary government's decision to move production to Santa Cruz del Norte in 1970. "The water there is no good."

The Arechabala family fled to the US and Spain after the revolution and gave up rum-making. For most of the past 30 years it made no attempt to protect brand; in some countries the Havana Club trademark had lapsed before the Cuban revolution. Meanwhile, the state-owned company that had taken over the Arechabala plant continued exporting rum under the Havana Club label and registered the trademark in more than 70 countries including the United States.

In 1993 the company formed a joint operation with Pernod Ricard to market the brand internationally. Sales of Havana Club started to climb.

Three years ago the branch of the Arechabala family in the US sold its claim to the Havana Club name to Bacardi, a private firm which is owned by descendants of another great Cuban distilling family that fled from the Castro regime and re-established its business in exile in the Bahamas. Its rum has become the biggest selling spirits brand in the world.

Pernod Ricard went to the US courts to challenge the validity of the Arechabalas' sale of the Havana Club trademark. It lost after Bacardi successfully lobbied the US Congress to remove legal protection from trademarks taken over by the Cuban government. It is this law the EU is challenging before the World Trade Organisation.

Bacardi's use of the Havana Club label has caused considerable anger in Cuba. "[Havana Club] is made with the fermented sugars of Cuba and the sugar cane grown in Cuba, and to dress something up as Havana Club which is made differently is misleading," says the company's general manager, Regla Jimenez. Castro has even threatened to start bottling fake Coca-Cola.

In Santa Cruz, working at the Havana Club distillery is considered a reasonable job. Workers get a monthly "basket" of soaps, cosmetics, cooking oil and other products only usually available for dollars, in addition to their meagre salary.

For the Cuban government, rum is the most profitable branch of a sugar industry which has for centuries been the island's source of wealth but today represents a drain on resources.

Highly protected markets in Japan, western Europe and the US make it impossible for low-cost producers such as Cuba to win their fair share of world markets.

With almost 1.5m Cubans working in the industry, closing down sugar mills wholesale is not an option for the government. Distilling the sugar into rum turns it from a loss maker into a valuable export commodity.

Expanding rapidly

The endgame everyone is playing for what happens when Castro dies. The US is almost certain to lift the economic sanctions it has imposed on the island, opening up the possibility of head-to-head competition between Bacardi and Pernod Ricard for the lucrative US market. The question of who owns the Havana Club label with all its cachet will be a crucial weapon in this battle.

It will take the WTO at least six months to come up with even a preliminary ruling on the rights and wrongs of the Havana Club case.

In the meantime, production at the Santa Cruz del Norte plant is expanding rapidly, from 1m cases this year to a target of 2m in two to three years' time. Set against Bacardi's worldwide sales of 20m cases, the threat from Havana Club seems small beer. However, as the legal wranglings of the past three years show, it is a threat which the Bahamas-based contender takes very seriously indeed.

webTitle: Letters: Reaction to George Monbiot's piece on Catholicism

fields.headline: It's natural to be normal
fields.trailText: George Monbiot knows of only two meanings of the word "natural" (Comment, July 13). He confuses the first with normal in the sense of what is usual statistically. His second sense relates to the world of birds and bees, the "non-human world". Odd behaviour there apparently justifies odd behaviour among humans on the basis that it is "natural".
fields.body:
George Monbiot knows of only two meanings of the word "natural" (Comment, July 13). He confuses the first with normal in the sense of what is usual statistically. His second sense relates to the world of birds and bees, the "non-human world". Odd behaviour there apparently justifies odd behaviour among humans on the basis that it is "natural".

In order to appreciate what the Pope means when he describes homosexual behaviour as unnatural, "contrary to the natural law", you need to have another sense of the word nature, and be able to think beyond the empirical sciences. You need to understand function and purpose, and be able to situate individual human acts harmoniously in a network of relationships creative of human society. Morality involves judgment as to what is conducive to individual and societal fulfilment. A rising statistic of hooliganism is not on the way to providing a norm of behaviour, nor does the behaviour of cat and mouse suggest a pattern of nature to be copied by humans.

George Monbiot's conclusion is so manifestly perverse as to suggest that the article is a spoof. With that key I have reread it with amusement.
Rt Rev Mario Conti
Bishop of Aberdeen

 I would not countenance unity with the Roman Church until it has reformed its attitude to sexuality. Like George Monbiot I regard this as immoral. But I object to his use of the phrase "ritual cannibalism". This is deeply offensive to the deepest sacramental Christian beliefs. To use such unnecessary insult is to undermine his case.
Rev John MacDonald Smith
Evesham, Worcestershire

 George Monbiot appears to believe that the only rationale for the Pope's complaint about the recent World Pride festival in Rome is that he must be gay. Therefore, we must conclude that Monbiot's repeated attacks on the Pope and church are due to him being a closet Catholic.
Barbara Crowther
London

webTitle: Letters: Readers comment on poverty in the UK

fields.headline: Give us the cash, Gordon
fields.trailText: I was surprised to read your story detailing school spending increases for "England and Wales" ahead of this afternoon's comprehensive spending review (Brown's budget bonanza for schools, July 17). I would point out that spending priorities here in Wales are decided on by the national assembly, not the UK government.
fields.body:
I was surprised to read your story detailing school spending increases for "England and Wales" ahead of this afternoon's comprehensive spending review (Brown's budget bonanza for schools, July 17). I would point out that spending priorities here in Wales are decided on by the national assembly, not the UK government.

Under the devolution settlement, Wales receives a proportion of UK government spending via the Barnett formula. How this total sum is distributed across health, education, transport and the other devolved areas is entirely a matter for the assembly. The crucial issue for Wales in the chancellor's statement today is how the UK government will deal with the European funds, in particular, objective one monies allocated to Wales, but paid to the Treasury by the EU. The economic regeneration of Wales depends on those funds being remitted to the assembly in addition to the Barnett funding.
Alun Pugh AM
alun.pugh@wales.gov.uk

 The argument about the numbers in poverty (Poverty gap hits Labour boasts, July 14) depends on the interpretation of statistical inequalities - household incomes below half the average. The real question is how many people have incomes too low for decent participation in social life, causing them to suffer the deprivations of health, education, housing and other social exclusions you constantly report. The evidence from the Family Budget Unit, on family and pensioner needs, suggests low incomes need raising by considerable sums before real poverty starts to reduce.

But the government persists in claiming the cause of poverty is not low incomes but personal characteristics such as unemployment, lone parenthood, disability or old age. If that were true, the royal family would be poor. The truth is that the single cause of poverty is inadequately low cash incomes.

Something the government could do which would reduce poverty - and the disillusionment which many Labour party core supporters feel - is to discover the income levels at which people suffer the deprivations it is rightly concerned about; to set dynamic minimum income standards to reflect the rising, minimally decent level of living which every political party ought to want to ensure for all the inhabitants of this rich country; and to raise the levels of all benefits and minimum wages to ensure no one falls below such minimum decency levels. If other countries' governments can manage some or all of this, why is this Labour government so timid in dealing with low- income poverty?
Prof John Veit Wilson
University of Newcastle

 You left out some key facts about the increase in household poverty. The period in question, April 97-March 99, is before the introduction of the minimum wage, working families tax credit, minimum income guarantee for pensioners and the big rise in child benefit. Even if things aren't moving as quickly as we would like, Labour has and is taking action to help people out of poverty.
Richard Burningham
Plymouth

 Polly Toynbee says everyone on working family tax credit is "guaranteed at least £214 a week" (Comment, July 14). All we are guaranteed is £85.65; the £214 is based on the assumption that the recipient of the credit is working a 36-hour week on the minimum wage. The government is anxious to see growth in the number of self-employed, who are allowed not to pay themselves the minimum wage. Quite a lot of us out there are living, and raising families, on less than half of Ms Toynbee's "guaranteed" sum.
Jenny Hardy Dingwall, Ross

webTitle: Letters: The Minister of Defence defends himself

fields.headline: Test case
fields.trailText: You claim that I had misled MPs by saying that an accident involving an RAF Chinook in 1989 was "only the result of wrong procedures" (Chinook campaigners in direct appeal to Blair, July 14).
fields.body:
You claim that I had misled MPs by saying that an accident involving an RAF Chinook in 1989 was "only the result of wrong procedures" (Chinook campaigners in direct appeal to Blair, July 14). If you had read Hansard you would have seen that what I said was that the incident concerned a case of negligence by the manufacturers during a ground test. This is factually quite correct. The MoD claimed damages from manufacturers not because of faults in the aircraft system exposed by the test, but because if adequate procedures had been in place, the malfunction would have been accommodated without damaging the aircraft. The MoD's case was therefore exactly as I described it to MPs.
Dr Lewis Moonie MP
 Ministry of Defence

webTitle: Letters: Gut reaction to Tony Blair

fields.headline: Gut reaction to Tony
fields.trailText: Now look Tory, sorry, Tony Blair. Masses of us voted for you on the ground that, if not quite Labour, at least you weren't the Tories. Now we've read your memo any lingering hopes we had about this are gone (Memo leak reveals rattled PM, July 17).
fields.body:
Now look Tory, sorry, Tony Blair. Masses of us voted for you on the ground that, if not quite Labour, at least you weren't the Tories. Now we've read your memo any lingering hopes we had about this are gone (Memo leak reveals rattled PM, July 17). You have no principles and care only for pandering to Daily Mail readers. Your attitudes on asylum seekers and on the Tony Martin case are unChristian in the extreme. (Did no one teach you in church that human life is more sacred than property?)

All this, of course, is "perception" - to quote directly from your memo. Maybe you don't really mean it. But the Tories do. And even Daily Mail readers aren't too stupid to tell the sincere from the insincere. The only people left to vote for you will be those who like the superficial conscience-salver of having voted "Labour" offset by the secret inner comfort of having really voted Tory. Maybe that will be enough, horrible thought though that is. But don't count on the necessary numbers of us being as shallow as you appear to be.
Deborah Collins
London

 Being out of touch with "gut British instincts" would represent a major strength in any government, I should have thought. Keep up the good work, Tony.
Anthony Purcell
Chelmsford, Essex

 With regard to Mr Blair's "gut British instinct" - would that be the same British gut, with "pussyhunter" tattooed on it, we saw being repatriated from Charleroi recently?
Peter Kenvyn Jones
London

webTitle: Letters: The influence of the far-right is over-estimated

fields.headline: Cooking up rightwing connections
fields.trailText: Henri Gault was not just "a sympathiser of the National Front" (Obituary, July 14). He was a member and financed its leader, the racist Jean-Marie Le Pen - an apologist for the SS who described the holocaust as "a detail of history".
fields.body:
Henri Gault was not just "a sympathiser of the National Front" (Obituary, July 14). He was a member and financed its leader, the racist Jean-Marie Le Pen - an apologist for the SS who described the holocaust as "a detail of history".

Mr Gault's influence on French cuisine is over-estimated. For example, when granting Jacques Maximin at the Chanteclair in Nice his fourth toque (the highest award of Gault-Millau), the guidebook criticised the restaurant for having "a billboard designed to solicit common passers-by". Oh la la, commoners enjoying excellence. Quel horreur! Maximin had previously earned three Michelin stars and been chosen as "best workman in France", the highest honour a French chef can achieve.

The high quality of French cuisine depends upon shared commitments of restaurants and customers. Individual critics may publicise the achievements of chefs but critics create nothing. Mr Gault will not be missed.
Brian Loughran
Antibes, France brian@riviera.fr

 Fred Pearce's article on The Ecologist's record over the last 30 years (Age of rage, July 12) was very charitable. However, it is much less charitable about me in those passages inspired by my ex-colleague Nicholas Hildyard and his guru Larry Lohmann.

My "flirtation" with the far right is a fiction. I have never had the slightest contact with any far right political party in any country. I have given two talks to new right cultural associations in France (1994) and in Belgium (1997). Everybody must be made aware of the escalating environmental destruction caused by our present economic policies if we hope to reverse them.

I do indeed believe in traditional society. For me, only a society based on the family and the community, in which people are emotionally linked to their society and the natural world by their traditions and their religion, can possibly be sustainable. However, for Hildyard and Lohmann, a religion that plays such a role is "authoritarian" and hence taboo.

However, they have their own authoritarian taboos, in particular against the expression of values that do not coincide with theirs.
Edward Goldsmith
The Ecologist
