Everybody must be made aware of the escalating environmental destruction caused by our present economic policies if we hope to reverse them. I do indeed believe in traditional society. For me, only a society based on the family and the community, in which people are emotionally linked to their society and the natural world by their traditions and their religion, can possibly be sustainable. However, for Hildyard and Lohmann, a religion that plays such a role is "authoritarian" and hence taboo. However, they have their own authoritarian taboos, in particular against the expression of values that do not coincide with theirs. Edward Goldsmith The Ecologist

fields.headline: Temple awaits another miracle
fields.standfirst: Legendary evangelist's church divided by feud over building work
fields.trailText: She was America's most famous evangelist, credited with miraculous powers and able to attract tens of thousands to her revivalist meetings.
fields.body:
She was America's most famous evangelist, credited with miraculous powers and able to attract tens of thousands to her revivalist meetings.

But today, for the first time in nearly 80 years, the temple which Aimee Semple McPherson created in Los Angeles has been closed, as the result of a fight that has split the church she founded and focused attention on leading evangelists in what is now a multi-million dollar business.

As a beautiful and charismatic young woman in the 20s, McPherson created the Foursquare Gospel Church and, with a mixture of "religious vaudeville" and "miracles", built up a devoted following. From its beginnings at the temple, the church has grown to embrace more than 3m followers in more than 100 countries.

When she died of a barbiturate overdose in 1944 at the age of 54, tens of thousands of mourners filed past her coffin. The church continued under the presidency of her son, Dr Rolf McPherson, but now the future of her mission is under threat in a battle between traditionalists and the new breed of evangelists.

At the centre of the row is the Angelus Temple, an imposing domed building overlooking Echo Park in what is now a predominantly Latino part of the city.

Vision

Dedicated in 1923, it is credited by worshippers with having been built with divine assistance: McPherson had been told that her vision of the temple was structurally impossible but she persisted and it was built according to her instructions. It houses a spectacular mural showing the second coming of Christ, one of the main tenets of the church.

Two years ago a husband and wife team, Ed and Ivy Stanton, arrived to take charge. As they saw it, the temple was run in a hopelessly old-fashioned way and was failing to attract the young. Part of the problem, they decided, was the poor lighting and acoustics, so they brought in builders to install a false ceiling which obscured the dome and mural.

"It was like deciding that Westminster Abbey wasn't contemporary enough and removing the whole of the interior," said Anna Crist, 66, a worshipper at the church. "The mural has meant so much to so many of our people."

She was also unhappy that the Stantons seemed to be preoccupied with looking for new worshippers in affluent white areas, while ignoring the poorer black and Latino parts of the city. She added that she found the new rock-based services offputting and the sermons uninspiring: "I'm not judging - God is our judge - but we were going home empty from their preaching."

She and other regulars decided to try to halt the changes and formed the Coalition to Save the Angelus Temple. They won support from the Los Angeles Conservancy, a historic preservation organisation, whose members were horrified at the plans to alter part of LA's heritage.

"It is quite astounding what they wanted to do," said Ken Bernstein, the conservancy's director of preservation issues. "This is the mother church, the centre of a large international church and it's one of only a handful of national historic landmarks in the city."

The coalition brought a civil case to halt the building works and succeeded in getting a temporary stay from the city council because the correct procedure had not been followed.

In January Dr McPherson wrote an open letter to the Stantons accusing them of fatally damaging the ministry, adding: "I don't know how you can ever restore communication and confidence if you ever want to."

He and his wife stopped worshipping at the temple and now attend a Presbyterian church in Hollywood.

The Stantons say they had no choice but to make the alterations. "To be real candid," said Pastor Ed, as he is known, "people's expectations today are very different from what they were in the 20s. People do not have the same tolerance."

He said the acoustics were so bad that some parishioners had told him it sounded like "you had marbles in your mouth", adding that many of "the old-timers" sat in the best seats and were thus unaware of the problems.

He rejected claims that the congregation had dipped from 600 to around 350, saying the opposite was true, and denied neglecting the poorer black areas. "Our staff is very multi-cultural. We are very sensitive to that."

Then, last Sunday, came a dramatic announcement from Pastor Ed - the Angelus Temple would close until further notice, and the church would move and reopen in September.

He used the occasion to attack the coalition, saying: "We do not serve structures. Structures serve people. When Jesus said he would build his church, he did not have bricks and mortar in mind, he had broken hearts in mind."

Certainly the row is about very much more than the bricks and mortar. To the traditionalists, the Stantons with their $845,000 (£565,000) home and large number of staff represent the new breed of evangelists who run the church like a business and care little for parishioners who do not fit into the target market.

Now the place where McPherson once preached to crowds of 5,000 is to stand empty and her followers are left to contemplate the message from Revelations that is carved on the temple wall: "Be thou faithful unto death and I will give thee a crown of life."

webTitle: A pedestrian club with a sole purpose

fields.headline: A pedestrian club with a sole purpose
fields.trailText: It may not rank among the great issues of the day, such as the death penalty, healthcare, or what's wrong with the Yankees' pitching staff, but there are those, none the less, who are prepared to pay the ultimate price for it.The cause? Walking around without shoes
fields.body:
It may not rank among the great issues of the day, such as the death penalty, healthcare, or what's wrong with the Yankees' pitching staff, but there are those, none the less, who are prepared to pay the ultimate price for it.

"I'll take a bullet for the cause," says Gordon Hlavenka, 42.

The cause? Walking around without shoes.

No one has been threatened with a gun yet, but members of the Dirty Sole Society do endure scorn and sneering.

Mr Hlavenka, for instance, recently strode purposefully through a bank, a market, a McDonald's restaurant and a Wal-Mart supermarket in a Chicago suburb, daring the pillars of the American mall to object to his bare feet.

A Wal-Mart employee obliged. "You can't walk around here without shoes, that's against the law."

Actually, it isn't. Nor is it illegal to drive barefoot, unless you happen to find yourself on a motorcycle in Alabama, though some other states warn against the practice.

The society, which has followers throughout the United States, exists to promote the physical and spiritual elevation it claims is to be derived from discarding socks and shoes.

Members take as one of their texts an article written in 1914 by James Leith Macbeth Bain, the Scottish mystic, poet and spiritual healer otherwise known as Brother James.

"For some years past," he wrote, "I have tasted the delight and realised the energy of the joy of drinking in the sun's heat by walking on the hot pavements of London and other cities, and even Edinburgh, the Athens of good taste . . .

"My body was simply aglow with radiant energy."

Brother James was an advocate of going hatless, too, although he did warn that doing so could result in harmful exposure to the sun.

But, he said: "I have never found that there is any such risk in the most free use and exposure of the feet to the solar energy."

Lest anyone should run away with the idea that going barefoot is something to be taken lightly, Brother Jack suggested a gradual approach involving the use of sandals in public as the first step.

The compromise appealed to Mr Hlavenka when he decided three years ago that something really must be done about the pungent whiff emanating from his sneakers.

At first he would tip-toe around the block in the dead of night when he was sure the neighbours would not see him. In time he progressed to slipping into petrol stations to buy cartons of milk. And now, his pleasure no longer a secret, he does everything, including shovelling snow, in his bare feet.

Well, almost everything: he wears shoes to church.

Mr Hlavenka is by no means the sole warrior in the barefoot battle. The society has about 600 members, and among the heroes of the struggle are a violinist who plays concerts in Manhattan in the regulation tuxedo but without benefit of shoes; a Methodist minister in Saratoga Springs, New York, who performs services and weddings barefoot; and a software engineer in Ohio who was sent for psychological evaluation after presenting himself for work wearing nothing below the ankles.

"The Dirty Sole Society is open to all who enjoy going barefoot everywhere regardless of age, gender, nationality, race, religion or sexual orientation," its manifesto says.

But there is much work still to be done. Consider the indignity visited upon the society's founder.

Paul Lucas of Mountain View, California, was ejected from the Billy DeFrank Lesbian and Gay community centre in San Jose because it was afraid it would be sued if his feet were injured.

webTitle: 58 die as plane crashes into housing estate in India

fields.headline: 58 die as plane crashes into housing estate in India
fields.trailText: A Boeing 737-200 crashed into a government housing estate and burst into flames in Bihar, India, yesterday, killing 58 people.
fields.body:
A Boeing 737-200 crashed into a government housing estate and burst into flames in Bihar, India, yesterday, killing 58 people.

Witnesses said one of the engines of the 20-year-old Alliance Air plane was on fire as it came in to land at Patna, about 650 miles south-east of New Delhi.

Amit Khare, a district magistrate, said 51 of the 58 people on board, including the crew of six, died, together with four residents of the estate.

A survivor said he felt sudden vibrations before the twin-engined plane plummeted to the ground.

Within hours, critics were lining up to blame the government for its failure to ensure civil aviation safety. "Be ready to hear 'pilot error'," the Air Traffic Controllers' Guild said.

Bratin Sengupta MP said a parliamentary standing committee had repeatedly warned about Alliance Air's fleet. "During several meetings of the committee we pointed out that many aircraft of Alliance Air are old and need to be replaced."

webTitle: TV film shows army bias in Moluccas fighting Indonesia

fields.headline: TV film shows army bias in Moluccas fighting Indonesia
fields.trailText: Independent television footage has proved for the first time that Indonesian soldiers sent to restore order in the Molucca islands are fighting alongside militant Muslims against the Christians they are supposed to be protecting.
fields.body:
Independent television footage has proved for the first time that Indonesian soldiers sent to restore order in the Molucca islands are fighting alongside militant Muslims against the Christians they are supposed to be protecting.

The evidence, which confirms the suspicion that government troops are exacerbating the sectarian conflict, coincides with President Abdurrahman Wahid's admission that he may ask for international assistance in solving the crisis.

Filmed at the weekend during a street battle in the region's main city, Ambon, the Associated Press Television News pictures show several Indonesian soldiers giving covering fire to about a dozen Muslim fighters.

Many of the civilians were armed with automatic weapons, including domestically made rifles which are issued only to the armed forces.

At nightfall, as houses and and churches burned, an army armoured car rumbled down the road to help the Muslims.

The fact that several of the Muslims were heard speaking in Javanese rather than Indonesian or a local dialect suggests that they were members of Laskar Jihad, a fanatical Javanese organisation which sent several thousand fighters to the Moluccas in May to help the Muslim war effort.

More than 40 people have been killed in Ambon in the past few days, including a pregnant Christian woman and her child, who died when a mortar round exploded in their home.

Of the 20 fatalities at the weekend, 13 were Christians and seven were Muslims.

More than 3,000 people have been killed and 500,000 left homeless since the fighting began in January last year.

There have been many reports that some sections of the security forces, particularly local police units, have sided with the Christians and given them automatic weapons

The defence minister, Juw ono Sudharsono, said in a newspaper interview on Saturday that he was powerless to intervene in the chain of command to ensure the replacement of the partisan troops.

"All I can give is advice and policy inputs to rehabilitate the entire army," he said.

Mr Sudharsono reiterated the widely held belief that the "rogue officers" were associated with "cronies" of the former presidents General Suharto and BJ Habibie.

Although he once again ruled out foreign military intervention in the crisis, Mr Wahid said yesterday that he might be willing to accept more than humanitarian assistance.

"If we cannot manage any more, we may cry for support in logistics and equipment only from abroad . . . not more than that," he told a meeting of provincial governors.

At a meeting with European Union ambassadors he said he hoped to lift soon the restrictions on foreign aid and media access to the region imposed last month when a state of civil emergency was declared.

"We very much hope that following this meeting that international NGOs will be allowed back into the Moluccas very soon," the British ambassador, Sir Robin Christopher, said, adding that this would initially be done through the United Nations Development Programme.

Sir Robin denied that Mr Wahid was under official pressure to allow foreign peacekeepers into the Moluccas.

"This remains a domestic problem for Indonesia and we think it is very important that the Indonesian government sorts it out," he said.

Thick smog from forest fires in Indonesia blanketed parts of Sumatra yesterday and reduced visibility in Malaysia.

The pall, caused by fires deliberately set to clear land for plantations, raised the fear of another health crisis like that of 1997, when forest-fire smoke covered several parts of south-east Asia, prompting thousands of tourists to cancel their visits .

Environmentalists have criticised governments in the region for not learning the lesson and not giving more information about the health risks.

fields.headline: Philippine rebels free sick hostage
fields.trailText: Muslim guerrillas in the southern Philippines have freed the first European among the 35 hostages they have been holding for almost three months.
fields.body:
Muslim guerrillas in the southern Philippines have freed the first European among the 35 hostages they have been holding for almost three months.

Renate Allert, 56, a German, was handed over yesterday by the Abu Sayyaf rebel group to the Philippine government's chief negotiator, Robert Aventajado, near the rebel's camp on the island of Jolo.

Her husband and son are among those still being held.

As she was released, the army accused another Muslim separatist group in the same region of shooting dead 21 people it seized on Sunday.

"She was released purely as a goodwill gesture," Mr Aventajado told a local radio station, implying that no ransom had been paid. The rebels have demanded $1m for each hostage. Some officials say it will be impossible to secure the release of the others without money changing hands.

Mrs Wallert has been suffering from hypertension and chest pains, according to doctors who visited the rebel camp. Her husband Werner collapsed 10 days ago after a party to celebrate the 25th birthday of their son, Marc.

They were among the 21 people seized from the Malaysian resort island of Sipaden on April 23. Thirteen Philippine evangelists and four European journalists have been kidnapped since then.

"My family didn't come out today so I'm not totally happy," Mrs Wallert said after being flown to Zamboanga city. "I hope the others will be released very soon, but I have no idea when this might happen."

Abu Sayyaf commanders had previously released two Malaysians. One of them, Abdul Jawa Salawat, said yesterday that he was told just before his release on Friday that all the hostages would be freed in a few days.

There have been many false dawns in the crisis, but many people believe the hostages will soon be free. "These things have a habit of lasting about three months and so we are not too surprised that it seems to be unwinding now," a police spokesman said.

Last night the army said the biggest Muslim rebel group, the Moro Islamic Liberation Front, murdered 21 people in a mosque in Lanao del Sur province on the island of Mindanao. It said the victims were among 29 people kidnapped on Sunday and that they were executed the same day. The front blamed the military for the killings.

webTitle: Rape photo 'used as blackmail to commit murder'

fields.headline: Rape photo 'used as blackmail to commit murder'
fields.trailText: A husband blackmailed his best friend into murdering his wife by producing a photograph he had kept secret for 10 years of the friend being raped by two men, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A husband blackmailed his best friend into murdering his wife by producing a photograph he had kept secret for 10 years of the friend being raped by two men, a court heard yesterday.

The friend, Darren Lake, 31, told Nottingham crown court that Colin Harrold, 35, produced the photo after offering to pay him £20,000 to kill his second wife, Diane Harrold, 36, and dump her body in the swimming pool at the couple's £330,000 home in Uffington, Lincolnshire.

Harrold allegedly told Lake that, if he did not agree to the murder, he would send the picture to Lake's father, girlfriend and ex-girlfriend. Lake feared it would jeopardise his visiting rights to his seven-year-old son, he told the court.

Lake, who was best man at Harrold's first wedding, has admitted to killing Mrs Harrold with a wooden post last October. Harrold denies murder and conspiracy to murder.

Lake told the jury Harrold asked him to kill Mrs Harrold six weeks earlier while he was at the house doing work for him. "He took me out to the pool and said, 'I have a proposition for you - 20 grand to knock off Diane'."

Though Lake had debts and needed money, "I couldn't believe what he was saying. I was shocked. Then he brought out a photograph - a picture of me 10 years ago. I was 20, and on holiday with Colin Harrold in Tenerife, my first trip abroad.

"The picture was of me being raped by two guys."

Lake told the court that it had happened when he had gone for a drink with three men after Harrold had gone to bed one night. He became "totally drunk" and two of the men took him to a beach and raped him. One of them had taken Lake's camera from his denim jacket, photographed the rape, then put the camera back - although Lake did not know this.

When he got back, grazed and bruised, he told Harrold he had fallen down stairs. Lake told the court he gave Harrold the holiday films to develop, but had no idea the rape picture existed. When he saw it, "My world caved in."

webTitle: Dumped islanders seek to return home

fields.headline: Dumped islanders seek to return home
fields.trailText: The British government removed Indian ocean islanders from their homeland to make way for a US military base in a plot designed to avoid the attention of the outside world, the high court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
The British government removed Indian ocean islanders from their homeland to make way for a US military base in a plot designed to avoid the attention of the outside world, the high court heard yesterday.

Hundreds of Ilois, the islanders, were forced to leave the Chagos archipelago and unlawfully "dumped" on the dockside at Mauritius in what their counsel, Sir Sydney Kentridge QC, described as "a very sad and by no means creditable episode in British history".

Documents read out in court revealed the lengths to which the late 1960s Labour government went to conceal the truth. Key to the scheme's success, in the words of Whitehall officials, was "to maintain the pretence there were no permanent inhabitants". That was essential to avoid having to recognise them as people "whose democratic rights have to be safeguarded".

The attitude of the Foreign Office was reflected in an exchange between diplomats in 1966. "We must surely be very tough about this," noted Sir Paul Gore-Booth, the FO's top official. "The object of the the exercise was to get some rocks which will remain ours ." Referring to a UN body on women's issues, he added: "There will be no indigenous population except seagulls who have not yet got a committee (the status of women committee does not cover the rights of birds)".

Dennis Greenhill, a diplomat, replied: "Unfortunately along with birds go some few Tarzans or Man Fridays whose origins are obscure, and who are being hopefully wished on to Mauritius."

The action is being brought by Olivier Bancoult, chairman of the Chagos refugee group in Mauritius.

Sir Sydney told Lord Justice Laws and Mr Justice Gibbs that between 1967 and 1973 Britain removed the entire population - 2,000 people, according to the islanders, half that number according to the British government. "It is not in dispute that this was done without the consent of the Ilois, without consultation with the Ilois and without any arrangements for their re-settlement."

Sir Sydney described how in 1965 the Chagos islands were split off from Mauritius, then a British colony, and made a separate colony, the British Indian Ocean Territory.

Whitehall claimed the territory's constitution was to promote "peace, order, and good government", or Pogg. In fact, it was to allow the US to build an air and naval base on Diego Garcia, the group's largest atoll.

The US had insisted the islands should be under direct UK control "to avoid any political difficulties". It also insisted that the permanent population should be removed.

London drew up an immigration ordinance in 1971 whereby entry would be strictly controlled by permit. "Its validity is at the heart of this case," Sir Sydney said. The islanders say it breached article 29 of the Magna Carta which forbids the banishment of citizens of the realm.

The ordinance, he told the court, was designed "to conceal the true facts relating to the population, to avoid as far as possible and for as long as possible, any financial, legal, or moral responsibility for the plight of the Ilois".

The intention was to ensure the islanders should not be regarded as permanent inhabitant and that they would be "evacuated as and when defence interests require this".

Documents released at the public record office also show that FO officials privately acknowledged they were open to "charges of dishonesty" and were "indulging in a policy of quiet disregard" to "minimise adverse reaction" to US plans to set up a base. They referred to "old fashioned" concerns about "whopping fibs". The documents also reveal that Anthony Greenwood, the colonial secretary, warned in 1965 that it was "important to present the UN with a fait accompli".

The ultimate decision to deny the islanders their rights was taken by two prime ministers, Sir Sydney said, referring to Harold Wilson and his Tory successor, Edward Heath.

The islanders insist they do not want to interfere with the large US air base which was used by B52 bombers during the 1991 Gulf war. They want to resettle in outlying islands and in areas on Diego Garcia not used by the US military.

Baroness Scotland, the FO minister responsible for dependent territories, said in a statement that the government was seeking the advice of consultants "to asess whether people could return to the outer islands and what the environmental impact would be".

The territory is directly administered by Britain.

webTitle: One in 100 women may have hepatitis C virus

fields.headline: One in 100 women may have hepatitis C virus
fields.trailText: Almost one in a hundred women in the UK may be infected with the potentially fatal hepatitis C virus, according to a study published yesterday.
fields.body:
Almost one in a hundred women in the UK may be infected with the potentially fatal hepatitis C virus, according to a study published yesterday.

The rate of infection has prompted authorities to call for a national screening programme of pregnant women.

Antenatal screening for the hepatitis C virus (HCV) could lead to earlier diagnosis and treatment and reduce long-term complications of the disease, such as liver damage and cancer, said the study, published in the medical journal Gut.

About 400,000 people in the UK are diagnosed with hepatitis C, but many more may unknowingly have the virus and show no symptoms. It is transmitted sexually or through blood. Researchers for the study tested more than 4,000 pregnant women for HCV when they went for their first antenatal appointment at St Mary's hospital in London between 1997 and 1999.

They found that 0.8% of the mothers-to-be tested positive for hepatitis C infection - and that two thirds of those who were positive did not know they were infected.

The report's author, Tina Cotzias, said: "It is noteworthy that a high proportion of our infected mothers attended for further follow-up and treatment, whereas patients with HCV in other settings have a high prevalence of subsequent non-attendance.

"Antenatal screening may therefore identify infected women when they are most receptive to medical intervention."

webTitle: United's new man plots global domination

fields.headline: United's new man plots global domination
fields.standfirst:
Better the red devil you don't know
City support for the Red revolution
fields.trailText: Peter Kenyon launched a new era at Manchester United yesterday, promising to improve the club's image and relationship with fans while raising its global standing by exploiting new technology and developing Far Eastern markets.
fields.body:
Peter Kenyon launched a new era at Manchester United yesterday, promising to improve the club's image and relationship with fans while raising its global standing by exploiting new technology and developing Far Eastern markets.

Kenyon, who takes over as chief executive on August 1, immediately distanced himself from his predecessor Martin Edwards, who in 20 years at the club has come under increasing criticism for the way he has treated fans and dealt with team issues.

Though Edwards will remain a non-executive director of Manchester United plc and will continue his duties as non-executive chairman of Manchester United FC, his resignation is being seen as a victory for those who opposed him within Old Trafford.

Kenyon immediately set out to win over supporters and the manager, Sir Alex Ferguson, who endured an uneasy relationship with Edwards.

Kenyon is expected to oversee the Old Trafford image makeover by appointing a communications director by the end of this month, establishing a fans' forum and launching a customer charter in an attempt to make fans feel a part of the £1bn empire.

"No business or brand can afford to ignore the opinions of its supporters or customers," Kenyon said yesterday.

"We have had a tremendous amount of success over the past 10 years but I am aware that our public image is not as good as it might be and that is something which concerns me. There is so much about this club to be proud of and we should be pushing that forward."

The new chief executive is also expected to lead United's advance in the Far East, where they have millions of fans, and to cash in on internet and secondary television rights, which could lead to a massive increase in revenue.

"I will continue to look at a number of opportunities for the business, including attacking the communications arena," said Kenyon, who has extensive experience with the sports industry, having made his name with Umbro.

Kenyon's appointment will be welcomed by Ferguson, who was barely on talking terms with Edwards and found him difficult to deal with when it came to transfers and player contracts.

The two men fell out over a number of issues. Many blame Edwards for not making sufficient money available for Ferguson to compete with the continent's biggest clubs in signing the best players.

Ferguson is due to stand down in two years' time, but Kenyon said yesterday that he wanted the manager to stay.

"What we have got is the best manager, who has done a fantastic job for us," Kenyon said.

"Nobody in their right minds would want to change a winning formula.

"It is incredible to think there is so much speculation surrounding something which is still two years away but when the time is right we will sit down and discuss the options with Sir Alex."

Edwards, despite his unpopularity among fans, will be used as a roving ambassador by United and continue to represent the club at Premier League meetings. Edwards has stated his desire to be chairman of Manchester United plc but that is unlikely to happen given the number of people who oppose him on the board and among shareholders.

Analysts said yesterday that despite Kenyon's support for United there is unlikely to be a complete untying of the purse strings and that the club is unlikely to compete with the likes of Lazio and Barcelona in the transfer market. He could, however, introduce more flexibility in the pay structure in an attempt to hold on to the club's biggest names. The captain Roy Keane almost left the club last year because of a contract dispute that many felt was badly handled by Edwards.

An analyst said: "Not breaking the bank has brought United positive results so why would they want to change a winning formula? They are not going to go out there and spend like mad."

United supporters welcomed Kenyon's appointment. A spokesman for the Independent Manchester United Supporters Association said: "Kenyon is aware that there is bad blood between the supporters and the board. His appointment is good for the club and we look forward to meeting him. He comes across as an honest, reasonable man who is prepared to listen to us."

webTitle: Better the red devil you don't know

fields.headline: Better the red devil you don't know
fields.standfirst:
Why Edwards had to go: Cautious thrift was fine for a cornershop but not for United
New man plots global domination
City support for the Red revolution
fields.trailText: Why Edwards had to go Cautious thrift was fine for a cornershop but not for United, says Jim White.
fields.body:
Just after half-time at this year's FA Cup final, there was a commotion among the Aston Villa fans. A wave of applause broke out as the beaming, white-haired figure of the Villa chairman Doug Ellis made his way past them on Wembley's cinder track, occasionally pausing to sign autographs for cheery young supporters.

It is hard to imagine Martin Edwards in the same circumstances. Among United fans, Edwards is a figure of loathing. Besides, strolling along the touchline engaging with his customers has never been the United chief executive's way.

He has always preferred to draw as little attention as possible to himself, keen to keep the arclight of publicity with its attendant intrusion into his personal business at arm's length. And this week, he is making an equally unobtrusive withdrawal from the corridors of power at Old Trafford, standing down as chief executive after nearly 20 years in charge without fuss or flurry, depriving his critics of the opportunity to revel in a forced departure.

In many ways, it ought to be the other way round: Edwards glowing in his fans' admiration, while Ellis steals in through the back door. While Ellis presides over a club that has consistently underachieved during his tenure, Edwards can point to an astonishing history of success on and off the field.

"What more do they want?" he has been known to observe to colleagues. "We've given them everything from the treble to the best stadium in the country and still they hate me."

Tellingly, though, there appear to have been no behind-the-scenes deals desperately trying to keep Edwards in charge. Nor is the queue of other major companies wishing to tap into his expertise by offering him a directorship forming up along Sir Matt Busby Way. The news that he is to step down has been greeted at the club with a sigh of relief, as if an embarrassing relative has finally gone home, allowing everyone else to get on with the party.

The reason Edwards is now quietly being allowed to relinquish power is the same as the root cause of his loathing among the fans. Worries have been growing within the organisation for some time that the way in which Edwards prefers to take business decisions to protect existing holdings is no longer compatible with the requirements of one of the country's biggest plcs.

His 20 years in control have been characterised by extreme monetary caution. Apart from an ill-fated move into basketball, he has acted slowly and conservatively. It could be said that much of the team's success on the field has been achieved in spite of Edwards. Luckily for him, his reluctance to sanction big-money buys and his imposition of a rigid pay structure have been more than offset by Sir Alex Ferguson's gifted man management.

And unlike Ellis at Villa, not one stand, not one player, not one megastore at Old Trafford has been financed from Edwards's pocket. The traffic has all been in the other direction: an estimated personal wealth of £100m from an investment of less than £100,000. Fans resent it, and the city does not find such tunnel vision a particularly attractive trait in chief executives either. Such caution might pass muster in a corner shop, but shareholders of large plcs want companies to grow and develop; they want entrepreneurial zest at the helm.

The United website saga is a perfect example of the Edwards problem. When Peter Kenyon suggested that a site should be set up, Edwards insisted it should be a subscription service: here was the opportunity to extract yet more cash out of the fan base. He was persuaded it should be free only after it was pointed out the investment costs were minimal. Within six months of starting up, it was the most visited site in China, news that sent the United share value over £1bn.

For the past year the chairman of Manchester United plc, Sir Roland Smith, has been manoeuvring an alternative to Edwards into place, sensing that in the new era of the football business, clubs require dynamic leadership.

Edwards's fellow board members might have over-looked many things - trouble with prostitutes, appaling public relations, even a corrosive rift with the company's two most significant employees, Ferguson and Roy Keane - but they could not ignore his inability to seize the broader picture.

Perhaps he saw the end himself. When he tried to sell United to Rupert Murdoch, he claimed the £87m he would have gained personally was only incidental. He was doing it, he said, because to go on into the new era, United needed new management ideas. The Murdoch bid may have failed, but at least Edwards can comfort himself that as of today the business his father left him has its new management.

fields.standfirst:
The challenge: Kenyon has to convince United fans as well as the shareholders
Better the red devil you don't know
New man plots global domination
fields.trailText: The challenge: Kenyon has to convince United fans as well as the shareholders.
fields.body:
Peter Kenyon marched on to centre stage at the Theatre of Dreams yesterday with all the confidence of a seasoned performer and delivered the sort of speech that should go some way towards persuading Manchester United fans that the days of the club's principal cast member making a drama out of a crisis are over.

United's all-powerful plc board finally confirmed yesterday what everyone had known for months: Martin Edwards was being replaced by a balding young prince who hopes everyone will live happily ever after.

On August 1, after a three-year apprenticeship, the 46-year-old Stalybridge-born Kenyon will take on one of the best jobs in football. In an instant it will elevate him from relative obscurity to a position of unrivalled profile, potential and possible pitfalls.

"Obviously having grown up just eight miles from here it's a dream job for me," he said. "It's a great opportunity and one that I have been working towards ever since I joined the club."

He also spoke admiringly of Sir Alex Ferguson, who has endured an uneasy relationship with Edwards. "I'd love Sir Alex to stay when his current contract expires. He has become the the most successful manager in our history and my attitude is that if it ain't broke we shouldn't fix it."

The words will have soothed the nerves of several of Kenyon's fellow board members and City advisers who have been agitated by the deterioration in Edwards's relationship with the club's supporters and a series of publicity gaffes.

Kenyon has made it his immediate priority to appoint a director of communications by the start of the season. The candidate must fulfil a range of roles from projecting a positive image of one of Britain's 250 biggest companies to updating the press on groin injuries.

"Being a global club brings with it new responsibilities and gone are the days when anything we do is quiet and unnoticed," Kenyon said. "We have learnt from all our overseas forays and the thing is we have got to get better at communication. It's our No1 priority for 2000."

Fans' forums are to be set up and a customer charter is to be adopted, allowing the club to be "more up front" about issues such as the frequency of its kit changes. Kenyon says he wants to work with the groups that have tended to be most critical of Edwards, such as the Independent Manchester United Supporters Association and Shareholders United.

The credentials Kenyon can offer United supporters are undoubted. He went to his first game with his dad in 1968 - the European Cup victory at Wembley. Edwards, on the other hand, has had to live with accusations of preferring rugby and Alderley Edge cricket club to football.

Kenyon joined the United board in 1997 after stints working in the United States and latterly with the sportswear manufacturer Umbro. He has quickly and quietly stamped his authority on the club.

He received praise in the City for the handling of United's search for a new shirt sponsor, which led to Vodafone signing a £30m four-year deal that will eventually allow fans to view video clips of goals on mobile phone screens.

Yet it is this sort of shareholder-friendly deal that could place Kenyon at odds with United supporters. As chief executive of a plc his first responsibility is to his investors and he is unlikely to sanction the huge spending spree on players that the fans crave.

Kenyon plans to please his shareholders by expanding United's global merchandising operation and turning manutd.com, the club's official website, into a vehicle through which fans around the world can interact with the club and view highlights of games.

It will also enable United to cash in on areas such as China, where it is estimated to have 12m fans. But Kenyon insists that United will not be flying around the world to appease sponsors and media companies.

"Much about United is sacrosanct and should not be bastardised in any way," he said. "If it doesn't fit, we shouldn't do it. Manchester United will be here long after I've gone. We're not in it to make a quick buck."

fields.headline: Brazil's frail troubadour
fields.standfirst: Joao Gilberto Barbican, London ***
fields.trailText: Joao Gilberto Barbican, London ***
fields.body:
Try this for an example of musical minimalism: a man sits on a stool before a single microphone at the centre of a stage which is otherwise empty save for two black monitor speakers. He wear spectacles, and is dressed in a grey suit and tie. Very quietly, for nearly two hours, he sings in Portuguese and plays acoustic guitar, making no announcements between songs.

This is what the weekend's concert was like, when the Brazilian jazz star Joao Gilberto made his British debut at the age of 69. Though he has been a prominent figure in the jazz scene since the 50s, he's an unlikely figure for a solo artist. You feel he would like to be at the back of the band, creating the perfect setting for the ones in the spotlight, as he did for Astrud Gilberto and Stan Getz on some classic 60s albums.

It is an extraordinary thing to see a performer of this age so exposed. Though the concept - voice and guitar - is simple, the music is rhythmically and melodically complex. And was there ever a style of popular music with chord sequences as labyrinthine as bossa nova's? The youthful voice of the records has changed, but the guitar sounds much the same. He never drops a note: the accompaniment to great songs such as Corcovado, Chega de Saudade and Besame Mucho is crisp and full of feeling. Gilberto sings more like a jazz singer now, his voice sliding across the beat, testing the limits of the genre. It's a frail instrument: for some of the descending phrases in Jobim's Vou te Contar the notes dissolve into an unpitched whisper.

Yet among friends (and most of his repertoire was greeted with respectful cries of recognition and applause) he can take chances. You marvel at his ability to retain the pulse while singing so freely, and then recall that he began his career as a drummer.

In the sold out auditorium there was a devotional air similar to that of Nina Simone's Meltdown concert last summer - even a moment of drama at the start when the lights went down and Gilberto failed to appear for a minute or so. The shy and the bespectacled could identify quietly with a man whose sensitivity to love's slings and arrows was expressed as deeply as any diva.

fields.headline: Conga creative
fields.standfirst: Giovanni Hidalgo Queen Elizabeth Hall, London ****
fields.trailText: Giovanni Hidalgo Queen Elizabeth Hall, London ****
fields.body:
The South Bank's annual Rhythm Sticks Festival is devoted not to a star, but to the tradition and languages of the world's percussion music. Rather than encouraging them simply to play their album-promotions, the festival regularly hurls some of the most creative percussionists in the business into open situations with unfamiliar partners.

On the opening night, the star was Giovanni Hidalgo, the 37-year-old Puerto Rican widely regarded now as the world's best conga player. He performed as an unaccompanied soloist, as part of an impromptu four-piece percussion ensemble, and more or less as contented sideman in a jamming Latin ensemble that eventually had the entire audience of the QEH on its feet and gyrating.

His resourcefulness and range of sound from an orthodox conga set and assorted percussion props is breathtaking. Sometimes his playing suggests a herd of galloping horses, sometimes scores of pattering feet. Then he toys with drum-melodies, almost idly struck patterns of sounds using the tunings of the congas, periodically bent in pitch by the robust application of the elbow.

Hidalgo's sound has a remarkable softness and pliability as well as power - and at times a liquidity and force at once, like torrential rain on a roof. The chattering sounds he makes with his nails echoes the flying rhythms of Indian as much as Latin music. Hidalgo played a long unaccompanied solo in each half, and had loosened so much by the second one that he seemed ready to go on all night. There would have been plenty of support for it.

fields.headline: The not good enough syndrome
fields.trailText: 18 July: I jumped at an exciting new job three months ago. But now I feel as is I could get sacked at any time.
fields.body:
The problem

I started a new job about 3 months ago. I was doing a dreary admin job I hated and I jumped at this opportunity when it came along a large pay rise and responsibility. But now I feel as if I am being watched by management and could at any time get screamed at or fired on the spot for no reason.

It isn't something that just bothers me because it seems to be rife throughout the whole company. It has got to the point where I am considering giving up the new salary and responsibility because I feel so insecure.

The solution

I don't know if this is about you or the company. You say it seems rife throughout the company, so perhaps there is a climate of fear in which managers think that it is appropriate to use threats and abuse to get staff to do what they want. Yet, you don't mention any of this in your letter, nor do you give any examples of instances where you have been screamed at or witnessed anyone else being screamed at.

This leads me to suspect that it isn't so much the company that is making you feel insecure, but you yourself. I think that you might be suffering from the very common not good enough syndrome that is particularly common amongst women.

Basically, people who achieve or who are successful, often feel that they have only managed this through luck and that any moment now, someone will suss them out and realise that they are not good enough after all. Your sudden rise up the career ladder would make you an ideal candidate for this syndrome.

You need to convince yourself that you are good enough and that you were offered the opportunity through merit, not luck. Your performance is good, so why should you be fired? And anyway, it isn't actually that easy to fire someone once they have been in position for six months since you might have a claim for unfair dismissal. So, the longer you are employed, the more you can relax about both your being good enough and their ability to get rid of you even if you weren't

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

fields.headline: Proud Tina's twilight
fields.standfirst: Tina Turner Wembley Stadium **
fields.trailText: Tina Turner Wembley Stadium **
fields.body:
When Tina Turner promises to "take you on a journey of my career", you expect something very special. Almost swallowed up by her huge, futuristic stage set, Turner rasps her way through her hits. From the full-throttle rock of River Deep, Mountain High to her scary alter ego the Acid Queen from The Who's rock opera Tommy, giant screens reflect black-and-white images of the old Turner, showing how much better she looks now than she ever did back then.

But while there's admiration, there's very little atmosphere or excitement tonight. There are the usual big-show antics - flames appear at the side of the stage, fireworks light the sky - but nothing can escape the feeling that it's all a bit average. While Turner claims to like her music "nice and rough", most of her show is spent taking it slow and easy.

It's only in the last 45 minutes of this two-hour set that the show takes on a life of its own. The Best gets everyone on their feet, What's Love Got to do With It gets them singing and Proud Mary is fantastic, all guts and spirit, just what Turner does so well. It's just a shame it took her so long to do it.

fields.headline: B&B wins 90% windfall majority
fields.standfirst: The big vote: Borrowers and investors back conversion despite warning of higher mortgage rates
fields.trailText: About 90% of Bradford & Bingley building society members voted for its conversion to a bank despite the institution's warnings last year that this would mean more expensive mortgages and lower savings rates, it was revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
About 90% of Bradford & Bingley building society members voted for its conversion to a bank despite the institution's warnings last year that this would mean more expensive mortgages and lower savings rates, it was revealed yesterday.

The overwhelming vote in support of conversion means Bradford & Bingley will float on the stock market on December 4, triggering windfalls officially estimated at between £647 and £815 per member. More than 2.5m savers and borrowers will benefit from the payouts.

At a special meeting in Sheffield Arena yesterday, it was announced that 1,506,866 investors voted by post in favour of demutualisation - about 94% - with 89,833 voting against it. A total of 170,863 mortgage customers also backed conversion, with 17,913 voting against, a ratio of 89% to 11%.

About 500 people attended yesterday's meeting, though nearly all the members cast their votes in a postal ballot.

The result was welcomed by the B&B board, which had originally opposed conversion but changed tack 15 months ago after a previous ballot showed members firmly in favour of a stock market flotation and windfalls.

Pro-mutuality campaigners attacked the move claiming that members would now get poorer rates on their savings and mortgages. In the literature it distributed early last year, B&B said that if it became a bank, "we would have to raise mortgage rates and lower savings rates".

Bob Goodall of the Save Our Building Societies campaign group said: "Short-term gain has won over common sense. It seems that turkeys do vote for Christmas."

The view that B&B members will pay for their windfalls with poorer rates is supported by some City analysts. One said: "B&B have already been moving away from the general level of rates paid by mutuals in anticipation of the need to increase profits to pay dividends to future shareholders." Its present mortgage rate is 7.64% - significantly higher than the 7.29% charged by Nationwide, the biggest building society.

Commenting on the result, B&B's chairman, Lindsay Mackinlay, said: "Based on this clear mandate, we can now proceed to float on the stock market. Eligible members can now look forward to receiving free shares and to becoming shareholders in a business with a record of success and a dynamic strategy for the future".

Bradford & Bingley is Britain's second largest building society and has more than 3m customers and total assets of £24bn. The group has 600 branches, including 370 estate agencies.

Mr Mackinlay pledged that no jobs would go or branches close as a direct result of demutualisation, and he fended off accusations that members of the board would benefit most from the conversion.

B&B controversially decided on a "flat-rate" share distribution scheme where every member receives the same size windfall - 250 shares - regardless of the size of their financial relationship with the society. Some analysts expected a rival bank to buy B&B before flotation, but a bid has failed to materialise.

Yesterday's vote result will put the spotlight on the remaining building societies but most of these have strong defences in place against so-called carpetbaggers. The majority of the large players require new members to sign away potential windfalls to charity.

webTitle: Classical music review: The Voluptuous Tango

fields.headline: Futurist and fantasist
fields.standfirst: The Voluptuous Tango Hoxton Hall, London ****
fields.trailText: The Voluptuous Tango Hoxton Hall, London ****
fields.body:
What began life for radio - composer Dominic Muldowney's The Voluptuous Tango won a Prix Italia in 1997 - has now been transformed into very effective music theatre.

Muldowney's exploration of a fictional encounter in Paris in 1932 between the Italian futurist and fascist Filippo Marinetti and the dancer Isadora Duncan uses the Habanera from Bizet's Carmen as its musical starting point, but then gradually expands to take in other tangos as the emotional temperature rises and the confrontation reaches its literal and metaphorical climax.

The text by David Zane Marowitz is very funny. Marinetti plies Isadora, who is hunting for a genius to father her next child, with recipes from his Futurist Cookbook. Their conversation switchbacks from mussels to Mussolini, but the dancer is repelled, and after the gastronomic foreplay Marinetti resorts to the Futurist Manifesto of Love-Making with equally unsuccessful results. There's a lot of speech, but Muldowney also gives both of them set-piece songs, numbers which hover between Eisler and Sondheim.

The staging uses the electronic soundtrack realised by Ian Dearden, with its collages of tangos and street noises, which formed the basis for the radio version but the voices - Marinetti, Duncan and a male chorus of four, who represent Marinetti's unspoken thoughts - are live; Di Trevis's production also added a pair of dancers who act out the manoeuvrings between the ill-matched couple. It was brilliantly realised - Richard Morris as a transcendentally arrogant Marinetti, Jenna Russell as Isadora, with Nicholas Johnson and Isabel Baquero as the poker-faced dancers - and a lot of fun too; Muldowney and Trevis have transformed The Voluptuous Tango in a theatre piece that will wear very well.

fields.headline: Markets merger mapped
fields.standfirst: Milan and Madrid join talks on forming pan-European exchange
fields.trailText: A combative Don Cruickshank, only recently enthroned as chairman of the London stock exchange, set out a vision of creating an international business-to-business e-commerce company yesterday as he gave details of the controversial plan to merge the London and Frankfurt stock markets.
fields.body:
A combative Don Cruickshank, only recently enthroned as chairman of the London stock exchange, set out a vision of creating an international business-to-business e-commerce company yesterday as he gave details of the controversial plan to merge the London and Frankfurt stock markets.

"The thought of a London-based stock exchange will soon almost be forgotten," he declared as he and his opposite number at Deutsche Börse, Werner Seifert, confirmed that talks to bring Nasdaq, the high-technology market, into a three-way merger were under way.

Merger talks are also being held with the Milan and Madrid bourses.

Mr Cruickshank, chairman designate of the proposed Anglo-German iX international exchange, where Mr Seifert will be chief executive, was speaking as documentation was published mapping the planned £75m merger ahead of a make-or-break shareholder vote on September 14.

London stock market authorities are pressing on with the plan in the face of resistance from dozens of smaller British brokerages which fear a large portion of their business dealing in small and medium sized companies will migrate to Frankfurt.

Initially the London exchange would take responsibility for trading in European blue-chip shares and the Germans would handle younger, smaller hi-tech issues.

For the merger to go ahead some 75% of the London exchange's 298 broking members must vote in favour.

In an attempt to placate those smaller broking houses which fear crippling costs for technology in swapping over to Frankfurt's Xetra Dax trading system, Mr Cruickshank yesterday announced subsidies of £30,000 per firm, although the response from market participants was dismissive.

"Assistance with conversion costs from Sets [the trading system in London] to Xetra is welcome, but without the IT specification who is to say it is enough?" asked Angela Knight, chief executive of the Association of Private Client Investment Managers. "The money on offer represents only about one week's work for a team of small systems engineers."

On the subject of market regulation, which will be split between London and Frankfurt, she said: "The regulatory authorities are confirmed, but not how they will work together. We are told what the new markets will be, but not how they will interlink."

Critics also claim that the issue of clearing and settlement of trades is being fudged, with transactions being split between CrestCo in Britain and Clearstream in Germany.

Cost savings from the merger are expected to be around £50m a year from January 2002.

"The thought of a London-based stock exchange will soon almost be forgotten," he declared as he and his opposite number at Deutsche Börse, Werner Seifert, confirmed that talks to bring Nasdaq, the high-technology market, into a three-way merger were under way. Merger talks are also being held with the Milan and Madrid bourses. Mr Cruickshank, chairman designate of the proposed Anglo-German iX international exchange, where Mr Seifert will be chief executive, was speaking as documentation was published mapping the planned £75m merger ahead of a make-or-break shareholder vote on September 14. London stock market authorities are pressing on with the plan in the face of resistance from dozens of smaller British brokerages which fear a large portion of their business dealing in small and medium sized companies will migrate to Frankfurt. Initially the London exchange would take responsibility for trading in European blue-chip shares and the Germans would handle younger, smaller hi-tech issues. For the merger to go ahead some 75% of the London exchange's 298 broking members must vote in favour. "Assistance with conversion costs from Sets [the trading system in London] to Xetra is welcome, but without the IT specification who is to say it is enough?" asked Angela Knight, chief executive of the Association of Private Client Investment Managers. fields.headline: Ebookers rides out of cash 'crisis'
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Shares in Ebookers surged 47% yesterday after the internet travel firm said it needed to raise less money than expected to take it through to profitability, and hoped to finalise the new investment "within the next few weeks".
fields.body:
Shares in Ebookers surged 47% yesterday after the internet travel firm said it needed to raise less money than expected to take it through to profitability, and hoped to finalise the new investment "within the next few weeks".

The London-based firm said it was in advanced talks with two strategic partners and five financial investors about raising £26m.

Ebookers has recently been subject to speculation about the rate at which it is burning cash and some analysts had estimated it would need to find £40m or £50m to take it through to profitability.

However, news that the company needs less money than predicted combined with strong second-quarter results lifted Neuer Markt-listed Ebookers shares by €3.30 to €10.20 (£6.40).

In March the shares were trading at €45 but recent fears that the company could run out of cash by the end of the year has dragged them as low as €6.

Chief executive Dinesh Dhamija, who has injected a further £2m of his own funds into the company, said: "We do not need as much money as many analysts thought and we are likely to become cashflow positive 15-18 months before many had predicted, and it was important that we made those points clear."

In the quarter to June 30, sales were £20m, an increase of 839% on the same period the previous year. Pre-tax losses increased from £666,000 to £6.6m. At June 30, Ebookers had £15.2m cash in the bank.

Another director has invested a further £2m.

British sales accounted for 39% of total revenues, down from 46% last time, reflecting the growing contribution of the firm's continental European operations.

Mr Dhamija, founder of the offline Flightbookers travel agency, said the potential strategic investors were "travel related" and likely to provide around £10m of the funds needed.

He said that once he had secured the new funding he planned to buy a travel agency in Italy which would take Ebookers in its 12th major European market.

webTitle: New test looms for man of the series

fields.headline: New test looms for man of the series
fields.standfirst:
Trescothick has put more than one batsman's place under threat, writes Mike Selvey
England's fast track to final
fields.trailText: Marcus Trescothick has put more than one batsman's place under threat, writes Mike Selvey.
fields.body:
The pitfalls of thrusting a player into a Test match on the strength of performances in one-day internationals are too familiar to the England selectors for them not to have, surely, twinges of discomfort at the talk of Marcus Trescothick opening the batting in next month's third Test. But as the undisputed player of the triangular NatWest series so far he has been making a case that will be hard for David Graveney and the rest to ignore when they choose their squad in 12 days' time.

His unbeaten 87 at Chester-le-Street on Saturday, scored out of 171 as England registered their first 10-wicket win in 314 limited-overs internationals, took his tally for the series to 244 at an average of 81, each run a switchblade in the heart of Mark Ramprakash and indeed Nick Knight, whose place in the one-day squad was taken by Trescothick after the Warwickshire left-hander broke a finger in the Lord's Test win two weeks ago. And, with Graham Thorpe making an impact on the England scene again and Nasser Hussain's cracked thumb all but ready to be tested - perhaps in the game against Zimbabwe at Edgbaston tomorrow afternoon - even Graeme Hick is threatened.

Trescothick's success to date has been a feather in the cap of the England coach Duncan Fletcher who, after being appointed last July, spent the last months of his Glamorgan contract making note of those who impressed him against his county. In the case of Trescothick, who had captained England at Under-19 level and went on last winter's A tour to Bangladesh and New Zealand without being overly successful, this came in the form of an innings of 167 in a low-scoring game in Taunton in which no one else passed 50 and in which he peppered the local churchyard with the sort of muscular aerial bombardment that used to come from Ian Botham, Viv Richards and Arthur Wellard.

"I remember that, and a lot of his runs came against Jacques Kallis and it was very impressive," Fletcher said on Saturday. "An innings like that can show that a guy can play. He has a simple technique and a very good temperament. He sits in the dressing room as if it's just another game, which is good to see because temperament is the key."

If, or rather when, he plays Test cricket he will find life altogether harder than facing Zimbabwean medium-pacers and a West Indian attack shorn of its ageless cutting edge and its masculinity by the playing conditions of the game. He may even need to move his feet a little faster and with more purpose, although Fletcher would not be daft enough to want to tinker with something that is functioning quite nicely. But let's not quibble at present. Trescothick is indeed uncomplicated, refreshingly so, standing tall at the crease, thumping the ball on the front foot with the full face of the bat and, if necessary, rocking back from there to pull and cut with equal emphasis.

The six he clumped over midwicket to finish the game was the sharpest of punctuation marks to an England performance a world away from the dross they had dished up the previous weekend. All the bowlers performed excellently, restricting West Indies to 169 for eight, and Brian Lara in particular to 54 from 101 balls by virtue of bowling straight and on a good length when 230 was the minimum on a blameless pitch (not a single wide in successive matches is a remarkable effort). The fielding and catching were also first rate, topped by Thorpe's stunner at short extra cover to get rid of Chris Gayle.

West Indies, however, performed as poorly as England did well. The strong northerly wind was icy but Jimmy Adams' men, many of whom have played in county cricket and the leagues, made it obvious that they would rather be elsewhere. Everyone puts hands in pockets when it is cold but mentally West Indies never took them out. The batting was insipid and the bowling juvenile so that Trescothick and Alec Stewart (74 not out) had the game sewn up with almost 14 overs in hand and with England's third highest opening stand.

The unequal nature of the contest did not detract from the effort that Durham had made to stage two games over the weekend. The pitches, notoriously unpredictable, played immaculately and, including a brace of male streakers who offended no one until one cavorted in front of the sightscreen (some things are just not done), a full house of 15,000 turned out in the wintry conditions, paying the same £28 that was said to have deterred thousands from Old Trafford on Thursday.

They want a Test match in these parts and they should be given one. Soon.

webTitle: Gascoigne offered two-year lifeline by Everton

fields.headline: Gascoigne offered two-year lifeline by Everton
fields.trailText: Paul Gascoigne will seek to resurrect his faltering career one last time later this week with a surprise move to Everton.
fields.body:
Paul Gascoigne will seek to resurrect his faltering career one last time later this week with a surprise move to Everton.

Just as the Middlesbrough midfielder was considering offers from Motherwell and Kilmarnock, the Merseyside club's manager Walter Smith, an old friend, provided the ageing former England international with an act of benevolence.

Smith has agreed to sign Gascoigne on a free transfer, generously handing him a two-year deal that will earn him around £22,000 a week. Once Gascoigne has finalised his deal, he will fly out to Italy to join his new team-mates at a training camp in Tuscany.

"He's never been long at one club because it is always difficult for someone with his mentality to have continuity in his life," said Smith.

"He loses the spark when he's been somewhere more than a couple of years and he relishes a new challenge. Despite what people say about him, he's got pride in himself and he wants to be up there with the best of them."

Although the one-time enfant terrible of the English game has more than a year of his contract left to run at Middlesbrough, the Teesside club grew tired of attempting to squeeze another productive season out of Gascoigne.

Indeed, their manager Bryan Robson, a friend and confidant of the troubled Geordie, recently indicated he would be willing to pay up the remaining months of Gascoigne's deal rather than see him drift aimlessly around the periphery of his club's affairs.

Before Smith intervened to toss one of his most favoured sons a most improbable lifeline, Gascoigne had been seriously considering moving to Australia or the US - world football's hard shoulder.

Smith has a soft spot for Gascoigne, having drawn the best out of him during their successful time together at Rangers. But he will inform Gascoigne's advisers that he will not hesitate to cancel, with immediate effect, their client's contract if he steps out of line.

Even so, yesterday's developments will undoubtedly be frowned upon by those purists among the Everton faithful who will regard Gascoigne as a potentially disruptive force within the club.

Worryingly for those who have marvelled at Gascoigne's fondness for self-destruction when left idle, it is by no means certain he will command a regular place in Everton's first team.

Although Smith last week sold the midfielders Don Hutchison to Sunderland and John Collins to Fulham - and will today sell Nick Barmby to the neighbours Liverpool - he has not been slow to line up replacements. The Ghanaian international Alex Nyarko joined from Lens in a £4.5m deal at the weekend and Sweden's Niclas Alexandersson and Denmark's Thomas Gravesen should soon complete moves from Sheffield Wednesday and Hamburg.

fields.trailText: Fiorentina have paid Benfica £12m for the services of Nuno Gomes, who will be asked to fill the boots of the Roma-bound Gabriel Batistuta.
fields.body:
Fiorentina have paid Benfica £12m for the services of Nuno Gomes, who will be asked to fill the boots of the Roma-bound Gabriel Batistuta.

The 24-year-old Gomes, Portugal's top scorer at Euro 2000 with four goals - including the third against England in the infamous 3-2 win - has signed a five-year deal and will also link up with his international team-mate Rui Costa.

However Gomes has incurred an eight-month ban - subject to appeal - from all Uefa and international games due to his conduct in the Euro 2000 semi-final and may miss out on most, if not all, of his new club's Uefa Cup campaign.

webTitle: Boys from Brazil show England the way

fields.headline: Boys from Brazil show England the way
fields.standfirst: Donnelly 69 | Leandro 47, 58
fields.trailText: Two goals from Leandro, the most talented of another impressive batch of Brazilians, accounted for this young England team yesterday. Yet at a time when the game in England is indulging in one of its regular bouts of self-analysis, there was promise of a more enlightened era ahead if these teenagers develop as expected.
fields.byline: John Wardle at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
Two goals from Leandro, the most talented of another impressive batch of Brazilians, accounted for this young England team yesterday. Yet at a time when the game in England is indulging in one of its regular bouts of self-analysis, there was promise of a more enlightened era ahead if these teenagers develop as expected.

The West Ham defender Glen Johnson in particular played with a patience and composure that reflected how coaches at this level are now stressing the importance of retaining possession. Tottenham's Marcel McKie and Nottingham Forest's Craig Westcarr are others who would not have looked out of place in the Brazilian side. And England even fielded a a couple of players who looked comfortable using their left feet.

Some of the players may come to reflect on this match as the highlight of a career that failed to live up to its promise. It would be a good memory - playing against Brazil at the Stadium of Light in front of a record crowd for a game at this level. But among the Brazilians Leandro and his midfield partner Marcio are unlikely to be among those who fail to make it.

Leandro, who plays for Vitoria, illustrated his immense talent with a 47th-minute free-kick placed past Lenny Pidgeley from 25 yards. He added Brazil's second 11 minutes later after Pidgeley turned away a swerving, low shot from Alberoni. Leandro drove against the post before beating the Chelsea keeper from the rebound to ensure they won the Nationwide Tournament.

Brazil's contribution to the remainder of the match was less satisfying. So young, yet so aware of the time-wasting and shirt-pulling of their seniors. There was even an unsightly scuffle involving most of the players when Ciaran Donnelly tried to retrieve the ball after scoring England's goal.

Donnelly missed an easier opportunity in injury-time, his obvious despair eased by England's insistence that it's not just about winning at this level. "If you were only interested in the result, you would be disappointed," their coach Kenny Swain said, "but we were thrilled with the boys' performance."

England: Pidgeley (Chelsea); Welsh (LIverpool), McKie (Tottenham), Schumacher (Everton), Johnson (West Ham), Taylor (Manchester United), Westcarr (Nottingham Forest), Beck (Everton), Sama (Millwall), Donnelly (Blackburn), Lambu (Millwall).

Brazil: Marcelo; Fernandez, Wendel, Wescley, Alberoni, Bruno, Leandro, Tavares, Marcio, Ricardo, Rafael.

Referee: U Rennie (Sheffield).

webTitle: Delaney off but Villa cancel out Czechs

fields.headline: Delaney off but Villa cancel out Czechs
fields.trailText: Mark Delaney will be fined by Aston Villa's manager John Gregory after being sent off in yesterday's first leg of this Intertoto Cup tie in the Czech Republic.
fields.body:
Mark Delaney will be fined by Aston Villa's manager John Gregory after being sent off in yesterday's first leg of this Intertoto Cup tie in the Czech Republic.

The 24-year-old Welsh international defender kicked out at the Dukla goalkeeper Michal Spit with 10 minutes to go in the third-round match.

It is the third time Delaney has been sent off in his past 10 matches for club and country after being dismissed in the FA Cup semi-final win over Bolton at Wembley in April and and then in Wales's encounter with Portugal.

"Mark claims the keeper punched him in the face and he retaliated," said Gregory after the goalless draw. "I have no complaints about the sending-off. I presume he will miss the second leg and he will be disciplined by the club."

Gregory was content with the result in what was Villa's first competitive match of the season after a turbulent summer at the club. "It was kind of what I expected, although I would have liked to have won," he said. "But I am fairly pleased at the way things went. There are no real mugs in Europe. You can't walk in and expect to win.

"Pribram passed it quite well but our boys said it was a great work-out. There was a lot at stake and a lot of pressure but we have come through it."

Villa understandably looked ring rusty in the opening 45 minutes. They threatened only once in the first half and their smattering of fans had little to cheer about.

Gareth Barry was one player to have a satisfactory afternoon. Drafted into a the centre of Villa's three-man back line in the absence of the captain Gareth Southgate, he looked assured and composed. Paul Merson took the captain's armband.

Villa took 10 minutes to carve open the first chance of the game. Ugo Ehiogu laid the ball into the path of Dion Dublin, who had ghosted into the penalty area. The striker's shot was struck firm and true but Spit reacted superbly to parry the ball to safety.

Dukla, the 11-time Czechoslovak champions who knocked out LASK Linz in the last round, were looking dangerous themselves. Their midfielder Lukas Jarolim broke forward in the 14th minute and tested the visiting goalkeeper David James with a firmly hit effort.

Dukla, who finished sixth in the Czech League last season, were growing in confidence and Tomas Kucera lifted the ball marginally over the top as they pressed forward.

Merson had the best Villa chance, which he put wide just past the hour, but Gregory's side will be hopeful of advancing to the next stage of the competition after Saturday's second leg at the home of West Bromwich Albion.

fields.headline: Summer job suits Windass
fields.standfirst: Windass 50, 73 (pen)
fields.trailText: At a time when other clubs are slowly beginning to gear themselves up for pre-season training, Bradford City appear to be doing their level best through the Intertoto Cup to show that football really is becoming a 365-day a year game.
fields.body:
At a time when other clubs are slowly beginning to gear themselves up for pre-season training, Bradford City appear to be doing their level best through the Intertoto Cup to show that football really is becoming a 365-day a year game.

Last Sunday they successfully negotiated the second leg of their second-round tie against the Lithuanian side Atlantas Klaipeda. On Tuesday, club officials were busy lobbying Uefa to have their three summer signings, David Hopkin, Ian Nolan and Peter Atherton, made available for this third-round tie (all were originally ineligible until the next round). By the end of the week, bookmakers had targeted Chris Hutchings as the manager least likely to be sitting behind his Premiership desk come next May, even though he has been in the job only a month.

Yesterday it was the supporters' turn to take centre stage by handing out complimentary copies of the club fanzine City Gent to officials and supporters of their Dutch opponents, an attempt to build bridges after the English PR fiasco that was Euro 2000. If intended as a ploy to lull RKC into a false sense of security it worked, Dean Saunders forcing their goalkeeper Rob van Dijk into action after only 30 seconds.

Dean Windass also wasted two glorious opportunities as the Dutch side, playing their first game of the season, struggled to find their feet. When they finally did so midway through the first half some fine approach play was undone by a lack of cutting edge up front.

Lee Sharpe, sporting a Beckham-style crew cut, helped Windass recapture his shooting form at the beginning of the second half. The former Manchester United man ran 20 yards with the ball before setting up Lee Mills, whose deflected shot fell kindly for Windass to head home from seven yards out.

A harsh handball decision against Virgilio Teixeira allowed the beefy No7 to hit his and Bradford's second from the penalty spot in the 73rd minute.

In between strikes City gave Hopkin, their record £2.5m signing from Leeds United, his first run-out since his transfer a fortnight ago. The 29-year-old Scottish international midfielder, who spent most of last season either in the reserves or warming the bench at Elland Road, looked decidedly rusty, confirming that Hutchings's decision to start him from the substitutes' bench was a good one.

RKC's best chance came shortly after Windass's opener, Rick Hoogendorp firing too close to the substitute goalkeeper Aidan Davison after Peter Atherton had been caught in possession.

"They're a good side with some dangerous players who can pass the ball around," said Hutchings afterwards. "We will take nothing for granted. The job is only half done."

Bradford City (4-4-2): Clarke (Davison, h-t); Nolan, Wetherall, Atherton, Myers; McCall, Windass, Whalley (Hopkin, 66min), Sharpe (Grant, 79); Mills, Saunders.

RKC Waalwijk (4-1-4-1): Van Dijk; Lamey, Nascimento, Teixeira, Nwakire; Van de Berg; Y Cornelisse (Heesakkers, 66), Gudjonsson, Hoogendorp (Redan, 81), Van Loenhout (Van Dinteren, 61); De Graef.

Referee: H Albrecht (Germany).
