fields.headline: Zimbabwe find rich pickings
fields.standfirst:
West Indies 287-5
Zimbabwe 290-4
Zimbabwe win by six wickets
fields.trailText:
West Indies 287-5
Zimbabwe 290-4
Zimbabwe win by six wickets.
fields.body:
This had been billed as the match that did not matter, because Zimbabwe had already qualified for the final next Saturday and West Indies' chances of ousting England as the other finalists were a mathematical long shot and no more. Instead, Chester-le-Street got the match it deserved for producing a brace of belting pitches over the weekend.

Against the odds and with the highest score of the tournament, Zimbabwe confirmed England's passage into the final and in truly magnificent fashion at that, winning by six wickets with five deliveries remaining. Ninety runs had come from the final nine overs and 47 from the last four.

Zimbabwe have now won four out of their five qualifying matches to date, losing only to England at Old Trafford last Thursday evening, and have picked up £46,000 in prize money and man-of-the-match awards, effectively doubling the touring fee of each player.

After 23 overs of their innings Zimbabwe, at 104 for four and chasing an improbable 288, were out of it as West Indies capitalised on some memorable batting from Sherwin Campbell (105), Brian Lara (87) and Wavell Hinds (42) by bowling and fielding in a disciplined fashion more in keeping with the international standards required after the shoddy, slapdash performance against England the day before.

They had reckoned without Murray Goodwin and Grant Flower, however, for from a desperate position the pair fashioned an unbroken fifth-wicket partnership of 186, scored at an average of almost seven runs an over, a Zimbabwean record for any wicket in limited-overs internationals.

Flower struck the winning runs by belting Reon King over mid-off and on to the boundary, leaving him four runs short of a century after an innings of only 87 balls and containing eight fours and a six. It might without quibble have taken the man-of-the-match award. Instead that went to Goodwin, who remained unbeaten on 112 from 137 balls with seven fours.

After this competition, personal and financial reasons mean that Goodwin will return to Australia, whence his family emigrated when he was a child, and he may well not play international cricket again. On the evidence of the Test series in May and now this he will be a huge loss.

West Indies lost their composure under pressure as Goodwin and Flower found the boundary and ran their runs vigorously, mixing aggression with common sense. None of the West Indian bowlers had the nous or ability to halt it and, with the game almost up, Jimmy Adams was forced to use Chris Gayle's off-spin to bowl the penultimate over. It yielded 11 runs and that was about that.

West Indies must have thought they had the game sewn up after their innings, which had been given early impetus by Hinds and Campbell with a first-wicket partnership of 86 before Hinds, whose driving had been majestic, hoicked a catch all the way to Carlisle, not down the A69 and across the Pennines but Stuart at deep-midwicket.

Campbell and Lara then put together what ought to have been the definitive stand of the match, 173 in 25 overs, before Lara was bowled by Dirk Viljoen trying to cut a straight ball, retribution for the left-arm spinner who had earlier been savaged by Lara for 22 in an over, including two sixes and two fours.

By this time, though, Campbell had reached his second limited-overs century for West Indies and exacted a price from the ground that had treated him so harshly when he was Durham's overseas player four seasons ago. Then, on friskier pitches than this, he managed just one half-century.

webTitle: Surrey take Oval form to Guildford

fields.headline: Surrey take Oval form to Guildford
fields.trailText: Surrey, the county champions, go into Wednesday's encounter with Leicestershire in Guildford 16 points clear at the top of the championship after four consecutive wins.
fields.body:
Surrey, the county champions, go into Wednesday's encounter with Leicestershire in Guildford 16 points clear at the top of the championship after four consecutive wins.

Saqlain Mushtaq and Ian Salisbury spun Surrey to a commanding 203-run victory over Yorkshire at the Oval to consolidate the champions' lead at the top.

The Yorkshire batsmen never really looked likely to reach their victory target of 330 once Saqlain began to extract spin on a true pitch, the Pakistan Test bowler finishing with figures of five for 41.

At the other end of the table Kent boosted their chances of staying in the First Division with an eight-wicket win over Derbyshire, another relegation-threatened side, at Derby.

Matthew Elliott was one of a number of Australians who enjoyed a profitable weekend. The Victorian set Glamorgan on their way to a two-wicket victory over Middlesex at Southgate. His 127 was the performance of the match on a wicket that had come under scrutiny.

Sussex's Australian left-hander Michael Bevan remained unbeaten on 151 in a draw with Essex at Arundel. Essex were then set 310 in 73 overs and held on for their sixth draw in nine Second Division games. The visitors called off their run-chase when another Australian, Stuart Law, fell to Bevan for 12.

Worcestershire's acting captain Steve Rhodes scored his first century in two years and the last man Glenn McGrath weighed in with a maiden half-century as their team escaped with a draw against Nottinghamshire at New Road.

The Australian fast bowler, with a previous best of 39 in a Test match against the West Indies, hit seven fours and two sixes on his way to 55.

Lancashire's tail-enders produced a rearguard action to foil Somerset's victory attempt in an enthralling draw at Taunton. At 324 for eight in their second innings, the visitors were still two runs behind with 39 overs left in the day.

Gloucestershire went down by an innings and 99 runs to Northamptonshire at Cheltenham with not even a sterling century by Jack Russell, his first in three years, enough to save the current kings of the one-day game. It was only Russell's fifth century in 19 years at Gloucestershire.

The 20 points Northamptonshire took from their second championship win saw them climb off the bottom of the Second Division above Middlesex.

 Hansie Cronje claimed yesterday that Mark Waugh and Shane Warne were guilty of the same bookmaking-related offences in 1995 that Cronje has admitted to in recent months.

The former South Africa captain, who lost his job in April when he said he took money from bookmakers to influence games, told Channel Nine television's Sixty Minutes programme that the Australians had made "exactly the same mistake".

In December 1998, the Australian Cricket Board admitted it secretly fined Waugh and Warne in February 1995 for giving what it called routine pitch and weather details to bookmakers during Australia's 1994 tour of Sri Lanka. "They've basically confessed to taking money from bookmakers and supplying information," Cronje said. "And it's exactly what I did in a lot of my dealings and it is wrong."

fields.headline: Rhodes' error costs Royals
fields.standfirst:
Worcestershire 145-9
Gloucestershire 149-7
Gloucestershire win by three wickets
fields.trailText:
Worcestershire 145-9
Gloucestershire 149-7
Gloucestershire win by three wickets
fields.body:
An astonishing blunder by Worcestershire's acting captain Steven Rhodes cost the Royals victory and allowed the Gladiators to make up ground on the National League leaders.

The Australian paceman Glenn McGrath had Gloucestershire on their knees at Cheltenham as he took three wickets in seven balls without having a run scored off him.

Surprisingly, he was taken off by Rhodes and from 76 for seven, Gloucestershire's Chris Taylor and Martyn Ball carved out a remarkable win.

McGrath, who had opened the attack with four overs for three runs, came back to complete his nine, but it was all too late.

Gloucestershire needed 15 off the final four overs and Ball drove to the boundary in the final over with one ball left. Taylor, in his first season with Gloucestershire, was the hero finishing with 37 after being dropped on 23.

Worcestershire, who had won the toss, never quite got up any steam with their batting. Mike Smith was in magnificent form for the home side, bowling his nine overs straight for nine runs and claiming the opener Paul Pollard for eight.

The middle order found runs through Vikram Solanki, who hit 45 off 69 balls, while Ryan Driver, clearing the pavilion with one hook, made 29 and Rhodes 27. But the Gladiators contained the Royals with only 11 runs conceded in the last five overs in which there were four run-outs.

Gloucestershire's Dominic Hewson and Jack Russell made a stubborn start, putting on 40 before the latter drove a return catch to Richard Illingworth in the 15th over.

With the score on 56, Hewson was run out for 34 and three balls later, Illingworth bowled Ian Harvey around his legs. The home skipper Mark Alleyne and Matt Windows rebuilt the innings, adding 20 in 11 overs, but four wickets fell with the score on 76.

It looked the Royals' match but Taylor and Ball, in a rearguard stand, put on 73 to see the Gladiators home.

webTitle: Poll slide adds to Blair gloom

fields.headline: Poll slide adds to Blair gloom
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's hopes of a summer recovery are dashed today by the latest Guardian/ICM opinion poll, which shows that Labour's lead has slipped to just seven points ahead of the Tories - the narrowest gap between the two parties since the landslide 13-point general election victory in May 1997.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's hopes of a summer recovery are dashed today by the latest Guardian/ICM opinion poll, which shows that Labour's lead has slipped to just seven points ahead of the Tories - the narrowest gap between the two parties since the landslide 13-point general election victory in May 1997.

The ICM survey was taken at the weekend before the leak of Tony Blair's own confidential memo admitting that his government was widely perceived to be "somehow out of touch with gut British instincts" on key populist issues such as crime and asylum seekers.

The leak was the subject of a high-level inquiry by the cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson, last night amid Labour hints that it had been orchestrated by the Tories after someone, inside Downing Street or an outside hacker, had intercepted Mr Blair's private communications.

The timing, on the eve of Gordon Brown's long-awaited unveiling of his £40bn comprehensive spending review and today's bad crime figures, is damaging. The Guardian's ICM poll will also dampen Labour's confidence, although Blair aides remain adamant that they are already on course to bounce back from mid-term difficulties.

The poll shows that last month's 11-point lead has been cut by four points in the face of a recovering Tory party. This is only the second time since the election that Labour's poll lead has fallen below 10 points to reach such a low point. The last time was in May.

It represents a sharp decline in popularity in the past year. The Tories have reached 35%, their highest poll rating since the election, suggesting that their "flatlining" days around the 30% mark may be in the past.

Last night delighted senior Tories claimed the leaked memo would encourage voters to believe that Labour is "all spin and no substance" - a belief that Downing Street is keen to kill.

"Now we know where all the spin and the gimmicks come from in this government. It comes from the very top," William Hague told reporters. Labour loyalists see the memo as unsurprising at worst and impressively lacking in complacency at best.

Some senior officials speculated that the same person who intercepted the private pollster Philip Gould's recent memo reporting allegations that Mr Blair is "all spin and no substance" is behind the latest leak - and might be using a trusted Tory as a go-between. Some MPs called for tighter electronic security for No 10.

Today's ICM poll confirms that the prime minister's anxiety in his leaked memo - handwritten at Chequers on April 29 and faxed to key advisers - that the party was being seen as "soft on crime" is still widely believed by the voters. It helps explain Mr Blair's tough remarks since then, including his ill-fated plan to impose on-the-spot cashpoint fines on lager louts.

Some 69% of the electorate, including 48% of Labour voters, say that the prime minister, despite his promise, has not been "tough on crime and tough on the causes of crime". But 42% of Labour voters believe he has delivered tough crime policies.

The government will try again today to dispel the perception by announcing extra cash to recruit more police officers as part of Mr Brown's package.

The shift comes as the latest crime figures are published, revealing a 16% rise in violent crime, the largest for more than 10 years, and a more modest 3.8% rise in the overall headline crime rate.

The accuracy of the prime minister's identification of crime as the party's weak spot is confirmed when the pollsters asked the voters which party they thought had the best policies on a series of policy areas. Labour still retains a strong lead over the Conservatives on its core issues of health (+19 points) and education (+18 points). It also retains a lead over the Tories on the economy (+8 points).

But there is growing and widespread scepticism over its performance on roads, railways and bus services (49% say none of the parties have the best policy or don't know) and crime (55% say none of the parties or don't know).

Labour retains a slim lead over the Tories on crime (22% to 18%) but the massive ab stention implies that the disillusioned Labour voter is not yet ready to vote Conservative.

The only issue on which the Tories actually have a lead over Labour is on tax (28% to 25%), despite last week's furore over Mr Hague's u-turn, ditching the opposition's "minimum tax guarantee".

 ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,056 adults aged 18-plus by telephone between July 14 and 15. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Somerset and Leicestershire had the chance to make up ground on the National League First Division leaders but, like Worcestershire, they both lost.
fields.body:
Somerset and Leicestershire had the chance to make up ground on the National League First Division leaders but, like Worcestershire, they both lost.

At Taunton Lancashire, having held out for a draw in the championship match on Saturday, added insult to injury yesterday with a seven-wicket win with as many over to spare.

Mike Atherton, overlooked for England one-day duty, and the Indian Sourav Ganguly led the victory charge with Lancashire's record National League opening stand.

They put on 192, Atherton hitting his second century in five days against Somerset. He made 105 off 115 balls including 14 fours, while Ganguly's 82 featured a six and 10 fours.

Earlier, Somerset had looked in little trouble at 103 for two with Jamie Cox (45) and Peter Bowler (27) at the crease. But the partnership was broken on 45, after which the home side slumped. The spinners Chris Schofield and Gary Yates each took two wickets and Somerset were all out for 198.

Leicestershire, who began the day in third place, also collapsed after a promising start against Northamptonshire at Grace Road. Aftab Habib (70) and Phil DeFreitas (40) gave the innings impetus with a fifth-wicket stand of 73. But when Habib was caught by Adrian Rollins at mid-on, the last six wickets fell for 26 with Darren Cousins and Tony Penberthy taking three wickets apiece.

The Australian left-hander Matthew Hayden then saw the visitors home by four wickets with an ubeaten 96, including three sixes.

Hayden's compatriot Michael Bevan took his National League average to 105 from eight innings with a fluent 89 not out, as Sussex beat Yorkshire by 70 runs at Arundel.

Adam Hollioake hit his first century in any limited overs competition as Surrey went clear at the top of the Second Division with a 67-run win over Glamorgan at the Oval. Hollioake hit two sixes and nine fours before being out for 111. Then it was brother Ben's turn with the ball, taking four for 42 as Glamorgan were bowled out for 201.

webTitle: Getting to grips with some of the worst housing in Europe

fields.headline: Getting to grips with some of the worst housing in Europe
fields.standfirst: Manifesto: special report
fields.trailText: Housing conditions in parts of Britain are probably the worst in western Europe. John Prescott, the environment secretary, accepted as much earlier this year when he launched a green paper, Quality and Choice: A Decent Home For All.
fields.body:
Housing conditions in parts of Britain are probably the worst in western Europe. John Prescott, the environment secretary, accepted as much earlier this year when he launched a green paper, Quality and Choice: A Decent Home For All.

While the country as a whole was enjoying "unprecedented prosperity", too many people were living in poor accommodation. Years of neglect in social housing had left a £19bn repairs backlog, he said.

The government has to make a start on those repairs or tens of thousands of people will be living in collapsing concrete blocks by the end of the decade. What is needed is the creation of a department of housing and urban affairs with a minister of cabinet rank in charge.

This ministry should co-ordinate a national renewal strategy, together with local councils and builders. They should be given powers to license private landlords and prevent them exploiting housing benefit, running at £15bn annually. This could lead to savings, with more people encouraged to live in "re-branded" council and housing association properties - 110,000 of which are usually empty at any one time.

This will take a big injection of public money, even if council homes are transferred to "social companies" that can raise funds on the open market. Shelter estimated £1.4bn extra a year was needed over the next decade. Given the scale of the task, that would be money well spent.

webTitle: Making town halls partners in democracy

fields.headline: Making town halls partners in democracy
fields.standfirst:
Manifesto: special report
Labour is embarked on its road to the manifesto - and so is the Guardian. In a unique experiment in British journalism, Guardian specialists draw 'blue sky' sketches of what should form Labour's programme for a second term. Today we look at local democracy
fields.trailText: Democracy is a twin-track process. As well as electing national governments, western nations bless local or regional government with considerable powers and financial freedom.
fields.body:
Democracy is a twin-track process. As well as electing national governments, western nations bless local or regional government with considerable powers and financial freedom.

While delivering services we take for granted - schools, social care, libraries, roads, refuse collection and public transport - this second tier of government acts as an essential check on the national executive, a democratic balance.

Yet in Britain, particularly in England, national governments apparently want to control everything. Councils are seen by many ministers as agents of Whitehall - delivering services according to a bewildering array of performance indicators, policed by a new 500-strong inspectorate in the audit commission.

A Labour second term should reverse the raid on local powers by the centre. Hints of abolishing education authorities and social services departments should stop - along with threats to bypass councils with neighbourhood forums.

Labour should draw up a settlement of the central and the local, defining the proper and legitimate powers of councils. In what could be Labour's constitutional big idea for the second term, the government should set up a "local democracy commission", to report within a year.

It must be coupled with reforms to take town and county halls into the 21st century. The government would argue that it has done just that, by driving through a local government bill, paving the way for elected mayors outside London and formalising a cabinet structure of executive decision-making. It has not.

English mayors will be a pale shadow of the US-model which once proved so attractive to Tony Blair. This is because councils can raise, on average, only a quarter of their spending; the rest must come from Whitehall, which can "cap" budgets regarded as "excessive or unreasonable".

Business rates are set nationally and redistributed to councils. In its last manifesto, Labour accepted there was a strong democratic case for returning the business rate directly to town halls. It has not delivered, on the grounds that councils cannot be trusted to set and collect busi ness taxes. That is wrong: councils perform precisely that function in other countries, and they can do it here. It should go further, and experiment with other local taxation in pilot areas - modest "tourist taxes" of, say, 5% on a hotel room and, perhaps, similar sales taxes - to raise funds in cities, and tourist "hot spots", where a large authority provides services for a much wider community that pays nothing for what it receives.

Labour should tie such a move to further reforms and democratic renewal. English councils, generally with three-member electoral wards, are far too large. Birmingham has 117 councillors, for example, Manchester 99. If turnouts of barely 30% are anything to go by, voters rarely identity with them. Single-member wards should be introduced to give voters one councillor to deal with instead of three.

While a cabinet, of no more than five, perhaps chaired by a mayor, will run a city or county, each local "minister" will chair a committee covering his or her portfolio. This will be the essential check and balance on executive power, providing a key role for the remaining councillors, instead of relegating them to the backbenches.

Voting reform could reinvigorate local democracy. The government should follow the example of Scotland, where proportional representation could well be introduced for elections to the country's 32 councils in three years' time. And remember: the Edinburgh Parliament, Welsh Assembly and new Greater London Authority are all elected by partial-PR.

The government should also experiment with other forms of democracy, parochial and regional. Why not have elected neighbourhood councils, or urban parish councils, where there is demand? Services, such as street cleaning, estate regeneration and school management, could be devolved to them, while a town hall sets the overall strategy.

At the regional level, the government is in a mess. It created eight regional development agencies, with collective budgets of around £800m - business-led quangoes appointed by John Prescott, the environment secretary. Already some are in turmoil, beset by in-fighting. The agencies need to be brought under democratic control.

Mr Prescott has encouraged the formation of non-elected regional chambers, or assemblies, in the eight regions, filled mainly by councillors and businessmen. These bodies need to be slimmed down to, say, the size of the 25-strong Greater London Assembly. As a first step they should oversee the agencies.

The government should also acknowledge that, in some regions, it has created an appetite for full regional government. In its last manifesto, Labour made a vague commitment by hinting at referendums to test the climate for elected assemblies in particular areas.

It should now consider a rolling programme of devolution to the regions, starting with the North-east and Yorkshire. But like London, the assemblies must be strategic bodies with powers to run health and higher education, and to oversee land-use planning, the regional development agencies, major roads and maybe public transport.

Powers must be strictly defined to ensure that big cities, languishing well behind their European rivals, lead an urban renaissance.

1 Give town halls powers to raise more taxes
2 Slash size of councils by two-thirds, creating new single member wards
3 Introduce PR into all local elections
4 Create neighbourhood councils where demand exists
5 Hold referendums to test climate for regional government

webTitle: Enough guff about the Queen Mum

fields.headline: Enough guff about the Queen Mum
fields.standfirst:
She may well be a splendid old lady, but she is also an absurdity

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: She may well be a splendid old lady, but she is also an absurdity.
fields.body:
Only three more weeks to go and we will have survived the month-long celebration of the life and work of an elderly lady whom we barely know. I am, in my charitable way, prepared to believe that Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother, is admirable in every particular - modest, self-effacing, compassionate, frugal - and that her detractors, who claim the opposite, are mean-minded iconoclasts. But I have to admit that a public figure who never gives interviews, appears on television or broadcasts on radio is bound, as far as the general public is concerned, to remain an enigma. Yet this summer we have treated Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon-as-was (to use my native South Yorkshire patois) with something approaching idolatry. She is even to be immortalised in a Ledo Collectible three and half inch model of Bull Nose Morris Van with her portrait on the side (£9.99 plus p & p).

The Queen Mother attracts our worship and "lovingly crafted tributes" in small part because of her age. It was Alan Bennett who wrote that, in England, anyone who can still crack open an egg at the age of 80 is automatically sanctified. But her status is the result of longevity combined with what, by rational standards, is not an automatic sign of distinction. We are required to love her because she was once married to the king. That is proof that a hereditary monarchy has no place in a grown-up world.

The absurdity was proved beyond doubt by a television programme which, last week, sought to draw attention to some of the Queen Mother's alleged failings. To redress the balance of a generally critical profile (and, I suspect, to provide a paragraph in the letter which will be drafted as a reply to complaints), viewers were exposed to the opinions of the Reverend Anthony Hall Harrison Harbottle who was described as Chaplain to the Queen Mother. Mr Harbottle spoke on behalf of those who had enjoyed the privilege of seeing his patron at close quarters. They would, he said, all agree that she was a living and literal example of the "beatific vision".

I t was not clear if he meant that the Queen Mother was bathed in God's redeeming light, a view which is no more than sacrilegious, or if he suggested that she radiated it herself, a judgment which is positively blasphemous. We can, however, be certain that he was speaking literally. To avoid any suspicion of metaphor he went on to say that she "already has one foot in Heaven". And Mr Harbottle has no doubt about what will happen when the rest of her passes through the pearly gates. When, he said, "the great call comes as it must come to us all", her spirit will watch over and protect the royal family that she leaves behind.

Were the reverend to offer such an opinion about the postmortem prospects of any human being who was not a member of the royal family, he would be taken away for rest and recuperation among people who believe themselves to be Napoleon Bonaparte. But talking arrant guff about the Queen Mother is regarded, at least by some of our more popular newspapers, as a sign of grace. There is also a theoretical justification for all the mystical nonsense. The Queen apparently believes that she is the Lord's anointed, chosen by providence to rule over us. It is a strange sort of meritocracy which has such a person as its head of state.

I console myself with the thought that the month of false sentiment which we now endure can only add to the pressure to bring our constitution up to date. The mood is already changing and the monarchists, who once took the divine right for granted, are beginning to defend their indefensible position with arguments which are as spurious as the institution they admire is anachronistic. A A Gill, in the Sunday Times a couple of weeks ago, warned that a republic might be led by a President Hattersley or a President Tebbit - undoubtedly a terrible prospect but not one which ought to keep us awake at night.

The president this country needs would have no executive authority. The prejudiced and partial decisions about how the nation is run would be taken, as they always have been, by the government in parliament. The head of state would be a jovial person (thus ruling out Tebbit and me) - content to sign bills into law, meet foreign dignitaries at airports and perform various other honorific functions without even the slightest suggestion that the office had anything to do with power.

Ideally, it should be somebody of whom we have never heard. I challenge you to tell me the name of the president of Germany. Perhaps more important, in the summer of 2000, we can be absolutely sure that his mother is not exalted above all others or that when he dies, his widow will be elevated to the status of saint and martyr. Nor will his son automatically succeed him to the presidency. If that seems a reasonable state of affairs, whether you know it or not, you are a republican.

webTitle: The primary school where crack dealers and yardies came calling - for the headteacher

fields.headline: The primary school where crack dealers and yardies came calling - for the headteacher
fields.standfirst:
Angela Ellis was headteacher of a north London primary school. She was highly regarded and even praised by Ofsted for her originality and vision. But then life spun out of control. Friends and family got caught up in crack cocaine and ran up huge debts. Yardie gangsters came calling at the school gates. She had a gun put to her head. Pleas for help to the local education authority went largely ignored. Now, out of a job and in despair, she tells her extraordinary story
Education Unlimited
Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Angela Ellis was headteacher of a north London primary school. She was highly regarded and even praised by Ofsted for her originality and vision. But then life spun out of control. Friends and family got caught up in crack cocaine and ran up huge debts. Yardie gangsters came calling at the school gates. She had a gun put to her head. Pleas for help to the local education authority went largely ignored. Now, out of a job and in despair, she tells her extraordinary story
fields.body:
It is no longer shocking to hear of secondary school students becoming involved with drugs. It would be shocking but not unprecedented to find primary school students doing the same. However, this is the story of a primary school headteacher who was sacked last month for stealing from her school after becoming embroiled in the payment of drug debts to a gang of armed crack dealers.

If you wanted to find a perfect symbol for the poisonous spread of poverty into Britain's schools and for the almost equally toxic effect of government policy on education, you need look no further than the strange and terrible story of Angela Ellis, who was the dynamic and successful headteacher of Stamford Hill primary school in Haringey, north London, until she fell foul of yardie dealers.

For two years, staff at the school witnessed a series of increasingly bizarre incidents. In the summer of 1998, somebody who had access to school keys stole cash and cheques from the safe. Classroom computers went missing and turned up in pawn shops. The money that the school steel band had earned disappeared. The headteacher had "strange visitors" in her office, went missing for long periods, borrowed a total of £3,500 from staff and called in to say she could not come to work, because she was hiding from yardies who were threatening to kill her.

After her sacking last month, Ellis, now 40, homeless and penniless, spoke to us. She talked about the night when a gun was held to her head, about a brother who was killed by dealers and a son who ran up huge debts to yardies, which she tried to pay off. She says she never used drugs herself. "It's about a drug culture that surrounds me," she said.

Her story uncovers a picture of a school invaded by the crude violence of its surroundings, of a desperate headteacher collapsing into chaos and, perhaps most significant, of the catastrophic failure of every single system that was supposed to support her:

 Ofsted visited a full year after staff first noted behaviour and yet the inspection team passed the school and commended Angela Ellis's vision;

 The school had no effective governing body - the chairman had resigned and not been replaced, there were unfilled vacancies, some governors failed to turn up and the governing body had simply ceased to run the school;

 Haringey local education authority consistently failed to support the school and then found it had been stripped of the power to deal with the crisis;

 The Department for Education was intent on privatising parts of the LEA, pushed out the director of education and tied up senior officials in long political negotiations.

Those close to the school say it is an extreme example of the danger of the government's drive to bypass LEAs, pushing funds and power down to headteachers and governors who may not have the time or the skills to handle them. They say the school had suffered a series of cuts in budget which had put enormous stress on the head.

Ellis does not pretend she did right. "I'm not saying I was completely innocent. Perhaps I am involved deeper than I want to be in things around me, but I was still trying to pull it together and run a school and run a personal life that was all falling apart. It has been a seedy underworld, but you have to protect people around you."

She had been a teacher for six years before she transferred to Stamford Hill in September 1995. The primary school, which has 260 pupils, stands on the edge of a notorious red light area. "There is drugs and prostitution day and night. We get drugs stuff in the playground, coming in off the street." In September 1997, she became headteacher. She tried to protect the school from its surroundings with extra security - a higher perimeter fence and a buzzer on the door to keep out intruders - but the drugs culture reached her at home.

She had friends and family who were using crack cocaine. In the winter of 1998, her brother, a dealer, was run off the road and killed in New York. Her 24-year-old son was using heavily. She says she does not know who broke into the school safe that summer but adds that she used to leave her keys lying around at home.

She knows it was someone in her family who pawned the school's iMac computers. "People that were close to me used it as a means of paying off what can only be described as drug debts. It was an indirect thing. I didn't realise at the time what was going on. At various times I took computers out of the school with the intention of returning them, but then it all got out of hand. I know who took them to the pawn shop. They had been in my home about two weeks before they went. I didn't personally take them but in an indirect way, I was responsible."

As her problems at home worsened, she began to suffer from the stress of her work. The school's budget has been hit by annual cuts of at least £30,000. At about the time she became head, the roof fell in on two classrooms, and it was 18 months before the LEA repaired it. The chairman of governors wrote 56 letters to the LEA pleading for help, received answers to only six and was given no extra funds. The school had trouble recruiting teachers and was forced to take on expensive supply staff. According to one of those who worked with Ellis, "she began to unravel". She went to the doctor and started to take time off for stress.

In June 1999, after a two-week absence, she returned to prepare for an Ofsted inspection, working until 3am on paperwork until, she says, she was so exhausted she had to ask the chairman of governors to deliver the papers for her. In their report, the inspectors praised her vision, although they noted that she carried a considerable workload. Ellis, however, drowning in stress after the Ofsted visit, simply failed to turn up to plan the new school year, and some parents brought their children to school in September without knowing what classes they were to be in.

That month, staff approached the chairman of governors about the headteacher's absences and about missing cash and school equipment. The LEA was given a written account of their worries. The LEA agreed to send the head to occupational health, who confirmed she was ill, but blocked the chair of governor's request for an audit of the school's finances and a running check on the whereabouts of computers. In November, the chairman resigned in protest at the LEA's failure to act.

Ellis was now alone. She belonged to no union. The chairman had been very active, but no one was appointed to replace him. The governing body was short of co-opted members because so few people in the community were willing to do the job. Some LEA governors failed to turn up. Months passed without a meeting. Haringey LEA was no better, distracted by a highly critical Ofsted inspection and embroiled in a struggle for survival with private consultants acting for the DfEE. Officials spent days in negotiations. The director of education was pushed out by ministers . Ellis says the LEA link inspector was very good but his time was stretched across too many schools. "The LEA could see I needed help. They just let me work through it, no matter how many stress certificates I sent in."

She says she was too distracted by stress to see how tightly crack cocaine was gripping some of those close to her. She found out in January, when three Yardies came to her house. "Somebody opened the door and they burst in. One of them held a gun to my head and they made demands for money they said they were owed. They said certain members of my family around the world would die. They knew my brother had died. They wanted £5,500."

That week, she and her son left their house. Ellis borrowed from her family and from teachers at school, a total of £3,500. Staff became increasingly fearful of their head's associates, who would disappear into her office or simply take her off for the day. One teacher agreed to meet the head and her boyfriend in the street to hand over £300 and was so unnerved by the experience that she was scared to sleep in her house.

Kitchen staff found someone had stolen their weekly lottery money; petty cash that had been earned by the steel band went missing. Ellis denies that she ever stole from the school. She agrees that she started to disappear for long periods. "I had a conversation with my deputy head and I said my life was at risk and I had left my home. My son had been run over, and I think it was no accident. I went to a safe house."

She was in real fear of the yardies - too scared to go to the police, too scared to identify them. It occurred to her that they might even attack the school to put pressure on her. "If they want to protect themselves, they will kill - whoever gets in the way, they will just take out other people."

On January 18, with more computers missing and the head borrowing cash in the staffroom, teachers went to their union. On February 15, a group of governors met but still could not agree on a new chair. The next day, with the NUT pushing, two LEA officials met staff, but the LEA had long ago lost the power to suspend or sack the headteacher. That was the job of the chair of governors. Who did not exist. The LEA agreed to set up an audit.

Two more months passed. The governors could not appoint a chair. There was a rumour that the headteacher had broken in at night with a man and slept there.

Ellis says this never happened. Finally, on April 11, a new governor was co-opted by the LEA and agreed to become chairwoman. Nine days later, she suspended the head.

The LEA audit team reported. Four computers, two laptops and video equipment were missing. And they had found a bag which the headteacher had left which contained cheques which had been stolen from the school safe in 1998. Some of them had been used with the forged signature of one of the governors. Ellis denies ever seeing the stolen cheques let alone forging signatures on them. On May 11, her pay was stopped. On June 7, she was sacked for gross misconduct.

Now, she has been enveloped by the poverty which she once tried to keep outside the school fence. Paying off the drug debts, she could not afford the rent on her home and has lost it. She put possessions into storage and believes she has lost them too because she failed to pay the weekly fee. "The clothes I am wearing are all I have," she said. "I sleep at a friend's house."

She is angry with the LEA. "The only time they stepped in was to say that I had commited all these crimes and that was the end of my contract. I got one lousy letter to say they were going to assess my fitness to run the school.

"I have never taken drugs. I have never even smoked a cigarette. I don't even drink alcohol. Thing just spiralled out of control. They think I was doing this for personal gain. I have never gained anything from what was going on around me."

But mostly, she is angry with herself: "I have been a really lousy parent and really lousy to people around me that needed my support. It's obvious I can't teach any more because this thing is going to be round my neck for the rest of my life.

"I'm a head. A head is not supposed to want help. Everybody else comes to school with problems and I am supposed to sort them out."

The primary school, which has 260 pupils, stands on the edge of a notorious red light area. "There is drugs and prostitution day and night. We get drugs stuff in the playground, coming in off the street." In September 1997, she became headteacher. She tried to protect the school from its surroundings with extra security - a higher perimeter fence and a buzzer on the door to keep out intruders - but the drugs culture reached her at home. She had friends and family who were using crack cocaine. In the winter of 1998, her brother, a dealer, was run off the road and killed in New York. Her 24-year-old son was using heavily. She says she does not know who broke into the school safe that summer but adds that she used to leave her keys lying around at home. She knows it was someone in her family who pawned the school's iMac computers. "People that were close to me used it as a means of paying off what can only be described as drug debts. It was an indirect thing. I didn't realise at the time what was going on. At various times I took computers out of the school with the intention of returning them, but then it all got out of hand. I know who took them to the pawn shop. They had been in my home about two weeks before they went. I didn't personally take them but in an indirect way, I was responsible." As her problems at home worsened, she began to suffer from the stress of her work. The school's budget has been hit by annual cuts of at least £30,000. At about the time she became head, the roof fell in on two classrooms, and it was 18 months before the LEA repaired it. The chairman of governors wrote 56 letters to the LEA pleading for help, received answers to only six and was given no extra funds. The school had trouble recruiting teachers and was forced to take on expensive supply staff. According to one of those who worked with Ellis, "she began to unravel". She went to the doctor and started to take time off for stress. In June 1999, after a two-week absence, she returned to prepare for an Ofsted inspection, working until 3am on paperwork until, she says, she was so exhausted she had to ask the chairman of governors to deliver the papers for her. In their report, the inspectors praised her vision, although they noted that she carried a considerable workload. Ellis, however, drowning in stress after the Ofsted visit, simply failed to turn up to plan the new school year, and some parents brought their children to school in September without knowing what classes they were to be in. That month, staff approached the chairman of governors about the headteacher's absences and about missing cash and school equipment. The LEA was given a written account of their worries. The LEA agreed to send the head to occupational health, who confirmed she was ill, but blocked the chair of governor's request for an audit of the school's finances and a running check on the whereabouts of computers. In November, the chairman resigned in protest at the LEA's failure to act. Ellis was now alone. She belonged to no union. The chairman had been very active, but no one was appointed to replace him. The governing body was short of co-opted members because so few people in the community were willing to do the job. Some LEA governors failed to turn up. Months passed without a meeting. Haringey LEA was no better, distracted by a highly critical Ofsted inspection and embroiled in a struggle for survival with private consultants acting for the DfEE. Officials spent days in negotiations. The director of education was pushed out by ministers . Ellis says the LEA link inspector was very good but his time was stretched across too many schools. "The LEA could see I needed help. They just let me work through it, no matter how many stress certificates I sent in." She says she was too distracted by stress to see how tightly crack cocaine was gripping some of those close to her. She found out in January, when three Yardies came to her house. "Somebody opened the door and they burst in. One of them held a gun to my head and they made demands for money they said they were owed. They said certain members of my family around the world would die. They knew my brother had died. They wanted £5,500." That week, she and her son left their house. Ellis borrowed from her family and from teachers at school, a total of £3,500. Staff became increasingly fearful of their head's associates, who would disappear into her office or simply take her off for the day. One teacher agreed to meet the head and her boyfriend in the street to hand over £300 and was so unnerved by the experience that she was scared to sleep in her house. Kitchen staff found someone had stolen their weekly lottery money; petty cash that had been earned by the steel band went missing. Ellis denies that she ever stole from the school. She agrees that she started to disappear for long periods. "I had a conversation with my deputy head and I said my life was at risk and I had left my home. My son had been run over, and I think it was no accident. I went to a safe house." She was in real fear of the yardies - too scared to go to the police, too scared to identify them. It occurred to her that they might even attack the school to put pressure on her. "If they want to protect themselves, they will kill - whoever gets in the way, they will just take out other people." On January 18, with more computers missing and the head borrowing cash in the staffroom, teachers went to their union. On February 15, a group of governors met but still could not agree on a new chair. The next day, with the NUT pushing, two LEA officials met staff, but the LEA had long ago lost the power to suspend or sack the headteacher. That was the job of the chair of governors. Who did not exist. The LEA agreed to set up an audit. Two more months passed. The governors could not appoint a chair. There was a rumour that the headteacher had broken in at night with a man and slept there. Ellis says this never happened. Finally, on April 11, a new governor was co-opted by the LEA and agreed to become chairwoman. Nine days later, she suspended the head. The LEA audit team reported. Four computers, two laptops and video equipment were missing. And they had found a bag which the headteacher had left which contained cheques which had been stolen from the school safe in 1998. Some of them had been used with the forged signature of one of the governors. Ellis denies ever seeing the stolen cheques let alone forging signatures on them. On May 11, her pay was stopped. On June 7, she was sacked for gross misconduct. Now, she has been enveloped by the poverty which she once tried to keep outside the school fence. Paying off the drug debts, she could not afford the rent on her home and has lost it. She put possessions into storage and believes she has lost them too because she failed to pay the weekly fee. "The clothes I am wearing are all I have," she said. "I sleep at a friend's house." She is angry with the LEA. "The only time they stepped in was to say that I had commited all these crimes and that was the end of my contract. I got one lousy letter to say they were going to assess my fitness to run the school. "I have never taken drugs. I have never even smoked a cigarette. I don't even drink alcohol. Thing just spiralled out of control. They think I was doing this for personal gain. I have never gained anything from what was going on around me." But mostly, she is angry with herself: "I have been a really lousy parent and really lousy to people around me that needed my support. It's obvious I can't teach any more because this thing is going to be round my neck for the rest of my life. "I'm a head. A head is not supposed to want help. Everybody else comes to school with problems and I am supposed to sort them out." Additional research by Helene Mulholland

fields.headline: The way forward
fields.standfirst:
Sir Peter Kemp, former Whitehall mandarin, subjects our
                                                  women's manifesto to a reality check, and suggests that a women's unit headed by a man might be a good idea
fields.trailText:
Sir Peter Kemp, former Whitehall mandarin, subjects our
                                                  women's manifesto to a reality check, and suggests that a women's unit headed by a man might be a good idea.
fields.body:
When prime minister, James Callaghan is said to have rebuked a colleague who wanted to have a minister for the family by saying: "In this government we are all ministers for the family". The creation of a pervasive awareness of what true equal opportunities means is what Labour in its second term should promise to achieve for women, as well, of course, as for ethnic minorities, gays and other groups perceived as disadvantaged.

The task is to create knowledge of where the inequalities are and a means of removing them. The women's unit proposed will be a good first step. It should have a base in cabinet but no executive power, this lying with individual departments and agencies. To show real commitment, it might be headed by a man. It will certainly be fearless and public speaking. Departmental ministers should be a favourite target.

The audit of practice by employers on equal pay, including the public sector and contractors for the public sector, should be pursued. But not solely on this issue - it should become part of the wider social audit and reporting which all companies should be involved in.

The time is certainly right for a review of income tax and national insurance regimes that might discriminate against - or even sometimes in favour of - women. Women should beware of moves to translate cash benefits for the family into tax credits (potentially a reversal of the "wallet to purse" policies of the 1970s so opposed by men). A study should concentrate on the effective take-home effect of any change. This goes very much for child support and child care and the concept of ensuring that women's income for what is still largely a woman's job should be pursued.

Many people, including many women, have doubts about the notion of what could effectively become positive discrimination when it comes to women's representation on company boards, quangos, local authorities, parliament and so on. In the world that the manifesto should aspire to these should not be necessary.

webTitle: Spaced out by the mundane needs of working life

fields.headline: Spaced out by the mundane needs of working life
fields.trailText: Working in cyberspace presents many problems - but one of the biggest headaches is finding the right hole in the real world to work out of. No matter how online you are, office space, equipment and all the other mundane needs of business have to be well managed.
fields.body:
Working in cyberspace presents many problems - but one of the biggest headaches is finding the right hole in the real world to work out of. No matter how online you are, office space, equipment and all the other mundane needs of business have to be well managed.

Believe us, we have seen the lot. There are internet incubators with dot.com executives crammed into tiny spaces, established companies with huge corporate boardrooms and cutting-edge marketing teams working in loft-like luxury.

For dot.coms, "meeting and greeting" space in particular seems to be in scarce supply. As organisations recruit at pace, it seems meeting space gets pushed out in favour of work space.

But you never know what to expect from start-ups. We had one meeting last week in a relatively small, unattractive open-plan office in London that was being shared by at least six dot.com start-ups. So packed was the office that we had to negotiate to get a square foot of privacy. For those start-ups selling things online, the problem of storing goods is as important as providing space for workers. One online retailer we visited didn't bother dividing staff from products. They had solved the problem by having their people work around the products they sell.

Every inch of space was taken. Alongside and in between the usual PCs and office furniture were piles of boxes which blocked out the light. The business was a success and the office - where about 30 people were based - had obviously been outgrown a long time ago.

In the same week, and in stark contrast, we visited one of the country's largest high street retailers. This was very much the traditional suit and tie operation with huge offices and a separate suite of meeting rooms.

We were in with the top managers and looked on with envy. The first thing that struck us was that looking around the large and ornate meeting room with the four of us in it, we noticed how our entire workforce - 10 and rising - could have happily occupied it with room to spare.

Interestingly some large organisations have by accident rather than design created a busy start-up atmosphere with an economic attitude towards space and equipment. This tends to be where the parent company has set up a separate internet business and given them clear resources and space to work with.

The problem here appears to be how fast the new economy side of the business swallows up the old - and will the holders of purse strings let them have the office space to do so.

 Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are co-founders of Rools.com, a service that lets teenagers buy securely online without a credit card.

fields.headline: The way forward
fields.standfirst: Sir Peter Kemp, former Whitehall mandarin, submits our Guardian wishlists to a reality check, and finds that the government must continue to build on devolution
fields.trailText: Sir Peter Kemp, former Whitehall mandarin, submits our Guardian wishlists to a reality check, and finds that the government must continue to build on devolution.
fields.body:
The manifesto should promise that the government carries through its achievements in devolution in Scotland and Wales and, circumstances permitting, in Northern Ireland. These were not intended to be overgrown local authorities. The Westminster parliament and Whitehall must take positive steps to withdraw, painful though it will be for them.

Two steps are needed, as suggested in the manifesto. The posts of secretary of state for Scotland and Wales (and, it must be hoped when settled down properly, Northern Ireland) should go. The idea of a "minister of the Isles" should be pursued - there is an effective one of these already, in the home secretary, where the Isle of Man, Channel Islands and so on are concerned. This residual responsibility should concern overall budgeting matters and the various territories' interest in reserved national matters such as defence, many international concerns and other similar aspects necessary for the integrity of the United Kingdom.

But in following through its logic the manifesto should promise that, subject to these reserved matters (which should be as minimal as possible), the territories should have more freedom than they have now. Abortion and broadcasting, certainly. But a government that believes in devolution should go further, even dramatically further, for instance by introducing more devolved tax regimes and regionally differentiated social security regimes and benefits.

As the manifesto says, the corollary of this is that the "West Midlothian" question must be tackled head-on, with Scottish and Welsh members at Westminster prohibited from discussing or voting on purely English affairs. There might be room for a standing constitutional commission to oversee the relationships and any specific issues that come up across the divides. Such a commission might be the vehicle for re-examining the "Barnett Formula" that allocates Westminster money to the devolved areas.

Labour has made a good start, but in its second term it must build on this.

fields.headline: M25 three freed
fields.standfirst: The issue explained
fields.trailText: Michael Davis, Randolph Johnson and Raphael Rowe - convicted of a murder and a series of robberies around the M25 - were today freed by the court of appeal amid scenes of uproar.
fields.body:
Michael Davis, Randolph Johnson and Raphael Rowe - convicted of a murder and a series of robberies around the M25 - were today freed by the court of appeal amid scenes of uproar.

Known as the M25 three, they were jailed for life in 1990 for a series of attacks in December 1988, including the murder of hairdresser Peter Hurburgh. The appeal case was based on the evidence of the three men - all black - who argued that four of the six victims referred to at least one of the offenders being white.

There was uproar in court as the appeals by the three men were upheld. Today's verdict followed a decision in the European court of human rights, which ruled that the appellants' trial had violated article six of the convention as the prosecution had used public interest immunity certificates to deny them evidence.

The three men had their case referred back to the court of appeal by the criminal cases review commission. The crown had argued that a breach of the European human rights convention, considered to be a "knockout blow" in favour of the three, should not lead to any presumption of an unsafe verdict. But Patrick O'Connor, for Rowe, told Lord Justice Mantell, Mr Justice Blofeld and Mrs Justice Rafferty that "in such a case the impact of the violation is that there must be a strong presumption at least that the conviction is unsafe".

fields.headline: CRE attacks Woodhead for 'ignoring race'
fields.standfirst:
Education Unlimited
Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Chris Woodhead, chief inspector of schools in England, will this week stand accused by the Commission for Racial Equality of ignoring race issues.
fields.body:
Chris Woodhead, chief inspector of schools in England, will this week stand accused by the Commission for Racial Equality of ignoring race issues.

In a report, the CRE condemns Ofsted, the inspection service, of failing to respond adequately to the Macpherson inquiry into the murder of the black teenager Stephen Lawrence.

Ofsted last night rejected the report, saying it was based on a false premise.

The CRE, while it acknowledges that Ofsted has improved its guidance to inspectors since the inquiry, says Mr Woodhead failed to address racism in his report last year.

"Race equality has yet to become a central part of the corporate culture and discourse within Ofsted," the report, to be published on Wednesday, says. "There is ... no mention of Ofsted's lead role in the prevention of racism through education in the 1998-99 annual report of HM chief inspector of schools.

"This is a notable absence, given the recommendations made in the widely publicised Macpherson report half way through the year in question, and confirmed by the government one month later."

The CRE authors, Audrey Osler, professor of education at Leicester University, and Marlene Morrison, spent a year on the report, Ofsted: School Inspection and Race Equality. In computer searches they found that in 10,623 reports from 1997 to 1999 by school inspectors contracted by Ofsted, 0.18% mentioned the phrase "racial equality" and 0.07% "race equality".

While 17.1% referred to "harassment", only 1.96% referred to "racial harassment".

The CRE accepts that these figures do not tell the whole story but believes they are an indication of Ofsted's reluctance to address race issues. They examined 30 school reports in detail.

The Macpherson report said schools should monitor racist incidents, report them to parents, governors and councils, and publish the number of racist incidents in schools. It recommended "that Ofsted inspections include examination of the implementation of such strategies".

The CRE has written to Mr Woodhead and Estelle Morris, the schools minister, asking for a response.

An Ofsted spokesman said last night that it would wait for publication of the report to make a full response. But he said the report was "very, very poorly researched" and "based on a false premise, a false understanding of what Ofsted's powers and duties are". It was "fundamentally not our job" to prevent and address racism in schools. "To base your whole report on that renders it meaningless."

In its handbooks, Ofsted tells inspectors to examine whether "pupils work in an atmosphere free from oppressive behaviour, such as bullying, sexism and racism... If there is evidence of racism, find out what the school is doing to combat this."

Inspectors should also check whether racial incidents are reported annually to the governing body, parents and the local education authority. "Take particular note of the measures the school takes to prevent bullying, harassment and racial incidents, and decide whether, in your view, they are working."

A CRE spokesman said last night: "The new framework for inspection of schools on race equality does take the matter forward but not to the extent that we would like to see.

"The point that Jack Straw made when he responded to the Macpherson report is that this is everybody's job. Ofsted has got a job to do in this respect the same as everybody else."

fields.headline: Straw blames the empire
fields.standfirst:
Race issues in the UK: special report
Football violence: special report
fields.trailText: Football hooliganism and racism are largely caused by English people with a distorted and racist view of their nationality, the home secretary, Jack Straw, said yesterday.
fields.body:
Football hooliganism and racism are largely caused by English people with a distorted and racist view of their nationality, the home secretary, Jack Straw, said yesterday.

Mr Straw has said in the past that the English have a propensity to violence. But yesterday he attributed racism and xenophobia in part to the baggage of empire, saying the relative smallness of Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland had allowed them to develop a fuller culture.

He said the propensity to violence was one reason the government was rushing through anti-hooligan legislation in the Commons this week.

Ann Widdecombe, shadow home secretary, denied that football violence was a peculiarly English problem, but said that Mr Straw had made concessions on the bill.

The bill, which includes powers for police to detain people for up to 12 hours on suspicion that they are planning to travel abroad to cause disorder, is due to have its committee stage today.

Mr Straw, speaking on GMTV, said he thought racists and xenophobes had attached themselves to the English official supporters' club.

He said almost every public institution in Britain was infected by the "institutional racism" detected in the Metropolitan police by the Macpherson report on the death of Stephen Lawrence.

Interviewed by Sir Herman Ouseley, former head of the Campaign for Racial Equality, Mr Straw said the Euro 2000 riots had proved that hooliganism could not be blamed on a small, hardcore minority of thugs.

fields.headline: Body found in hunt for missing Sarah
fields.standfirst: More about the Sarah Payne case
fields.trailText: Detectives hunting for missing eight-year-old Sarah Payne today found the body of a young girl north of Littlehampton.
fields.body:
Detectives hunting for missing eight-year-old Sarah Payne today found the body of a young girl north of Littlehampton.

The body was found near the grounds of Brinsbury agricultural college, in Pulborough, West Sussex, about ten miles from the area where Sarah disappeared on July 1.

Assistant chief constable Nigel Yeo said that Sarah's parents had been informed but could not confirm that the body was that of the missing schoolgirl.

Mr Yeo said the priority would be to identify the body. "Obviously some missing people can travel quite long distances. We have to be careful not to jump to any conclusions," he said. "We have to actually go on the evidence and one of the first things that my colleagues will be doing today is to try to confirm who is the victim of this tragedy, to try to find out whether it's related to this inquiry."

"For somebody, possibly the Payne family, this is very sad," he added.

Police were notified of the discovery of a partially covered body just after 11am by a young man walking near the college grounds. Search teams were sent to the area, followed by a Home Office pathologist. The area, little more than 10 metres from the A29 and covered by six-foot-high ferns, had not been previously searched. Forensic officers, CID members and a search team are currently carrying out fingertip searches of the area as police helicopters hover overhead. Mr Yeo said the mood among his officers was grim.

"Everyone shared a great degree of hope that we would find Sarah alive, there is a lot of sadness because whatever has happened, what we have down the road is a human tragedy, whoever it is." Sarah was last seen at Kingston Gorse, near East Preston, West Sussex. Police believe she was abducted after she left her two brothers and sister with whom she had been playing in a cornfield.

Her parents, Sara and Michael, both 31, were told of the news by detective superintendent Alan Ladley and family liaison officers from the force. They were this afternoon still at the house of Sarah's grandparents, Terry and Lesley Payne, in Kingston Gorse.

fields.headline: Headliners, Executives and Presidents
fields.trailText: GOODISON'S GAZZA GAMBLE
fields.body:
GOODISON'S GAZZA GAMBLE

The world of football rejoiced today as everybody's favourite roly-poly funster Paul Gazza joined Everton from Middlesbrough on a free transfer. But why is everyone so happy? Because the two-year deal he's signed guarantees top-flight laugh-a-minute larks for all until 2002, of course. Mind you, there may not be much in the way of amusement over at Liverpool, whose players could be forgiven for wondering exactly what a pumped-up Gazza will try in the Merseyside derby to prove his loyalty to the cause.

"It's a gamble and hopefully I won't let anyone down," the plump playmaker told the world's press today, kindly providing them with a line to trot out when everything goes plastic-breasts up. "Things didn't go well for me at Boro, although I was unlucky with the injuries," he said, hiding his left elbow under the table. As if to prove a point he went on: "Everybody knows I haven't got any brains, they're in my feet."

What Everton regulars will think of all this is anybody's guess, but at least club vice-president Bill Kenwright is looking forward to seeing Gazza tear around Goodison all red-faced and out of breath. "What was the most dominant thing for me in signing Gazza was the passion," he enthused. "It was abundant... a fantastic passion!" A slightly over-excited Kenwright then told the press he had signed "a headliner" and "a cherry of a real footballing nature". Quite what that means we're not sure. But whatever happens to Gazza at Goodison, at least there's someone who speaks his language.

HEY BROTHER, CAN YOU SPARE A SEAT ON THE BOARD?

He used to be known as Money. The sort of married man who could walk into a Brazilian hotel and make the women swoon just by waving his chequebook, sorry, hand. The type of astute businessman that would contemplate selling the biggest club in Britain to a man who sees UFOs for £10m and a new stand. The type of moralist who would also contemplate selling the club to Robert Maxwell. Or Rupert Murdoch, for that matter. But today, Money Martin Edwards is no more. At least for now.

Manchester United (that's the plc) informed the stock exchange this morning that, as of August 1, Money Mart will step down as chief executive of Manchester United (that's the football club) and will be replaced by Peter Kenyon. Kenyon immediately took the opportunity to answer the questions the supporters are asking (at least those who don't have to pay to get into Old Trafford). Will United break their wage structure to sign "the big stars"? "There won't be any major changes." Will the Imperial Lord Ferg stay on as manager? "Everybody at Manchester United [not sure which one] would like Sir Alex to stay as long as he feels he wants to."

So it's the people's Kenyon, with Money Mart languishing in the role of "non-executive chairman" of Manchester United (the football club). Money, however, is still expected to put himself forward as chairman of Manchester United (the plc) when current chair Sir Roland Smith stands down in 2000. But he faces a strong challenge from Manchester United (the plc) non-executive director Roy Gardner. Roy is the boss of Centrica (who own both British Gas and the AA) and therefore has experience running concerns which have nothing to do with each other (like say a football club and a money-printing operation). Money meanwhile only has around 50,000 enemies in the terraces. Who will win out, we wonder?

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I can't see any malice because he did not have a good command of the language in which the contract was written" - A lawyer for Tony Yeboah, explaining why the former Leeds fat boy failed to pay tax on £750,000 of earnings. Must remember that one come tax return time.

REAL TIME

Pepe Fiver, the Fiver's easily duped Spanish cousin, has not had a great time of it recently. Firstly he got into a little trouble going the wrong way up a one way street during the Pamplona bull run. Then he spent 200m pesetas investing in lastminuto.com, before acquiring the Iberian distribution rights to "Honest" off some bloke in a black Seat convertible. Fortunately his luck turned yesterday when he cast a vote for Florentino Perez in Real Madrid's presidential election. Perez won against all the odds you see, and that means that Luis Figo is definitely signing for Real! Definitely!

"As I've said before I've done everything necessary to bring Figo to Real Madrid," Perez said today after he was elected to the club's presidency on the back of a campaign which amounted solely to a promise to buy Spanish football's biggest star for a world-record fee (and the guarantee of a free season ticket for every member, at a cost of over £8m, if he didn't). "What's happened is that since the news broke he [Figo] has been under such pressure that I'm going to have to start work immediately on this," Perez said, trying the old, I-would-complete-the-transfer-but-his-phone's-been-engaged line.

Of course, the longer Figo's in the shower, the more likely people are to believe Perez's vanquished predecessor, Lorenzo Sanz, who claimed during the election that Perez was talking rubbish. Not to mention Figo himself who said he had made no arrangement to join Madrid and had in fact been caught on camera calling Madrid fans "cry babies" (a harsh epithet if ever there was one). Not that Pres Perez is all that bothered. He stood up today and reassured fans once more that: "One of the two things is going to happen." Yep, and even Pepe might be able to guess which one.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Barcelona defender Winston Bogarde is the subject of a £5m bid from Chelsea. A deal could be completed by the end of the week.

Liverpool are to step up their pursuit of Middlesbrough left-back Christian Ziege. But Gerard Houllier has denied offering Titi Camara as part of a £5m bid.

Newcastle are preparing a £3.1m offer for Galatasaray midfielder Sergen Yalcin.

Manchester City will make a £4.5m bid for 6ft 7in Czech Republic striker Jan Koller.

Charlton have joined Celtic in taking an interest in Aston Villa midfielder Alan Thompson. The ex-Bolton player would cost £2.5m.

Wimbledon expect to sign former Arsenal and Liverpool midfielder Michael Thomas on a free transfer this week.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Aston Villa manager John Gregory is hopeful that Benito Carbone will return to the club. Gregory said: "I have spoken to him in the last two days and the door is not shut. He has got until the weekend to make a decision before I go to plan B. He can't keep us hanging around. The talks were quite positive. I hope we can sort it out because it would be a big boost to see him back here."

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Channel 5: Major League Soccer (3am, 4.30am)

What's so major about it?

Sky Sports 2: World Football Show (6.30pm, 10.45pm SS1)

You call this a show?

British Eurosport: Football (5pm)

And what the hell is this?

webTitle: The unkindest price cuts of all

fields.headline: The unkindest price cuts of all
fields.standfirst: Roy Greenslade on the latest national newspaper circulation figures
fields.trailText: Roy Greenslade on the latest national newspaper circulation figures
fields.body:
It is galling for journalists to accept, but there can't be the least doubt: price cuts make a difference. Circulation rises whenever a paper sells itself cheaply, whether tabloid or broadsheet. Look at the Scotsman's phenomenal surge over the past two months, up from 78,000 in April to a record-breaking 105,000 last month, due to a discounting operation as potent in its results as the one launched by Rupert Murdoch in 1993 to boost the Times's sale.

The Mirror, having suffered a blip in its gradual sales rise of recent times, cut its price to 20p last Saturday and added something like 500,000 more sales. The Sun, also at 20p that day, rose dramatically too. The Daily Telegraph couldn't hope to survive unless almost half its sale was at a cut rate. Similarly, the Independent's tenuous grip on a 225,000 headline sale is reliant on 30,000 discounts and 34,000 bulks.

Too many modern newspaper readers have come to expect something for nothing. Some are promiscuous, cherry-picking daily for the best buy. Many don't always give up their regular paper, but take an extra one.

Occasionally, these expensive exercises bear long-term fruit. The Times did hang on to a great deal of its audience and it will be interesting to see if the Scotsman, which is dedicated to maintaining its price cut, can do the same. It faces new competition soon from a Swedish-owned business daily.

Among the tabloids, which often get spectacular increases when they cut prices, holding on to buyers is much more difficult. The vast majority disappear overnight. They are undoubtedly losing sales to the free Metro, as the haemorrhage of their sales in London proves.

But papers which have preferred to concentrate their resources on consistent editorial excellence and flair have been less disturbed by either the Metro phenomenon or the price-cut fluctuations. They include the Daily Mail, which is owned by the Metro's publisher, the Guardian and, wait for it, the Daily Star.

The Star has enjoyed a surprisingly steady sales record in the past year, a tribute to its editor Peter Hill and his able deputy, Hugh Whittow, along with their small staff. It has weathered the sales decline far better than its better-resourced red-top rivals.

But the Star's future, like that of all Express Newspapers titles, is uncertain. Will they survive whatever emerges from the eventual media conglomeration fought over by their owners, United, along with Carlton and Granada?

I thought I detected a turn-around in the fortunes of the Daily Express recently and possibly even a halt to the rise of the Daily Mail. Yet another good month for the Mail and a lacklustre one for the Express disproves my thesis. The undeniable truth is that improvements to the Express don't impinge one iota on the Mail. It may have an awful lot of Labour-voting readers, but they prefer the editorial package of their right-wing paper. This would have been no surprise to the Mail's founder, Lord Northcliffe. One of his reasons for launching the Mail was his belief that the wider public were not too interested in politics. Oddly, the Mail carries many more political stories and features than the Express. But these are expertly mixed with a range of human interest material which the Express just doesn't have space for.

In the Sunday market, there is no doubting the strength of the Observer's revival, accomplished by making small, incremental advances without the aid of price-cutting. Its intelligent monthly sports magazine OSM, which was promoted on television, probably had an effect. But there has been an all-round editorial improvement while, over at the rival Independent on Sunday, there was a worrying dip in sales despite widespread discounting. Sometimes, it seems, even price cuts don't work!

RG
