webTitle: No 10's leaked memo reveals faults in RIP bill

fields.headline: No 10's leaked memo reveals faults in RIP bill
fields.standfirst:
If it is possible to hack into Downing Street's email, then why does the government want firms to give up their encryption keys, asks online editor Victor Keegan
Memo leak reveals rattled PM
fields.trailText: If it is possible to hack into Downing Street's email, then why does the government want firms to give up their encryption keys, asks online editor Victor Keegan.
fields.body:
Downing Street is understandably in turmoil over the implications the weekend leak revealing Tony Blair's thoughts about where the government is going wrong.

Either the leak is the result of a highly placed "mole" or the work of a hacker.

If it is a mole, then it can be dealt with. After all, Labour in opposition received numerous leaks from civil servants disaffected with the Conservative government. It is embarrassing - but part of a long political tradition of leaking.

But suppose it is the work of hackers. This is a double embarrassment for the government.

If it is possible to tap into the government's allegedly secure website - monitored and protected by the huge resources of MI5, MI6 and GCHQ - then where does this leave corporate sites, or the hundreds of thousands of less sophisticated sites created by small businesses?

The government has pledged to make Britain the best place in the world for e-commerce. But security is at the core of electronic business, to protect payments and to keep commercial secrets intact.

If hackers can access the government's site, it sends a highly pessimistic message to companies around the world planning to do electronic business with UK companies. And, of course, individuals as well.

Which raises the second embarrassment to the government. If the technology exists to break into secure government sites, including possibly emails, then why on earth is the government taking drastic powers through the RIP bill to force companies and individuals to give up their encryption keys?

This move - the exact opposite of the policies of many other western countries - is based on the premise that companies and individuals will have to suffer because of the wider need to track down criminals such as paedophiles (the people least likely to surrender their secret codes).

Yet it appears that the technology exists for the government to track down such people without risking the civil liberties of the rest of the nation. Explanations, please.

webTitle: X-Men shows superhero strength at US box-office

fields.headline: X-Men shows superhero strength at US box-office
fields.trailText: The comic book adaptation, X-Men, has taken $57.5m over its opening weekend, making it the biggest non-holiday, non-sequel ever
fields.body:
The comic book adaptation, X-Men, has opened in the US to huge success. It has taken $57.5m over its opening weekend, making it the biggest non-holiday, non-sequel ever. It is also the fourth largest three-day opening after such heavy weights as The Phantom Menace, Jurassic Park and Mission: Impossible 2.

Early fan reviews of the film were extremely positive (see our story), but the critics were less kind, and suggested that the adaptation was unlikely to appeal to non-comic book fans.

Jonathan Foreman in the New York Post writes that the film "gets off to a terrific start. For the first 20 minutes, it promises to be one of the best-ever movie adaptations of a comic book." But he then adds, "the pace slows, and you're asked to focus on characters so thinly sketched that it's hard to really care what happens to them."

Desson Howe at the Washington Post described it as a "visually entertaining but empty adaptation"; while David Sterritt, writing in the Christian Science Monitor, included a box-office forecast: "My guess is that X-Men will fail to show superhero strength at the ticket window," he wrote, "it has lots of action, some solid performances, and a few real issues on its mind. But it's awfully dark in mood and appearance not an ideal approach to warm-weather escapism." Phillip Wuntch, however, in the Dallas Morning News, concluded that "X-Men will appeal to all your senses without insulting your common sense."

The success of the film with the movie-going public and comic-book fans alike means that sequels are already being planned. According to 20th Century Fox's Tom Sherak: "X-Men's opening bodes well for a sequel. Patrick Stewart and Hugh Jackman have already signed up."

fields.headline: What's in a leak?
fields.standfirst: Government leaks are not a new phenomenon. They have caused outcry and forced cabinet ministers out of office in the past, writes Derek Brown
fields.trailText: Government leaks are not a new phenomenon. They have caused outcry and forced cabinet ministers out of office in the past, writes Derek Brown
fields.body:
The disclosure of the prime ministerial memo is the latest in a long line of leaks, plants and Chinese whispers which have dogged the government since it took office.

Leaking is not a wholly Labour pastime, however. In the 32 months between the general election and the end of last year, the government launched no less than 60 leak inquiries. But in the last two years of the Major government, there were 70 such inquiries.

But the leak that is most deeply graven on the hearts of politicians and Westminster watchers happened longer ago than that. Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchequer in the postwar Labour government, let slip a few morsels from his 1947 budget speech to a wily young Evening Standard reporter, Robert Carvel.

Carvel's story appeared before the Chancellor delivered his speech, and Dalton was obliged to resign in disgrace. Those were the days when leaks sank ships.

There was a feeble echo of the 1947 sensation when, in his first budget speech in 1997, Gordon Brown was accused by Conservatives of leaking some innocuous details. The Chancellor was able to brush aside the attacks by saying that he was only confirming what had been promised in the election campaign.

In the 80s, an esoteric but venomous dispute over how best to bail out the foundering Westland helicopter company ended with the resignation of Conservative ministers Michael Heseltine and Leon Brittan. Each man accused the other of leaking highly sensitive departmental memos.

The last years of the Major government were enlivened by a steady stream of more gossipy leaks about who was in or out of favour, and who stood where on Europe.

In Labour's time, the twin phenomena of leak and plant have become closely intertwined. Over the winter, the Ministry of Defence was embarrassed by a series of disclosures of military cockups. The standard issue army rifle was said to be unreliable; the Royal Navy had ordered its ships to slow down to save fuel; units serving in the Balkans had been issued with faulty radios.

The ministry's embarrassment was genuine. But were the stories leaked to discredit ministers and the top brass, or were they carefully released to put pressure on the Treasury for a bigger military budget?

The Lobby system of reporting government and parliament is ideally suited to the leakers and planters. They can insinuate their stories to the media, secure in the knowledge that they will never be identified.

Of the present cabinet, Home Secretary Jack Straw has been the one most plagued by leaks, notably over his freedom of information legislation - heartily disliked by many Labour MPs who dare not speak out openly against it - and his various schemes for getting tough on crime.

The British establishment's obsessive instinct for secrecy has been gravely undermined since the mid-90s by the growth of the internet. Leaked documents going far beyond tittle-tattle have found their way on to the web. The most explosive, in Whitehall eyes, concern the doings of the spy networks MI5 and MI6.

fields.headline: My big break
fields.trailText: In my 10 years working for news-stand magazines, I've become a bit of an evangelist for student media. And I'm quite rare. Student magazines and newspapers are, often quite rightly, derided for their multitude of sins - horrible, preachy editorial, endless pictures of marching students, and crap poetry.
fields.body:
In my 10 years working for news-stand magazines, I've become a bit of an evangelist for student media. And I'm quite rare. Student magazines and newspapers are, often quite rightly, derided for their multitude of sins - horrible, preachy editorial, endless pictures of marching students, and crap poetry.

But there's another side to them. Student publications are the best breeding ground for anyone wanting to be a journalist. Bar none. You can do a media course if you want (although their quality is distinctly variable, and employers often don't take them seriously), but if you don't write for the college magazine you will never have the experience of testing out your style on the public. Theorise all you like in the classroom, but this is what it's all about.

I usually tell people my big break was a speculative letter to the editor of Smash Hits when I was 20, asking if he had any jobs going. But it wasn't really. My big break was walking into the editorial office of Overdraft magazine - geddit? - in my first week at the Polytechnic of East London. The skills I learned during my year as a writer and a year as the editor stood me in good stead for everything I've done since. My time editing Overdraft's pop column meant I had plenty to show the Smash Hits editor at my interview. My populist approach to college news (beer, sex, drugs, crap TV) led others to believe that I understood late teens and early 20s enough to edit student bible Sky magazine. The impossible deadlines I brought upon myself by leaving things too late meant I was perfect material to edit Emap's weekly celeb-fest, Heat.

So if you're involved with any kind of student journalism and you think what you've done deserves attention, please enter these awards. If you write crap poetry you can just sod off.

 Mark Frith is a judge of the Guardian Student Media Awards. He has been editor of Smash Hits and Sky Magazine, and has edited Heat since its launch early last year.

 You have one more week to enter the Guardian Student Media Awards 2000, please call 0808 100 4878 for an application form. As well as cash prizes and work experience at the Guardian, the overall winner will receive an extended work placement at the Guardian and Guardian Unlimited and a subsistence award of £1,000. The 13 categories include Student Reporter of the Year, Student Photographer of the Year and Student Magazine of the Year. The deadline for entries is 21 July 2000.

fields.headline: Need to know: James Booth
fields.trailText: Age? 35.
fields.body:
Age? 35.

Who is he? Director and co-founder of tangozebra.com, a UK-based internet software company developing solutions for the delivery of multimedia across a network. Former classical guitarist, foreign exchange dealer and computer-based music producer.

What's the clever idea? "The ability to put interactive voice on to the web, in any language, according to user profile, using Tangozebra's N-XEC technology, which requires no additional plug-in software or dedicated streams of data. Our Talking Forms system can produce sentences out of words or phrases and string them together according to interaction of an user."

How does it work? "In the Talking Forms, N-XEC is used to control the playback of audio files in response to a user filling in a form, requesting assistance or making an error. The software loads into the website that contains the interactive form and calls in a series of audio clips. The user accesses the form and a guide voiceover explains the initial process. The user can then activate audio help buttons which explain each specific section, in any language and can be turned on and off at will. These are delivered by unique instructions contained in a special pre-loaded sequencing file that selects which audio clips to put together to produce the correct vocal response."

What's the thinking behind it? "We started in 1996, looking at how we might apply sound on the internet in the same way as images. Talking Forms we've just launched, mainly online shopping and registration forms. Almost everywhere on the net there are forms requesting information. But while there's a rapid increase in online shopping, 75% of users abandon shopping forms because they get confused or need help. We've developed Talking Forms as a solution. The other useful thing, from the corporate point of view, is the built-in tracking mechanism that analyses each stage of the process and allows the retailer to see where the users are having problems and improvements can be made. We've signed three major corporates already: Flextech TV, a classical music website called classical.com and a high street chain."

Possible shortcomings? "From a competitiveness point of view, it isn't suitable for live audio, broadcasting whole pieces of music on the web."

What's next? "A call-back button will be integrated soon into the forms, giving an additional level of help. Also, educational interactive content on the web."

fields.headline: New media diary
fields.trailText: * The biggest internet economy trend of 2000? Assorted analysts in the Industry Standard (www.thestandard.com) nominate:
fields.body:
* The biggest internet economy trend of 2000? Assorted analysts in the Industry Standard (www.thestandard.com) nominate:

1) "The rising power of the audience. Online audiences tend to be much savvier than those offline, and are much less tolerant of traditional advertising and branding campaigns. The disparity between companies that are "clueful" or "clueless" in this respect will become obvious, and will begin to cause substantial shifts in market share." - Christopher Locke, co-author of The Cluetrain Manifesto.

2) "If 1999 was the year of the dot.com, 2000 will be the year of the dot-community. Grassroots sites based on shared values and common interests will steal market share from the big portals." - Andrew Shapiro, author of The Control Revolution.

3) "Take every number from Forrester, Gartner and Jupiter, add them, multiply by two, and you'll have accurate predictions. That's not just a trend, it's my investment model." - Larry Downes, co-author of Unleashing the Killer App.

4) "Dot.coms and e-businesses will be valued on the number of repeat customers, their lifetime value and their retention rate. Internet advertising revenues will be based on customer acquisition bounties and transaction fees, not eyeballs or click-throughs." - Patricia Seybold, chief executive of the Patricia Seybold Group and author of Customers.com.

5) "The next decade will see, I hope, the arrival of data (such as catalogues, weather, stock prices) that will be processable and combinable by machine. It will be the rebirth of knowledge representation, where human meets machine. It will be a chance for a search engine to figure out the real, logical answer to a question instead of drowning you in wild guesses." - Tim Berners-Lee, director of the World Wide Web Consortium.

*Damien Eames in New Media Age: "Internet VCs are forever shifting focus and the new thing is P2P [Path to Profitability]. Unfortunately, fundable P2P businesses are in short supply. If you want to fund a Wap portal (with no idea how it will compete against the network operators) or a digital entertainment studio (with no revenue line in its business model), you'll have no trouble finding a fresh-faced entrepreneur to back. P2P is trickier - for several years profitability hasn't really been as much of an issue as the idea. Is it 'neat' or 'cool'? If so, let's party."

*Vanessa Richardson in Redherring.com: "In the past decade, women have started their own companies at a rate twice that of the national average and now own 38% of all US firms. The number of female-owned ventures has doubled from 4.5m to 9.1m since 1987. By 1999, female-owned companies employed more than 27m people (9m more than 1996) and annual sales had risen from $2.3 trillion to $3.6 trillion in three years."

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: Thwarted in its Premier League bid, but with plenty of money freed up, the BBC is starting to wave its chequebook in a concerted attempt to buy up stars. Channel 4 is a key target in this move to revive BBC1, ordered by director-general Greg Dyke.
fields.body:
* Thwarted in its Premier League bid, but with plenty of money freed up, the BBC is starting to wave its chequebook in a concerted attempt to buy up stars. Channel 4 is a key target in this move to revive BBC1, ordered by director-general Greg Dyke. Award-winning camp comedy star Graham Norton, whose contract with 4 expires in December, is being tempted with close to £5m over two years, more than doubling his current rate, and he won't be the first. Except, confirms Channel 4, he's not signed yet. In part, it's down to uncertainty about whether mainstream BBC1 formats would suit him. "The worst thing you can do is rush into the market and buy up stars for huge sums without knowing what you'll do with them," says a key observer. And there is also the BBC's patchy track record in fostering careers. Two words, Graham: Vanessa Feltz.

* The collapse of the "celebs on screen" show OK!TV after a contract dispute between publisher Richard Desmond and ITV is causing undisguised delight at Carlton. It made the first hit series before parting company with demanding Desmond, who then decided to make the show as an independent, with GMTV's "help". The upshot leaves a fraught Network Centre scrabbling around for a 5.30pm show it can strip five nights a week from September onwards. But ITV can now expect a call from rival magazine Hello!, which competed with OK! for the programme slot, but was pipped to the post because its coverage of obscure European royals didn't thrill. OK!, meanwhile, is expected to switch its affections to Sky, a match made in celebrity heaven.

* Interesting to see trade secrets laid bare. The new showbusiness columnist of the News of the World, Rav "I never stitch up anyone" Singh, modestly explained his route to success last week in the London Evening Standard. His first Fleet Street job was on the Star show-biz desk, but he was nearly fired for having no contacts. "So I started taking the best PRs out for dinner," he said. The result was that he built up a corps of highly-placed publicists he can call at any time, and so now feels he has every significant star covered. Never has the link between showbiz writers and PRs been so candidly put - by a hack. As every PR from Max Clifford upwards knows, little appears in the tabloids by accident.

*Disappointment of last week was the non-appearance of "the globe's biggest adman, J Walter Thompson", billed by Channel 4 - and hence many newspapers - as part of Thursday's panel on The E-Millionaire Show. Resurrection not being among his many talents ("We don't know when Thompson died, but he retired in 1916 aged 69," says JWT), Jon Snow had to make do with live zillionaire Martin Sorrell.

*The BBC makes great play of its beefed-up role as the nation's educator, ready and willing to take us all on "learning journeys". In fact, it won Cabinet support for its new licence fee settlement for precisely that purpose. So the diary was pleased that last year the BBC spent £53m on educational programmes, but confused to learn that Channel 4, its public service rival, quietly stumped up £60m.

fields.headline: SNP leader to stand down
fields.standfirst: Alex Salmond's departure after 10 years leaves another vacancy in Scottish politics, writes Julian Glover
fields.trailText: Alex Salmond's departure after 10 years leaves another vacancy in Scottish politics, writes Julian Glover.
fields.body:
Alex Salmond, leader of the Scottish National party since 1990, has announced that he is to stand down from his post in September, leaving the party to fight the general election under a new leader.

The news will dismay many of the SNP's supporters but has been on the cards for some time. The energetic and likeable campaigner has taken his party to a strong position in Scottish politics, but upset many party activists by moving the SNP away from its socialist roots. His apparent acceptance of devolution as a possible substitute for the party's goal of full independence has also caused party unrest.

The unrest showed in public earlier this year over the suspension of party treasurer Ian Blackford. Blackford threatened to sue Salmond for defamation.

Explaining his decision to go, Salmond said that the SNP was in its strongest position ever, with more than 200 local councillors. The party is also ahead of Labour in the Scottish opinion polls.

Salmond said that he had only come to the decision at the weekend, and believed that 10 years as leader was "an appropriate time" to stand down. He will, however, continue as the Scottish parliament member for Banff and Buchan, in north-east Scotland, for "as long as the people wish me to do so". He has held the seat since 1987.

After his election, Salmond quickly became a prominent political figure, interrupting the budget in 1988 and being suspended from the House of Commons for his protest against the poll tax. A former oil economist, he was a member of the 79 group of SNP radicals and was expelled from the party for a short time in 1981.

More recently the SNP leader has come into conflict with those in his party who want the leadership to pursue a more radical policy. Some party members were also frustrated at the SNP's failure to beat Labour in the first elections to the Scottish parliament last year. Any leadership battle is certain to highlight tensions between impatient fundamentalists and others in the party who do not view immediate Scottish independence as a sensible goal.

Several candidates are likely to put themselves forward but the most obvious successor is deputy leader John Swinney. A respected operator in the Scottish parliament, Swinney shares Salmond's gradualist approach to independence but is widely seen as lacking in charisma. A braver choice would be the maverick patriot Kenny MacAskill, a hardliner who once called England "the great Satan". Other likely candidates include Alex Neil, Andrew Wilson and Roseanna Cunningham, the popular member for Perth and Kinross.

Alex Salmond's resignation makes him the third party leader to leave the job in this parliament, following the departure of the Liberal Democrat leader, Paddy Ashdown, last year and the Plaid Cymru leader, Dafydd Wigley, earlier this year.

His decision means that both of Scotland's main political parties will be leaderless over the summer. First minister Donald Dewar, Labour's leader in Scotland, is still recuperating at home from heart surgery carried out earlier in the year. The Liberal Democrat's Scottish leader, Jim Wallace, is standing in as the country's first minister.

The Liberal Democrat's Scottish leader, Jim Wallace, is standing in as the country's first minister.

fields.headline: Salmond's resignation letter
fields.standfirst: Alex Salmond has announced that he will stand down from the leadership of the Scottish National party this September. This is the full text of his resignation letter.
fields.trailText: Today, I have announced that I shall not be seeking re-election as national convener after a period of 10 years.
fields.body:
Today, I have announced that I shall not be seeking re-election as national convener after a period of 10 years.

I thought I would drop a note to each branch and constituency secretary, SNP councillors and PPCs to explain directly my reasoning for taking this step.

The party is now at its strongest position ever. We are the official opposition in the Scots parliament, we have over 200 local councillors, we lead the Scottish opinion polls and are at over 30% in the Westminster polls.

I am absolutely convinced that the SNP will win the next Scottish election and take Scotland forward to independence.

However, translating that political success onto a personal level, that would effectively lock me into a further decade as party leader.

I have decided instead to pass on the torch.

We have demonstrated that we have a strong team in the Scots parliament and a number of colleagues are well capable of leading the SNP.

In order to give people the full opportunity to submit nominations in this new situation, in consultation with the national secretary, I have extended the deadline for all conference nominations until Friday, August 4.

It has been a rare privilege to lead the SNP over the past decade. In addition, I have enjoyed myself enormously.

I have no complaints and no regrets.

Neither have I any intention of giving up politics. I have told my own constituency party that I will continue as MSP for Banff and Buchan as long as people wish me to do so, and I hope to serve Scotland in the future in some other capacity.

The SNP is a uniquely democratic political party - you elect your leader and sustain him or her by your support.

I have been fortunate in always being able to count on the grass roots of the party - please extend that same loyalty to your new national convener.

Yours for Scotland,

Alex Salmond

fields.headline: Government leaks
fields.standfirst: How does a memo get from the prime minister's own computer to the Fleet Street front pages - and is the leaker breaking the law? Julian Glover explains
fields.trailText: How does a memo get from the prime minister's own computer to the Fleet Street front pages - and is the leaker breaking the law? Julian Glover explains.
fields.body:
What's happened?
A memo written by the prime minister, apparently at Chequers, has been splashed on the front pages of national newspapers, causing acute embarrassment to the government. The memo, sent to a handful of ministers, civil servants and special advisers, on April 29, indicates that there is a mole within Downing Street or, just as worrying, a weakness in the government's computer system that allows hackers to access the prime minister's private documents. As a result, Downing Street security services are rushing to find the source.

Leaks always happen. Why get worried now?
Revelations from the heart of government are common and the fine line between leaking and briefing is uncertain. ("Leaking is what you do; briefing is what I do", as former prime minister Jim Callaghan once put it). But the prime minister's inner circle is usually immune. Since June, however, there have been three significant leaks. Two emails sent by pollster Philip Gould revealed criticism of the prime minister's speech to the Women's Institute; and on Saturday, the Guardian printed emails sent by the prime minister's private secretary, Anji Hunter, about her management of the BBC's fly-on-the-wall documentary on Downing Street. Leaks such as these make life very difficult for those working in Number 10. Like the rest of us, they've come to depend on computers and emails - and it will be hard for Tony Blair to now maintain trust in his personal staff.

So why are these leaks happening?
There's no evidence that the leaks have all come from the same person, although this is possible. What's puzzling everyone is the motive. A common source of leaks is the apparent victim, to get good coverage or do down a rival. But only an ultra cynic would argue that Tony Blair has approved these leaks from Downing Street. Another theory is that hackers have been at work either for fun or for money. Other possibilities include someone with access has been passing them to the press or to the opposition for political reasons, or because of a personal grudge.

Why?
Anyone's guess. In the past, civil servants such as Clive Ponting (over the Belgrano affair) and Sarah Tisdall (over American missiles) leaked documents because they had access to documents on major policy issues which they believed to be morally wrong. But very few civil servants will have seen the Downing Street memos - and anyway, they concern the trivia of government rather than policy. Downing Street has hinted that the Conservative party might have had something to do with it, but haven't offered any evidence so far.

Is leaking illegal?
Almost certainly, if you are a civil servant who has signed the official secrets act. Clive Ponting was tried for sending documents to MPs, although the jury failed to convict him and Sarah Tisdall was sentenced to six months' imprisonment but released after four. The position for MPs is less clear. When they join the Privy Council senior parliamentarians swear to "keep secret all matters committed and revealed", but they are hardly expected to uphold this in practice. It's almost unthinkable for a politician to be prosecuted for leaking; but the prime minister can, of course, end the political career of anyone in his party he decides is guilty.

fields.headline: Timetable: Sarah Payne disappearance
fields.standfirst:
Body of small girl found in hunt for missing Sarah
More about the Sarah Payne case
fields.trailText: Saturday July 1: At 7pm Sarah goes off with her two brothers and sister to play in a secluded wheatfield 150 metres from her grandparents' home near East Preston, West Sussex.
fields.body:
Saturday July 1: At 7pm Sarah goes off with her two brothers and sister to play in a secluded wheatfield 150 metres from her grandparents' home near East Preston, West Sussex.

Sarah hurts herself while playing and decides to walk home. Her 13-year-old brother Lee follows but loses sight of his sister. He tells police he saw a white van and a Ford Mondeo on the lane.

Sarah fails to return home and is reported to the police as a missing person, and a dozen people help officers search the area.

Sunday July 2: A full-scale search is launched involving 300 people, among them police officers with sniffer dogs, soldiers and volunteers. Members of the public are urged to check their gardens. A total of 150 officers are assigned to the job.

Meanwhile, 250 miles away in Cheshire, a woman helps a "distressed" little girl matching Sarah's description - and answering to her name - in a motorway services toilet at Knutsford on the M6 in Cheshire. Police, who are later contacted by the woman, do not release details of the 5am "sighting" for another week for operational reasons.

In the evening a man in his 40s is arrested at a flat in Littlehampton, West Sussex, and a white van is towed away.

Monday July 3: Another man, in his 30s, from the Crawley, West Sussex, area, is arrested. Meanwhile, Sussex Under Water Search Unit scour storm drains leading to the sea and 600 members of the public call in with information.

Tuesday July 4: Police continue to question the two men. Officers are granted an extra 36 hours to question the man in his 40s. Sarah's parents make an emotional TV appeal.

Wednesday July 5: Sarah's brother Lee takes part in an identity parade in Brighton involving the man in his 40s. Police later release both men on bail. Sarah's mother Sara says she is convinced her daughter is still alive.

Thursday July 6: The hunt turns nationwide as police halt mass local searches using volunteers and ask other forces to check their known sex offenders. Sarah's parents make a tearful TV appeal directly addressing their daughter, holding up cards from wellwishers and telling her to "hang in there".

Friday July 7: A reconstruction of Sarah's last-known movements is filmed with the help of four local children who agree to play the parts of the missing eight-year-old and her brothers and sister. Police receive more than 500 calls in response.

Saturday July 8: A fresh appeal is made by Sarah's grandfather Terry, who weeps as he reads out heart-rending messages from her brothers and sister. Meanwhile, police mount a stop-and-question operation to quiz day-trippers to the area exactly a week after Sarah disappeared.

Sunday July 9: The Payne family visit the centre of the police operation at the Littlehampton incident room and thank officers for their tireless work in the search for Sarah.

Monday July 10: Police release details of the possible sighting made at Knutsford eight days earlier, and call for other people who may also have seen Sarah to get in touch. More than 800 new calls come in.

Meanwhile, a second possible sighting is made, in Scotland, but police do not disclose this for two days.

Tuesday July 11: Detectives release an e-fit of the man seen with the girl in Knutsford which is published on the covers of several of Wednesday's national newspapers.

Wednesday July 12: Monday's second possible sighting of Sarah - at a service station on the A80 near Glasgow - is made public by police but they say the description of the man "she" was with does not fit the individual in their e-fit. CCTV footage from the service station is flown down to Sussex for closer scrutiny.

Police say they have now had 10,000 calls from members of the public - more than 20 times the usual response to an appeal on BBC1's Crimewatch UK.

Police announce that a man, thought to be in his 30s, has been arrested on the Wirral in connection with Sarah's disappearance but say the arrest is not a "significant" development and he is likely to be released soon.

Monday July 17:Detectives hunting for missing Sarah find the body of a young girl north of Littlehampton.

fields.headline: Mind the credibility gap
fields.standfirst: The Sunday Times has been hit with a raft of complaints from people featured in its news pages. But the 'victims' would do that, wouldn't they. Roy Greenslade isn't so sure
fields.trailText: The Sunday Times has been hit with a raft of complaints from people featured in its news pages. But the 'victims' would do that, wouldn't they. Roy Greenslade isn't so sure
fields.body:
What are we to make of the Sunday Times? It is a very successful newspaper, handsomely out-selling its rivals with a regular sale in excess of 1.3m. It is a highly professional package with its specialised sections appealing to a broad range of people. It has enjoyed a fine postwar history, transforming itself under the guidance of Denis Hamilton and, later, Harold Evans, from a rather staid paper into a challenging, agenda-setting must-buy for the middle classes.

Despite the misgivings of its staff and some readers, it has prospered under the ownership of Rupert Murdoch and did not, as doom-mongers forecast, decline under the editorship of Andrew Neil. Readers were clearly not put off by his championing of the free market and support for the Tory party. In the years since October 1994, when John Witherow became editor, he has largely kept the paper on its previous political course. But it has been impossible to ignore the groundswell of dissatisfaction from people who have featured in the paper's news pages, its main section.

I have received more unsolicited complaints about the Sunday Times than any other paper and I have written twice in the past year about two very different kinds of story, involving the treatment meted out to ecology protesters and to Prince William.

Many other instances of alleged inaccuracy, distortion and misrepresentation have remained on file and I may well have ignored them but for the sudden eruption of complaints in recent months.

I accept that people and institutions who are embarrassed by stories routinely grumble about the press but it would appear from my conversations, both casual and formal, that the Sunday Times appears to have lost its credibility among the nation's opinion-formers. Readers, on the other hand, have largely remained in the dark about its many alleged errors because, according to the host of complainants I have spoken to, the paper is reluctant to admit any wrong-doing.

This certainly chimes with my experience of having put a number of specific allegations about supposedly untrue stories to the paper. In every instance, the paper's managing editor, Richard Caseby, totally rejected fundamental criticisms of falsehood, in spite of the complainants including the Churches of England and Scotland, St James's Palace, a leading bank and senior political figures.

Caseby's point is that the Sunday Times is "an aggressive investigative paper which often writes about subjects people prefer to keep hidden". In other words, they would complain, wouldn't they? So, given the yawning gap between the paper's view and the views of its "victims", which are backed by my own hunches and experience, I present the case for and against the Sunday Times over 10 hotly disputed stories.

Claim 1: Last December, the paper's hyperactive royal correspondent Christopher Morgan announced: "Queen states she will never meet Camilla." Months later she did so.

Sunday Times reply: "The report was an accurate reflection of the Queen's feeling at the time and she is entitled to change her mind."

Claim 2: On June 18, Morgan, who doubles as the paper's religious affairs correspondent, wrote a story headlined: "Charles explores Scottish wedding with Camilla". This claimed that the Prince of Wales was "exploring" the possibility of marrying Camilla Parker Bowles in "secret discussions" with the Church of Scotland.

Both St James's Palace and the Church's spokespersons denied the story. Instead of making a formal complaint, the moderator of the Church of Scotland, Andrew McLellan, decided to "set the record straight" in an interview on BBC Radio 5 Live. In a straightforward reply to interviewer Nicky Campbell, he denied that any such discussions had occurred.

On Friday, St James's Palace made an official complaint to the Press Complaints Commission (PCC) about both that story and another involving Prince William.

Reply: The Sunday Times stands by its story and points to the fact that the moderator later told the Tablet that a Scottish marriage for the Prince could not be ruled out.

Claim 3: The Church of England contested a front-page story in April, again by Morgan, which alleged that the Archbishop of Canterbury was "anxious" for Charles to marry Camilla. Despite strenuous attempts to get the paper to carry a retraction of what they regarded as a totally false story, the Church's press office eventually threw in the towel.

Reply: "The Archbishop hasn't denied the story, merely questioned its sourcing."

Claim 4: Yet another Morgan story of two weeks ago, headlined "Blair blocks church choice of two bishop candidates" claimed that Tony Blair had rejected the Church of England's preferred candidates for two bishoprics. A Church of England spokesman said: "The story is untrue, simple as that." It was also flatly denied by Downing Street.

Reply: "Our sourcing is impeccable. It isn't surprising that both No 10 and Lambeth Palace deny it because it's so embarrassing."

Claim 5: In April this year a splash headlined "High-street bank backs Rover bid" said that Abbey National was to fund the car firm's takeover by Phoenix. An Abbey National spokeswoman told me unequivocally that the story was wholly untrue.

Reply: "Abbey National admitted the following week that it was in negotiations to provide commercial finance for both Phoenix and Rover dealers through one of its subsidiaries."

Claim 6: A story on April 16 alleged that the Labour party's parliamentary chairman, Clive Soley, had described old people as "racist". He immediately complained to the PCC, vehemently denying having said such a thing and claiming to have been misquoted.

I have known Soley for many years and it's fair to say that we have disagreed profoundly over his past attempts to introduce press regulation. But even when our debates have been heated, I have never found him less than honest. I just cannot imagine him saying anything as crass as the paper implied, nor is it likely that he would have lied about it. During the course of the PCC's attempts to negotiate a deal, the paper provided a transcript of a tape-recorded conversation between Soley and one of their reporters.

But Soley remains convinced that there is important contextual matter missing from the transcript and the PCC's attempt at conflict resolution has so far failed.

Reply: "The paper stands by its story and by the validity of its transcript." Caseby says: "If Mr Soley feels he did not accurately convey his position we have offered to clarify it. To date he has failed to respond to this overture."

Claim 7: Last week Lord Levy also submitted a formal complaint to the PCC about the Sunday Times's story on his tax affairs. The precise terms of the letter are confidential, though it is known that Levy is arguing that the paper broke three clauses of the editors' code of practice.

Reply: "The paper is satisfied that its stories about Levy are true in substance and detail." Caseby says: "We welcome the chance to demonstrate that we have complied fully with the editors' code."

Claim 8: The Levy case, which rests on the paper's alleged distortion of facts, highlights one of the problems complainants often face, as I discovered when looking at another dispute in which the Campaign for State Education (Case) complained about a story in June last year which claimed the group was planning "to close 60 grammar schools".

When the then chairman of Case, David Gordon, wrote to protest that all the central allegations were untrue he was surprised to receive a strong letter in defence of a story he thought indefensible.

The paper would not even agree to correct its most obvious error: Gordon was called Wood in the story. "In the end," says Gordon, "I just gave up. They reduced the whole argument to one of semantics, going over the meaning of every word. The essential point was that, in broad outline, the story was wrong."

Reply: "The Case denial is unsurprising. The story was true, as confirmed by follow-up stories in the Daily Telegraph and Daily Mail."

Claim 9: Gordon believes the overriding reason for the distortion was the paper's political agenda. It had an ulterior motive. That would also appear the case in a story in February last year which insinuated that "Blair crony" Lord Bassam was "at the centre of a controversy" because he might have used his influence to win government contracts for his employer, KPMG.

Bassam immediately said the claims were "preposterous". No other paper took up the claims, so there was no "controversy". The non-story vanished overnight.

Reply: "Our report, prompted by MPs and competing firms questioning Bassam's role, was truthful. It has since emerged that KPMG has won the lion's share of the government's multi-million pound consultancy contracts."

Claim 10: A month later a story headlined "Mandy looks for a nice little earner" alleged that Peter Mandelson's "friends" were seeking a private sector job for him.

Direct quotes in which Mandelson denied the accusation were placed way down the story, but the headline and early paragraphs implied that his denial was not to be believed. Mandelson told me he has never sought any kind of job outside politics.

Reply: Caseby says: "I agree the headline was too strong. It should have more accurately reflected the fact that it was Mandelson's friends, rather than him, seeking a job."

These are far from the only disputed stories. But the Sunday Times is keen to point out that some of its exclusives, which were denied after publication, subsequently turned out to be true. It cites four such instances, including two about the BBC in February concerning redundancies and the sale of its internet service.

Clearly, its recent revelation about a memo from Blair's adviser Philip Gould was spot on. Similarly, its long-running Liam Clarke revelations about the army's dirty tricks activities have been first rate. But the paper's overall record, despite its trenchant defence, still raises journalistic eyebrows - especially those of reporters assigned to follow up its stories, as news desks on rival papers and broadcasting news editors readily point out.

Roy Greenslade is a former employee of the Sunday Times

I just cannot imagine him saying anything as crass as the paper implied, nor is it likely that he would have lied about it. During the course of the PCC's attempts to negotiate a deal, the paper provided a transcript of a tape-recorded conversation between Soley and one of their reporters. But Soley remains convinced that there is important contextual matter missing from the transcript and the PCC's attempt at conflict resolution has so far failed. Reply: "The paper stands by its story and by the validity of its transcript." Caseby says: "If Mr Soley feels he did not accurately convey his position we have offered to clarify it. To date he has failed to respond to this overture." Claim 7: Last week Lord Levy also submitted a formal complaint to the PCC about the Sunday Times's story on his tax affairs. The precise terms of the letter are confidential, though it is known that Levy is arguing that the paper broke three clauses of the editors' code of practice. Reply: "The paper is satisfied that its stories about Levy are true in substance and detail." Caseby says: "We welcome the chance to demonstrate that we have complied fully with the editors' code." Claim 8: The Levy case, which rests on the paper's alleged distortion of facts, highlights one of the problems complainants often face, as I discovered when looking at another dispute in which the Campaign for State Education (Case) complained about a story in June last year which claimed the group was planning "to close 60 grammar schools". When the then chairman of Case, David Gordon, wrote to protest that all the central allegations were untrue he was surprised to receive a strong letter in defence of a story he thought indefensible. The paper would not even agree to correct its most obvious error: Gordon was called Wood in the story. "In the end," says Gordon, "I just gave up. They reduced the whole argument to one of semantics, going over the meaning of every word. The essential point was that, in broad outline, the story was wrong." Reply: "The Case denial is unsurprising. The story was true, as confirmed by follow-up stories in the Daily Telegraph and Daily Mail." Claim 9: Gordon believes the overriding reason for the distortion was the paper's political agenda. It had an ulterior motive. That would also appear the case in a story in February last year which insinuated that "Blair crony" Lord Bassam was "at the centre of a controversy" because he might have used his influence to win government contracts for his employer, KPMG. Bassam immediately said the claims were "preposterous". No other paper took up the claims, so there was no "controversy". The non-story vanished overnight. Reply: "Our report, prompted by MPs and competing firms questioning Bassam's role, was truthful. It has since emerged that KPMG has won the lion's share of the government's multi-million pound consultancy contracts." Claim 10: A month later a story headlined "Mandy looks for a nice little earner" alleged that Peter Mandelson's "friends" were seeking a private sector job for him. Direct quotes in which Mandelson denied the accusation were placed way down the story, but the headline and early paragraphs implied that his denial was not to be believed. Mandelson told me he has never sought any kind of job outside politics. Reply: Caseby says: "I agree the headline was too strong. It should have more accurately reflected the fact that it was Mandelson's friends, rather than him, seeking a job." These are far from the only disputed stories. But the Sunday Times is keen to point out that some of its exclusives, which were denied after publication, subsequently turned out to be true. It cites four such instances, including two about the BBC in February concerning redundancies and the sale of its internet service. Clearly, its recent revelation about a memo from Blair's adviser Philip Gould was spot on. Similarly, its long-running Liam Clarke revelations about the army's dirty tricks activities have been first rate. But the paper's overall record, despite its trenchant defence, still raises journalistic eyebrows - especially those of reporters assigned to follow up its stories, as news desks on rival papers and broadcasting news editors readily point out. Roy Greenslade is a former employee of the Sunday Times

fields.headline: Memo leak reveals rattled PM
fields.trailText: Downing Street was close to paralysis after the spectacular leak of a confidential memorandum written by Tony Blair to his closest advisers setting out the weaknesses of his government, specifically the perception that his adminstration and he himself personally are "somehow out of touch with gut British instincts".
fields.body:
Downing Street was close to paralysis after the spectacular leak of a confidential memorandum written by Tony Blair to his closest advisers setting out the weaknesses of his government, specifically the perception that his adminstration and he himself personally are "somehow out of touch with gut British instincts".

The leak, written just before the local elections, shows the degree to which Mr Blair has been rattled by the perception that he is seen to be soft on previously Tory issues, such as immigration, defence, homosexuality and family issues.

In an implicit assault on the stewardship of the home secretary, Jack Straw, Mr Blair discusses the rise in crime and says the Metropolitan police "are putting in place measures to deal with it; but as ever we are lacking a tough public message along with the strategy".

The memo, sent from Chequers to a small group of Mr Blair's closest advisers on April 29, also complains that the "constant barrage of small stories [is] beginning to add up on defence and even issues like Zimbabwe, we are seen to be insufficiently assertive".

Publication of the leaked memo was held back by the leakers to maximise damage to the government ahead of tomorrow's spending review.

Downing Street refused to go on the record, but some sources suggested there was circumstantial evidence that the conduit had been the Conservative party. This was strenuously denied by shadow cabinet sources.

The leak is the third from deep within Downing Street or Chequers within a month, raising the prospects of a highly placed mole, or a computer hacker within government or outside. The security services were said to be working overtime to locate the source of the leaks, the scale of which was beginning to undermine the credibility of those who claim emails and websites can be protected from dedicated hackers. The Cabinet Office website was invaded as recently as Friday to sprawl graffiti over drugs legalisation. Downing Street said last night a top level leak inquiry was already under way.

The memo will be seen to be damaging to a prime minister who has repeatedly insisted that he is not concerned by newspaper stories or the media portrayal of his government. It reveals instead a man acutely aware of his image and the need to find tough initiatives with which he can be associated. He suggest at one point "the government needs something tough with immediate bite which sends a message through the system. Maybe, the driving licence penality for young offenders. But this should be done soon and I personally should be associated with it."

The memo states on defence: "We need to make the spending review work for defence. Big cuts and you can forget any hope of winning back ground on standing up for Britain. Fol lowing the Tony Martin murder trial, exploited successfully by William Hague, Mr Blair suggests "asking a senior judge to look at changing the sentencing law, ie to allow lesser sentences than life.

"On asylum, we need to be highlighting removals and decisions plus if the April figures show a reduction and then a downward trend.

"On crime, we need to highlight the tough measures: compulsory tests for drugs before bail the confiscation of assets, the extra number of burglars jailed under 'three strikes and you're out' Above all we must deal now with street crime, especially in London."

Overall, he claims, there is a clutch of "disparate issues combining 'on your side' issues with toughness and standing up for Britain. They range from the family - where, partly due to MCA (the Married Couples Allowance) and to gay issues, we are perceived as weak; asylum and crime ,where we are perceived as soft; and asserting the nation's interests due to the unpopularity of Europe."

He insists: "All this, of course, is perception. It is bizarre that any government I lead should be seen to be anti-family. We are in fact taking very tough measures on asylum and crime. Kosovo should have laid to rest any doubts about our strength in defence.

"But all these things add up to a sense that the government - and this even applies to me - are somehow out of touch with gut British instincts."

Yesterday's leak was the third in recent months. The Sunday Times on June 11 printed two emails sent on June 4 by the Labour pollster Philip Gould to Mr Blair and his press secretary, Alastair Campbell, setting out his criticisms of the prime minister's planned speech to the Women's Institute.

The Guardian at the weekend printed a string of emails sent by Mr Blair's private secretary, Anji Hunter, ranging from March to April, preparing for a BBC documentary on life inside Downing Street.

webTitle: Spin war over leaked Blair memo

fields.headline: Spin war over leaked Blair memo
fields.standfirst: As Labour closes ranks behind an accident-prone Tony Blair, William Hague enjoys the opportunity to 'rattle' the prime minister once more, writes Mark Tran
fields.trailText: As Labour closes ranks behind an accident-prone Tony Blair, William Hague enjoys the opportunity to 'rattle' the prime minister once more, writes Mark Tran.
fields.body:
A furious spin war broke out today over Tony Blair's leaked memo as Labour ministers and Tory leaders sought to turn the document to their advantage.

In the memo Mr Blair warned that Labour appeared to be losing ground on issues like law and order, asylum, dissent and the family. "All of this, of course, is perception," he wrote. "But all of these things add up to a sense that the government - and this even applies to me - are somehow out of touch with gut British instinct."

As Downing Street started an inquiry into how the memo was passed to newspapers the Times and the Sun, Mr Hague said it showed that the prime minister no longer had any belief in what he was doing.

"Now we know where all the spin and the gimmicks come from in this government," Mr Hague told reporters. "It comes from the very top. It comes from the prime minister himself. It shows that the government gets very rattled that we are now setting the agenda. They don't really know where to turn next. We have got a government that is only in government in order to fight elections."

Conservative party chairman Michael Ancram said the leak was a sign of the turmoil within the government itself. "Everybody is attacking each other, they are all trying to undermine each other," he said.

The leaked memo is the latest blow to Mr Blair, who has looked increasingly accident-prone ever since he was heckled during a speech at the Women's Institute several weeks ago. Since then, he has had to drop his idea for instant fines for drunken yobs after the police said it was unworkable. He has also suffered a scathing attack from Ken Follett, the novelist and Labour supporter, who accused the government of being all spin and no substance. Poor performances at question time have similarly eroded Mr Blair's reputation for surefootedness.

Labour ministers have tried gamely to turn the leaked memo into a positive, arguing that it showed Mr Blair was ahead of events. Education secretary David Blunkett said: "The leak of the memo is not welcome, but the contents spell out a prime minister who is concerned, who is engaged, who is ahead of some of the issues which have blown up since. It is a prime minister one step ahead of the reality of what then hit us."

Mo Mowlam echoed that sentiment as Labour closed ranks behind the embattled Mr Blair. "There is no suggestion we are out of touch. To say we are is not the case, it is a myth. I do not feel that we have things drastically wrong. We are sticking to what we are doing and we are confident about where we are going but we are not complacent or over-confident."

Labour will try to regain the initiative tomorrow when the chancellor, Gordon Brown, unveils his comprehensive spending review. He is expected to announce big spending increases for education and the police. Mr Blair is particularly sensitive to charges that he is soft on crime, especially in the light of the memorable Labour soundbite he coined during the 1997 election campaign - "Tough on crime, tough on the causes of crime".

fields.headline: Diego Garcia
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the British colony that's been colonised by the Americans
fields.trailText: 1. The US Immigration Service, in its handy guide to the British Indian Ocean Islands Territory, laconically notes that there is no indigenous population.
fields.body:
1. The US Immigration Service, in its handy guide to the British Indian Ocean Islands Territory, laconically notes that there is no indigenous population.

2. That's not quite true: the people of the Chagos Archipelago were thrown off the islands in the late 1960s, when prime minister Harold Wilson was desperate to curry favour with the USA.

3. The archipelago was ethnically cleansed, so to speak, to make way for a US military base on the southernmost island of Diego Garcia, which is now home to a fleet of nuclear-capable B-52 bombers.

4. Most of the dispossessed islanders now live in squalor in Mauritius, and they want to go home. They say that as British subjects, they should be allowed to return to British territory, and today they are taking the British government to court. The Foreign and Commonwealth Office, which adopts a high moral tone on the universality of human rights, is silent on the issue.

5. That is odd, because 20 years ago, foreign secretary Robin Cook was speaking up for the rights of the Diego Garcians. Today, he is more at ease threatening to use the island-based bombers to attack Iraq.

6. In his more idealist phase, Cook backed the standard left line, now shared by the Green party, that colonial injustice must be reversed.

7. To complicate the issue, the islands are claimed by Mauritius, 1500 miles to the south-west. The claim is based on the fact that the archipelago was administered from Mauritius - when it too was a British colony.

8. Many of the US personnel on Diego Garcia also seem a bit baffled about where exactly they are. But they live comfortably on a tropical paradise, and probably have only a passing awareness that a territory which rises to just five metres above sea level could be doomed by global warming and rising sea levels.

9. There is also a token contingent of British servicemen on Diego Garcia. Their bizarre rituals tend to mystify their American colleagues.

10. The fragile ecology of the coral islands is already threatened by drastic over-fishing.

fields.headline: The M25 three
fields.standfirst:
The so-called M25 three were today freed by the court of appeal after three judges ruled that their convictions were unsafe. We explain what the case is about
M25 three freed by court
fields.trailText: The so-called M25 three were today freed by the court of appeal after three judges ruled that their convictions were unsafe. We explain what the case is about.
fields.body:
Why were the M25 three jailed?
Michael Davis, Randolph Johnson and Raphael Rowe had served 10 years of a life sentence for murder and a series of robberies. The original trial judge described the events of the evening of December 15 1988 as "an orgy of violence".

What happened?
Hairdresser Peter Hurburgh and Alun Eley were dragged from their car near Chelsham, Surrey, close to the M25 London orbital motorway by three men. The victims were stripped, battered and doused with fuel. Mr Hurburgh died of a heart attack while Mr Eley was robbed of £10.

What did the attackers do next?
The gang, now using the dead man's car, drove along the M25 to Oxted, Surrey, where they broke into a house and beat up a retired businessman and his son, who suffered serious stab wounds. Later the same night, the gang raided another house, binding and gagging the owners before making off with jewellery and credit cards.

Why was there doubt about the convictions?
Witnesses claimed that two of the gang were white - but the three men arrested and later convicted of the offence, Mr Rowe, Mr Davis and Mr Johnson were all black.

What about forensic evidence?
There was no forensic evidence and fingerprints found at the murder scene did not match those of the convicted men.

Have they appealed before?
In July 1993 appeals against their convictions were dismissed, with Lord Watkins stating that there was not "even a lurking doubt" about their safety.

Were there any other doubts surrounding their convictions?
The convicted men argued that key witnesses had struck a deal with police to help the prosecution. Documents which they believed might contain that information were kept from their lawyers and the original trial court through the use of public interest immunity certificates.

What did the European Commission of Human Rights have to say about the case?
It ruled in March 1999 that the use of the gagging orders meant the three men did not get a fair trial. The Criminal Cases Review Commission referred the case back to the Court of Appeal in April 1999 after lifting the orders to reveal that money was paid to a suspect who became a key prosecution witness. In February this year the European Court of Human Rights ruled that two of the men were denied a fair trial as the prosecution had withheld important evidence.

fields.headline: Hague 1, Blair 0
fields.standfirst: The memo leaked to the Times and the Sun shows a prime minister more concerned with his tabloid image than his standing with his supporters, political editor Michael White suggests
fields.trailText: The memo leaked to the Times and the Sun shows a prime minister more concerned with his tabloid image than his standing with his supporters, political editor Michael White suggests.
fields.body:
On Saturday night Tony Blair could be seen assuring the BBC's Michael Cockerell that he wasn't over-concerned with his image and would look forward to the day when he never had to think about presentation again.

Forty-eight hours after Cockerell's documentary, The News From Number Ten, a memo leaked to the Sun and the Times showed him in rather a different light. Here was a prime minister whose administration was "somehow out of touch with gut British instincts" on such issues as crime, immigration, defence, even marriage and the family.

What on earth is going on? First, the government is going on. It has hit a rough patch and its weaknesses are being exposed, albeit later than is customary with modern governments.

Alastair Campbell's decision to cooperate with Mr Cockerell will assist that exposure, not least by showing Mr Blair's considerable dependency on him. But the leak is merely the restoration of business as usual when the tabloids - and their broadloids stablemates - are relentlessly hostile to Labour.

But it is worth recalling that the Tories are not yet electable and that William Hague's u-turn on his October tax guarantee was a damaging one. However much the Telegraph tries to talk up the narrowing gap between the parties found by the Gallup poll, it is still a gap and it is a large one. Labour remains set to win the coming election with a majority of 50 to 100 seats.

None the less the leaked memo damages Labour, as it was intended to do. It shows a prime minister uneasy about his own performance and that of key colleagues, notably, the home secretary, Jack Straw, whose portfolio Mr Blair once held.

The date of the memo is significant and may explain the law and order fear - it was written three days after Mr Hague joined in the fray over Tony Martin, the Norfolk farmer jailed for murdering a burglar.

Indeed, the memo could be said to show a leader impressively on the ball across a range of departmental issues. Loyalists were already saying that today as they read the text in full. Apart from some unguarded phrases - understandable in a man who did not expect to read his memo in the Sun - it is full of robust common sense.

But a number of things are missing. Mr Blair does not seem interested in heartland issues, such as fears for job losses and the high pound. His concern focuses instead on attacks from the right on Middle England issues of the type beloved of the Daily Mail. These include tough penalties against law-breakers, concern that dislike for the euro is weakening the government and worries about defence.

These issues may be "gut instincts" for some of the British people, certainly those of them that write leaders for the Mail. But what of liberal England and northern England? What of Labour activists and the cultural left, trade unionists and factory workers, single parents, gays who thought Labour wanted to include them inside its big tent? What of other interest groups and perspectives?

In a sense the question is unfair. We know the memo was not written for publication. We do not know its context. The PM may have addressed all those issues in a separate memo the following day.

The question uppermost in the minds of ministers, MPs and officials, not to mention journalists, is where the memo came from, from whom and why. It is hard to believe that Labour has a traitor inside No 10 with access to computers that contain such information.

It is also hard to believe that it is a politically motivated leak by a Labour insider, someone based outside No 10 who is seeking to damage Mr Blair and his entourage. But we should not dismiss the thought entirely - politics is full of vehement enmities.

There has been a series of damaging leaks in recent weeks, mostly to the Murdoch press, nominally still favourable to New Labour, but in reality servants of their master's voice and interests.

The Sunday Times gets most of them, the Sun and Times got this one. Every case is different, certainly the apparent theft of fundraiser Lord Levy's tax details looks like a professional job, done with no questions asked by the journalists who printed the findings.

The latest leak is intriguing because of its nature - it went to two papers, not one - and because of those involved in handling it. There is some evidence that Conservative central office had a card up its sleeve ahead of Tuesday's comprehensive spending review, presented by Gordon Brown.

If this was it, it was certainly a good one. It achieved its aim of making the government look shallow and defensive with Mr Blair keen to place himself at the centre of good publicity.

But the ancient Roman historian, Juvenal, once posed a question, always worth asking of a leaker, albeit rarely asked: "Cui bono ?" wrote Juvenal 2,000 years ago. "Who benefits?" Mr Hague benefits.

However much the Telegraph tries to talk up the narrowing gap between the parties found by the Gallup poll, it is still a gap and it is a large one. Labour remains set to win the coming election with a majority of 50 to 100 seats. None the less the leaked memo damages Labour, as it was intended to do. It shows a prime minister uneasy about his own performance and that of key colleagues, notably, the home secretary, Jack Straw, whose portfolio Mr Blair once held. The date of the memo is significant and may explain the law and order fear - it was written three days after Mr Hague joined in the fray over Tony Martin, the Norfolk farmer jailed for murdering a burglar. Indeed, the memo could be said to show a leader impressively on the ball across a range of departmental issues. Loyalists were already saying that today as they read the text in full. Apart from some unguarded phrases - understandable in a man who did not expect to read his memo in the Sun - it is full of robust common sense. But a number of things are missing. Mr Blair does not seem interested in heartland issues, such as fears for job losses and the high pound. His concern focuses instead on attacks from the right on Middle England issues of the type beloved of the Daily Mail. These include tough penalties against law-breakers, concern that dislike for the euro is weakening the government and worries about defence. These issues may be "gut instincts" for some of the British people, certainly those of them that write leaders for the Mail. But what of liberal England and northern England? What of Labour activists and the cultural left, trade unionists and factory workers, single parents, gays who thought Labour wanted to include them inside its big tent? What of other interest groups and perspectives? In a sense the question is unfair. We know the memo was not written for publication. We do not know its context. The PM may have addressed all those issues in a separate memo the following day. The question uppermost in the minds of ministers, MPs and officials, not to mention journalists, is where the memo came from, from whom and why. It is hard to believe that Labour has a traitor inside No 10 with access to computers that contain such information. It is also hard to believe that it is a politically motivated leak by a Labour insider, someone based outside No 10 who is seeking to damage Mr Blair and his entourage. But we should not dismiss the thought entirely - politics is full of vehement enmities. There has been a series of damaging leaks in recent weeks, mostly to the Murdoch press, nominally still favourable to New Labour, but in reality servants of their master's voice and interests. The Sunday Times gets most of them, the Sun and Times got this one. Every case is different, certainly the apparent theft of fundraiser Lord Levy's tax details looks like a professional job, done with no questions asked by the journalists who printed the findings. The latest leak is intriguing because of its nature - it went to two papers, not one - and because of those involved in handling it. There is some evidence that Conservative central office had a card up its sleeve ahead of Tuesday's comprehensive spending review, presented by Gordon Brown. If this was it, it was certainly a good one. It achieved its aim of making the government look shallow and defensive with Mr Blair keen to place himself at the centre of good publicity. But the ancient Roman historian, Juvenal, once posed a question, always worth asking of a leaker, albeit rarely asked: "Cui bono ?" wrote Juvenal 2,000 years ago. "Who benefits?" Mr Hague benefits.

webTitle: Perez ousts Sanz as Real president

fields.headline: Perez ousts Sanz as Real president
fields.standfirst: Madrid gets ready for Real decision
fields.trailText: Florentino Perez, the 53-year-old head of a leading construction firm, has been elected as president of Real Madrid. He will formally replace the current incumbent, Lorenzo Sanz, this evening.
fields.body:
Florentino Perez, the 53-year-old head of a leading construction firm, has been elected as president of Real Madrid. He will formally replace the current incumbent, Lorenzo Sanz, this evening.

Sanz had widely been expected to win another term: his five-year reign brought two European Cups to the Bernabeu, the first of which, in 1998, ended a 32-year wait for Europe's ultimate prize.

But Perez's controversial pledge to sign Luis Figo from Barcelona swung the result, and he was backed by 55% of the 30,000 club members who voted.

Perez claimed to have an agreement to sign Figo from Real's great rivals in a $57m deal. Although Figo himself denied the story, Perez stuck to his guns and even made an $8.5m promise to pay the season-ticket fees of club members if he was elected and failed to close the deal.

The Figo controversy overshadowed Sanz's on-field successes, as did Perez's claims that the club debt was running at $247m - Sanz insisted Real were no more than $110m in the red.

Perez also benefited from his greater organisation in rounding-up postal votes, where he had a clear majority - voting in person at the club's training ground complex yesterday was said to be much closer.

Sanz's defeat means he will not realise his personal ambition of leading Real in their centenary celebrations in 2002. He will also have to give up his position as head of the G-14, the lobbying group made up of the biggest clubs in European soccer.

webTitle: July 17: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: July 17: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Vinnie Jones gets funny, Sony close to deal with Patricia Cornwell, Russell Crowe set for Miracle directing debut, Janet Jackson to return to the screen, and Minnie Driver to star in British comedy
fields.body:
 Footballer-turned-movie-star Vinnie Jones has revealed he is writing his own film script. Jones - who made his screen debut in the British gangster film Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels - says he is working on a comedy. In an interview with Esquire magazine, Jones, who is currently starring in Gone in 60 seconds alongside Nicholas Cage and Angelina Jolie, said the story focused on an up-and-coming boxer and was set in a pub.

 Sony Pictures is close to signing a deal with author Patricia Cornwell for the film rights to her 11 crime novels in which medical examiner Dr Kay Scarpetta appears. In the past, Cornwell's novels have attracted Hollywood's attention but none has yet reached the silver screen. The deal is thought to guarantee a five-year option on each of Cornwell's novels and includes film rights to all the novels she writes during that period.

 Gladiator star Russell Crowe looks set to make his directorial debut in a film in which he will star as a Jesuit priest. The notorious perfectionist looks likely to direct A Course in Miracles, the story of a Jesuit priest who has a crisis of faith after investigating supposed miracles.

 Janet Jackson is set to star opposite Eddie Murphy in his new sequel Nutty Professor II: The Klumps. Jackson is to play the pretty colleague and fiancee of the oversize Sherman Klump in the comedy. The singer has not been seen in a movie role since she starred as a beautician in John Singleton's romantic drama Poetic Justice, seven years ago.

 Minnie Driver is to star in a British comedy thriller called High Heels and Low Lifes in which she will play a nurse who overhears potential robbers planning a bank robbery and then blackmails them for $2m to keep their secret.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: The latest transfer talk leaked to the press, possibly by a high-ranking civil servant
fields.trailText: Newcastle are preparing a £3.1m offer for Galatasaray midfielder Sergen Yalcin, who is also a target for Turkish club Gaziantepspor. However, Bobby Robson may need to up his offer for the Turkey international - Gala are holding out for £4.5m.
fields.body:
Newcastle are preparing a £3.1m offer for Galatasaray midfielder Sergen Yalcin, who is also a target for Turkish club Gaziantepspor. However, Bobby Robson may need to up his offer for the Turkey international - Gala are holding out for £4.5m.

Manchester City will make a bid for 6ft 7in Czech Republic striker Jan Koller. Anderlecht had rated Koller at £7m but have had no takers at that price - Joe Royle could succeed with a reduced offer of £4.5m.

Charlton have joined Celtic in taking an interest in Aston Villa midfielder Alan Thompson. The ex-Bolton player would cost £2.5m.

Wimbledon expect to sign former Arsenal and Liverpool midfielder Michael Thomas this week, according to the Daily Star. The 32-year-old Thomas is a free agent after a spell at Benfica and has impressed Dons boss Terry Burton in pre-season training.

Planet Football report that West Ham striker Paulo Wanchope could move to Spanish side Malaga. Wanchope has yet to win over the Upton Park faithful and the arrival of Davor Suker and Frederic Kanoute has further undermined his status with the Hammers. The Costa Rican would replace Malaga's £9m-rated Catanha, who is expected to move to either Deportivo la Coruno or Celta Vigo.
