webTitle: 'When you brake, planes at 30,000ft will know about it'

fields.headline: 'When you brake, planes at 30,000ft will know about it'
fields.standfirst: From luxury tour bus to mobile conference centre - the VW Sharan is a van for all the people, says  Giles Smith.
fields.trailText: From luxury tour bus to mobile conference centre - the VW Sharan is a van for all the people, says Giles Smith.
fields.body:
It's an odd thought, in this golden age for family transportation, but people used to cope. People had children, often in numbers, and they drove those children around without purchasing a vehicle the size of a bread van. I grew up in a family of six, which probably could have made good use of a people carrier, had such a thing existed. But we travelled about in a Morris Minor, sitting on each other's heads.

People won't tolerate that now. These days, children from six months upwards require their own aircraft-style reclining seat, drinks holder, personal stowage pocket and tip-down table device. If you don't offer them these facilities as standard, they simply won't go anywhere with you. Many of today's parents face a straightforward decision: buy 20 grand's worth of luxury bus or have no family life worth speaking of.

The VW Sharan - which first came out five years ago, but which is now back with us in a set of restyled, second-generation models - is 20 grand's worth of luxury bus. Twenty-five grand's worth if you want the Sport V6 version with the five-speed tiptronic gearbox.

It has drinks holders coming out of its ears, or rather its dashboard and seats. It is imposingly roomy and tall (from a seat in the back, you can see over hedges and into people's bedrooms). It accommodates seven people comfortably (so long as at least two of them are small). Nobody is required to sit on anybody else's head. It's full of light - inevitably, given that it contains as much glass as a medium-sized conservatory. And it goes pretty fast and handles like a car. Well, more like a car than like a bread van.

A shame, then, about that name, which seems to cry out for a VW Tracey as a companion piece. The idea is that you should stress the second syllable ("Sha- ran ") but in any case, when it comes to car names, VW seem heroically untroubled by the possibility of unfortunate resonances in the British marketplace. This, after all, is the company that produces a vehicle called a Bora (named after a wind, apparently, rather than after somebody you wouldn't want to be trapped with at a party).

It's German, so the doors go chunk rather than poing, and it's a VW, so everything about it is reassuringly solid, properly anchored to what it's meant to be anchored to. It has lots of tidy pieces of design, such as the doorhandles, the catch on the rear door and the cute silver bullets that hold the additional indicators on the side of the car. At night, the clocks light up mauve, which is very nice, assuming you like mauve.

What's more, you can jigger about with the seating plan - fold the rear seats down to create tables, push seats back or pull them out. At their own request, I posted my children in the seats right at the back, which seemed to have for them the same allure that rear coach seats on school trips will hold for them in a few years' time. The fact is, they could monkey about with impunity there because, from where I was, they might as well have been in the car behind.

But if you wish, you can get front seats that spin through 180 degrees, enabling you to face your passengers around a small work surface. (Note: best not try this while the car is in motion.) I can only think that when VW refer to possible "business applications" for the Sharan, they mean this aspect, which in effect reconfigures the vehicle as a mobile conference room. Alternatively, you can remove all five of the rear seats altogether and convert your Sharan into the thinking man's white van.

Beyond its adaptability, though, perhaps the most impressive thing about the Sharan is the evidence it offers of VW's familiarity with parental paranoias. The button that locks all the doors from the inside is thoughtfully placed beside the window controls, just by your right hand, so you can slam your fist down on it if you see anyone trying to escape (or, perhaps more urgently, if you see any further children trying to get in).

Also, the car comes with a giant band of red reflectors and brake lights, extending the entire width of the back door, and there's another stripped brake light running along the top of the rear window. That's quite some display. When you slow down, planes at 30,000ft are going to know about it. It's like a big, nervous, electric "Child on board" sticker.

All this, and it isn't even all that ugly. Seen head on, the car looks like the Eurostar - big-nosed, but kind of go-ahead. VW have restyled the bonnet so that it arches up in the middle, but you still, of course, can't see where it ends from the driver's seat, so your ability in particular to park the car successfully depends on the development of a kind of sixth sense about its length (which does, inexplicably, come after a while).

Even so, a thrill to own and drive? Of course not; it's a people carrier. Like the song says: "The wheels on the bus go round and round, all day long."

The lowdown

Price on the road: from £18,645

Top speed: 110mph

0-62 mph: 15.2 seconds

Fuel consumption: 29.1mpg

On the stereo: Nelly the Elephant

At the wheel: Tony Blair

En route for: Legoland; the Dordogne

webTitle: Edwards out, Kenyon in at United

fields.headline: Edwards out, Kenyon in at United
fields.trailText: Martin Edwards will step down as chief executive of Manchester United from August 1 and will be replaced by Peter Kenyon. United's plc released a statement confirming the move, which has been in the offing for some time, to the London Stock Exchange this morning.
fields.body:
Martin Edwards will step down as chief executive of Manchester United from August 1 and will be replaced by Peter Kenyon. United's plc released a statement confirming the move, which has been in the offing for some time, to the London Stock Exchange this morning.

Edwards will remain as a non-executive director of Manchester United plc and continue his duties as non-executive chairman of Manchester United FC. David Gill will be appointed deputy chief executive, while retaining his responsibilites as group financial director.

Kenyon, 42, and a former executive at sportswear manufacturer Umbro, said of his appointment: "I am delighted. I've been involved with the club for three years - and it's been a nice apprenticeship."

Kenyon will take charge of United at an interesting time. He will be charged with making the most of an expected explosion in broadcasting, while also enhancing the club's reputation after their perceived problems during Fifa's World Club Championship earlier this year.

"Being a global club brings with it new responsibilities and gone are the days when anything we do is quiet and unnoticed," Kenyon said this morning. "We have learnt from all our overseas forays and, the thing is, we have got to get better at communication. It's our number one priority for 2000.

"I will continue to look at a number of opportunities for the business, including attacking the communications arena," he said.

Also high up on Kenyon's list will be Sir Alex Ferguson's future at the club. Ferguson is set to retire at the end of the 2001-2 season, but this morning Kenyon said he would do anything to prolong the Scot's time in charge at Old Trafford.

"Everybody at Manchester United would like Sir Alex to stay as long as he feels he wants to," he told Radio 4's Today programme. "Certainly there's no pressure from this end for it to come to an end after two years." Kenyon is believed to have a better working relationship with Ferguson than his predecessor, with whom Ferguson clashed several times in the last couple of years.

Edwards' decision to stand down as the club's chief executive increases speculation that he is set to move into Manchester United's most powerful position, that of chairman of the plc. The current chairman, Sir Roland Smith, agreed last March to stay on for a further year and Edwards could well take his place at the end of that time.

webTitle: Brazilian film wins top honours at Karlovy Vary festival

fields.headline: Brazilian film wins top honours at Karlovy Vary festival
fields.trailText: Brazilian film Me, You, Them (Eu, Tu, Eles), directed by Andrucha Warrington, has won the Grand Prix Crystal Globe at the 35th Karlovy Vary International Film Festival
fields.body:
Brazilian film Me, You, Them (Eu, Tu, Eles), directed by Andrucha Warrington, has won the Grand Prix Crystal Globe at the 35th Karlovy Vary International Film Festival. The film also picked up the best actress award for Regina Case.

The little-known spa town of Karlovy Vary, in western Bohemia, paid host to some of Hollywood's biggest stars on Saturday night for what is one of the summer's hottest events in central Europe's social calendar (see our earlier story). Guests included Woody Harrelson, who was there with his documentary about marijuana, Grass, Alicia Silverstone, who presented Kenneth Branagh's Love's Labour's Lost, and Edward Norton, presenting his own Keeping The Faith.

The award for best director went to Vinko Bresan for Croatian title Marshal Tito's Spirit, while best actor was jointly awarded to British actor Ian Hart for the UK-Norwegian co-production Aberdeen, directed by Hans Petter Moland, and Hamid Farokhnezad for his role in the Iranian feature The Bride Of Fire (Arous-E Atash).

Special jury prizes were awarded to Peppermint Candy (Bakha Sating), directed by Korea's Lee Chang-Dong, and Big Animal, directed by Polish actor Jerzy Stuhr from a screenplay by the late Krzysztof Kieslowski.

Special jury mentions went to French director Bernard Rapp's Une Affaire De Gout, and Angels Of The Universe, directed by Iceland's Fridrik Thor Fridriksson.

 Official festival site

fields.headline: Importance of not being Salome
fields.trailText: Over the years it has been used as evidence of a little known aspect of Oscar Wilde's flamboyant life story - that of his transvestite tendency.
fields.body:
Over the years it has been used as evidence of a little known aspect of Oscar Wilde's flamboyant life story - that of his transvestite tendency.

A photograph appears to show the writer as the biblical seductress Salomé, but now research suggests the figure is not Wilde but a female opera singer. The photograph appeared in an article on Wilde in the French newspaper Le Monde in 1987. In Richard Ellman's biography it is captioned: Wilde in costume as Salomé - Collection Guillot de Saix, Paris.

The playwright's grandson, Merlin Holland, has long doubted that it was Wilde, and has worked with a German scholar, Horst Schröder, to prove his theory.

Mr Schröder discovered a photograph of Alice Guszalewicz, a Hungarian soprano who sang in the opera Salomé in Cologne in 1906. Her jewellery and clothing were almost identical to that of the Wilde figure.

Mr Holland said: "Whatever anyone has said about Oscar and his naughtiness, he wasn't the sort of person who would dress in women's clothes and have himself photographed."

In response to Mr Holland's urging, Penguin, publisher of the Ellman biography, is considering removing the image from future editions.

fields.headline: Obituary: Robert Robins
fields.standfirst: Historian of languages living and dead, speaker of many, and writer of the great basic textbook of linguistics
fields.trailText: In 1964 R H "Bobby" Robins, who has died aged 78, published his General Linguistics: An Introductory Survey. It was translated into eight languages, including three Asian ones, and incalculable numbers of students worldwide have pored over the volume as their introduction to the subject.
fields.body:
In 1964 R H "Bobby" Robins, who has died aged 78, published his General Linguistics: An Introductory Survey. It was translated into eight languages, including three Asian ones, and incalculable numbers of students worldwide have pored over the volume as their introduction to the subject.

Robins was a historian of linguistic ideas, and another of his widely used textbooks, A Short History of Linguistics (1967) was at the popular end of a list of publications which culminated in the deeply scholarly The Byzantine Grammarians (1993).

During nearly nearly 40 years in the department of phonetics and linguistics at London university's School of Oriental and African Studies, Robins was at the heart of nearly every enterprise there promoting linguistics. He was professor of general linguistics from 1966-86, and subsequently became emeritus professor.

His apprenticeship in field linguistics had left him with a lifelong concern for minority languages. In 1951 he had been a research fellow at the University of California at Berkeley, and seven years later he published The Yurok Language, a monograph on a long extinct Native American language of California.

Recovering such unwritten languages entails painstaking fieldwork. He spoke of the undertaking as a sort of rite of passage, in the tradition of the great American structuralists like Edward Sapir, Leonard Bloomfield, and Harry Hoijer who, as part of their academic work, had considered it their duty to document America's native languages.

In that spirit of linguistic investigation, Robins wrote a series of articles on Sundanese, which is a language of Java. These were subsequently published as a bilingual Indonesian-English collection, Sistem dan Struktur Bahasa Sunda (1973).

Robins was a doctor's son, born in Broadstairs. He acquired the first instalments of his vast stock of erudition at Tonbridge School, and later at New College, Oxford, in 1940-41 and 1945-48, where he took a first in Literae Humaniores (Greek and Latin literature and ancient history).

In the intervening period, the second world war determined events and he served in Royal Air Force intelligence, teaching Japanese to servicemen. He was always gifted in mastering languages and it became apparent, many years later when he gave an opening address in Japanese at a Tokyo conference, that for him at least learning Japanese had not been a mere crash course.

Robins joined Soas as a lecturer in the department of phonetics and linguistics in 1948. Eighteen years later he succeeded the brilliant, redoubtable, Professor John Rupert Firth to the chair of general linguistics. Firth headed Britain's first department of general linguistics. For many years, the inaugurators of linguistics programmes in other British universities, and further afield, usually began their careers in the Soas department and were often his colleagues, or later his students.

Robins headed the department from 1970 almost until his retirement in 1986, and he was an excellent head. Nobody would have dreamed of missing the fortnightly departmental meetings where there would be a paper by a departmental member or visiting speaker, followed by full-blooded debate. Robins's comments, combining erudition and wit - delivered in a unique and inimitable style of English - were unforgettable.

Within linguistics, Robins's position was very broad church amid rival creeds. This tolerance probably arose out of his longer time-perspective: as an historian of linguistic ideas, he was enabled to evaluate real originality. His headship came at a time when, in certain institutions, every linguist had become a follower of the ideas of Noam Chomsky of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. In Robins's department, courses on Indo-European grammar, stratificational grammar, tagmemics (linguistic analysis based on the function of grammatical position in a sentence) and the structure of an American Indian language (the last was taught by Robins) were on offer, alongside courses on the MIT's syntactic, phonological and semantic ideas.

Robins was a member of many academic bodies at home and abroad, including fellowship of the British Academy. There were two Festschrifts in his honour. At the time of his death, he was president of the Henry Sweet Society for the History of Linguistic Ideas, of which he was also a founder member. But the body with which Robins will be most strongly associated is the oldest of the linguistics societies, the Philological Society. He was its secretary for 18 years and became its president and later president emeritus, a title created uniquely in recognition of his devotion to the organisation.

Modest, urbane and sociable, Robins was a private man whose sharp mind generally led him to form quick opinions both of ideas and persons. So while he did not suffer fools gladly, for those who received his approval, warm support and loyalty were given unstintingly. He viewed life with an almost naive enthusiasm.

He first met his wife Sheila at Soas; theirs was a very happy marriage. She died in 1983.

webTitle: Hurley's career at risk over strike-break

fields.headline: Hurley's career at risk over strike-break
fields.trailText: Liz Hurley has put her burgeoning Hollywood acting career in jeopardy by crossing an actors' picket line
fields.body:
Liz Hurley has put her burgeoning Hollywood acting career in jeopardy by crossing an actors' picket line, reports today's Daily Mail.

Hurley, the $3m 'face' of Estee Lauder, made an advertisement last week for the cosmetics giant but, in so doing, broke a strike by the powerful Screen Actors Guild. The Guild is boycotting all advertising work in a campaign for better pay. Richard Dreyfus and ER star Noah Wylie are among those who have rejected advertising work to show their support for the campaign.

Guild spokesman Greg Krizman warned Miss Hurley that she had put her union membership at risk, adding, "without it, her chances of starring in another Hollywood movie are nil." An outraged fellow actress said of Hurley: "Some of her fellow Screen Actors Guild members who are toughing out the strike on tuna casserole and temp work would certainly love to give her a big spanking." Clearly, even roughing it in Hollywood bears little relation to reality.

Hurley, the first actress to cross the picket, claims she knew nothing about the strike. A spokesman for her production company, Simian Films, said: "Elizabeth had no idea anyone was on strike as no one told her." Clearly she neither reads the papers or even talks to her fellow thespians.

webTitle: Dozens dead as passenger jet hits housing estate

fields.headline: Dozens dead as passenger jet hits housing estate
fields.trailText: Dozens of people were killed today when an passenger jet carrying 58 people crashed into houses as it attempted to land at an airport in eastern India.
fields.body:
Dozens of people were killed today when an passenger jet carrying 58 people crashed into houses as it attempted to land at an airport in eastern India.

The Alliance Air jet was making a second landing attempt at Patna airport in eastern India, India's Civil Aviation Ministry said.

Twenty bodies, burned beyond recognition, were pulled from the metal wreckage in the hours after the plane hit two houses in a government employees' complex a mile from the airport.

Five members of a family of seven died when the Boeing 737-200 hit their house, witnesses said. Three more people died at Patna Medical College Hospital after 14 were taken there for treatment, hospital officials said.

Four of the survivors were people pulled from the smashed brick houses where the 20-year-old plane landed.

The pilot, Captain Sohan Pal, 35, may have been flying too low, AH Jung, secretary of the Civil Aviation Ministry, told reporters in the Indian capital, New Delhi. The plane was in perfect condition, had passed its checks and "the pilot reported no problems during the flight", Mr Jung said.

He dismissed reports of an engine fire before the crash. He said visibility was hazy and the pilot had asked for a second attempt at landing, which was not unusual.

But a witness, Ashok Kesri, said: "The plane was on fire before it hit the house."

Relatives, police and airport workers rushed towards the smouldering pile of metal wreckage, screaming and crying as they tried to find survivors. Thousands of people swarmed around the plane, whose tail could be seen above their heads resting against a brick house. The house's ceiling and wall were smashed in. Another house next-door had bricks missing from the front.

The Boeing 737 was carrying 52 passengers and six crew members, said AK Vashisht, a deputy general manager for the state-owned Indian Airlines, the parent company of Alliance Air.

Some men grabbed a hose and tried to help soldiers and police put out the flames. More than 20 fire engines surrounded the wreckage and put out the flames about three hours after the crash.

The flight had been heading for New Delhi, with a scheduled stop in Patna, capital of India's poorest state, Bihar.

India has frequent air crashes. The worst was a collision of a Saudi jetliner and a Kazak cargo plane over New Delhi that killed 349 people in November 1996.

webTitle: Analysis of ITV's green light to consolidate

fields.headline: And then there were three
fields.standfirst: After months of lobbying and jockeying, the DTI opened the door to ITV consolidation on Friday. But the future shape of the network is still wide open. Will it be one company or are there further fights ahead? Maggie Brown believes the answer lies in the programming history of Granada Television
fields.trailText: After months of lobbying and jockeying, the DTI opened the door to ITV consolidation on Friday. But the future shape of the network is still wide open. Will it be one company or are there further fights ahead? Maggie Brown believes the answer lies in the programming history
fields.body:
The voice at the end of the phone sounded dejected. "Not such a good day for us," it said from way inside Michael Green's Carlton empire. What had seemed like a master stroke last November, a merger cooked up with Lord Hollick's United News and Media, has been checked.

The two companies, currently considering their next moves, are indeed free to merge. The argument for further consolidation of ITV has been won - but at a pretty high price. There will have to be two equally powerful and balanced groups, not a single United/Carlton controlling three of the biggest licences and bossing the rest of the regional tiddlers. Granada has spoiled the party.

The highest price will be disposing of, arguably, the juiciest bit of Clive Hollick's empire, the Meridian franchise based in Southampton, which serves the rich south coast. It is the core of United, which Granada (or anyone else) could now buy.

Those who are close to the competition commission's inquiry were saying on Friday: "Hats off to Granada. They have played a blinder. It is their day." So much so that the Granada camp was initially "pleasantly surprised" by the report. Clearly caught napping by the merger announcement last year, it has fought its way back into the game - first by announcing its intention to bid for either of its rivals. Next it pushed for the whole merger issue to be referred for scrutiny, while grouping its media companies into a single quoted business, Granada Media, with its catering business in a separate arm. Now it is emerging from months of purdah with a big cash war chest and the advantage.

Chief executive Charles Allen has been handed the initiative by the competition commission with permission to bid for either target, United or Carlton, subject only to the ownership restraints of the broadcasting act (these prevent it breaching audience share limits or - since it owns LWT - acquiring Carlton's London weekday licence). "We are well placed to lead the consolidation of ITV," said Allen on Friday afternoon with all the satisfaction of a cat savouring a bowl of cream.

The chances are that Granada's top team, headed by Allen, with non-executive directors such as the former BSkyB executive David Chance on hand, will act fast, within 21 days, and won't want to be forced onto the back foot a second time. It can make a hostile bid for one, and then make disposals. Or do nothing (unlikely). Or it could negotiate a carve-up: by getting agreement to buy Meridian from a merging Carlton/United as the price for suspending hostilities.

How did it win through? The central point in its closely guarded submission was success in convincing the commission that if the merger went ahead three of the four leading and fastest-growing ITV franchises, between them taking 55% of (net) advertising revenue - Carlton, Central and Meridian, with Granada's LWT the fourth - would be in the same hands.

These big four are in the midlands and south, and their importance was based on economic analysis. They serve areas, Granada argued, where advertisers were prepared to pay a premium, which meant they would continue to pull ahead. It was, in other words, a convincing way of expressing something more visceral, the fear that a Carlton/United merger would create a north/south TV divide, excluding Granada. This point was expressed cleverly in precisely the right kind of economic terms which the competition commission could address, although it weighed most heavily on the minds of northern MPs who have been resolute in backing Granada's interests.

There has been some smart lobbying going on by a team which also defeated the controversial digital BBC licence fee proposal earlier this year. Smart, because Meridian actually accounts for a relatively modest 6.9% of net total advertising, compared with Central (at 10%), Carlton (9.5%) and LWT (7.2%). Granada, based in Manchester, has a 6% share, not so far adrift from Meridian - indeed, you could argue that there is a "big five" in ITV rather than a "big four".

And there's also the issue of programming. The Carlton/United lobby argued that Granada's takeover plans pose another kind of dominance, in programme supply. Its franchises, Granada, LWT and Yorkshire-Tyne Tees, are ITV's top three programme-makers, supplying 48% of the network's original productions. But the risks of a merged company's interests unduly influencing programming choice were judged not great enough to operate against the national interest by the commission.

So Granada's creative strength emerges from the inquiry unchallenged. This is what makes the report so clever and politically acceptable. It delighted the Department of Culture and even some staunch opponents.

"I think the competition commission has been pretty sensible," says David Scott, managing director of Channel 4, who lobbied against the initial plan. "It's fantastic news for Granada," says a senior ITV Network source. "[trade and industry secretary] Stephen Byers didn't want to go down in history as the man who destroyed ITV," says another ITV insider. "Granada is special. It is trusted and has a track record."

In contrast, United is still building its programme-making base under the respected leadership of former Channel 4 director of programmes, John Willis, while Carlton's recent problems of quality control, combined with a general failure to match high profits with high programming standards, have not helped.

Granada's creative strength makes it by far the most important ITV player. It made eight of ITV's 10 top-rated programmes last year (excluding sports coverage). Overall, 30% of the UK's top-rated programmes came from its studios in 1999. Last week it pulled off a further coup, with ITV announcing that Yorkshire's Emmerdale would be running five nights a week from the autumn.

Granada is, however, far from being a relaxed company for creative types to work in contentedly. "If editors and department heads lose orders, then they have to make people redundant," an insider explains. "There is huge attention to the bottom line. The control of costs is ruthless." That's why so many respected programme-makers leave after a while, another executive adds, "they don't like the notion of profits regardless". None the less, Granada's studios continue to deliver because of a long tradition which has given it strength and focus. "I have huge admiration for it," says a leading competitor ruefully. "Especially when you consider the state it was in."

The current management, led by Gerry Robinson and Charles Allen, gained control of Granada in 1992, much to the old guard's horror. It was the oldest and grandest of ITV companies, but still a small, over-manned regional franchise, overly focused on ITV.

Eight years later, Granada Media has transformed itself into a bigger player, through acquisition and organic growth, with international interests and a half share in ONdigital which serves more than 700,000 homes. In 1994 it acquired LWT through a bitter-resisted hostile bid and gained a foothold in London for the first time, and a slate of weekend entertainment programmes. Since acquisition, LWT programme sales to all channels have risen by 54%. Ailing Yorkshire-Tyne Tees (acquired in 1997) has also flourished, reversing a decline in advertising.

The fact that this creative critical mass looks set to grow is good news for viewers. But the commission's verdict is bad news for ad agencies and advertisers, who wanted to stick with the current divided system. "No attention has been paid to the people who pay the money. We are disappointed," says Nick Phillips of the agencies' trade body, the IPA. "It reinforces our view that we don't have a voice at the table. We will be lobbying to enshrine a 'duty of care' for advertisers in the wording," says Bob Wootton of ISBA, the advertisers' organisation.

The commission has removed the 25% rule which prevents any company controlling more than a quarter of the TV advertising market, thereby allowing airtime sales in future to be controlled by two operations. And nothing has been put in its place - just a clear indication that ITV is to have two balancing sales forces.

Despite the talk of a single ITV company on the horizon, the one - sizeable - crumb of comfort is that the report states it may be five years or more before ITV's share of TV advertising drops to 50%. Which categorically puts the prospect of a one-owner ITV, while still inevitable, years away.

And there's also the issue of programming. The Carlton/United lobby argued that Granada's takeover plans pose another kind of dominance, in programme supply. Its franchises, Granada, LWT and Yorkshire-Tyne Tees, are ITV's top three programme-makers, supplying 48% of the network's original productions. But the risks of a merged company's interests unduly influencing programming choice were judged not great enough to operate against the national interest by the commission. So Granada's creative strength emerges from the inquiry unchallenged. This is what makes the report so clever and politically acceptable. It delighted the Department of Culture and even some staunch opponents. "I think the competition commission has been pretty sensible," says David Scott, managing director of Channel 4, who lobbied against the initial plan. "It's fantastic news for Granada," says a senior ITV Network source. "[trade and industry secretary] Stephen Byers didn't want to go down in history as the man who destroyed ITV," says another ITV insider. "Granada is special. It is trusted and has a track record." In contrast, United is still building its programme-making base under the respected leadership of former Channel 4 director of programmes, John Willis, while Carlton's recent problems of quality control, combined with a general failure to match high profits with high programming standards, have not helped. Granada's creative strength makes it by far the most important ITV player. It made eight of ITV's 10 top-rated programmes last year (excluding sports coverage). Overall, 30% of the UK's top-rated programmes came from its studios in 1999. Last week it pulled off a further coup, with ITV announcing that Yorkshire's Emmerdale would be running five nights a week from the autumn. Granada is, however, far from being a relaxed company for creative types to work in contentedly. "If editors and department heads lose orders, then they have to make people redundant," an insider explains. "There is huge attention to the bottom line. The control of costs is ruthless." That's why so many respected programme-makers leave after a while, another executive adds, "they don't like the notion of profits regardless". None the less, Granada's studios continue to deliver because of a long tradition which has given it strength and focus. "I have huge admiration for it," says a leading competitor ruefully. "Especially when you consider the state it was in." The current management, led by Gerry Robinson and Charles Allen, gained control of Granada in 1992, much to the old guard's horror. It was the oldest and grandest of ITV companies, but still a small, over-manned regional franchise, overly focused on ITV. Eight years later, Granada Media has transformed itself into a bigger player, through acquisition and organic growth, with international interests and a half share in ONdigital which serves more than 700,000 homes. In 1994 it acquired LWT through a bitter-resisted hostile bid and gained a foothold in London for the first time, and a slate of weekend entertainment programmes. Since acquisition, LWT programme sales to all channels have risen by 54%. Ailing Yorkshire-Tyne Tees (acquired in 1997) has also flourished, reversing a decline in advertising. The fact that this creative critical mass looks set to grow is good news for viewers. But the commission's verdict is bad news for ad agencies and advertisers, who wanted to stick with the current divided system. "No attention has been paid to the people who pay the money. We are disappointed," says Nick Phillips of the agencies' trade body, the IPA. "It reinforces our view that we don't have a voice at the table. We will be lobbying to enshrine a 'duty of care' for advertisers in the wording," says Bob Wootton of ISBA, the advertisers' organisation. The commission has removed the 25% rule which prevents any company controlling more than a quarter of the TV advertising market, thereby allowing airtime sales in future to be controlled by two operations. And nothing has been put in its place - just a clear indication that ITV is to have two balancing sales forces. Despite the talk of a single ITV company on the horizon, the one - sizeable - crumb of comfort is that the report states it may be five years or more before ITV's share of TV advertising drops to 50%. Which categorically puts the prospect of a one-owner ITV, while still inevitable, years away.

fields.headline: A swaggering predator called Granada
fields.standfirst: Mathew Horsman on the ITV power play
fields.trailText: Mathew Horsman on the ITV power play
fields.body:
Stage one of the consolidation of ITV got off to a ripping start last week, when the DTI announced the results of the competition commission's inquiry into the various bids by Granada, United and Carlton to be the ultimate winner of a single Channel 3. And we were left in no doubt as to the first stage winner: Granada Media Group. The report reads very nearly like Granada's own submission to the commission, accepting virtually every argument put forward by the owner of LWT, Yorkshire-Tyne Tees and Granada Television. That leaves Granada in the yellow jersey, able to take control on its own of the next stages that should see ITV under single ownership within two or so years.

To recap: last November, Carlton and United announced their intention to merge, which would create a TV powerhouse owning Carlton, Central and Westcountry (Carlton's licences) and Meridian, Anglia and HTV (United's franchises). Granada, at first wrong-footed by the announcement, went on the offensive, declaring that it would bid for either United or Carlton rather than see its two arch-rivals achieve a friendly merger.

Since then, we have been in waiting mode. Because every permutation of merger or takeover would have been illegal under one or another set of rules, the whole business had to be reviewed by the commission. There was never any chance that the primary restraint on consolidation, the ceiling of 15% of total TV audience, would be lifted this side of a new broadcasting bill. However, the other major constraint - the limit of 25% of airtime advertising sales - was a different matter. It was based on a set of informal undertakings with the office of fair trading, and could be lifted without primary legislation. That would free Carlton and United to merge, and would allow Granada to own either of its two rivals, provided it sold enough franchises to move below the 15% ceiling on audience.

In the end, the expected result was duly delivered. Yes, says the commission, the airtime sales limit will be abolished. But there was a wrinkle. Accepting verbatim the Granada argument, the commission said that no company should be allowed to control more than two "premium" ITV licences. Premium means any licence that sells airtime at a premium to the ITV average, and only four franchises - Carlton, Central, LWT and Meridian - fall into that camp.

So in order to merge, Carlton and United would have to sell Meridian. Granada, by contrast, could buy either Carlton or United without special conditions. It would, however, have to abide by the broadcasting act, and keep below 15% of audience share. It would also have to abide by the act's London-split provisions, which prohibit common ownership of the London franchises in the week and at the weekend.

So we have the rules laid down. What happens next? Let's take this in order, and apply some logic (an admittedly dangerous thing to do when dealing with the outsized egos and irrationality of ITV chieftains). First, the rationale behind the merger of United and Carlton looks pretty weak if the two have to sell Meridian. Is it really worth all that effort merely to add Anglia and HTV to Carlton's three licences?

Let's say the two parties decide to proceed anyway. They could then offer Meridian to Granada (at a suitable premium). But surely Granada's shareholders, who have just stumped up £1.3bn and backed a new listing for the de-merged media side of the old hotels and media conglomerate, deserve more than just one piddling licence for all that support? Granada has made suitably aggressive noises about its natural role as the consolidator of ITV. One licence does not a swaggering predator make. And would United-Carlton even want to sell the licence to Granada? Why not to another player, just to annoy Granada's Charles Allen?

It seems more likely to me that Granada will instead force the pace, by bidding for either Carlton or United. It may then extract additional concessions - that is, win more than just Meridian - for its troubles. A bid for United looks tempting on the surface. No problems there with the London split, and a chance to add at least two licences to the Granada stable (although not all three - that pesky broadcasting act gets in the way again).

But United is the also-ran in this bunch, and only derives a quarter of its profits from TV. Does Granada really want to waste time trying to find a buyer for the endlessly struggling Express Newspapers or for exhibitions? Also, United is already about as expensive as it can get: how much more than £10 a share does Charles Allen want to justify paying for second best?

Finally, why go for the third prize when the second prize is achievable now? The danger of leaving Carlton out at this point is that when the time comes for the ultimate consolidation of two companies into one (and make no mistake, that is where we are heading), Granada will have to deal with a stronger Carlton rather than a weaker United.

Of course, there are problems with a bid for Carlton. First, something would have to be done with either LWT or Carlton to meet the conditions of the London split. Second, Granada would also have to sell at least one licence to be below the 15% ceiling under the act.

The first hurdle could be handled by selling the licence to a third party (RTL-Pearson, perhaps?) and then buying it back when the rules change. (This would have to be done carefully, to avoid the appearance of "warehousing"). Granada could even keep 20% of LWT and still remain within the rules.

Although the share prices of the various companies last Friday seemed to suggest a different outcome was being predicted by the City, I still think Carlton is the more logical target for Charles Allen. It derives 50% of its profits from TV, is in the process of selling Technicolor (so Granada would not have to deal with that legacy) and would give Granada a lovely contiguous licence called Central to go with Granada and Yorkshire TV. The stock market, by contrast, marked down Carlton's shares and marked United's up, suggesting a bid for United was the expected outcome.

Logic may not always be the prime motivator but my money is still on Carlton being the target in Charles Allen's sights. And whatever the outcome, it will be for Allen to decide. In the next few weeks, the whip hand is his.

 Mathew Horsman is a media analyst at the City firm of Investec Henderson Crosthwaite. His firm publishes research and recommendations on shares mentioned in this article.

webTitle: Cook's wake-up call for the 'sleeping giants'

fields.headline: Cook's wake-up call for the 'sleeping giants'
fields.standfirst: Every week Wisden tracks down a player who has excelled in  a recent County  match. Today we talk to Northamptonshire's Anglo-Australian batsman Jeff Cook
fields.trailText: Jeffrey William Cook was born in Sydney, Australia , 28 years ago. He has lived in England for seven years and finally qualified to play as an Englishman at the start of this season. Last summer he scored 1250 runs at 54.34 for the Northamptonshire 2nd XI . He has also played Sydney grade cricket for St Georges and East Suburbs. Last Thursday, Cook scored 137, his maiden first-class century, as Northants notched up 543 in their innings win over Gloucestershire at Cheltenham.
fields.body:
Jeffrey William Cook was born in Sydney, Australia , 28 years ago. He has lived in England for seven years and finally qualified to play as an Englishman at the start of this season. Last summer he scored 1250 runs at 54.34 for the Northamptonshire 2nd XI . He has also played Sydney grade cricket for St Georges and East Suburbs. Last Thursday, Cook scored 137, his maiden first-class century, as Northants notched up 543 in their innings win over Gloucestershire at Cheltenham.

"I first came to England in 1993 and was on the fringes of the Northants staff then. I got married in England and decided to settle here and try to qualify. Last year I managed to break into the 2nd XI and did pretty well. This was only my third Championship match, but I've played in a lot of the one-dayers.

"The century against Gloucstershire was special as it was my maiden first-class hundred. The pitch was pretty flat - a very good wicket to bat on - but I think that they bowled pretty well. There wasn't much in it for the seamers, and they lost a spinner early on to injury [Tom Cotterell] so they stuck at it quite well. I remember being on 89 and hitting two fours to move to 97, before taking a single and finally reaching my hundred with a four straight down the ground over the bowler's head.

"I enjoyed batting with Mal [Loye] and Salesy [David Sales] - they both obviously know a lot about Championship cricket, and can tell me about the opposition players. I've had a couple of 80- or 90-run partnerships with Salesy before and he's a very good player. I reckon that he must be about next in line for a Test place - he just loves batting so if he gets to a hundred he'll usually go on to a big one. Obviously I'd like to play Test cricket - everyone wants to play cricket at the highest level they can - but having waited so long to qualify I'm just concentrating on scoring runs for Northants at the moment. I think that the club is due a trophy, and a decent run in the NatWest [Northants meet holders Gloucestershire in the quarter-finals] would be good. I guess that Northants are kind of the sleeping giants of county cricket.

"I think that the standard of county cricket is quite good. Obviously the weather has meant that the pitches haven't been very good for batsmen this season but the quality of the players themselves is high. So far I've enjoyed playing against fellow Australians such as Darren Lehmann [Yorks], Ian Harvey [Gloucs], and Glenn McGrath [Worcs]. I've played against McGrath in Sydney Grade Cricket so I guess I'm used to him! At the moment I'm working on my bowling: I'm kind of a seamer and I think that the skipper wants me to bowl a bit in one-day matches. The bottom line is for me to keep scoring runs for Northants and try and help them to be as succesful as possible."

Jeff Cook was talking to Tom Bowtell. To read last week's My Day in the Sun, in which Middlesex's Tim Bloomfield reveals how he helped skittle Somerset for 58, click here

webTitle: News: Emin to clean up as Turner-shortlisted bed goes to Saatchi

fields.headline: Emin to clean up as bed goes to Saatchi
fields.trailText: Tracey Emin, who made an art form out of displaying her dirty linen in public, looks like cleaning up. Charles Saatchi, Britain's foremost patron of the visual arts, is to pay £150,000 for her most notorious work, My Bed.
fields.body:
Tracey Emin, who made an art form out of displaying her dirty linen in public, looks like cleaning up. Charles Saatchi, Britain's foremost patron of the visual arts, is to pay £150,000 for her most notorious work, My Bed.

A reconstruction of Emin's unmade bed, with soiled sheets and surrounded by empty vodka bottles, cigarette packets and a condom, My Bed attracted praise and opprobrium when it was shortlisted for the Turner Prize last year.

Even by the standards of that never knowingly uncontroversial award, the bed caused a stir, raising Emin's profile to new heights and providing a vehicle for others to propel themselves into public view. Two Chinese performance artists gained publicity by leaping on to the mattress and staging a pillow fight before being separated by Tate Gallery security guards.

Mr Saatchi, who championed many of the young British artists (YBAs) who emerged in the mid-1990s, including Damien Hirst, said he was a late convert to Emin's work.

"I was very slow to get the loopiness of Tracey's work, but I'm a helpless fan now."

The Tate was initially interested in buying My Bed and opened negotiations with Emin's agent, Jay Joplin. Little progress was made, however, and Mr Saatchi stepped in last week.

As well as the bed, he has agreed to pay £75,000 for a beach hut built by Emin on the seafront in her home town of Margate.

Both works will go on show at the Saatchi Gallery in St John's Wood, north London, in September, in the Ant Noises 2 exhibition, sequel to the hugely successful 1997 Sensation exhibition at the Royal Academy that marked the YBA's arrival at the heart of the British art establishment. (Ant Noises is an anagram of sensation.)

The "loopiness" that attracted Mr Saatchi to Emin's work has ensured she has remained among the most famous artists in the country, despite being derided by some critics as lacking depth and talent.

Prior to My Bed, she provoked mild outrage with Everyone I Have Ever Slept With 1963-1995, a tent embroidered inside and out with the names of all her bed partners, which fetched £40,000.

Her challenging work was complemented by some memorable disappearances on television. In 1997 she stormed out of the Turner Prize dinner, and the following year she enlivened a live arts programme with a drunken, expletive-filled appearance.

In an interview with Tatler magazine, which appears next month, she insisted that she had grown up somewhat in the past 18 months, and now worked with a discipline absent from her previous work.

"She can drink, swear like a squaddie and is clearly brilliant at attracting publicity," said David Lee, former editor of Art Review. "It's visibility and controversy which gets the price up."

In which case Emin, 37, would appear to be an old master.

webTitle: Safe male pill 'on sale in five years'

fields.headline: Safe male pill 'on sale in five years'
fields.trailText: A male contraceptive pill which is 100% effective and has no unpleasant side effects could be on the market within five years, according to scientists.
fields.body:
A male contraceptive pill which is 100% effective and has no unpleasant side effects could be on the market within five years, according to scientists.

A team working at Edinburgh University claim to have achieved complete success in international trials.

Scientists now hope that the male pill could appear on shelves in the UK in the next five years.

Previous attempts to manufacture a male pill have been hampered by severe side effects. These include high blood pressure, weight gain, acne and a loss of sex drive. But scientists working on this latest drug claim to have eradicated them.

Trials held in Scotland, South Africa, China and Nigeria have also proved to be successful.

Professor David Baird of Edinburgh University's centre for reproductive biology has described the results as "very encouraging".

The results of the trials will be formally announced at the World Conference for Gynaecologists and Obstetricians in Washington in September.

The trials were backed by the Dutch pharmaceutical company Organon.

The pill contains a synthetic steroid, desogestrel, which inhibits sperm production. Its other main ingredient is the male sex hormone, testosterone, to counteract the loss of sex drive.

A male pill would provide an alternative to vasectomy or female sterilisation.

It would also provide an option for those couples worried about the health implications of the female contraceptive pill.

In 1995 the government's medical advisers warned that women taking the "third generation" pills ran double the risk of developing potentially fatal blood clots.

But the Catholic church in Scotland was quick to condemn the latest development.

A spokesman said: "As far as we are concerned any form of artificial contraception is wrong - a male pill would be as wrong as a female pill."

He warned that the development of a male pill could lead to a more relaxed attitude to abortion and marriage which in turn could lead to an increased number of unplanned pregnancies.

fields.headline: Blair's alarm at Hague fightback
fields.standfirst:
Leak shows growing unease in Downing Street over Tory leader's ability to strike a chord with voters on popular issues

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Leak shows growing unease in Downing Street over Tory leader's ability to strike a chord with voters on popular issues.
fields.body:
Yesterday morning on GMTV, both Jack Straw and Ann Widdecombe denied they were involved in a Dutch auction to capture the populist law and order vote.

However, the extraordinary leak only 15 hours later of a memo from the prime minister's own computer suggest the opposite is the case.

The leak seriously rattled Downing Street simply because it had to confront the possibility that the administration is defenceless in the face of a computer hacker, or a fifth columnist in the prime minister's closest entourage.

A Downing Street spokesman conceded that the leak was spectacular, but insisted the document did not reveal any fundamental calumny or deceit by Mr Blair.

The spokesman claimed the memo dealt with a set of issues and concerns the prime minister had largely addressed, including crime, especially rural crime, defence spending, support for the family and finally the freeing up of the time of Mr Blair's spokesman Alastair Campbell to devote more energy to assembling a consistent message on formerly core Tory issues.

Nevertheless, the memo also reveals the speed with which Mr Blair became privately rattled by the sudden ability of William Hague, after years in the doldrums, to capture touchstone rightwing issues in a way which left the government looking apologetic and flat footed.

Mr Hague finally found his political voice when on April 26 he sided with the Norfolk farmer Tony Martin when he was found guilty of murdering a burglar.

Mr Hague followed up with calls for detention camps for all asylum seekers and demands that drug pushers near school gates be jailed for life. He also proposed scrapping the early release of prisoners.

Mr Hague admitted privately that he had decided to give up making worthy and unreported speeches on the environment. He was going to go for topical issues and give vent to the instincts of the core Tory vote. In public, Mr Blair accused him of being opportunistic, suffering poor judgment or advocating lynch law. In private, Mr Blair was demanding a counter-attack, implicitly venting his frustration at the home secretary, Jack Straw, for failing to deliver tough messages.

Philip Gould, the party's private pollster, and Mr Blair have always watched hawkeyed for any sign that they were losing the traditionally Tory ground which they and New Labour had spectacularly colonised before the 1997 election.

Mr Blair repeatedly told allies of the advice given to him by Bill Clinton, who claimed his party's political success had been based on giving special attention to the new voters lured to the Democrat cause in 1992.

Any suggestion that the Tories were making a comeback in the fields of defence, the family, asylum or crime would have alarmed Blair.

Other leaks from the computer of Mr Gould to Mr Blair, mainly written at the time of the local elections, suggest Mr Blair was being advised that Mr Hague had struck a chord.

Despite the attacks from the left, suggesting Mr Blair was ignoring his core vote and the heartlands, the memo reveals him more preoccupied with protecting his political right.

The Downing Street policy response to the Hague revival is now relatively clear. Sir Charles Guthrie, the chief of defence staff, has been told the Ministry of Defence will have above inflation rises in this week's spending round. A story was leaked at the week end suggesting Mr Blair had personally authorised the increases.

On asylum, Mr Straw - who admitted yesterday it has been the most difficult political issue confronting him - has been forced to make as much as possible of the recent fall in the asylum backlog led by the increase in asylum decisions.

On family issues, Mr Blair has let it be known he will not be expecting quick implementation on proposals to give gays new rights in the imminent sexual offences review.

He also called a police summit to discuss ways to tackle burglary. The initiative backfired badly when he proposed drunks should be frogmarched to cash machines to pay on the spot fines, an idea rejected by chief constables as barmy.

fields.headline: Schools budget bonanza
fields.standfirst:
Comprehensive Spending Review 2000: Special Report
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government will tomorrow announce a big increase in the schools budget which will see spending on every pupil in England and Wales increase by more than £500 over the next four years.
fields.byline: Patrick Wintour, Larry Elliott and Will Woodward
fields.body:
The government will tomorrow announce a big increase in the schools budget which will see spending on every pupil in England and Wales increase by more than £500 over the next four years.

As part of his comprehensive spending review, Gordon Brown, the chancellor, is also to provide an £800m neighbourhood renewal fund designed to reduce inequalities between rich and poor.

At the insistence of David Blunkett, the education secretary, a large part of the extra education spending will be devoted to secondary schools in inner cities. Ministers will present the spending as the first stage in a long term drive to ensure resources in state schools match those in privileged private schools.

Cabinet sources told the Guardian yesterday: "Education will not be taking a back seat because of the big increases set aside for health. Education did better than health in this year, but both departments will get almost exactly equivalent percentage rises over the four years, including this year 2000-01."

The March budget forecast health spending rising over the four years by 6.1%.

The sources added: "Spending per pupil will rise by £180 extra this year - 2000-01. By the end of the three year run following - the period covered by tomorrow's spending review announcements, ending in 2003-04 -it's likely spending will have risen by well in excess of an additional £300 per pupil in real terms. That makes it total around £500 per pupil extra on top of inflation over four years."

The sources continued: "We can now start over a very long period to narow the gap between public and private education funding. There is no way it is going to be done in one or two spending periods, but if we can have a consistent and continuous rise in the spending curve then we can make it."

In a more controversial move, ministers have also decided to extend performance-related pay for teachers to sixth-form and further education colleges at a cost of £50m. The extra money will be aimed at the "chalkface worker" rather than senior or middle-ranking staff.

In another major announcement, Mr Brown is set to hand out an extra £1bn over three years to deprived communities through a neighbourhood renewal fund and other measures as part of an attempt to save Britain's rundown estates.

The decision follows a review across Whitehall led by the Treasury permanent secretary, Sir Andrew Turnbull, and the innovative work on neighbourhood renewal conducted by the social exclusion unit.

Mr Brown has been struck by research showing huge disparities between the most deprived parts of Britain and the rest of the country. The figures showed 30% higher mortality rates, unemployment rates two-thirds higher than the national average and 1.3m adults with a reading age of seven.

Districts to receive extra funds include inner London boroughs such as Tower Hamlets and Lambeth, Liverpool, Sandwell, Middlesborough and Doncaster.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, has secured an increase in the crime fighting fund budget to bring numbers of police back to the level at the time of the last general election.

In March he announced he had compressed plans to recruit an additional 5,000 police officers from the planned three years to two, adding that 2,000 additional police officers would be recruited this year, instead of the planned 1,000.

However, problems with retention and a retirement bulge have seen overall numbers falling to 2,500 below the level of the general election.

Meanwhile, the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, has won a 5.8% real terms increase by the third year, the largest real terms increase for diplomacy for 10 years. He is also to spend an extra £64m over three years improving the BBC World Service and internet access to it.

The shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, yesterday predicted an unsustainable spending binge and said his party would not match the government. He said realism now, rather than spending above the level of economic growth, would in the long term guarantee higher spending.

Main points

Spending will increase overall by 3.3% a year, bringing an increase of more than £40bn in three years' time

£21bn likely to be added to health budget over four years

£4bn a year extra expected to be invested in transport

£500 per pupil extra on top of inflation over four years

£800m for the neighbourhood renewal fund designed to reduce inequalities between rich and poor

£50m extension to performance-related pay scheme for teachers in sixth-form and further education colleges

webTitle: Full text of the leaked memo

fields.headline: Full text: we are seen as weak and soft
fields.standfirst:
The full text of Tony Blair's private memo, leaked to the Times and the Sun yesterday, setting out his government's weaknesses.
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The full text of Tony Blair's private memo, leaked to the Times and the Sun yesterday, setting out his government's weaknesses.
fields.body:
Touchstone issues

There are a clutch of issues - seemingly disparate - that are in fact linked. We need a strategy that is almost discrete, focussed on them. They are roughly combining "on your side" issues with toughness and standing up for Britain. They range from: the family - where, partly due to MCA (married couples' tax allowance) and to gay issues, we are perceived as weak; asylum and crime where we are perceived as soft; and asserting the nation's interests where, because of the unpopularity of Europe, a constant barrage of small stories beginning to add up on defence and even issues like Zimbabwe, we are seen as insufficiently assertive.

All this, of course, is perception. It is bizarre that any government I lead should be seen as anti-family. We are, in fact, taking very tough measures on asylum and crime. Kosovo should have laid to rest any doubts about our strength in defence. But all these things add up to a sense that the government - and this even applies to me - are somehow out of touch with gut British instincts.

The Martin case - and the lack of any response from us that appeared to empathise with public concern and then channel it into the correct course - has only heightened this problem.

We need a thoroughly worked out strategy, stretching over several months, to regain the initiative in this area. Each of these issues should be analysed and the correct policy response drawn up. Then each should be dealt with, but with a message that ties it all together. This is precisely the sort of thing AC and CF [Alastair Campbell and Charles Falconer] should do if a new system is put in place which frees up their time.

My thoughts are:

i) Possibly on the Martin case, asking a senior judge to look at changing the sentencing law, ie to allow lesser sentences than life. We also need far tougher rebuttal or alternatively action, re the allegations that jurors were intimidated.

ii) On asylum, we need to be highlighting removals and decisions plus if the April figures show a reduction, then a downward trend. Also if the benefits bills really start to fall, that should be highlighted. Plus some of the genuine asylum claims should be given some publicity.

iii) On crime we need to highlight the tough measures: compulsory tests for drugs before bail; the PIU (Performance Innovation Unit) report on the confiscation of assets; the extra number of burglars jailed under "three strikes and you're out". Above all, we must deal now with street crime, especially in London. When the figures are published for the six months to April, they will show a small, 4%, rise in crime. But this will almost entirely be due to the rise in levels of street crime - mobile phones, bags being snatched. This will be worst in London. The Met police are putting in place measures to deal with it; but as ever we lack a tough public message along with the strategy. We should think now of an initiative, eg locking up street muggers. Something tough, with immediate bite, which sends a message through the system. Maybe, the driving licence penalty for young offenders. But this should be done soon, and I, personally, should be associated with it.

iv) On defence, we need to make the CSR (Comprehensive Spending Review) work for defence. Big cuts and you can forget any hope of winning back ground on "standing up for Britain".

v) On the family, we need two or three eye-catching initiatives that are entirely conventional in terms of their attitude to the family. Despite the rubbish about gay couples, the adoption issue worked well. We need more.

I should be personally associated with as much of this as possible.

TB 29 April 2000

fields.headline: Diageo to confirm Pillsbury deal
fields.trailText: Diageo is expected to announce the merger of its Pillsbury US food unit with General Mills today, in a move which will herald closer ties between Diageo's two remaining businesses, UDV spirits and wines and Guinness brewing.
fields.body:
Diageo is expected to announce the merger of its Pillsbury US food unit with General Mills today, in a move which will herald closer ties between Diageo's two remaining businesses, UDV spirits and wines and Guinness brewing.

The merger deal will value Pillsbury at $10.5bn (£6.5bn) and give Diageo a 33% stake in a General Mills-Pillsbury business. In addition, Diageo will receive $4.5bn in cash while General Mills takes on $4.5bn of Pillsbury debt.

The share-and-cash deal was approved by the Diageo board on Friday and by the General Mills board over the weekend. It will create the world's fifth largest food company and bring annual combined cost savings of $400m by 2003.

But the stock-swap deal is set to prompt a move to bring Diageo's UDV Johnnie Walker whisky and Smirnoff vodka unit closer to its Guinness beer division and to drive through cost savings expected to cost hundreds of jobs.

Diageo believes that efficiencies can be pushed through by closer links as new ready-to-drink spirit combinations such as Smirnoff Ice and Mule are sold increasingly in the same marketplace as premium-priced beers.

The move will focus Diageo around a beverage-alcohol core which earns two thirds of the group's profits, but will be its engine of growth after the Pillsbury stake is sold and its Burger King hamburger chain is floated by 2003.

The combination of General Mills and Pillsbury will create a food group with annual sales of $12.8bn, behind Nestlé, Philip Morris's Kraft-Nabisco unit, Unilever-Bestfoods and US group ConAgra.

Pillsbury's future has been under review at Diageo since February 1998, only two months after Diageo was formed from the merger of Guinness and GrandMet. Diageo agreed the deal with General Mills after merger talks with Bestfoods earlier this year because of their better product and geographic fit.

Reuters

fields.headline: Killer drivers face lifetime bans
fields.standfirst:
Tougher penalties expected in road safety crackdown
Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Tougher penalties for speeding and drink-driving offences, and possible lifetime bans for drivers who kill, are expected to be recommended by ministers after a five-month review of the driving laws.
fields.body:
Tougher penalties for speeding and drink-driving offences, and possible lifetime bans for drivers who kill, are expected to be recommended by ministers after a five-month review of the driving laws.

A Home Office spokesman confirmed yesterday that a consultation paper is to be published within the next few weeks. Among expected measures are maximum fines for speeding increased to £1,000; banned drivers forced to retake their tests; larger fines and longer bans on drink-drivers; and lifetime bans on some drivers who kill.

Charles Clarke, the Home Office minister for criminal justice, said at the weekend that it was wrong that motorists who killed faced a maximum sentence of 10 years, compared with the maximum of 14 years for burglary. He is reported to have said there was a case to make causing death by dangerous driving the motoring equivalent of manslaughter, which carries a life sentence.

The consultation paper is expected to recommend a change in the approach that has guided sentencing in such cases for more than 50 years - that of penalising motorists on the basis of the quality of their driving or their carelessness, but not directly on the basis of the consequences for others.

Ministers were surprised to discover during the review that a quarter of the 300 drivers convicted each year of causing death by dangerous driving were not sent to prison; some were merely fined and had their licences endorsed.

An offence of causing death by careless driving may be introduced. But a Home Office spokesman yesterday played down the suggestion that the consultation paper will demand that the offence carry with it a maximum life sentence.

Motoring organisations reacted cautiously. The RAC questioned whether it was tougher penalties that were needed, or the better enforcement of existing penalties.

A spokesman pointed out that, although the 10-year sentence was available to the courts for drivers who killed, it was rarely used. The AA also questioned whether it would be right to jail a driver who ran over somebody as a result of a momentary lapse of concentration and a glance away from the road.

"There has been a review of road traffic penalties, looking at the whole range of penalties for different types of offences," the Home Office spokesman said.

"They have been particularly looking at the whole area of bans and retraining of driving offenders, but we cannot say exactly what will be in the consultation paper."

The review has been carried out by the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions, the Lord Chancellor's Department, and the Home Office.

webTitle: Hague own goal on school policy

fields.headline: Hague own goal on school policy
fields.standfirst:
Education Unlimited
Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague has angered Tory councillors in his constituency with a speech mistakenly criticising them for spending thousands of pounds on unnecessary repairs to a school.
fields.body:
William Hague has angered Tory councillors in his constituency with a speech mistakenly criticising them for spending thousands of pounds on unnecessary repairs to a school.

The Conservative leader scored an own goal when he accused his local education authority in North Yorkshire of spending £98,000 to replace sound windows at a school in his Richmond constituency, instead of using the money to save the job of a teacher who was to be made redundant next term.

He was rebuked by a senior Tory councillor and by the headteacher of Romanby county primary school, in Northallerton, and told to get his facts right in future - but Mr Hague went ahead with the remarks, in his keynote speech earlier this month to launch the Tories' education policy, promising to abolish education authorities (LEAs) and allow schools to decide how to spend their budgets.

Mr Hague told an audience at the rightwing thinktank Politeia that a school in his constituency was "being forced to lose a teacher this year because of budget cuts" and that the school would "much rather" spend the £98,000 on retaining the teacher than on an upgrade for all its windows which, he said, had "nothing wrong" with them and would "last another 20 years at least".

Mr Dennis also pointed out that, despite Mr Hague's claims, a senior maintenance officer had confirmed that the windows were in urgent need of replacing, as the single-glazed metal frames dating from the 1950s leaked, causing "considerable heat loss" and "significant condensation problems", while the "twisted hinges and insecure catches" posed a security risk.

The councillor's letter came in response to an advance of Mr Hague's speech, and to a letter sent by the Tory leader some days earlier to David Ashton, Tory leader of North Yorkshire county council, complaining about the repairs.

webTitle: US check on sheep in new BSE alert

fields.headline: US check on sheep in new BSE alert
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: Government scientists are to hold urgent talks with their counterparts in the United States over the discovery that sheep imported from Europe are showing signs of a disease that may be linked to BSE in cattle.
fields.body:
Government scientists are to hold urgent talks with their counterparts in the United States over the discovery that sheep imported from Europe are showing signs of a disease that may be linked to BSE in cattle.

Three flocks quarantined in the state of Vermont are being destroyed under the orders of the US agriculture department which has begun tests to establish whether the disease believed to have spread to humans has also transferred to sheep.

Scientists in Britain have long feared this is possible, although the disease has been successfully introduced to sheep only in laboratory tests.

Now experts working for the government have commissioned a risk assessment to quantify the threat to human health if BSE were found in Britain's 40m sheep.

From January, all sheep will have to be tagged as part of European Union measures to track major diseases. The Ministry of Agriculture said last night: "There is nothing to suggest that what they have discovered in America is BSE at the moment. But whatever they discover we will look at with interest."

Government officials are trying to quantify the costs of a human epidemic of variant CJD, linked to eating beef from infected cattle years ago, which has so far claimed 67 lives in Britain with at least eight other victims probably suffering from the fatal condition.

Experts are worried by a rise in cases in recent months, and are investigating an apparent cluster involving five people, four of whom have died, around the Leicestershire village of Queniborough.

Members of the main scientific advisory committee in BSE and variant CJD are meeting to discuss both issues today.

News of the US investigations emerged as Robert Will, head of the CJD surveillance unit in Edinburgh, reiterated his fears that the high proportion of young victims resulted from their exposure to foods containing mechanically recovered meat used in baby foods, pates, beefburgers, pies, sausages and other dishes often on school meal menus.

Many risky materials from cattle were banned from food in 1989, although enforcement of the restrictions is thought to have been poor. But mechanically recovered meat, known as MRM, machined off animal bones, was not banned until 1995.

Professor Will told the Independent on Sunday: "Foodstuffs which contained that material could be particularly dangerous. One possible explanation for the age distribution is that young people tend to eat these products more than the adult population."

Prof Will was not available yesterday but the Department of Health said: "There is nothing new in this. Everyone has been well aware for a long time that reprocessed meat was a potential means of transmission.

"Scientific research continues. Reprocessed meat was used in a very wide variety of feedstuffs, certainly not babyfood and school meals. Nobody should be in any doubt there is no risk now from these things."

The US investigations involving 376 sheep could take several years. Four were found to have a BSE-like disease which could be a new form of scrapie, a sheep disease long endemic in Britain, but not known to be dangerous to humans.

The tests will be conducted at a secure facility at Plum Island, near New York. The animals were dairy sheep imported from Belgium and the Netherlands in 1996 and their milk, and cheese made from it, has been sold for some time. Their lambs have also been sold for food.

Britain has banned some parts of sheep, including the head, from entering food for some years but is slightly relaxing controls as a trade-off for EU-wide measures.

Scrapie is increasing in Britain, with nearly 600 cases reported last year. The actual incidence may be eight times as high. It is mostly identified in older sheep.

webTitle: BBC faces inquiry into online giveaway

fields.headline: BBC faces inquiry into online giveaway
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC is facing an inquiry by the office of fair trading into its practice of giving away online news services to mobile phone operators and internet sites.
fields.body:
The BBC is facing an inquiry by the office of fair trading into its practice of giving away online news services to mobile phone operators and internet sites.

ITN, the commercial television news operator, has prepared a complaint for the OFT, and may even seek to take the BBC governors to court.

It argues that while firms such as Cellnet, Vodafone and Yahoo! profit from the BBC's publicly funded services, the licence fee payer is being sold short.

ITN also accuses the BBC of crowding out competitors, such as Reuters and Sky, by using its privileged status as a non commercial operation.

The BBC concedes that, in trials, it has not been charging for the use of its online news services, but points out that the trials are due to end soon, after which a decision will be made on whether to start charging.

The BBC's rivals have long harboured a grudge over its vigorous pursuit of a digital market. Sky and ITN were angry that the corporation did not charge cable television operators to carry its news channel BBC News 24, which is funded by the licence fee.

While the BBC could afford to subsidise the channel from its guaranteed income generated by the licence fee, Sky News had to charge carriers to have any hope of making a profit.

Now, the BBC is using a similar tactic with mobile phone operators and internet portals, which provide news headlines services to their customers. ITN says this is an abuse of the corporation's position, and might be against the spirit of its charter.

Stewart Purvis, the chief executive of ITN, writing in the Guardian today, says: "Most licence fee payers already know that some of their money is spent on digital services. What they probably don't realise is that the content which is generated for bbc.co.uk at some considerable expense is then offered to a whole series of commercially funded operators for free."

He said the BBC should come clean to the public. "The BBC should try to explain to licence payers how it can afford to be quite so generous to wealthy private sector companies when it cannot afford to buy the rights to sporting events for BBC1 and BBC2.

"Perhaps more importantly, if the BBC continues to offer online news content free-to-air on these commercial platforms, all of the other news providers who have traditionally kept the BBC on its toes through vigorous competition will be crowded out of the market."

If the OFT decides to take up the case, ITN will approach the European commission's competition regulators. It is also taking legal advice on whether to launch a judicial review.

Privately, the BBC believes its commercial rivals are simply jealous of the success of its online services, which are widely regarded as market leaders.

A spokeswoman for the corporation said yesterday that the mobile phone trials were due to end in the next few weeks. A decision on whether to charge for them would be taken then. "The trials, which have been approved by the Department of Culture, Media and Sport, are going well, and are due to come to an end soon. Once we have seen the results, and subject to various approvals, we will be considering our position."

ITN believes the case demonstrates the need for the BBC to be brought under a system of independent regulation.

The government is consulting the broadcasting industry for a communications white paper, due out this year. Chris Smith, the culture secretary, has indicated he favours a fundamental shake-up of the regulatory system. It is possible that the BBC's governors will be brought under the umbrella of an independent system, or perhaps even abolished altogether.
