webTitle: That gentleman's club by the Thames. What's it in aid of?

fields.headline: That gentleman's club by the Thames. What's it in aid of?
fields.standfirst:
Droning, fawning, jousting, antiquated: Westminster is now intolerable
Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Droning, fawning, jousting, antiquated: Westminster is now intolerable.
fields.body:
His smile, beatific in its anticipation, precedes him these days. Menzies Campbell is a very happy man. I think - and I think he thinks - that he will be the next speaker of the House of Commons, heir to a plump salary, fine lodgings in the Palace of Westminster and a life devoid of base party politicking. Perfection? Perhaps, for a distinguished 59-year-old Liberal serving a freshly installed party leader 19 years younger. But there ought, at least, to be a furrowed brow or two before the deed is done.

"Be happy for me," Betty Boothroyd said as she bowed out. More happiness: but this was joy at quitting the job - an echo across two centuries of Speaker Fletcher Norton, brain numbed by hours of wriggling boredom. "I am tired! I am weary! I am heartily sick of all this!" And that was the tolerably interesting parliament of then - not the intolerably uninteresting parliament of now.

The historic theory, you will recall, is that the speaker is the most eminent of all MPs, holder of an office which changed forever in 1642 when Mr Speaker Lenthall became a servant of the Commons not a servant of the Crown. The great names of some of his successors - Peel, Shaw-Lefevre, Lowther and Brand - linger in legend. But that, again, was then. Now we tend to get less lingering fry.

They are decent chaps doing, by and large, a decent, lonely job. Some - like George Thomas - appear to confuse being speaker with election as president of an undeclared republic and use it as a platform for windy lectures on public morality. Some, like Bernard Weatherill, adopt a lower, terser profile. But only Westminster - the great gentlemen's club by the Thames - would so conflate their significance. The parting tributes to Betty Boothroyd, in their lavishness, might more appropriately have been bestowed on the mapper of the genome.

That isn't to belittle Madam Speaker. She was in no sense a political heavyweight (her nearest sniff of office was 13 months as an assistant whip a quarter of a century ago) but the past eight years made her a folk heroine, a woman coping with vigour and humour in a man's world. Maybe she got a touch Queen Mum-ish towards the close - the flummery of speakerdom tends to load on portent with the robes. Nevertheless, she will be missed. Backbenchers thought she was on their side against the arrogance of ministers and the spinning of the Whitehall machine, always striving to make parliament central again, not some routine satellite of Governance Inc. Lenthall's baton has passed a long, long way - so that this speaker was the last defender left of the Commons against an overweening executive. Alas, she could never win.

Thus deeper issues flow for the transition. It is entirely typical of this cocoon of a club that it should guard its supposed privileges jealously. It wants due BBC prominence for its toil. It wants ministers to tell it - not John Humphrys - the big news first. It seeks the independence to rock the boat at PM's questions and to have its legislative voice heard, rather than taken for granted. In short, like Ms Boothroyd, it wants the old order restored - and it is, of course, egged on by a parliamentary press which hankers nostalgically after just those reflected glories for itself. But can we now solemnly realise that this is a dream? That the old order is pushing up daisies? That there is no point in choosing another Betty to try and to fail once more?

P arliament isn't important in national life because it says it is important. Parliament is only important for what it does - and that, syphoning instant restraints on supposed football hooligans through the Commons in a day, is often merely feeble. The thwarted (on teachers' pay) go to the courts, not to their MPs' surgeries. The Lords - almost from habit - cut up rough from time to time. The denizens of the Lower Chamber keep their heads down and their powder bone dry.

When we talk of reform, we talk mainly about modest things like changing working hours so that MP mums can see the kids occasionally. Tinkerings. The media round, as Mr Blair plangently complained on Alastair Campbell's home movie this weekend, is now a 24-hour ordeal. New candidates - such as Blond Boris Johnson - are chosen because of their selection meeting skills at TV parlour games. Ministers fight for broadcasting slots, not unwatched appearances in the House. The public opinion that matters has to be reached directly through staged press conferences and glossy brochures - or even from the back of a lorry. Westminster is an obscure loop line.

Prime ministers present and future shun the Commons of necessity. A Premier Hague, whatever knives he seeks to twist in current debate, would be exactly like Premier Blair. Their opposite numbers across Europe, for the most part, find their own parliaments infinitely less demanding of time and energy. The British work load, gone to Edinburgh, Cardiff and Brussels, is less. The scope for meaningful rebellion in a world of autonomous central bankers and open trading frontiers is much less, too.

These aren't little things. Together, they constitute a giant shift, pushing MPs down the pecking order. No backbencher today has a chance of making a reputation as an orator. You can't bring an empty Chamber to its feet. Escape comes only through the prospect of advancement to a place on the payroll, a reward for docile behaviour. Those who stumble and fall from favour - the Frank Fields of this life - may be whisperingly dismissed as embittered. The rule of the whips is absolute.

Mr Speaker Campbell (if it is he) is an incisive operator. It is difficult to believe he will want to settle for a career of pomp with scant circumstance: and the challenges have never been clearer. When Gordon Brown belabours Oxbridge elitism, he basically attacks not just an entrance system - but a style, a demeanour, a mode of debating learned at the Union and never shaken off. William Hague (with his 29% approval rating) is the embodiment of that style. Points of order, points of information; honourable stand-ups and dishonourable sit-downs; green leather benches and flunkeys in period mufti.

Suddenly the clean modern lines and conversational tone of the Scottish assembly make it look out of touch. Suddenly the fawnings and joustings of Question Time seem pointless irritation. Suddenly the dronings into another deserted night begin to offend the intelligence. This is the club of relevance lost, a collection of furnishings, fittings and quaintnesses which cut it of from the people. Tony Blair isn't the only one who "is heartily sick of all this".

Madam Speaker couldn't turn the clock back. The next Mr Speaker needs the reforming zeal of a Speaker Peel - for serving this Commons now means turning the clock definitively forward.

fields.headline: SAS behind Sierra Leone rescue
fields.standfirst:
Family sees British paratrooper land safely home after 10 weeks in UN garrison besieged by rebels
Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: A Parachute Regiment officer landed back in Britain last night praising the dramatic weekend operation in which he and more than 200 other UN observers and soldiers were rescued from a rebel siege in Sierra Leone by forces acting on directions from SAS teams and backed by Chinook helicopters.
fields.body:
A Parachute Regiment officer landed back in Britain last night praising the dramatic weekend operation in which he and more than 200 other UN observers and soldiers were rescued from a rebel siege in Sierra Leone by forces acting on directions from SAS teams and backed by Chinook helicopters.

The operation by UN and British forces was "extremely professional and extremely swift - it's of great credit to the people involved", Major Andrew Harrison said after being reunited with his wife Carolyn and two small daughters at RAF Northolt, west of London.

An unarmed UN observer monitoring the notional peace peace between Sierra Leone's Revolutionary United Front rebels and government, Maj Harrison was taken captive by the RUF in early May along with 10 other observers. Soon after, they were sent to a UN base at Kailahun where 222 Indian troops of the Unamsil peacekeeping operation were surrounded by the rebels.

Maj Harrison said that the day before Saturday's land and air operation, the rescuers messaged him at the base on his satellite phone to tell him what was about to happen.

"For weeks people had been trying to negotiate the freedom of movement for the Kailahun company and without success," he said last night. "Of course I can't be objective but I felt it was time for action and indeed swift and decisive action was taken."

He said the rescue helicopters touched down for about 30 seconds.

Guided by SAS spotters who had been covertly monitoring the rebels, Indian helicopters and British Chinooks - the latter said to be in Sierra Leone to help train government troops - picked up the military observers and flew them to Sierra Leone's capital, Freetown.

They also brought out more than two dozen peacekeepers from the Indian garrison who were suffering from illness. The rest of Unamsil's 222-strong Indian contingent left Kailahun by road and was said last night to have got safely to another UN base at Datu after encountering some shooting on the road.

The main fighting was done by a ground force of Nigerian, Indian and Ghanaian soldiers that moved in on the rebels at Kailahun backed by the helicopters. The troops inflicted an unspecified number of casualties in clashes with the rebels.

There were also reports that the two British Chinooks involved had encountered some shooting when they landed.

Geoff Hoon, Britain's defence secretary, had agreed to a Unamsil request for help to lift a siege that had lasted for more than 10 weeks at the Indian garrison.

The Conservative party's defence spokesman, Robert Key, said: "We congratulate the government on what we know must have been a difficult decision."

The Unamsil commander, Major-General Vijay Jetley, has been criticised for letting the rebels run rings round the UN forces in Sierra Leone.

The rebels had been adopting an "increasingly threatening posture," UN secretary general Kofi Annan's spokesman, Fred Eckhard, said on Saturday: "The use of force by Unamsil to extract its personnel from the area had become inevitable."

Maj Harrison, 33, said that when he was first abducted he was threatened physically and verbally by the rebels.

After her husband's RAF jet landed at Northolt last night, Mrs Harrison said: "It has been a very long 10 and a half weeks and under the circumstances it has been very stressful for myself and all of the family. We are a very close family and every one has felt it very hard." During Maj Harrison's time trapped at the base, he had also been able to keep in contact with his wife by satphone and email.

Three other Britons taken captive at the same time - Major Phil Ashby, Major Andrew Samsonoff and Lieutenant-Commander Paul Rowland - managed to escape in a jungle trek in May.

Mr Hoon welcomed what he called the "decisive action" by Unamsil but insisted that the British forces involved - including soldiers of the Royal Anglian Regiment - had been under national command.

Gen Jetley, the Unamsil commander, told reporters at his base in Daru: "The men were not only rescued, they were also rescued with all the weapons they had in their possession." In recent months some Unamsil units menaced by the RUF had simply turned over their arms and vehicles.

The rebels suffered "serious casualties" on Saturday during fighting with the Ghanaian troops, according to Major Arun Anthanarayan, an officer attached to Unamsil. Peacekeepers later leaving Kailahun by road also shot back at rebels attacking them.

Gen Jetley maintained that the UN force, which is close to its authorised strength of 13,000 - making it the UN's biggest current peacekeeping operation - would continue to operate throughout the west African country. "It is our mandate for us to deploy, but this time we will have to do it in a robust manner because of our past experience," he said.

The Indian government said yesterday it remained fully committed to the UN mission in Sierra Leone. "Of course we will continue to stay on," the foreign minister, Jaswant Singh, said in New Delhi. But with the rebels in control of much of the country and government forces factionalised, the auguries are not good.

fields.headline: Brown's beneficence
fields.standfirst:
Increasing public spending levels is not necessarily a boon to the poor. The money often ends up lining the pockets of the wealthier classes
Comprehensive Spending Review 2000: special report
fields.trailText: A mystery at the heart of the third way is how much a progressive, fairness-minded government should actually be spending. Is the UK's 39.5% of GDP the right amount; would 10% more - pushing us up to French and German levels - be better? It is not a question Gordon Brown is going to answer this week when, despite the size and shape of his rabbit having been plain for a long while, the prestidigitator of the public finances performs.
fields.body:
A mystery at the heart of the third way is how much a progressive, fairness-minded government should actually be spending. Is the UK's 39.5% of GDP the right amount; would 10% more - pushing us up to French and German levels - be better? It is not a question Gordon Brown is going to answer this week when, despite the size and shape of his rabbit having been plain for a long while, the prestidigitator of the public finances performs.

On present evidence, Labour is wedded to 40% as a kind of norm. If the economy continues broadly on track, by 2005 public spending will have risen to only 40.5% of GDP, which is still less than in John Major's last year. Edging it up in a continental direction would be, says Peter Robinson of the Institute for Public Policy Research "a perfectly feasible option". Provided taxes rose to pay for it. And that is one explanation for the arbitrary limit with which the Blair government works - closure on the fiscal front.

There is another, troubling reason. Government is not sure what effect public spending has. Interest groups clamour for it, for tanks or prisons, but their effect is not exactly uncontroversial. Relating given levels of spending with "big picture" questions such as prosperity, wellbeing or even, God forbid, public happiness is so difficult it is rarely attempted.

But Gordon Brown dresses to the left. His acolytes like to present him as the least neo of Labour's neo-socialists. They expect the chancellor's spending plans to address inequality - there are signs it has continued growing under Labour. So he shall. Education spending, tipped to rise at the same rate as health, is now accepted as the most direct if the most long-term way of addressing social exclusion and low income. In a new book the Nobel prize-winning economic historian Robert Fogel says whatever else governments do or don't do, they must bump the share of GDP spent on schooling up to unprecedented levels, from about 7% to 12% of GDP*.

But Gordon Brown will also be judged in the short term. Will his tenure leave the distribution of income fairer? A key indicator this week will be what the Treasury allows for spending by the Home Office, Department of Trade and so on and what it projects for social security, disability and pensions. This is the difference between increases under departmental spending limits and "annually managed expenditure". On present evidence the former will get 4.7% a year in real terms over the planning period 2001-2004 against 1.7% for welfare.

Such figures may look ideologically suspect for a would-be egalitarian but they do accord with an emerging Anglo-Saxon consensus about big government. It is the argument made by American academics that the best explanation for declining public trust in the state has to do with the dramatic growth in what are called transfer payments. The chart shows how significant an element in state activity welfare cash has become. In the UK total spending has fallen from the watershed of the mid-70s - Peter Shore turns out to have been right in saying the party was over - but transfers have risen. They have been financed, notes Carl Emmerson of the Institute for Fiscal Studies, by large decreases in investment spending by the state. That has resulted partly from privatisation but also the large reduction in council house building. But (the Americans argue) the more government redistributes the more it generates winners and losers. Everyone benefits from spending on hospitals or roads. But payments to pensioners or asylum seekers are perceived as looting one person's pocket to fill another's, and resented.

Gordon Brown's question (though he is unlikely to pose it) is whether such transfer spending "works". Does big government make for a fairer society? Economists of an Anglo-American stamp, the kind whose thinking informs the analyses of the OECD, are dubious. Vito Tanzi and Ludger Schuknecht* have collected together a great array of measures of the effectiveness of public spending across the western world, noting how it has been since 1960 that public spending has anywhere risen from its previous maximum of about a third of GDP.

The growth area has been welfare transfers, which rose from an average of 5% of GDP in the 30s - when the means test was mean - to 23% now. This constitutes excessive "churning", they say: government taking from and giving to broadly the same people. These economists tend to a narrow view of government purposes and probably miss the ways in which state spending can provide a frame and inspiration for civil society and private economy.

None the less it is hard to reject their empirical finding that big-spending governments turn out to be not much more successful than small ones in counteracting inequality. That is because even in social democratic Scandinavia, transfers end up in the pockets of people who already have considerable resources. Across the west, in the mid-80s 57% of transfers went to the middle 60% of the income distribution, 16% to top fifth and only 27% to the bottom fifth. Sweden is a more egalitarian society than the United States, yes, but not by the margin you might think.

Gordon Brown will say his new public service agreements target spending better. But he is unlikely to offer a reason for why this total of spending, no more, no less.

*The Fourth Great Awakening by Robert Fogel, University of Chicago Press.

*Vito Tanzi, Ludger Schuknecht: Public Spending in the 20th Century, CUP £13.95 (pub August 24).

fields.headline: Winsor sets inspectors on Railtrack
fields.standfirst:
Transport in Britain: special report
More about transport
fields.trailText: Railtrack will have to accept constant and rigorous inspection before the rail regulator, Tom Winsor, agrees to increase its access charges from a figure of more than £2bn to a full £3bn a year over the five years beginning in 2001.
fields.body:
Railtrack will have to accept constant and rigorous inspection before the rail regulator, Tom Winsor, agrees to increase its access charges from a figure of more than £2bn to a full £3bn a year over the five years beginning in 2001.

Industry sources confirmed last night that a team from the regulator's office will be sent in to Railtrack to ensure that the money is being applied correctly.

If it is not, the privatised monopoly will be instructed to change its methods. Railtrack will have to pay for the inspections.

Mr Winsor is expected to tell Railtrack's chief executive, Gerald Corbett, that he wants to see efficiency gains of 3-5% over the period, to give value to passengers.

The regulator is allowed to review the company's charges only once every five years and this is the first opportunity he has had to tackle the issue since taking over the job a year ago.

Mr Winsor is known to be angry that in the first five years since privatisation of the system, Railtrack's stewardship of the infrastructure has been generally poor.

Mr Winsor will insist that Railtrack improve its act. His review is likely to suggest that he is anxious for Railtrack to succeed and that he wants a tough but fair delivery, particularly as the company will get more money.

Railtrack's infrastructure improvements, costing about £12bn over the past five years got off to a slow start. The company blamed the move from state control to privatisation for its problems and will be spending £2.5bn this year, although a large portion of this is on the first section of the Channel tunnel rail link.

Railtrack will have to set out a financial framework on how it will carry out the plan, but it will be left to choose its priorities.

It recoups its money from investment by charging the 25 train operating companies for using the track. An increase in access charges could be passed on in higher fares to the consumer, and it will up to the shadow strategic rail authority to make sure that they are properly regulated.

Railtrack has warned the regulator that just to sustain the network over the next five years means that it must spend about £1.3 bn a year more than is allowed for in its current charges.

It says: "Unless the regulator reflects this in his review, the company will be put under such financial pressure that it will have severe implications for the rail investment programme."

It says it was funded to deliver a no growth railway, with no specific quality targets. It claims that delivering a better railway has cost it £2bn more on renewals than when the regulator first set his access charges five years ago.

It said last night: "We hope that Mr Winsor will recognise the impact of traffic growth and service improvements of almost 30%. We believe that they should encourage him to adopt more realistic assumptions about potential efficiency savings.

"The regulator should take account of the substantial risks associated with complex construction projects and allow us a rate of return on enhancement investment which properly reflects those risks."

Railtrack is facing up to the threat of competition from other contractors who could bid for the Railtrack's own work. This would place Railtrack in a difficult financial situation. By the end of the year its debt will be almost £3bn.

The regulator is also getting ready to reduce Railtrack's escalating costs for the £5.8bn improvements to the west coast main line between London and Glasgow. He says they are excessive and has cut them by about £1bn.

Railtrack suddenly doubled the cost without warning earlier this year, in a move which infuriated ministers. Mr Winsor is to add to Railtrack's problems by insisting that the project must still be completed by 2005.

In a call for more money for the rail system, the Engineering Employers' Federation notes that spends only 1% of GDP on transport, compared with Germany's 2% and the 2.4% of Italy.

fields.headline: Alastair and me
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: When the prime minister's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, announced that he was letting the cameras in for me to film behind the scenes, one veteran political editor gave me a gypsy's warning: "These people can be very seductive, Michael. Beware the stocking tops of power."
fields.body:
When the prime minister's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, announced that he was letting the cameras in for me to film behind the scenes, one veteran political editor gave me a gypsy's warning: "These people can be very seductive, Michael. Beware the stocking tops of power."

It was a phrase that rang through my head. There was a clear danger that all my producer Alison Cahn and I would see was everyone on best behaviour. And leaked early memos from Anji Hunter, Blair's assistant, now suggest that was exactly how it started off.

But we weren't naifs entering the Downing Street jungle. I'd been making political films for 25 years and have written two books about prime ministers and the media. Anything we filmed that didn't have the ring of truth or we felt was put on for or affected by the cameras was consigned for horizontal filing. Campbell had no rights over the film nor did he ask for any.

And over four months we just went on filming and filming inside Number 10. If you have access, you see things that by definition you can't if you are waiting on the other side of the famous black door. People get used to you and get on with the business they have to do. Campbell himself was apparently oblivious to our camera which caught him suggesting to a BBC journalist that he change the subject at a Blair press conference. He could not know in advance what journalists would ask him at the twice daily lobby briefings. And sometimes he would emerge the worse for wear.

Some suggest it was a sanitised version of Campbell we saw. But most accepted we captured the genuine feel of the briefings, which could be bruising encounters where Campbell's contempt for much of the press would be on display. It was true that he didn't swear - but he never did when the cameras weren't there.

He did not deny that he sometimes swore in what he called "the margins of the lobby" - coming in and going out - and there are well documented instances of the ripeness of his language to journalists on the telephone. But the worst instance of bad language in the briefings themselves any journalists could come up with was when he once famously said: "That's crap, spelled C-R-A-P."

There was much speculation in the lobby about why Campbell agreed to the film. Some supposed it was his vanity, others that he could control me and others that he was preparing some kind of exit strategy and sees this as a good job application.

I think he agreed to do it because he felt the government would gain from a film that looked objectively at the state of relations between Number 10 and the media. In a section of interview not in the film, he said: "We fulfil a basic, necessary and legitimate function... But the press, hand-in-hand with the Conservatives, say it's all just spin. It is all part of the strategy to say you can't trust the prime minister."

No previous press secretary has ever been on terms of such intimacy and near equality with his prime minister. Consider: they are roughly the same age, and come from the same background: provincial, professional middleclass (Campbell is the son of a vet). Their children are of an age and play together and their partners are best friends. Cherie Blair's special assistant is Campbell's partner, the journalist Fiona Miller. There is also the fact as Professor Peter Hennessy puts it: "Alastair's greatest attribute is that he can say 'bollocks' to the PM and it is to Blair's credit that he has someone like that around him."

The danger for all prime ministers is that they become surrounded with sycophants, courtiers or people who tell them what they want to hear. Campbell is not like that. He is capable of interrupting Blair in mid-sentence to tell the accompanying journalists that they will miss their train if they do not leave immediately, and of making wry remarks on camera to Blair about his performance. Blair in turn calls Campbell "the best in the business" and has high regard for his presentational skills.

But what neither could have bargained for when they agreed last February to us making the film was that Campbell's role and the question of spin would become so much a central part of the story. As to what the PM and his press secretary think of the programme, the only clues I have come from journalists who tell me they've had their cards marked: the line was that Campbell was "quite relaxed" about the film, but that it had failed from Number 10's point of view to show quite how "corrosively cynical" journalists had become about this government. My head is still spinning about that piece of spin.

Michael Cockerell's News from No 10 was shown on BBC2 on Saturday

Some suggest it was a sanitised version of Campbell we saw. But most accepted we captured the genuine feel of the briefings, which could be bruising encounters where Campbell's contempt for much of the press would be on display. It was true that he didn't swear - but he never did when the cameras weren't there. He did not deny that he sometimes swore in what he called "the margins of the lobby" - coming in and going out - and there are well documented instances of the ripeness of his language to journalists on the telephone. But the worst instance of bad language in the briefings themselves any journalists could come up with was when he once famously said: "That's crap, spelled C-R-A-P." There was much speculation in the lobby about why Campbell agreed to the film. Some supposed it was his vanity, others that he could control me and others that he was preparing some kind of exit strategy and sees this as a good job application. I think he agreed to do it because he felt the government would gain from a film that looked objectively at the state of relations between Number 10 and the media. In a section of interview not in the film, he said: "We fulfil a basic, necessary and legitimate function... But the press, hand-in-hand with the Conservatives, say it's all just spin. It is all part of the strategy to say you can't trust the prime minister." No previous press secretary has ever been on terms of such intimacy and near equality with his prime minister. Consider: they are roughly the same age, and come from the same background: provincial, professional middleclass (Campbell is the son of a vet). Their children are of an age and play together and their partners are best friends. Cherie Blair's special assistant is Campbell's partner, the journalist Fiona Miller. There is also the fact as Professor Peter Hennessy puts it: "Alastair's greatest attribute is that he can say 'bollocks' to the PM and it is to Blair's credit that he has someone like that around him." The danger for all prime ministers is that they become surrounded with sycophants, courtiers or people who tell them what they want to hear. Campbell is not like that. He is capable of interrupting Blair in mid-sentence to tell the accompanying journalists that they will miss their train if they do not leave immediately, and of making wry remarks on camera to Blair about his performance. Blair in turn calls Campbell "the best in the business" and has high regard for his presentational skills. But what neither could have bargained for when they agreed last February to us making the film was that Campbell's role and the question of spin would become so much a central part of the story. As to what the PM and his press secretary think of the programme, the only clues I have come from journalists who tell me they've had their cards marked: the line was that Campbell was "quite relaxed" about the film, but that it had failed from Number 10's point of view to show quite how "corrosively cynical" journalists had become about this government. My head is still spinning about that piece of spin. Michael Cockerell's News from No 10 was shown on BBC2 on Saturday

webTitle: Who will get what in Brown's giveaway?

fields.headline: Who will get what in Brown's giveaway?
fields.standfirst: Economic strength and a cautious approach to public spending mean the chancellor will give a £40bn boost to Labour's election chances in his spending review tomorrow. Guardian writers examine what it will mean for Britain and consider the key areas that are likely to benefit Comprehensive Spending Review 2000: Special Report
fields.trailText: Economic strength and a cautious approach to public spending mean the chancellor will give a £40bn boost to Labour's election chances in his spending review tomorrow. Guardian writers examine what it will mean for Britain and consider the key areas that are likely to benefit
fields.body:
The economy

In overall terms, spending will increase by 3.3% a year, with current spending on items such as pay rising by 2.5% a year and capital investment doubling to 1.8% of gross domestic product.

By the end of the three-year spending programme in 2003/04, departmental spending will be more than £40bn higher. Extra spending of 5.6% a year for health was announced in the Budget, and it is anticipated that education will receive an increase of a similar size tomorrow. Transport will be the major beneficiary of the rise in capital spending.

Two obvious questions arise: can the increases be afforded; and which parts of spending will be squeezed to allow for the big increases in health and education?

Provided the economy stays healthy, the spending plans will be funded by running down the budget surplus amassed by the government since it came to power.

Health and education can receive increases of more than 3.3% a year because spending on other items, such as interest payments on the national debt and unemployment benefits, are coming down.

Larry Elliott

Education

After a troubled week the spending review should put a smile back on the face of David Blunkett.

Education will be the big winner of the review, with increases in spending likely to be around the same as health, around £180 per pupil this year, and more than £500 over three years - £300 in real terms.

Tony Blair signalled the government's intentions last week when he told the Commons: "The priorities remain education, education, education; and our response will be investment, investment, investment - guaranteed."

After concentrating on primary schools for the first part of the parliament, the focus will shift towards secondary education, with big cash injections for city comprehensives in poorer areas.

Mr Blunkett and Gordon Brown noted the popularity of the extra £300m devolved to head teachers to spend as they wanted in the last Budget, and will want to repeat something similar this time. There will be not so much emphasis on "money with strings" for school budgets, though this remains the policy when it comes to increasing teachers' pay.

He will announce that performance-related pay is to be extended, in a form yet to be determined after the courts barred the current system, to sixth form and further education colleges.

The education secretary has resisted pressure to set higher targets for test results at key stage two at age 11, and will not go down that route for tests at seven and 14 either.

But his plan to eventually separate school and local education authority budgets may be one for the next manifesto.

Will Woodward

Crime

Jack Straw is under pressure on three fronts. By the election he needs to be able to prove that police numbers are rising to a higher figure than he inherited from the Conservatives.

It is a difficult task since the Home Office cannot direct police forces to recruit, but merely ring-fence cash from which the constabularies can make bids for extra officers. In 1992 there was one officer per 414 population in England and Wales. Latest statistics show this figure has risen to 426.

Mr Straw would like to see figures for violent crime reduced, but this may require extra spending on prisons.

Violent crime, detested by the public, is expected to show a 4% increase when the latest statistics are published tomorrow.

He will also need to do more to fight drugs, the motor for much inner-city crime. He has agreed that the relatively successful pilots for his drug treatment and testing orders will be extended nationwide in the autumn, but this will be expensive and require more drug referral units and more spending.

The work of the Home Office has also been at the centre of five of the 15 cross-departmental reviews in the spending review. Mr Straw will be announcing measures to improve performance management and target setting within criminal justice.

Patrick Wintour

Transport

An £80bn plan to take transport through the next decade is expected to be unveiled by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, later this week.

But Whitehall insiders last night described the operation as being "something akin to a smoke and mirrors exercise" with little attention paid to detail.

Mr Prescott first promised the plan as long ago as December, since when the figures have been manipulated by Whitehall so as to promise more than will be delivered.

Under the plan the government will be expecting to invest £4bn a year, with an equal amount expected to be coming from the private sector.

The first positive move by Mr Prescott will be the announcement of £330m expenditure on a train protection warning system for the railways. This had been earmarked, but will begin to be installed by Railtrack from next month as a direct result of the Paddington crash last year.

The government is also likely to underpin the escalating cost of renewing the West Coast mainline between London and Glasgow because it is an infrastructure project.

In the first few years there will be more bypasses and light rail systems, but no large investment in road building. Motorists can expect to see immediate work on removing key bottlenecks.

Ministers are likely to face criticism for producing a plan that is light on detail, but they will defend this by saying that it takes years to make transport changes.

Keith Harper

Health

A four-year package of increases in spending on the NHS was announced in the March budget and there is not expected to be any topping up this week. Over the four years from 2000/1 to 2003/4 the real terms rise in health spending will be 6.1% - the largest sustained growth on record, and double the historic trend since the NHS was founded in 1948.

Health ministers are avoiding translating this into cash totals, for fear of a lack of credibility after the over-hyping of past amounts. In March the chancellor talked of £21bn to increase the health budget over four years by 50% in cash terms and 33% in real terms. Since the increases were front-loaded to ease the crisis of NHS underfunding, the real growth over the coming three years will be 5.6%.

Details of how this will be spent are to be announced next week on the publication of the national plan for health in England, including proposals for cutting waiting times and breaking down boundaries between the work of doctors, nurses and other health care staff. Ministers believe their main constraint is shortages of trained staff rather than money. Although there will have to be campaigns to recruit specialist doctors from abroad, the seven-year programme to train doctors within the NHS cannot be accelerated.

This week's spending review will also provide extra resources for social care including that of the elderly in residential homes.

John Carvel

webTitle: Site opens window on industrial traditions

fields.headline: Site opens window on industrial traditions
fields.standfirst: The Museum of Science and Industry in Manchester reveals its new look today, with the accent on public access to its collections
fields.trailText: The Museum of Science and Industry in Manchester reveals its new look today, with the accent on public access to its collections
fields.body:
One of the most successful and popular museums in the north-west unveils its dramatic new look today after years of planning.

Modern glass and steel edifices have been added to former railway buildings which date back to the 1830s and now form the Museum of Science and Industry in Manchester. Work began on the final phase of development in March 1999 after the museum secured £8.8m from the Heritage Lottery Fund and the European Regional Development Fund.

As part of the project a collections centre has been completed, which is due to open next year. It aims to improve visitors' access to the collections and ensure exhibits are better managed.

The glass-fronted entrance and reception area has a large metal sphere and cone sculpture outside; it symbolises the museum and forms part of its logo.

There is also a new shop and Warehouse for the World - an evocative sound and light show. As visitors enter the museum, television screens show them what they can expect to see.

The culture secretary, Chris Smith, and the chairman of the Heritage Lottery Fund, Eric Anderson, will visit Castlefields today.

Patrick Greene, director of the museum, said the launch was the culmination of two decades of work. "The process of rescue, repair and adaption of five major historic buildings has been a painstaking one," he said. "This project could not have been undertaken without the enormous support from the Department of Culture, Media and Sport and the Heritage Lottery Fund.

"They have enabled us to achieve in the last four years what we thought it would have taken at least 15 years to achieve at the present rate of fundraising. It has made a difference in that the museum is now more accessible to people and it is a real place for people who live in this city to visit." He said it was a thrill to see a process which started almost two decades ago come to fruition.

Dr Greene believes the Museum of Science and Industry is now one of the top six science museums in the world.

Last year it attracted 364,000 visitors, making it one of the top 10 pay for entry museums in Britain. "It is the first time we have been in the top 10," Dr Greene said. "Although we have been in the top 20 for a few years now. We want to make the experience of coming to our museum habit forming."

Visitors come from all over the world and the museum is also popular with school parties across the north-west. The average visitor spends four hours there.

The museum is made up of five former railway buildings linked on a seven acre site which used to house the world's first passenger railway station.

The platform is still there and from next spring trains will operate along a short track.

As part of the extension, the museum's cramped restaurant has been replaced by a huge open-plan contemporary structure which can accommodate 200 people. It was officially opened in February by Loyd Grossman, who is one of the museum's trustees.

Dr Greene believes the modern restaurant with its wooden floors blends in well with the historic buildings.

Next to the restaurant, a dramatic glass lift and staircase tower have been installed at the end of the main building. It boasts panoramic views of Manchester and Old Trafford, the home of Manchester United football club.

Former railway warehouses, which until 18 months ago were semi-derelict, have been completely refurbished.

The new buildings have been designed by architects from the north-west and they will make the museum's reserve collections more accessible to the public, who will be able to see what is going on behind the scenes through large glass windows.

When new objects enter the museum they will be photographed and catalogued in full view of the visitors. Dr Greene said the idea was that visitors could window shop behind the scenes.

A rusty old motorbike from 1924 manufactured by Manchester-based Dot (Devoid of trouble) was being catalogued and restored in one of the new buildings. It is a painstaking process which will probably take several months to complete.

A warehouse from 1830, the oldest railway building in the world, has been transformed into an audiovisual centre. A film aims to give visitors a snapshot of life in the 19th century in the industrial city. It includes a haunting and ironic song, Manchester's Improving Daily, with lyrics about the air being too thick to breathe.

The building was restored in 1996 but has been fitted out with money from the lottery grant with a modern reception area and the Futures exhibition on the third floor. The exhibition celebrates how new technology has changed lives and boosted industry in Manchester.

But there is still work to be done. Over the next few years, new galleries will be created once funding is available.

Dr Greene said: "When I first came here 17 years ago we had just 12 staff and lots of empty semi-derelict buildings. Now we have got 112 staff and we just keep moving forward."

fields.headline: Efficiency is not enough
fields.standfirst: Comprehensive Spending Review 2000: Special Report
fields.trailText: As the chancellor often reminds us, prudence and stability are a key feature of the success of the economy. After decades of boom and bust, this is no mean achievement.
fields.body:
As the chancellor often reminds us, prudence and stability are a key feature of the success of the economy. After decades of boom and bust, this is no mean achievement.

Yet, in another of the chancellor's favourite topics, productivity in manufacturing, the issue of boom and bust remains. Given the need for sustained improvements in productivity just to stay in the world economic race, the volatility of our performance in this respect is critical to our competitive future.

Tomorrow's comprehensive spending review and the next Budget following this will play a critical role in whether manufacturing sees a sustained improvement in productivity.

Over the last decade, productivity changes in manufacturing have been through four distinct phases. It started the decade by jogging along at just over 2.5%. A world recession and an overvalued pound spurred companies into action, growing by 5% and upwards for three years. However, in the four years from 1995, it collapsed, recording no improvement at all in output per employee. Only in 1999 did the productivity beast stir again with an annual improvement of 3.6% and much faster increases in the second half of the year.

To football fans, this seems like the form of a perennial relegation struggler. A season of dismal performances ends with an upturn that is just enough to save the team from the drop. The team reverts to mediocrity once the danger is passed. In most cases, the trap door of relegation usually opens for a team that has regularly flirted with it.

This is the danger for manufacturing. Regular improvements are needed to survive in an increasingly competitive world. The growth of e-business makes it much easier for customers to demand significant and sustained reductions in costs. Becoming more efficient by cutting costs, reducing faults and speeding delivery times will be the bare minimum needed just to stay in the supply chain.

Greater efficiency is unlikely to be enough. The growth of e-business offers tremendous opportunities. More profitable opportunities lie in developing new products with a high design content, increasingly customised to the needs of the individual customer.

For now, higher skill levels, deeper capital markets and a sophisticated and prosperous customer base give Britain and other mature economies an advantage over lower cost rivals elsewhere in the world. Yet this edge will soon be worn away without investment.

With export margins at a 25-year low, the cash available for investment is limited. The conservative attitude of lenders has not helped, with shorter pay-back periods and high rates of return required for investment to go ahead.

The government can help this process by improving the productive capacity of the economy through a greater emphasis on investment in education and the transport infrastructure, a process it can begin with its spending plans for the next three years, rather than unnecessary cuts in taxation. In addition, it could look at extending 100% first year capital allowances from computers to all machinery and equipment which currently only gets 40%.

Analysis by Oxford Economic Forecasting for the Engineering Employers' Federation and other traded sectors suggests that capital allowances can have a significant benefit for manufacturing investment and economic growth. It should also look at the feasibility of extending tax credits for research and development along the lines of the scheme in the US. The government could also learn from the US in its approach to flexibility of regulation.

A final way government can help industry is to put a stop to another element of "boom and bust" - the careers of ministers at the Department of Trade and Industry. Three secretaries of state in three years means the revolving-door policy of the Conservatives is being continued. Some of the chancellor's much-lauded stability would be welcome here.

Stephen Radley is chief economist at the Engineering Employers' Federation

webTitle: Mowlam wants to see Livingstone back in Labour party fold

fields.headline: Mowlam wants to see Livingstone back in Labour party fold
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Mo Mowlam, the Cabinet Office minister, courted further controversy yesterday by saying Ken Livingstone should be allowed to rejoin the Labour party.
fields.body:
Mo Mowlam, the Cabinet Office minister, courted further controversy yesterday by saying Ken Livingstone should be allowed to rejoin the Labour party.

Deputy leader John Prescott and party officials have repeatedly said Mr Livingstone must remain expelled for at least five years as punishment for standing against the official Labour candidate Frank Dobson in the London mayoral elections in May. A campaign to win Mr Livingstone's reinstatement is being mounted by leftwingers with the aim of winning support at the party conference in the autumn.

Ms Mowlam, speaking on Breakfast with Frost, said she was not sure about the timescale, but went on: "I'd like to see him back. I think it was very unfortunate he left. I did not support that at all and I think Frank Dobson fought a good battle for us, but I'm a believer in inclusivity, people ought to be in rather than out".

In the first sign of a rapprochement with ministers, Mr Livingstone is understood to have shelved plans to use the courts, if necessary, to fight the partial privatisation of London Underground.

He has also agreed to hold a joint press conference with the London transport minister Keith Hill this week to announce the impact of the spending review on London Transport. Ministers are preparing to announce an extra £3bn over the next three years, much of which will be spent on improving London's buses.

Mr Livingstone is not dropping his opposition to partial privatisation of the tube, and still favours the government raising the cash through bonds, an idea being investigated further for Mr Livingstone by a team led by Will Hutton, former Observer editor.

fields.headline: Unspun hero
fields.standfirst:
Another week, another Clare Short 'gaffe'. This time she has described the Catholic church as 'stuck and wrong'. But in a world uneasy with spin, could she be the perfect politician?

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Another week, another Clare Short 'gaffe'. This time she has described the Catholic church as 'stuck and wrong'. But in a world uneasy with spin, could she be the perfect politician?
fields.body:
Clare Short, the secretary of state for international development, used to have a Great Dane called Fred ("so he didn't get any illusions of grandeur"), but he died and wasn't replaced. She's trying to persuade her mother to have a dog now, a spaniel perhaps, that Short would walk when she goes home to Birmingham at weekends - but she won't "because of what it would do in the garden". Short looks mournful when she tells me this.

"Dogs are nice," she says, "and they teach you how you should be with your friends. They always love you unconditionally. You shout at them and two minutes later they love you again and therefore you love them. And if human beings were like that to each other we'd all be a lot happier."

Clare Short is, you might say, the Fred of the Labour party, always being shouted at, always bounding back. Everyone waits for "the Clare Gaffe", the blowing of the Short fuse; anticipates the rebuke, the tap on the nose; then smiles happily when there seem to be no hard feelings all round. Take her past advocation of higher tax "for people like me" or her attack on Blair's "men in the dark", or last week's comments on the Catholic church's opposition to contraception ("stuck and wrong", "just another burden" in the fight against Aids). Hardly had an hour gone by before the prime minister's office issued a statement distancing itself from Short's "personal" views: "Blair chides Short" read the headlines. But then it all seemed to end as quickly as it began. "There is absolutely no difference between me and Tony Blair on HIV/Aids," Short tells me doggedly, "and there was no rebuke."

We meet in her office in Victoria where a secretary carries around an "out of order" sign to secure the lift in case Short needs it. It's a tatty building, as it should be when your brief is to help the poorest of the poor, but Short seems on top of the world here, striding down the long corridors in her swishy black trousers and heels, two steps ahead of her aides, queen of all she surveys. She is full of beans, says there is nothing she could be doing that was "more important, more needy... more noble. Don't tell the others," she adds with a laugh, "but this is definitely the best job in government." At the suggestion, though, that it was canny of the prime minister to have given it to her, to have funnelled her passions and convictions in that direction, she is suddenly quite crisp. "What I resist," she says, "is that I'm the sort of person only this would do for. I've had that all my life. It's partly to do with being a woman, it's partly to do with really believing what I believe in. People think that means you haven't got a good brain - a woman who feels passionately presumably doesn't do all the analysis."

She is a big woman in the flesh, an elegant 54 with long legs and a broad chest. The cheekbones on her face with its Aztec features and ruddy complexion are so high they bump her eyes. She is much grander than you expect, majestic even. She is strident, wonderfully articulate, on the subjects of globalisation and international investment agreements, on the increase of literacy, the decrease of mortality. Only when she gives a throaty guffaw and kicks off her shoes do you realise she's wearing pop socks. Only when she relaxes, when she's talking about dogs and family, do you really notice the Birmingham accent.

In a world uneasy with spin, Short is a still point, a haven in a storm. She might even, in the current climate, be the perfect politician. "I'm not sure that all my colleagues would agree," she says at that. "To be honest I never could talk the soundbites. I just can't bear it. It offends me intellectually." She thinks in retrospect that spin may have been justified in 1997 -"If standing on our heads and waggling our toes in the air would have made us win we'd all have done it" - but that they should have been more confident earlier. "I think the country is in tune with our real values and we could have been more straight about what we're doing." Only the press, she believes, is "is still obsessed with spin over substance", driven - last week being a case in point - by "the need to report drama and clashes". She has often had a bad time in the papers, "when you're ripped apart in front of all those people who don't know you," most notably during her campaign against page three girls.

"If I had known the price you pay in media terms and all that personal stuff I don't think I would have had the courage to [go into politics] at all," she says.

She finds the House of Commons can be "very silly". People no longer snigger when cervical cancer is mentioned as they did when she first became MP for Birmingham Ladywood in 1983, but prime minister's question time is a trial.

"Once a month Tony comes on after me and I sit there and think, 'Good heavens!' Well, it's so... so schoolboyish. It is. It really is. And I think, 'God, I've got to keep a sensible face because people will think I'm frowning at what Tony's saying, and I'm not. I'm thinking, 'What a wallyish way of organising our country!'"

As for Blair's perceived phoniness: "I said to Alastair [Campbell], 'It's time you put Tony out on the media now.' People have begun to think he's so awful that if they see the real him they'll like him. He's a very different kind of character to me - well, he's a man - but there is a large part of him that is completely genuine and absolutely straight. People just need to hear him being practical and informed and just knowing what he's doing."

She believes in openness and she has always talked about the big things in her personal life. She gave extremely moving interviews about the death from Alzheimer's in 1993 of her husband, the former Labour minister Alex Lyon. And she was very careful three years later to manage, in media terms, the reunion with Toby, the son she gave up for adoption when she was 18, and who had contacted her when he was a 31-year-old solicitor with Tory leanings.

Even now she has firmly prepared things to say about it. She says she has to be careful, for both their sakes. "I've always been a kind of optimist and I've always liked people but since I've got Toby back it's like a completion of my fundamental happiness. I always had a bit of pain in me and that's healed, so I'm happier than I probably deserve to be. You know, profoundly in a way. And he's completely gorgeous - I love him to bits."

But if you ask her more questions she does start to falter a little. When I wondered if she regretted that Toby had never met Alex, she says, "I haven't, you see, because then I wish . . . or you know you go back and unwish all the bad things ... Obviously I wish he wasn't adopted so I don't sort of allow myself that game because it's you know..." And then she suddenly growls, "But I waited for him. Eighteen, and I thought, 'Right, where are you?' It was quite hard that he didn't come forward then." And when I ask how much she thought about him all those years (she and Lyon never had children) she just sort of makes some noises: "Um. Er-ha. Ohhh. When I saw people with little boys in their arms... Er, again strongly. Er." And then, pulling herself together again, she goes to get me a glass of water.

When she comes back she says, "There are probably a lot of people in politics who have a tough time but they hide it all because politicians pretend they're perfect. And of course we know that life's more turbulent than that, and often people who have been through things understand deeply when someone else is hurting. The evidence seems to be that people like to know the truth and actually feel more trust in you if you have feet of clay like everybody else."

One of her assistants pops his head round the corner then and reminds her that she has "a meeting about the UN" to go to. Short says, "I go back to Birmingham on Thursdays. Everybody knows me there. I don't have to be ... da da da da. And you need that. You know, having a car waiting for you and people organising your life, it could give you illusions of grandeur. You need to be an ordinary person in your ordinary place." And then she puts her shoe back on. Even as she does so someone is probably already scurrying down the corridor with the "out of order" sign to block the lift.

webTitle: Byers to back risk ventures at expense of declining industries

fields.headline: Byers to back risk ventures at expense of declining industries
fields.standfirst: Comprehensive Spending Review 2000: Special Report
fields.trailText: Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, is to signal a further shift in his department's policy towards funding innovative small businesses in the new economy and away from providing aid for declining industries in the wake of tomorrow's comprehensive spending review.
fields.body:
Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, is to signal a further shift in his department's policy towards funding innovative small businesses in the new economy and away from providing aid for declining industries in the wake of tomorrow's comprehensive spending review.

In his Commons statement on the government's three-year spending plans the chancellor, Gordon Brown, will earmark several hundred million pounds to encourage risk ventures throughout Britain's regions and to convert technological breakthroughs made by scientists in the country's universities into commercial products.

But Mr Byers is expected to seize on this and set out a clearer, more defined role for the modern department of trade and industry in two keynote speeches early next month than the confused mixture of often conflicting policies from which it has suffered since its inception.

The policy shift, first adumbrated by his predecessor, Peter Mandelson, has been prompted by the initial debacle over BMW's abrupt decision to pull out of Rover, the car group, and questions this has raised about the role of government in the global economy.

The government will tomorrow announce a tenfold increase in funding for regional development agencies to encourage innovation and enterprise among small businesses.

The £150m over the next three years, coming on top of the £35m set out in the Budget to promote "clusters" of hi-tech firms in specific areas such as Cambridge, is designed to support the development of sectoral networks, incubators, innovation centres and technology parks for small businesses.

A further £180m will be added to the £85m already set aside for the government's small business service to provide seed venture capital for new economy firms. Of that, £70m will go to the Phoenix fund meant to encourage risky but innovative enterprises in areas of the country hit by structural decline and normally shunned by the banks. "It's right that all regions benefit from the stable economy built by the chancellor," Mr Byers' aides said.

Britain's scientific community will also gain a further £110m on top of the £1bn an nounced by Mr Brown last week. This extra funding is designed to develop links between business and universities and includes £80m for the university innovation fund to promote academics as entrepreneurs.

Fifteen million pounds will go to the science enterprise challenge, a scheme to encourage post-graduates to set up in business, and £10m to converting discoveries made within publicly funded research programmes into commercial products or processes.

Under Mr Byers, the DTI has become aggressively pro-consumer, mounting campaigns to force price-cuts in supermarkets and cars, but has also been forced to intervene on behalf of the coal and shipbuilding industries and to set aside £138m to help regenerate the West Midlands after the threat to close the Longbridge car plant.

The trade and industry secretary believes some state aid for "old" industries should continue in the absence of an agreed EU stance.

webTitle: Blunkett pledges to record income from home rental

fields.headline: Blunkett pledges to record income from home rental
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: David Blunkett yesterday pledged in future to record rental income from his London home in Westminster's register of members' interests, after it was disclosed he failed to register that he was letting it for £700 a month.
fields.body:
David Blunkett yesterday pledged in future to record rental income from his London home in Westminster's register of members' interests, after it was disclosed he failed to register that he was letting it for £700 a month.

The education secretary has been renting out the house in Wimbledon, south-west London, since earlier this year, after moving into a rent-free government-owned flat in Belgravia, central London.

The Sunday Telegraph reported that the house, which was formerly Mr Blunkett's personal residence, had been rented out to a teacher.

Ministerial colleagues have registered their income from renting their homes, including Jack Straw, the home secretary, Margaret Beckett, leader of the Commons, and Chris Mullin, the environment minister.

Mr Blunkett said yesterday: "I have had this one-bedroomed home since 1987. I do not have to declare its letting, but in the interests of transparency I am more than happy to do so."

His spokesman said that, as Mr Blunkett had not yet received any income from the rental agreement, he had not thought it necessary to register the arrangement. He said: "This is Mr Blunkett's own home which he occupied from 1987 onwards. It remained empty for a period but was let by him earlier this year.

"As the early rent is still outstanding, and some weeks ago the tenant agreed to leave at the end of July, he believed that in the absence of ongoing income he did not have to reg ister the arrangement. This was especially so as any rent received had gone on refurbishment and restoration of the property.

"Any future rent income will be registered in order to avoid any accusations of a lack of transparency in the personal financial arrangements of the secretary of state, albeit that in these circumstances registration is optional."

The Commons rules of conduct for MPs state that members should declare any significant income from property not being used as their residence, but no threshold is set above which income must be declared. MPs on the standards and privileges committee last week proposed a threshold of 10% of the annual parliamentary salary of £48,371.

webTitle: Emin to clean up as bed goes to Saatchi

fields.headline: Emin to clean up as bed goes to Saatchi
fields.trailText: Tracey Emin, who made an art form out of displaying her dirty linen in public, looks like cleaning up. Charles Saatchi, Britain's foremost patron of the visual arts, is to pay £150,000 for her most notorious work, My Bed.
fields.body:
Tracey Emin, who made an art form out of displaying her dirty linen in public, looks like cleaning up. Charles Saatchi, Britain's foremost patron of the visual arts, is to pay £150,000 for her most notorious work, My Bed.

A reconstruction of Emin's unmade bed, with soiled sheets and surrounded by empty vodka bottles, cigarette packets and a condom, My Bed attracted praise and opprobrium when it was shortlisted for the Turner Prize last year.

Even by the standards of that never knowingly uncontroversial award, the bed caused a stir, raising Emin's profile to new heights and providing a vehicle for others to propel themselves into public view. Two Chinese performance artists gained publicity by leaping on to the mattress and staging a pillow fight before being separated by Tate Gallery security guards.

Mr Saatchi, who championed many of the young British artists (YBAs) who emerged in the mid-1990s, including Damien Hirst, said he was a late convert to Emin's work.

"I was very slow to get the loopiness of Tracey's work, but I'm a helpless fan now."

The Tate was initially interested in buying My Bed and opened negotiations with Emin's agent, Jay Joplin. Little progress was made, however, and Mr Saatchi stepped in last week.

As well as the bed, he has agreed to pay £75,000 for a beach hut built by Emin on the seafront in her home town of Margate.

Both works will go on show at the Saatchi Gallery in St John's Wood, north London, in September, in the Ant Noises 2 exhibition, sequel to the hugely successful 1997 Sensation exhibition at the Royal Academy that marked the YBA's arrival at the heart of the British art establishment. (Ant Noises is an anagram of sensation.)

The "loopiness" that attracted Mr Saatchi to Emin's work has ensured she has remained among the most famous artists in the country, despite being derided by some critics as lacking depth and talent.

Prior to My Bed, she provoked mild outrage with Everyone I Have Ever Slept With 1963-1995, a tent embroidered inside and out with the names of all her bed partners, which fetched £40,000.

Her challenging work was complemented by some memorable disappearances on television. In 1997 she stormed out of the Turner Prize dinner, and the following year she enlivened a live arts programme with a drunken, expletive-filled appearance.

In an interview with Tatler magazine, which appears next month, she insisted that she had grown up somewhat in the past 18 months, and now worked with a discipline absent from her previous work.

"She can drink, swear like a squaddie and is clearly brilliant at attracting publicity," said David Lee, former editor of Art Review. "It's visibility and controversy which gets the price up."

In which case Emin, 37, would appear to be an old master.

The "loopiness" that attracted Mr Saatchi to Emin's work has ensured she has remained among the most famous artists in the country, despite being derided by some critics as lacking depth and talent. Prior to My Bed, she provoked mild outrage with Everyone I Have Ever Slept With 1963-1995, a tent embroidered inside and out with the names of all her bed partners, which fetched £40,000. Her challenging work was complemented by some memorable disappearances on television. In 1997 she stormed out of the Turner Prize dinner, and the following year she enlivened a live arts programme with a drunken, expletive-filled appearance. In an interview with Tatler magazine, which appears next month, she insisted that she had grown up somewhat in the past 18 months, and now worked with a discipline absent from her previous work. "She can drink, swear like a squaddie and is clearly brilliant at attracting publicity," said David Lee, former editor of Art Review. "It's visibility and controversy which gets the price up." In which case Emin, 37, would appear to be an old master.

webTitle: Air traffic control sell-off may be grounded

fields.headline: Air traffic control sell-off may be grounded
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The government's £1bn plan to privatise Britain's air traffic control service (Nats) could be abandoned though lack of parliamentary time, government sources said last night.
fields.body:
The government's £1bn plan to privatise Britain's air traffic control service (Nats) could be abandoned though lack of parliamentary time, government sources said last night.

The plan, held up in parliament by the Commons and the Lords, is being brought back to the upper chamber in late September. Its delay runs the risk of wrecking the government's new transport legislation if it is not dealt with more swiftly.

The Lords remain even more hostile to the privatisation plan than the Commons, in spite of continuing backbench doubts among Labour MPs. Government managers said yesterday that as a last resort the plan could be resurrected in Labour's election manifesto.

Industry sources also confirmed yesterday that there would be little time for the government to rush through the sale before a May election and that it would get a low price.

The sources said that a quick sale would reduce the price of Nats by at least £200m and produce adverse public reaction similar to what happened when the Tories rushed through the privatisation of rail in the lead-up to the last election. After the Paddington rail crash, the expectation among some ministers was that the privatisation of air traffic control would be withdrawn because of public concern about safety.

The Treasury has made it clear to the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, that it no longer requires the money from the sale. But Mr Prescott appears to be firm in his belief that the plan is a sound one and will improve management by bringing in the private sector.

The plan will have to get royal assent by October or be dropped. One Whitehall source said yesterday that the government was unwilling to see the collapse of its railway and congestion charging legislation.

The government's plans were further complicated yesterday by an announcement from Nats that it has suspended a £53m contract to upgrade part of the air traffic system.
