webTitle: Hague's jibes are a spent force

fields.headline: Hague's jibes are a spent force
fields.standfirst: Comprehensive Spending Review 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair always said that this would be a Labour government like no other. And so it has proved. When Gordon Brown opens the doors to his sweetie shop tomorrow and hands out the goodies, the nation will see that Labour is the genuine article: a real tax-and-spend administration.
fields.body:
Tony Blair always said that this would be a Labour government like no other. And so it has proved. When Gordon Brown opens the doors to his sweetie shop tomorrow and hands out the goodies, the nation will see that Labour is the genuine article: a real tax-and-spend administration.

Confused? It is actually quite simple. Blair and Brown are different from Wilson and Callaghan in that they have taxed first and spent later. Previous Labour cabinets were spend-and-tax governments - they spent with abandon on arriving in office, then asked voters to pick up the tab as polling day approached. Hardly a winning formula.

In terms of staying in power, the Blair-Brown approach makes more sense. Taxes were increased sharply in Labour's first two years, and spending was even lower than it would have been under the Conservatives. The result has been a burgeoning budget surplus. When the Conservatives say Mr Brown will have to impose new tax increases to pay for his spending plans, they are wrong. Labour can increase spending by 3.3% a year, while the economy is growing by 2.5% by drawing down all the money Brown has been stashing away in the treasury's piggy bank.

To give credit where it is due, the government has handled the public finances in precisely the way it said it would while in opposition. But getting top marks for honesty does not mean that the approach has been cost free. Politically, it has suffered because the high expectations voters had for improvements to public services have not been met. Taking a tough line on spending was one thing; trying to pull the wool over our eyes with a bundle of inflated claims has merely fostered a cynicism that will result in the government receiving scant credit even when things start to get better.

Moreover, the figures from the Department of Social Security last week show that Labour's first two years in office saw an increase in the number of people living below the poverty line. The explanation is simple. The government allowed incomes at the top to rise very rapidly, while keeping a tight lid on incomes at the bottom by indexing benefits to inflation. Alistair Darling's attempt to play down the figures by saying that the number of people living in absolute poverty has fallen is casuistry of the highest order. Absolute poverty has fallen steadily since the industrial revolution, which is why yesterday's luxuries are today's necessities. When it was in opposition, Labour used to excoriate the Conservatives when there was an increase in the number of people living in households below half the national average income. If this yardstick was right then, it is right now.

False economy

The government's parsimony has also had economic costs, although these are less quantifiable. Capital investment in Britain's infrastructure is even lower under Labour than it was under the Conservatives, and this is particularly evident in transport, where spending is down by more than a third in real terms since the mid 90s. The private finance initiative has not papered over the cracks, although it has lined plenty of pockets. Ministers have told us constantly that the key to a successful modern economy is a well educated and highly skilled workforce, so why the delay giving David Blunkett the extra billions needed for schools?

It is now too late to cry over spilt milk. The government chose to hold back spending in its first two years and to concentrate on eradicating the fiscal deficit inherited from the Conservatives because its main priority was not tackling pensioner poverty or modernising schools, but convincing the financial markets Labour could manage the economy competently. Throughout, the chancellor would intone gravely that his prudence was for a purpose, and now, at last, Labour can start to act as a Labour government should.

Brown and his team argue that the sustained increases in health and education spending would not have been possible had Labour not first established its credentials, and they are right. The 1964-70 and 1974-79 governments were forced into deep cuts in public expenditure as the economic climate darkened. In retrospect, Brown's handling of public spending may look much smarter than, say, Robin Cook's much-vaunted ethical foreign policy, where the government's decision to sell arms to military dictatorships and cuddle up to big business has made the boasts of those first few heady days look utterly hollow.

Amid the justifiable claims that Labour has been forced to the right by William Hague's populism, the economy is one area where the government has moved the Conservatives to the left. Michael Portillo claimed yesterday that he would spend more on health and education than Brown. Last week's watering down of Hague's absurd "tax guarantee" was another indication of how the rules of engagement are set by the chancellor, and the Conservatives will have their work cut out explaining how they could find the savings to pay for their tax cuts.

Brown's next challenge is to rehabilitate the idea of public spending. On the face of it this should not be difficult, given that only those who live in gated mansions and travel everywhere by helicopter could fail to see that Britain has become the text-book example of JK Galbraith's wisdom about private affluence and public squalor. However, the denigration of the public realm has been so intense that Labour has to show that the billions coming out of the Treasury are being well spent. As such, Brown's billions will come with all sorts of New Labour strings attached - public service agreements, capital charging, quantifiable targets. The treasury insists that this process has been streamlined since the first comprehensive spending review two years ago, with fewer yet more-meaningful objectives, but there are dangers with this approach - departments are given the wrong targets (such as cutting class sizes or hospital waiting lists), quantity comes at the expense of quality and ministries are encouraged to cheat to meet their goals.

For the next year, this will not trouble the government much, because, in the short-term, the CSR is crucial to Labour's re-election plans. Throughout the autumn and winter, spending ministers will dribble out announcements on how the money will be used to build a hospital in this marginal constituency or a school in that. Barring an unexpected disaster, it should be enough to win Blair his second term.

Civilisation has its price

Looking ahead to Blair 2, things get more interesting. Governments normally like to go in for a bit of belt-tightening early in a parliament to make room for a splurge later on. The spending commitments in the CSR mean that this will not happen, and there is a danger - albeit unlikely at the moment when the economic background is so benign - that higher public spending will lead to over-heating.

More important, perhaps, is that, according to the Treasury's forecasts, the public finances will be back in the red by the time the plans for the next spending review are laid, even though the borrowing will be only for capital projects.

Will Labour be able to keep on spending at the present rate? Perhaps. It could be that the trend rate of growth has improved so that the growth of spending and the growth of the economy are aligned. Nobody, least of all the chancellor, one suspects, is banking on this. It could be that overall spending growth can be cut while spending on priorities is maintained because reduced debt interest payments and lower unemployment allow the government to shift resources from "bads" to "goods". Brown will announce an extra £3bn for departments tomorrow precisely for this reason. But if neither of these things happen, Labour will be forced to decide whether it is prepared to raise taxes. If this is the choice, there should be no hesitation. Tax is the price we pay for a civilised society.

webTitle: Mugabe faces new row on land seizure

fields.headline: Mugabe faces new row on land seizure
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The Zimbabwean president, Robert Mugabe, announced a new cabinet at the weekend, dropping several heavyweight politicians and omitting the war veterans' leader, Chenjerai Hunzvi.
fields.body:
The Zimbabwean president, Robert Mugabe, announced a new cabinet at the weekend, dropping several heavyweight politicians and omitting the war veterans' leader, Chenjerai Hunzvi.

After his Zanu-PF party's narrow victory on June 27, when it won 62 of the 120 seats in parliament, he reduced the size of his cabinet and left out such nationalist stalwarts as Emmerson Mnangagwa, Eddison Zvobgo and Witness Mangwende.

Mr Mugabe abolished the post of minister for war veterans' affairs, which had been expected to go to Mr Hunzvi.

There were also contradictory messages about the simmering land issue, making it uncertain whether the war veterans will leave the 1,400 farms they now occupy illegally.

The vice-president, Joseph Msika, said land seizures would start immediately. He said the war veterans would be moved off the 1,400 farms to 200 farms designated for seizure through lawful - although questionable - means.

"Our 'Fast Track' land resettlement starts today. We are moving people onto farms today," he said on Saturday.

"The government will shift the war veterans and peasants from farms that were not identified."

But, revealing the simmering conflict between Mr Mugabe and the veterans, Mr Hunzvi said they would "stay put" on the farms they now occupy until they were satisfied that the government was seizing land fast enough.

In a speech to 4,000 war veterans, Mr Hunzvi warned that anyone who opposed them would end up "6ft underground", and he pressed Mr Mugabe to speed up the land confiscations.

"I do not usually want to give our government ultimatums, but today I am doing so," he said. "If the government does not speed up taking the remainder of the farms, we the war veterans are going to do that. I give them two weeks from now."

Earlier the veterans had shouted that Zanu-PF was "rotten from the top". Mr Mugabe had been due to address them, but he cancelled at the last minute.

"Mugabe feared being roasted by Hunzvi and the veterans, so he avoided them," said a Zanu-PF insider.

"He is becoming more isolated. Mugabe is afraid of appearing before the general public because they support the [opposition] Movement for Democratic Change. And even within his own Zanu-PF party his support is limited."

Mr Mugabe relied heavily upon Mr Hunzvi and his supporters during the election campaign, encouraging them to invade white-owned farms and intimidate MDC supporters.

He ordered the police not to arrest the war veterans who spearheaded a violent campaign. Now that the veterans believe they are above the law, he will find it difficult to restore their respect for law and order.

Mr Mugabe still has eight provincial governorships to announce, and Mr Hunzvi might be placated by being given one of them.

webTitle: Treasury told to ease up on long hours

fields.headline: Treasury told to ease up on long hours
fields.trailText: Britain's leading workaholic, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, is being told by Treasury mandarins to cut down the long hours culture in his department.
fields.body:
Britain's leading workaholic, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, is being told by Treasury mandarins to cut down the long hours culture in his department.

The Treasury has formed a task force to reduce working hours following evidence that the devotion to duty demanded of its conscientious civil servants is a barrier to recruitment.

This comes as a survey reveals British managers worked longer hours than their American counterparts, and were second only to Germans.

The Treasury has been trying to attract more civil servants from the private sector but officials admit they are finding it difficult.

Mr Brown, the son of a Methodist preacher, is seen as the personification of the work ethic. He is known to ring political colleagues in the early hours to discuss proposals in a speech and enjoys working breakfasts.

Research submitted to the Treasury select committee's inquiry into the efficiency of the department has found that, between January and March 1999, 3% of staff worked more than 20 hours over their fixed contracts; 6% worked an extra 16 hours, and 13% more than 11 hours, and 31% more than six hours.

A Treasury memorandum suggests: "We all need to ensure we manage our time effectively - for example, by discussing with those for whom we work what jobs we can eliminate entirely, because they add little value... and by remembering that calling meetings before 9.30am or after 5pm and continuing them after 6pm is unsociable and can cause particular problems for people with families."

Research by an office supplies firm, Esselte, found German company bosses worked more than 70 hours a week compared with 60 hours by their British counterparts. The survey of 550 managers showed they worked harder than five years ago.

webTitle: A new ball game for Boris

fields.headline: A new ball game for Boris
fields.standfirst:
Boris Johnson is the new Tory choice for Henley. Martin Bell offers him some tips on how to survive the move from journalism to politics

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Boris Johnson is the new Tory choice for Henley.  Martin Bell offers him some tips on how to survive the move from journalism to politics.
fields.body:
Boris Johnson will discover, if he hasn't already, that on leaving journalism to enter politics, he is moving from a profession held low in public esteem to one held even lower. Nor will his former colleagues garland him with their good wishes. Far from it. They will tend to regard it as a form of betrayal which they describe as "crossing the line." He will enter their target zone. The meaner spirits will carp and cavil. The more generous ones will regret the waste of a talent.

Mr Johnson has been there before, of course, but only to tilt at an electoral windmill. While he was still a Daily Telegraph columnist, he stood as Conservative candidate in Clwyd South in the last election. I am not sure that his editor, Mr Charles Moore, was altogether in favour of the venture - in fact I am reliably informed that he wasn't - but Boris went ahead anyway. And I was grateful to him, for he provided me with just the sort of top cover that I needed. His true blue newspaper could hardly criticise a journalist for standing for parliament in Tatton, when one of its own was doing the same in Wales.

At the next election, I think he will find his journalistic background an advantage. He has nothing to fear from the papers' interviewers, since he has been there and done that himself. The same applies to the news reporters and columnists. He has been trading in soundbites for years.

He will need to keep, at least in his own mind, a list of the genuinely ill-intentioned. There are only a few of them out there, and he probably knows them already. He can also count on high quality advice from his family. His father-in-law is the BBC correspondent Charles Wheeler, who can teach him the paramount importance of steadiness under fire. This will help him through the sort of ambush that a high-profile candidate may attract. I speak from experience.

He has another advantage. As long as he remains editor of the Spectator, he is unlikely to be attacked by it; although it would be the sign of an enlightened regime there if he were to invite another of its Johnsons - most Spectator columnists are called Johnson - to return to the theme of the presumption of journalists in standing as "media candidates." Paul Johnson has only to update a polemic from 1997 which he directed at me, and apply it to his employer.

A possible weakness for the journalist-turned-candidate is sensitivity to criticism. Journalists can hand it out but they can't take it. Politicians by contrast tend to have the hides of oxen and to need them. An electoral campaign, even for so safe a seat as Henley, is not for the faint-hearted.

As it happens, I have already advised Boris Johnson about this, without knowing his intentions. He came to interview me a couple of months ago for a radio documentary he was presenting about "why people hate Tories." I protested that it was a mistaken premise. I don't hate Tories - or Lib Dems, or Labour supporters for that matter. I have seen too much of the rage of hatred to have any time for it at all. I just find some people easier to admire than others - and that has nothing to do with party politics.

The conversation turned to what kind of a campaign he should run if he were ever to stand for parliament. I suggested a kind and gentle one. Courteous to his opponents and without the clamour and acrimony that are the disfiguring features of the party battleground. This would play to Johnson's strengths which in my entirely neutral view, are decency, originality, and a stylish way with words. Whatever else he is or may become, he is certainly not an identikit New Tory.

One other piece of advice I would offer, to a journalist or to anyone else with political ambitions: being an MP is best seen not as a career, but as a parliamentary episode that can end at any time. It is a contract with the people and it is wise to regard it as a short-term contract at that.

Since Mr Johnson's election seems more or less assured, I hope he enjoys it as much as I have. They just could be the best years of his life.

Martin Bell is MP for Tatton

At the next election, I think he will find his journalistic background an advantage. He has nothing to fear from the papers' interviewers, since he has been there and done that himself. The same applies to the news reporters and columnists. He has been trading in soundbites for years. He will need to keep, at least in his own mind, a list of the genuinely ill-intentioned. There are only a few of them out there, and he probably knows them already. He can also count on high quality advice from his family. His father-in-law is the BBC correspondent Charles Wheeler, who can teach him the paramount importance of steadiness under fire. This will help him through the sort of ambush that a high-profile candidate may attract. I speak from experience. He has another advantage. As long as he remains editor of the Spectator, he is unlikely to be attacked by it; although it would be the sign of an enlightened regime there if he were to invite another of its Johnsons - most Spectator columnists are called Johnson - to return to the theme of the presumption of journalists in standing as "media candidates." Paul Johnson has only to update a polemic from 1997 which he directed at me, and apply it to his employer. A possible weakness for the journalist-turned-candidate is sensitivity to criticism. Journalists can hand it out but they can't take it. Politicians by contrast tend to have the hides of oxen and to need them. An electoral campaign, even for so safe a seat as Henley, is not for the faint-hearted. As it happens, I have already advised Boris Johnson about this, without knowing his intentions. He came to interview me a couple of months ago for a radio documentary he was presenting about "why people hate Tories." I protested that it was a mistaken premise. I don't hate Tories - or Lib Dems, or Labour supporters for that matter. I have seen too much of the rage of hatred to have any time for it at all. I just find some people easier to admire than others - and that has nothing to do with party politics. The conversation turned to what kind of a campaign he should run if he were ever to stand for parliament. I suggested a kind and gentle one. Courteous to his opponents and without the clamour and acrimony that are the disfiguring features of the party battleground. This would play to Johnson's strengths which in my entirely neutral view, are decency, originality, and a stylish way with words. Whatever else he is or may become, he is certainly not an identikit New Tory. One other piece of advice I would offer, to a journalist or to anyone else with political ambitions: being an MP is best seen not as a career, but as a parliamentary episode that can end at any time. It is a contract with the people and it is wise to regard it as a short-term contract at that. Since Mr Johnson's election seems more or less assured, I hope he enjoys it as much as I have. They just could be the best years of his life. Martin Bell is MP for Tatton

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.body:
Sunday Times

Granada Media is stepping up the pressure on its ITV rivals Carlton Communications and United News & Media. Granada executives are likely to demand that United sells at least two franchises as the price of avoiding a hostile £5.5bn bid.

Frustrated by the six-year delay in delivering the £1.7bn Bowman project to modernise the army's battlefield communications system, the government is considering scrapping the system being developed by Archer, the consortium led by BAE Systems, and reopening the bidding.

Sunday Telegraph

The health care group Nycomed Amersham is posed to announce a US flotation for its life sciences business in a move that will value the operation at more than $3bn. The group, which made many of the gene sequencers that cracked the human genetic code, is at present making the final preparations for the flotation, but will keep a majority stake in the business.

Conran Holdings, the private company owned by Sir Terence Conran, which owns the Conran shops and restaurants, has suffered a 40% collapse in profits to £4.2m as a result of the going over budget and late opening of the Great Eastern hotel in London and Guastavino's, sited below New York's 59th Street bridge.

Mail on Sunday

Vodafone AirTouch, Britain's biggest company by market capitalisation, looks certain to face a shareholder revolt after failing to mollify investors over a £5m bonus for chief executive, Chris Gent. At least one in 10 of Vodafone's investors plan to abstain or vote against the company's remuneration policy on July 27.

Sunday Express

Bradford & Bingley is expected to announce today that its ballot of members has voted to convert the building society into a bank, triggering windfalls of at least £500 for 2.5m savers and borrowers.

Observer

Dixons is back in talks to sell Freeserve, Britain's most widely used internet service provider, to Deutsche Telekom's T-Online. Talks collapsed last month because Dixons put too high a price tag on Freeserve, but the subsequent sharp fall in Freeserve's share price has meant that T-Online is now reconsidering at a lower price.

The future of the merger between Carlton Communications and United News & Media hangs in the balance as terms for the deal are revised to prevent it collapsing altogether. Although cleared by trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, more generous terms will have to be offered to Carlton's shareholders to save the merger.

Sunday Business

British horseracing will receive a boost this week when it announces a new television rights package worth up to £350m. Channel 4, the BBC, BSkyB and Premium TV, a subsidiary of cable television company NTL, are thought to have agreed a new 10-year broadcasting deal with all 59 British racecourses.

IoS

The two big cable companies, NTL and Telewest, are facing bills running into billions of pounds because of the shoddy laying of television cables. The companies are already engaged in remedial work at scores of locations, where local councils have called them back to relay road surfaces damaged by digging.

Philip Green is planning to take Bhs down market in an attempt to reduce costs in readiness for a quick exit from the retail chain he bought in April. The entrepreneur has already called in his suppliers and demanded they squeeze prices if they want to continue doing business with Bhs.

Interims Glaxo Wellcome, Northern Rock, Rights & Issues Inv Trust, SmithKline Beecham. Finals None scheduled. AGMs Aea Technology, Baldwins Industrial, City Of London Properties, Dairy Crest Group, Northern Foods, Pilkington, TR Property Investment Trust. EGMs Freecom.net.

webTitle: Spaced out by the mundane needs of working life

fields.headline: Spaced out by the mundane needs of working life
fields.standfirst: Starting up
fields.trailText: Working in cyberspace presents many problems - but one of the biggest headaches is finding the right hole in the real world to work out of. No matter how online you are, office space, equipment and all the other mundane needs of business have to be well managed.
fields.body:
Working in cyberspace presents many problems - but one of the biggest headaches is finding the right hole in the real world to work out of. No matter how online you are, office space, equipment and all the other mundane needs of business have to be well managed.

Believe us, we have seen the lot. There are internet incubators with dot.com executives crammed into tiny spaces, established companies with huge corporate boardrooms and cutting-edge marketing teams working in loft-like luxury.

For dot.coms, "meeting and greeting" space in particular seems to be in scarce supply. As organisations recruit at pace, it seems meeting space gets pushed out in favour of work space.

But you never know what to expect from start ups. We had one meeting last week in a relatively small, unattractive open-plan office in London that was being shared by at least six dot.com start-ups. So packed was the office that we had to negotiate to get a square foot of privacy. For those start-ups selling things online, the problem of storing goods is as important as providing space for workers. One online retailer we visited didn't bother dividing staff from products. They had solved the problem by having their people work around the products they sell.

Every inch of space was taken. Alongside and in between the usual PCs and office furniture were piles of boxes which blocked out the light. The business was a success and the office - where about 30 people were based - had obviously been outgrown a long time ago.

In the same week, and in stark contrast, we visited one of the country's largest high street retailers. This was very much the traditional suit and tie operation with huge offices and a separate suite of meeting rooms.

We were in with the top managers and looked on with envy. The first thing that struck us was that looking around the large and ornate meeting room with the four of us in it, we noticed how our entire workforce - 10 and rising - could have happily occupied it with room to spare.

Interestingly some large organisations have by accident rather than design created a busy start-up atmosphere with an economic attitude towards space and equipment. This tends to be where the parent company has set up a separate internet business and given them clear resources and space to work with.

The problem here appears to be how fast the new economy side of the business swallows up the old - and will the holders of purse strings let them have the office space to do so.

 Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are co-founders of Rools.com, a service that lets teenagers buy securely online without a credit card.

fields.headline: Time to go local globally
fields.trailText: This weekend the leaders of the G8 countries will be seen skulking on the Japanese island of Okinawa. Conveniently, the surrounding shark-infested waters mean there will be a marked absence of Jubilee 2000 banners and Seattle type street unrest.
fields.body:
This weekend the leaders of the G8 countries will be seen skulking on the Japanese island of Okinawa. Conveniently, the surrounding shark-infested waters mean there will be a marked absence of Jubilee 2000 banners and Seattle type street unrest.

The leaders will have other pressing matters on their minds - the price of oil, how to ensure taxation doesn't frighten off hi-tech investors and such things. In short, they will do what politicians do, short-term management of the economic status quo.

Yet it is the issues raised by the excluded debt campaigners and highlighted by the Seattle protesters that should be at the heart of the G8 discussions. These critics recognise that the true threats to the international economy are the rising inequality, job insecurity and environmental instability inherent in globalisation. For Jubilee 2000, debt is the battering ram that allowed the rich to open and subordinate the economies of the developing world. Instead of concentrating on World Bank and IMF apparatchiks, the debt campaigners went for their paymasters, the G8 leaders.

At Seattle, the question of who controls these governments was raised. The established groups protested about how the World Trade Organisation's rules hurt their issue specific interests - jobs, the poor, the environment. However, many of the street protesters were also fingering the real powers behind the nation state's throne - big business and international banks. There is growing recognition that transnationals are the new gods of the economic universe and the G8 heads of state are their ever-more obedient sons. The third member of this terrible trinity - which empowers the gods and weakens the sons - is Mrs Thatcher's most corrosive four-letter legacy: Tina. That "there is no alternative" to international competitiveness is the new theology that limits the ambitions of not just supine politicians, but also of far too many political activists. This mindset allows for no fundamental challenging of globalisation, merely efforts to make it kinder and gentler.

Yet there is an alternative. That is for priority to be given to rebuilding local economies everywhere. This replaces globalisation's insistence on perpetual and ruthless competition, with an emphasis on communities being allowed to rediversify and flourish under local people. This unites groupings as diverse as Polish farmers protecting their livelihoods from the encroaching European Union and those in Britain defending small shops and hospitals.

To turn these scattered local struggles into the norm is the challenge. It will require a set of self-reinforcing "localisation" policies. These can provide the necessary framework to replicate "the local, globally" approach everywhere. The present defeatist acceptance of globalisation must be replaced with the goal of re-introducing regional self-reliance. Local economies would be rebuilt through the grounding of business via "site here to sell here" rules, funded by money made to stay predominantly where it was generated. Free of the threat of relocation, countries could raise sufficient green and other taxes to pay for community renewal.

Lastly, trade and aid flows would be aimed at rebuilding local economies, rather than condemning them to a race to the bottom through increasingly open markets.

Which brings us back to debt campaigners and the G8. To rid permanently the poor of debt, beggar-your-neighbour globalisation must be replaced by better-your-neighbour localisation. Otherwise, it will not be long before the poor are forced to borrow and the whole cycle will begin again.

But it is too much to expect such radical thinking from politicians. Rather it must be the politically active, driven by a worsening economic situation for most of the world, who must move from opposition to proposition. In short a new rallying cry is needed: "localists of the world unite - there is an alternative".

 Colin Hines is the author of Localization - A Global Manifesto, published by Earthscan on July 20

fields.headline: Carlton rethinks merger terms
fields.trailText: Carlton Communications is thought to want to renegotiate significantly the terms of its planned merger with United News & Media amid intense speculation that the unwanted attentions of a cash-rich Granada Media could scupper their £10bn deal altogether.
fields.body:
Carlton Communications is thought to want to renegotiate significantly the terms of its planned merger with United News & Media amid intense speculation that the unwanted attentions of a cash-rich Granada Media could scupper their £10bn deal altogether.

Sources close to Carlton were last night indicating that it would press for the "nil-premium" terms of the original deal to be revised in light of the government's insistence that United's star Meridian franchise must be sold if the deal is completed and of Carlton's stronger share price performance since their marriage was proposed.

The renegotiation would reflect a perception in the City that United is a less attractive proposition to Carlton shareholders without Meridian. Carlton could demand that the offer to its shareholders is improved by as much as 15% and main investors are likely to be consulted.

It is likely to intensify pressure on United's chief executive, Lord Hollick, who knows that Granada is still prepared to launch a hostile counter-bid for United.

Analysts believe that the pressure of being forced to renegotiate the deal could test Lord Hollick and Carlton chairman Michael Green's reputedly brittle relationship to breaking point. "I doubt very much whether their deal will go ahead now," said one analyst.

However, sources close to all three media companies were last night at pains to emphasise that the consolidation of the ITV network set in train by the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, last week was unlikely to take place instantaneously.

"It's not going to be a quick process from here on in," said one senior media industry executive.

Granada is thought to want Meridian and at least one other United franchise, probably Anglia. Its ambitions have been stoked by the £2bn of cash it raised through its recent flotation and by Mr Byers's ruling, which observers say puts Granada in place to drive the consolidation of ITV from three main players into two.

Granada chairman Charles Allen has previously intimated that he is prepared to sit down at the negotiating table with either party in an attempt to hammer out a friendly deal.

Analysts say a carve-up of United's assets has now become a distinct possibility. Granada is likely to be a leading force for any break-up but could work with either Carlton or RTL, the pan-European television group formed by a merger of the television assets of Pearson, Bertelsmann and Belgium's Audiofina.

RTL is due to list in London shortly with a value of about £14bn and has been tipped as a possible counter-bidder for United.

Analysts believe RTL may collude with Granada by trying to break up United. They say such a deal would enable Granada to get the ITV franchises it wants and RTL to take full control of Channel 5 by adding United's 35% stake to its existing 65% shareholding.

RTL would then invest heavily in production to make Channel 5 a stronger rival to ITV.

Pearson, which through Pearson TV is a large shareholder in RTL, might then buy Miller Freeman, the magazines and exhibitions group owned by United, analysts said.

fields.headline: UK fights plans for regulator
fields.standfirst: Brown to oppose European body
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown will today do his best to scupper a French idea which some in Britain fear could lead to the creation of a pan-European financial services regulator.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown will today do his best to scupper a French idea which some in Britain fear could lead to the creation of a pan-European financial services regulator.

Britain is, however, the only European country formally to oppose the French proposal, which seeks to establish a panel of so-called "wise men" to carry out a detailed review of the way Europe regulates its stock markets.

British diplomats refused last week to endorse the idea at a meeting of EU ambassadors and, according to diplomatic sources, it is now a case of "14 against one".

Mr Brown will outline Britain's concerns at a meeting of EU finance ministers in Brussels today, the first under France's six-month EU chairmanship, at which the five members of the controversial panel are expected to be chosen.

Although the report which the panel produces will not be binding, the fact that it will be drafted by what is likely to be a relatively high-profile team of experts means that it is bound to be taken seriously.

At a time when Europe's stock markets are actively coming closer together, many in Brussels and Paris believe that the logic of having a single European financial regulator is increasingly compelling.

The Paris, Brussels and Amsterdam bourses plan to merge by early next year to form Euronext, while the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges are busily discussing the terms of their own merger.

France denies that the panel will pave the way for a single regulator but French officials do admit they believe that the current rash of stock exchange mergers and corporate takeovers makes a nonsense of Europe's disparate national rules.

Britain is doing its upmost, however, to ensure that the group's mandate and role are as limited as possible and that finance ministers clearly prescribe its room for manoeuvre at today's meeting.

The idea is known to be regarded by some in the Treasury as unwelcome meddling in an area where Britain's expertise is unchallenged. And others fear that it may be a roundabout way of merging the newly established Financial Services Authority with a pan-European regulator.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: MGt, the media outsourcing services group based in Fife, is to create 500 new jobs in Scotland over the next two years. The company, which employs 450 staff at its Kirkcaldy headquarters, said the new jobs would be in the areas of client management, IT, business analysis and finance.
fields.body:
MGt creates 500 jobs

MGt, the media outsourcing services group based in Fife, is to create 500 new jobs in Scotland over the next two years. The company, which employs 450 staff at its Kirkcaldy headquarters, said the new jobs would be in the areas of client management, IT, business analysis and finance.

In addition, MGt is expanding its call centre and focusing on research and development of technology solutions.

Stock exchange merger details

The London stock exchange is today expected to publish the details of its proposed controversial merger with its German rival in a prospectus designed to placate all the members of the exchange.

The outcome of the vote on the merger is by no means certain to back the management, as opposition is being waged by some smaller members of the exchange. They are anxious about the cost of introducing the German electronic trading system and the plan to move the market for high technology companies to the German financial centre.

Connex on-line shopping

Connex, the embattled train operator, is talking to leading supermarkets about a scheme whereby customers can have their shopping dropped off ready for them at their local railway station.

The idea is to bolster the supermarkets' internet based operations by using Connex stations as delivery points. Commuters can place orders from home through the internet and arrange for the items to be delivered at their local station which are collected on the homeward journey.

Egg opens shares service

Internet bank Egg will this week go head-to-head with companies such as Charles Schwab when it launches a share-dealing service offering "very competitive" fees.

The Prudential banking subsidiary will follow this up with a general insurance broking service due to go live next month. Customers will be able to obtain quotes for products such as home and motor insurance from a panel of around eight to 12 insurers, who will be offering "specially negotiated rates"

webTitle: US ready to pay for peace deal

fields.headline: US ready to pay for peace deal
fields.standfirst:
Israel and the Middle East: special report
Middle East agreement will depend on support
fields.trailText: The Clinton administration is preparing to ask Congress to approve at least $15bn in extra spending - possibly as much as $40bn - to implement the key terms in any Middle East peace deal reached in the talks at Camp David, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The Clinton administration is preparing to ask Congress to approve at least $15bn in extra spending - possibly as much as $40bn - to implement the key terms in any Middle East peace deal reached in the talks at Camp David, it emerged yesterday.

As negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians continued for the sixth day at the presidential retreat in Maryland, reports in Washington underlined the scale of the price which the government is willing to pay for a peace deal in a presidential election year, and to secure Bill Clinton's legacy.

While military and political power are fundamental to its ability to bring the opposing sides together at Camp David, the reality is that it is US money which is the ultimate guarantee of any deal reached there.

Any agreement is certain to be conditional upon the US providing the biggest package of new Middle East aid for almost a quarter of a century. Under the 1978 Camp David agreement, the US is still paying Egypt and Israel combined annual support amounting to $5bn (£3.1bn).

The 1998 Wye River agreement between Israel, Jordan and the Palestinians came with a $1.88bn American aid tag.

Among the items for which US dollars would be required are the relocation of Israeli military bases and borders, a fresh arms deal with Israel, and compensation to Palestinian refugees for the loss of their homes.

Officials describe the emerging terms of such a package as "still vague", but the secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, has begun to discuss the broad outlines with senators.

Senator Mitch McConnell, a leading Republican, accused Mr Clinton yesterday of trying to "buy an agreement because it's an election year".

Not surprisingly, there are signs that both the Israelis and the Palestinians have embarked on a bidding war for financial support from Washington as part of a deal on new borders in the region.

The Israeli ambassador to Washington, David Ivry, spent much of last week mobilising congressional allies in support of a huge request for extra aid to implement a deal.

In the past week alone Mr Ivry has held separate meetings with between 30 and 40 members of Congress on the issue, the Israeli embassy confirmed.

Palestinian officials, meanwhile, have floated the figure of $40bn to cover compensation to Arabs who lost their land and homes at the time of Israel's establishment in 1948.

Even if, as expected, this proves to be an unrealistic figure, there is no doubt that Washington will have to write several large cheques to ensure Palestinian agreement to any Camp David deal.

The lion's share would almost certainly go to Israel to pay for the the security arrangements it would need in consequence of an agreement. Israel is expecting to spend billions of dollars relocating its armed forces to defend the redrawn borders which will be at the heart of any deal. Some Israeli officials have asked for more money to "remake the Israeli military in the US image", a Republican source said.

While the White House accepts that Washington will be the principal financial guarantor of any deal the US managed to bring about, the administration has said that it expects America's allies to contribute too.

The European Union, Japan and Saudi Arabia will all face demands for support, and President Clinton is likely to raise the issue at the G8 summit in Okinawa this week.

fields.headline: The colossus of roads
fields.standfirst:
They pollute the air and destroy the countryside, but motorways are spectacular architectural achievements too, argues Jonathan Glancey

Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: They pollute the air and destroy the countryside, but motorways are spectacular architectural achievements too, argues Jonathan Glancey.
fields.body:
Eleven years ago I wrote an article to coincide with the 20th anniversary of the Westway, the elevated A40(M) motorway that snakes in and out of west London. I tried to suggest that beyond its brutal design, beyond the way it sliced through old London with the finesse of a blunt butcher's knife, the Westway was a fascinating road, a thing of strange if questionable beauty.

Readers weren't having it. Aside from two informative letters from engineers involved in the project, the response was perhaps rightly vituperative, and, at the time, not a little shaming. My problem, like many other people I know, is that I like fast cars and public transport, civilised city centres and the thrill of driving on dramatic roads into big, sodium and neon-lit cities by night.

Since then, this controversy seems to have melted into the lead-free air. Or at least it has if you go down to the Architecture Foundation, a gallery in deepest, traffic-laced London St James's. Their exhibition, It's a Gas On the Road, is an unashamed celebration of "petrol pumps, flyovers and architecture for the car". Originally a Hayward Gallery roadshow, On the Road has been extended by Helen Jones's It's a Gas, a homage to the petrol station.

To most people the banal roadside pitstop is a necessary and useful nothingness, a blind spot in the day, something to do with packets of Handy-Andies, M&Ms and bored staff in red jumpers: to design historian Jones they are as intriguing as out-of-the-way votive shrines are to the church-crawler with a pocket full of Pevsner.

It's a small show on a giant subject, and it doesn't come much bigger than the Westway or the Humber Bridge, built by Freeman, Fox and Partners in 1981. What it says, to me at least, is that the shock of Spaghetti Junction (Sir Owen Williams and Partners, 1972) has long since vanished. An A-road of contemporary writers, photographers and historians sing the body concrete. One young critic suggests that, for an Italian baroque architect of the 17th century, the Westway would have curves "to die for".

The point, though, is clear: in little more than a decade, the arterial road and its panoply of car parks and service stations, bridges and tunnels, has been elevated from the status of a pariah to the pantheon of architectural wonders. The Westway and Spaghetti Junction are up there, if you swallow the Architecture Foundation's line, with Giovanni Lorenzo Bernini's Piazza Navona.

It makes sense, in an age when the car is no longer king, that we should look at roads and roadside architecture in a new light. To protest against insensitively planned new roads in our crowded islands makes obvious sense, yet we cannot ignore the fact that even motorway protesters beetle down to campsites in battered VW campers - along the roads that flourished in the wake of the Beeching report of 1963 that signed the death sentence for an integrated British railway network.

For nearly 40 years, from the era of the Morris 1100 and Cortina Mk1, we have been a nation not so much in thrall with roads and their attendant architecture, as dependent on them. The Forth Road Bridge, one of the first engineering wonders of the road-dependent age, opened a year after Beeching. The railway age was now to be challenged by the structural might of the motorway epoch.

Who can fail to be impressed by the nature-defying Humber Bridge, and who can fail to be fascinated, as well as frustrated, by the M6's Spaghetti Junction? At a time when Britain's sordidly privatised railways have been relegated to those of Cuba on a bad day, we can't help feeling we need our cars more than ever before; and, as we do, perhaps we can't help paying more attention to the roadside architecture that serves them. One of Jones's discoveries when compiling It's a Gas is James Trew, busy at work on a chain of sculptures based on petrol station canopies, but located in natural settings in France rather than on the roadside. Trew sees the petrol station canopy as the "epitome of artificiality".

So critics, artists and historians are queuing up, like Friday afternoon traffic on the A40, to give praise to this relatively new, if curiously overlooked, architecture: all this before one gets to grips with Edward Platt's fascinating book Leadville: A Biography of the A40.

We can see, too, how some of the best contemporary architects have been taking roadside architecture increasingly seriously. The Architecture Foundation exhibition shows a model of Foster and Partners 1998 design for a Repsol petrol station chain in Spain. A couple of months back Ivan Margolius published his handsome book Automobiles by Architects (Wiley-Academy, 2000). Inside is Le Corbusier and Pierre Jeanneret's 1928-36 design for a "voiture minimum"; but, more importantly, there's Le Corbusier, one of the most influential architects of the 20th century, posing in front of his Voisin 10CV, which was used as a modernist prop in several famous photographs of his early white villas of the late 1920s.

From then on, streamlined (and otherwise all but featureless) modern buildings were best seen through the windscreen of Le Corbusier's Voisin, Frank Lloyd Wright's Cord 810 drophead, the Adler Standard 6 designed by Mies van der Rohe in 1931.

In the early 60s, Alison Smithson, the English architect who co-designed the Economist building where the Architecture Foundation has its gallery, wrote AS in DS, an intriguing, if largely forgotten, book about the relationship between architecture, landscape and the road as seen through the windcreen of her Citroen DS. The book was shaped on the floorplan of the sensational French car that, on its launch in 1955, Roland Barthes compared to a gothic cathedral. Here, said the philosopher, was "the beginnings of a new phenomenology of assembling, as if one progressed from a world where elements are welded to a world where they are juxtaposed and held together by sole virtue of their wondrous shape". And who but a confusion of modern French philosophers could argue with that?

The fact, however, that so many diverse talents have turned their attention to the architecture of the road, from the heroic poetry of bridges to the doggerel of petrol stations, should encourage us to hope that a future generation of architects will see roads not as high-speed rats' alleys between their wonderful buildings, but as the glue that, for better or worse, sticks our towns and their architecture together.

It's a Gas On the Road is at the Architecture Foundation, London SW1 (020 7839 9389) until September 3. Leadville: A Biography of the A40 is published by Picador, price £9.99.

webTitle: Settlers protest against talks with Palestinians

fields.headline: Settlers protest against talks with Palestinians
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: A man was taken to hospital when Jewish settlers and Palestinians clashed in Hebron in the second day of unrest yesterday.
fields.body:
A man was taken to hospital when Jewish settlers and Palestinians clashed in Hebron in the second day of unrest yesterday.

A Reuters cameraman, two Palestinian journalists, and four Palestinians were injured in fighting in Hebron, where 400 Jewish settlers live among thousands of Arabs.

The Israeli army had no immediate comment on the violence. It said on Saturday that the trouble appeared to have broken out after a Palestinian youth tried to kiss a settler.

Israeli troops withdrew from most of Hebron in 1997 under an agreement with the Palestinian Authority, but are deployed around Jewish enclaves.

Meanwhile, the security forces evacuated 30 young Jewish settlers from a site near the village of Al Khader (above) after they had set up a renegade out post and watchtower to protest against possible Israeli concessions to the Palestinians at the Camp David summit.

Soldiers and policemen tried to prise protesters off the roof of one of the shacks erected by the group. The settlers sang Israel's national anthem as they were taken away.

Two settlers were arrested during the evacuation, the army said.

It was predicted that tens of thousands would gather in Rabin Square in Tel Aviv last night to protest against the peace talks.

fields.headline: Don't serve Best, pleads doctor
fields.trailText: George Best's doctor took the extraordinary step yesterday of begging every barman in Britain to refuse to serve alcohol to the football legend.
fields.body:
George Best's doctor took the extraordinary step yesterday of begging every barman in Britain to refuse to serve alcohol to the football legend.

Professor Roger Williams spoke after it was revealed that the former Manchester United star had been drinking again despite his pledge to give up for good.

He spent weeks in hospital earlier this year receiving treatment for a serious liver condition caused by years of heavy drinking.

Prof Williams confirmed that Best, 54, would undergo tests in a few days to assess any damage caused by Thursday's session, which came after a reported row with his wife.

"Everybody knows him, everybody loves him and everybody wants to help him. Serving him drink isn't doing that," said the professor.

"Why should people serve him? It's a bit off. Staff could do their bit to help the doctors and everyone else."

Best is such an instantly recognisable figure and his alcohol addiction so well documented that there is no excuse for bar staff continuing to sell him alcohol, he added.

It was reported yesterday that Best had his first alcoholic drink for 18 weeks in a pub near his home in Chelsea, west London, on Thursday, apparently after a row with his wife, Alex, 28.

He is said to have continued drinking in a West End wine bar and then a casino until it closed at 4am. Later on Friday he booked himself into Forest Mere health farm in Liphook, Hampshire.

Yesterday, as he left his home, Best said: "I'm feeling fine thank you. I'm looking forward to a break."

He and his wife left for Heathrow airport, from where they were due to fly to an unknown destination.

Best was taken to the Cromwell hospital with suspected liver failure in March. Doctors diagnosed severe liver damage and told him he could never drink again.

The star later spoke movingly about his problem, saying: "I'd been ill for weeks. I couldn't hold down any food or drink and had been coughing up blood but I refused to see a doctor and carried on drinking."

Best made a televised pledge in April never to drink again. He spoke of having children and said that he did not want his wife to become a widow at the age of 28.

Prof Williams said: "He has been improving steadily and this is obviously a bit of a setback but he is well in himself and we don't know that it's done any particular extra harm. I'm going to be seeing him again this week to decide how best to go forward."

A single drink could seriously harm someone in Best's condition, he said, but he added that the extent of any damage would depend on how much his health had improved during abstinence.

"He knows the problems of his weakness to alcohol and he was upset by the fact that it's happened again,' he said, adding that Best claimed he had drunk only a "few glasses".

"Most people as they get older and iller have a much lower alcohol tolerance, which is why I would doubt it was more than a few glasses."

I'm going to be seeing him again this week to decide how best to go forward." A single drink could seriously harm someone in Best's condition, he said, but he added that the extent of any damage would depend on how much his health had improved during abstinence. "He knows the problems of his weakness to alcohol and he was upset by the fact that it's happened again,' he said, adding that Best claimed he had drunk only a "few glasses". "Most people as they get older and iller have a much lower alcohol tolerance, which is why I would doubt it was more than a few glasses."

fields.headline: Political sages
fields.standfirst:
Elder sometimes does mean better
Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Interventions at the weekend by two Tory elder statesmen get reported today as William Hague's latest embarrassment from within his own ranks. The fault is his own.
fields.body:
Interventions at the weekend by two Tory elder statesmen get reported today as William Hague's latest embarrassment from within his own ranks. The fault is his own. The price he paid for his surrender to the right was excommunication of the ancients, but their political skills (Kenneth Clarke) and depth of knowledge (Lord Hurd) mean they are unlikely to fade quietly away.

On penal policy, Douglas Hurd is an expert. Ignoring the costs - Mr Hague seems to believe in public sector economy and effectiveness everywhere except police and prisons - the Tory leader has adopted the mantra lock 'em up. Little wonder the former home secretary characterised his party as mindless in wanting to deal with crime through American levels of incarceration.

As for Europe, the publication of Kenneth Clarke's dialogue with Malcolm Rifkind was a potent reminder that there is an intelligent pro-euro Tory position which now has no spokesperson on that party's front bench.

These critics, rightly, did not exempt Labour. Lord Hurd blamed competition between Jack Straw and William Hague for bidding up prison as the universal panacea for crime. Kenneth Clarke said, without frills, that joining the euro is a till-death-us-do-part marriage which carries with it economic risks. His honesty contrasts as sharply with government fudging as his own party's obscurantism.

Of course age is no guaranteed repository of political insight. Ex-ministers do not always turn the dross of their public service into the gold of policy wisdom. But we have few mechanisms to transmit lore and learning between successor generations of office-holders. Dynamics do not change that much over time and it would be a foolish minister or shadow who said they had nothing to learn from a forbear. Problems of policy return again and again.

All this applies to Labour, too. Where are the owls to whom Tony Blair might turn at moments of perturbation for a comforting word? Breaking the chains of history was a necessary part of Labour's preparation for office - abandoning Clause Four, for example. But once there, history matters again. Comparisons between Mr Blair and Harold Wilson have blossomed in recent weeks. They contain an essential truth. Bright young men in the entourage, an aggressive press secretary too, are not enough to form the counsel of a prime minister. He needs dialogue with his party's past.

fields.headline: Brownian motion
fields.standfirst: Spending will determine Labour's identity Comprehensive Spending Review 2000: Special Report
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown's apotheosis tomorrow has been extensively trailed. Thanks to the prime minister's Frost programme promise we have long known that health spending will be rising by at least 5.6% a year from April next.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown's apotheosis tomorrow has been extensively trailed. Thanks to the prime minister's Frost programme promise we have long known that health spending will be rising by at least 5.6% a year from April next. Unless David Blunkett lost heavily - unlikely given the weekend briefings - education will be neck and neck. You do not need to be a senior wrangler to work out that leaves an average annual increase of nearly 4% in real terms for other Whitehall departments, assuming Mr Brown does nothing as dramatic as, say, reconnect social benefits to growth in earnings rather than prices.

The chancellor's test this week, amid the hue and cry over "presentation", is presentation. That is to say, when he sets out his stall, his duty is to play the statesman. These are spending plans . If Tony Blair goes to the country in May next year, Mr Brown's largesse will have been visible for barely a month. He must not pretend the public are going to wake up on Wednesday in some new world of public affluence. Mr Brown's other task is to indicate just what this spending says about the Third Way or at least the limits of progressive government in a globalised era - and so about the identity of this Labour government.

Last week research for the Smith Institute reminded us how class-bound the United Kingdom remains. Socio-economic circumstance, birth and upbringing, parents' job and income: these still determine life chances. New figures from the Department of Social Security showed how during Labour's first two years income inequality may, if anything, have risen - not surprising, given how little room for fiscal manoeuvre Labour had allowed itself, but dismaying none the less. So, how far will the comprehensive spending review set about making the UK a fairer place? Mr Brown's best answer is likely to be that large, sustained increases in spending on schools, together with nursery provision and the like will eventually make a difference to the skills, capacity and lives of the socially excluded. But that difference will be measurable only over years, generations even. Falsely precise promises and claims of "turnaround" will not wash. When the media clamour and the opposition speechify, modesty is not easy.

The government has surely learned, however, that hyperbole has become its worst enemy. The country may be transfixed by large increases in health spending, but it will not be transformed; the National Health Service will not change much in the short run. This money will change none of the difficulties of control, quality, technology and access that are faced in varying degree by every health-care system, whatever its mixture of public, voluntary and private.

On present reckoning, over the next five years Labour spending will stick pretty close to 40% of GDP. This is no magic ratio. It is entirely arbitrary and reflects nothing more than the government's assessment of what the public will wear by way of taxation. Available sums will buy health increases, but will not also purchase significant increases in welfare benefits - on a scale to attack official measures of inequality. To get both means spending a larger proportion of national income.

But Mr Brown, like his Downing Street colleague, has a fatal tendency to play two ends against the middle, to attempt to be all things to all people. Tomorrow he has the nation's attention. It will be a golden opportunity to behave like a fiscal adult. He is no magician. Unless the public wills more resources he is, at best, a mere juggler of equally pressing claims.

fields.headline: Shaming and naming
fields.trailText: In support of Chris Smith, Alan Howarth and Lord Falconer (Letters 15 July), the Department of Culture is one of the most successful ministries.
fields.body:
In support of Chris Smith, Alan Howarth and Lord Falconer (Letters 15 July), the Department of Culture is one of the most successful ministries. But, Labour's commitment to universal free admission to our national museums and galleries appears to have been stymied by the chancellor. Proper funding is necessary, as he must well know, to say nothing of dealing with cockeyed VAT regulations which inhibit free admission.

Sir Hugh Leggatt
Vevey, Switzerland

 In the light of the high court ruling today (Blunkett humiliated in pay row, July 15), has it ever been suggested that a system of performance-related pay be applied to government?

P and N Minney
Kettering, Northants

 As Blunkett's discomfiture was apparently due to bad advice from a civil servant, can we expect this individual to be named and shamed?

Penny Davis
Norwich

 You report "the electors of Henley-on-Thames ... chose Boris Johnson as their future Tory MP" (Tories choose Boris Johnson, July 15). Really? I thought this was just the blue rinses select another blonde toff stage. There are at least two other prospective parliamentary candidates, including Labour's admirable Janet Mathews.

David Winchester
Chairman, Henley Constituency Labour Party
david@segment.co.uk

 I fled Michael Brown's constituency for North Yorkshire, where I was represented by Leon Brittan and then William Hague got landed on me; when I sought to escape, I landed in John Redwood's patch. I sought sanctuary in the relative sanity of Michael Heseltine - and now Boris Johnson. What have I done to deserve this persecution?

Julian Dunn
Great Haseley, Oxon

fields.headline: All in the mind
fields.standfirst: In the BBC's new series, Brain Story, Professor Susan Greenfield confronts us with the physical apparatus of the human soul. It's thought-provoking stuff, says  Mark Lawson
fields.trailText: In the BBC's new series, Brain Story, Professor Susan Greenfield confronts us with the physical apparatus of the human soul. It's thought-provoking stuff, says Mark Lawson.
fields.body:
When the American insult of "dumbing down" began to be widely used by the critics of the BBC, executives coined a provocative antonym. They were, they insisted, in fact "braining up" the schedules in comparison with the programming of the 70s.

This declaration of cerebral content becomes literal this week with Brain Story, in which a scientist billed in the credits as Professor Susan Greenfield CBE (giving her the odd distinction of joining Jimmy Savile and Thora Hird as the only TV presenters to list their state honours after their name) examines the head.

The reference to her CBE really wasn't necessary, because Professor Greenfield claims a significant distinction merely by speaking her first link. The global overview documentary series - in which the presenter has a new city and a new outfit for each speech - has always belonged to men: Attenborough, Bronowski, Clark, Robert Winston, Henry Louis Gates. In TV history, Greenfield becomes as significant a pioneer as Margaret Thatcher and Betty Boothroyd in politics, although a less frightening TV presence than either.

The fear was that Greenfield had been admitted to the club even as the wrecking ball swung towards it. Many critics have felt in recent years that the factual grand tour is a genre reaching its end. Greenfield redresses one of the objections - paternalism - but faces the others. In a multi-channel environment, will the audience still attend to complex information over 50 minutes of documentary? Do attempts to inject human interest inevitably dilute intelligence?

On these questions, Greenfield is lucky with her subject. In a series about the history of art, anecdotes and visual gimmicks tend to distract from the argument. In this area, the weird stories are central to the thesis. The human interest tales help to explain how the brain makes humans interesting.

Rather like a series about motoring which starts in the scrapyard rather than the showroom, Greenfield uses damaged brains, with one everyday function removed, to show how the whole should work. An Alzheimer's patient - a subject played merely for sentimentality in some parts of television - becomes here the basis for an investigation of the brain's impact on personality.

The sort of freak medical cases loved by newspapers - the amputee who can still feel their missing arm, the brain-damaged concert-goer who can no longer be moved by music - all have a purpose beyond peculiarity here. The cases of Van Gogh and a modern female patient are used to explore whether epilepsy encourages artistic creativity and spiritual visions.

Those stories touch on the subversive nature of Brain Story. Greenfield's amiability on screen disguises the fact that she's often being as provocative as the more openly challenging Richard Dawkins. The underlying question of the series is whether experiences which many consider sacred and profound - religious belief, romantic love, appreciation of art and music - are simply the result of how our heads are wired.

In the stand-out moment of the first programme, a surgeon works inside the skull of a patient kept awake during the operation. (It should already be clear that Brain Story is a series not ideally suited to a TV supper.) About to remove a tumour from Sarah's brain, he needs to establish which bumps on the cauliflower control speech, in order to avoid the risk of his incisions leaving her mute. So Sarah counts while he presses on her exposed cerebrum with electrodes which will jam her signals. When the countdown halts, he knows he's located her speech lobes.

It's famously said that once you start to think about the process of walking, you're at risk of falling over. In the same way, watching Brain Story is a curiously self-conscious experience. You find yourself reflecting on the processes which allow the presenter to think and then speak her script, and the viewer to hear and then understand it. The programme is also difficult to review, making you aware of the possibility that any emotion you feel - interest, admira tion, pleasure - is merely the result of electrical storms on your cortex.

Well, my neurons say that while Greenfield's material helps her - because the brain is a subject of both academic and general interest - this episode (produced and directed by Andrew Cohen) shows far fewer concessions than most recent landmark documentary series to the American market or fears about the audience's attention-span.

A common critical gibe against TV presenters is that they don't have a thought in their heads. No one will be able to say this about Professor Greenfield, because at one point she wears a device (a literal thinking cap) which allows us to watch the pulsing of her brainwaves as she speaks to us. (We'll all have our own private list of hosts who'd be unwise to wear this device during their shows.) And, anyway, her accessible braininess is established throughout a documentary which is in two senses cerebral. She's the first TV personality able to explain to you what personality is.

Brain Story, tomorrow, 9pm, BBC2

fields.headline: New standards for 1m carers
fields.standfirst: Welfare reform: special report
fields.trailText: The government will today announce an overhaul of social services to set national standards for about 1m staff caring for many of the most vulnerable.
fields.body:
The government will today announce an overhaul of social services to set national standards for about 1m staff caring for many of the most vulnerable.

At a conference in London, the health minister, John Hutton, will unveil plans for a national agency to set guidelines for all local authority social services departments in England, including protocols for care of the elderly and adoption. He is also expected to astonish social workers by agreeing to their 20-year campaign for a three-year degree course in social work to be the normal route into the profession.

Consultants appointed by the Department of Health have concluded that the two-year diploma in social work is inadequate. The diploma is not recognised as a professional qualification in any other EU country.

The former Conservative health secretary, Virginia Bottomley, rejected requests for a three-year degree in social work, arguing that the profession needed "streetwise grannies" not graduates.

But ministers have concluded that the challenges facing the profession require induction through a national curriculum in universities. They want to replace the confusion of diploma syllabuses in 80 colleges with a three-year programme in a small number of centres of excellence.

Mr Hutton will use the conference, organised by the Guardian and National Institute for Social Work, to foreshadow a consultation paper, due next month, on raising the quality of social services.

A new Social Care Institute for Excellence (SCIE) will be established to give authoritative guidance on good practice. It will be modelled on the National Institute for Clinical Excellence that advises the health service on the cost effectiveness of drugs and treatments.

Although social services will continue to be administered locally, SCIE's protocols are expected to reduce variations in the service that ministers regard as unacceptable.

For example, the proportion of children in care going for adoption varies from 11% in some authorities to 1% in others. The proportion of older people getting home care in some authorities is three or four times that in others.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.body:
MI5 recruits on the internet

MI5 is recruiting undercover photographers over the internet, it emerged yesterday. Successful applicants should be physically fit with good night vision, no fear of heights or enclosed spaces, and at least five years' experience of professional photography. The job, with a starting salary of just under £20,000, could lead to promotion to senior management level in the security service, whose website is www.mi5.gov.uk

Research boost for adoption

Children adopted at an early age are not significantly more likely to get into trouble when teenagers than youngsters brought up by their natural parents, a study has suggested. Researchers at the Institute of Psychiatry in London found adopted children exhibited some behavioural problems in their teenage years, but it also showed these teenagers to be better socially adjusted than adolescents brought up in a traditional family unit.

Antrim murder: three charged

Two men, aged 20 and 27, and a woman, 25, will appear in court in Ballymena today charged in connection with the murder of a man in Larne, Co Antrim, on July 12. Andrew Cairns, 22, was shot dead on a night of violence in the province.

Poll reformers fear vote rigged

The Electoral Reform Society, which campaigns to strengthen democracy and oversees private ballots in Britain, is investigating claims of vote rigging in a poll to elect members of its council.

Four share £7.5m jackpot

Four ticket holders shared Saturday's £7.5m National Lottery jackpot. The winning numbers were 1, 2, 7, 35, 39, 44, bonus number 14. No one gained the £250,000 top prize in the Thunderball draw. The numbers were 4, 11, 12, 18, 27, Thunderball 11.

webTitle: Cult may appeal over runaway boy

fields.headline: Cult may appeal over runaway boy
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The leader of a religious cult feared to be hiding a boy aged 16 vowed yesterday to appeal against a ruling making the teenager a ward of court.
fields.body:
The leader of a religious cult feared to be hiding a boy aged 16 vowed yesterday to appeal against a ruling making the teenager a ward of court.

David Mackay, leader of the Jesus Christians, said the cult was taking legal advice before reuniting Bobby Kelly with his family.

Bobby, who had planned to go to business school, left home more than two weeks ago, saying he was going to join the cult only hours after meeting members in a shopping centre.

Last week, his grandmother Ruth Kelly, with whom he lived in Romford, Essex, asked the high court for help in bringing him home, and he was made a ward of court.

On Saturday Mr Mackay claimed on BBC radio that Bobby was not with the cult: "We definitely won't take him out of Britain." But yesterday he said: "We expect that Bobby will be handed over to the authorities shortly, [but] if there is some way we can appeal against that court order, then we will do.

"We feel that the ideal thing for a 16-year-old kid, who under any other circumstances would be allowed to make his own decisions, is that he should be able to have whoever he wants as friends. He should be allowed to live with his grandmother, but he should be allowed to have visitors."

webTitle: English Heritage grows reeds for thatching

fields.headline: English Heritage grows reeds for thatching
fields.trailText: English Heritage is starting its own cottage industry, growing thatch for the nation's ancient roofs.
fields.body:
English Heritage is starting its own cottage industry, growing thatch for the nation's ancient roofs.

There are 24,000 listed thatched roof buildings in Britain, but because suitable straw and reed is not available, material is imported. The price of a bundle of phragmites autralis reeds, enough for a square foot of roof, has risen to £1.85, making thatch very expensive to repair.

English Nature, charged with creating habitats for rare birds that live in reeds, notably the near extinct bittern and threatened hen harrier, has seen a business opportunity. The organisation is planting thatching reeds on old peat workings on the Somerset levels. Robin Prowse, site manager of Meare Heath, near Glastonbury, said there was no local knowledge of how to grow reeds for thatching, and he had to call in experts from Norfolk reed beds to advise him.

Jack Lewis, of Compton Durville in Somerset, a thatcher for 35 years, said: "We have real difficulty getting the materials we need. Reed is not really traditional round here - we find straw even on ancient buildings, but we cannot get it. We import reed from places like Hungary, Poland, and Turkey."

Some 40,000 bundles were needed annually for Somerset alone, and imported reed was packaged, straight, and free of weeds.

"English Nature will have to work hard to produce the quality we need. It's no use producing stuff with rubbish in it and reeds like a dog's hind leg," said Mr Lewis.

Mr Prowse said 25 acres had been planted and could be harvested in two years time. "Potentially it is an important industry for this area, which will provide a useful income we can plough back into more reed beds. It is a rare example of an industry that is of nothing but benefit for the wildlife."

webTitle: Mother flies to Colombia in search of missing son

fields.headline: Mother flies to Colombia in search of missing son
fields.trailText: The mother of a horticulturalist will this week fly to Colombia in an effort to find her son and his travelling companion, who have been missing in the jungle on the border with Panama since March.
fields.body:
The mother of a horticulturalist will this week fly to Colombia in an effort to find her son and his travelling companion, who have been missing in the jungle on the border with Panama since March.

Sarah Hart Dyke's son, Tom, 24, and Paul Winder, 29, a merchant banker, were travelling in a region beset by warring rebel groups.

Mr Hart Dyke has worked at Kew Gardens, and had been travelling for two years collecting and studying plant species. He met Mr Winder in Puerto Rico, and the pair intended to hike from Panama through the Darien Gap into Colombia. They were reported to have ignored warnings from locals of guerillas, drug gangs and paramilitary groups.

Two rebel groups, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia and the National Liberation Army, operate in the area. Colombia has the world's highest kidnap rate, with 1,500 people seized last year.

At the weekend the Foreign Office confirmed that photographs of the two had been circulated in Panama and Colombia, and that Oxfam and other charities, and the Catholic Church, had been asked to provide information.

Mr Winder's father recently spent two weeks in Panama. He said at the weekend: "There is a 95% likelihood of them being dead. It would be very unusual for them to be held for four months without their captors demanding a ransom."

Yesterday prayers were said for Mr Hart Dyke at St Botolph's church, in the grounds of his family's castle at Lullingstone, Kent.
