fields.headline: Touched by Bill's courage
fields.trailText: May I add a note to your obituary on Bill Alexander (July 14)?
fields.body:
May I add a note to your obituary on Bill Alexander (July 14)? In his book The Life and Work of JBS Haldane, Ronald Clark recalled the work of the great scientist investigating the loss, with 99 lives, of the submarine HMS Thetis off Liverpool three months before the outbreak of war in 1939. Haldane involved four non-scientific colleagues in the investigation - all former members of the International Brigade. Haldane said "I chose these men as colleagues because I had no doubt of their courage". They were subjected to increasing concentration of carbon dioxide, and suffered severe panting, head-aches, vomiting and temporary incapacity. One was Bill Alexander.

I had known Bill for over 50 years, including living with him and his wife Lena for a time in Birmingham and working with him in the Communist party and never once did he mention these experiments and the risks involved.

Gerry Cohen
London

 I was at Sandhurst when Bill Alexander arrived, which would haw been in 1943 - not 1940. He finished top of his intake not of his year (I believe the King presented him with the accolade). Another memory of him is that he tried to trace for me the antecedents of two Kent men who died in Spain and are now forgotten - many went with assumed names and we have never traced their origins.

Les Turner
Maidstone, Kent

 Richard Baxall rightly emphasised Bill's life-long political commitment, courage and self-discipline. But he failed to mention that Bill was a man of great humanity and sensitivity, and above all humour - who loved, and was much loved by his family and his children (who have names) and the many people who were privileged to know him.

Judith Nesbit
London
Judith@nesbit.dircon.co.uk

webTitle: On the internet, suffixes earn money

fields.headline: What's in a name?
fields.standfirst: On the internet, suffixes earn money
fields.trailText: Stand by for the next gold rush. The organisation that oversees the issue of top-drawer internet suffixes - such as dot.com and dot.net - has decided to issue more names to meet insatiable demand. They will be the first new ones for over 10 years.
fields.body:
Stand by for the next gold rush. The organisation that oversees the issue of top-drawer internet suffixes - such as dot.com and dot.net - has decided to issue more names to meet insatiable demand. They will be the first new ones for over 10 years. The actual names have not been decided yet, but when they are, they will trigger a worldwide scramble to register the most eye-catching names first. Short of winning the lottery, there is no easier way to make money than to rearrange the letters of the alphabet to produce a catchy domain name that a willing corporation can turn into a brand.

The word "dot.com" has already passed into the language as a superior kind of internet company, not to be confused with your common or garden dot.co. As a result practically all of the dot.com names have been bought up by companies or cyber-squatters planning to turn words into title deeds with the intention of selling them on at a fat profit. Recently, speculators have also moved into country domain names as a source of cyber fortunes. The suffix ".it" may not mean much in its native Italy, but it offers countless combinations - from buy.it to wap.it - that English-speaking companies would die for.

Although the new domain names have not yet been agreed, it is likely that suffixes such as "dot.travel" will be made available. A domain name such as Global.travel could thus be worth a lot of money. But what would be the fairest way of allocating it? If it was announced that dot.travel would become available at midnight on a certain day, computers around the world would be programmed to hit the site on the stroke of midnight triggering an unseemly free-for-all with an unfair advantage for the fastest access. There could be an auction (such as the recent one for radio spectrum that netted over £22bn) in which obvious combinations are posted on the internet before bidding begins. Either way, it will give new meaning to the value of words.

webTitle: Rights and wrongs of the Ilisu dam

fields.headline: Rights and wrongs of the Ilisu dam
fields.trailText: You report the claim by the international development select committee that the Foreign Office did not raise the effect of the Ilisu dam on human rights, in particular resettlement of the local population (Turkish dam funding condemned, July 13).
fields.body:
You report the claim by the international development select committee that the Foreign Office did not raise the effect of the Ilisu dam on human rights, in particular resettlement of the local population (Turkish dam funding condemned, July 13). This is simply untrue. Since spring of last year we have raised the significance of this project for government policy on the environment and human rights. Since last summer we have fully contributed to the development of the government's conditions for this project.

Our first concern was that any resettlement plan must meet international standards and reflect thorough public consultation. The four tough conditions for the project announced by Stephen Byers last december include precisely those requirements on resettlement. Far from demonstrating the lack of consultation which the select committee alleges, the conditions underline the high degree of consultation with the Foreign Office.

Robin Cook MP
Foreign secretary

 The scandal over the Labour government's plan to give export credit for the Ilisu dam in Turkey may indeed echo that of the Pergau dam under the Tory government in sacrificing the interests of local people for commercial and political considerations. I went to the Kurdish region of Turkey six weeks ago with two other MEPs, including a visit to Hasankeyf, which would be flooded by the dam. We were shadowed all the while by security police. It was clear to us that the Turkish government's dam projects could not be dissociated from the continued repression of the Kurds and denial of their political and cultural rights.

The British government should cease to deal with Turkey in the perspective only of its strategic position in Nato and its attraction as an export market. All EU member states and institutions must encourage and press Turkey to speed up its progress towards European standards on human rights, the rule of law and protection of minorities, which must imply a peaceful settlement with the Kurds, recognising and respecting their identity and their human and civic rights.

Sarah Ludford MEP
sludford@europarl.eu.int

fields.headline: The Holocaust's divided legacy
fields.trailText: As the publisher of Norman Finkelstein's The Holocaust Industry, I am dismayed at Jonathan Freedland's article (An enemy of the people, July 14).
fields.body:
As the publisher of Norman Finkelstein's The Holocaust Industry, I am dismayed at Jonathan Freedland's article (An enemy of the people, July 14). He seems not to disagree with any of the significant arguments in the book, but insists they have all been made previously. He is quite wrong: Finkelstein's explanation for the comparatively recent adoption of the Holocaust as a major issue by American Jewish leaders has never been made before and his research on the misappropriation of Holocaust compensation is both new and shocking.

Freedland's primary criticism is that the tone of the book implies a hostile attitude towards the Jews and that Finkelstein, a Jew whose parents were survivors of the Nazi camps, is self-hating. Freedland repeatedly suggests similarities between Finkelstein's outlook and that of Holocaust denier David Irving.

These claims are crudely insulting of a writer who has displayed great courage in raising difficult questions about the policies of Jewish leaders and their detrimental effect on the wider Jewish community. Hannah Arendt, in the storm prompted by the publication of her book Eichmann In Jerusalem, was defended by Gershom Scholem as someone who loved the Jews. Arendt declined this defence pointing out that whilst she loved her friends and family she could not possibly love an entire people. Freedland's requirement that Finkelstein waves a flag of affection for all Jews draws on the same reasoning as anti-Semites who preach hatred against them.

Colin Robinson
Verso

 Even the most uninformed reader should be able to recognise the tell-tale signs of demagoguery in Finkelstein's wild rhetoric, quotations out of context, and the mixture of trivial and significant detail jumbled together.

But why should the Guardian showcase this bit of American vulgar sensationalism just when your own Imperial War Museum has opened an impressive Holocaust wing and days before the opening of the conference Remembering for the Future? The ill-considered outburst you chose to print only reinforces my sense as an American of a certain British obtuseness when it comes to Jewish matters.

Prof Froma I Zeitlin
Director of Jewish Studies,
Princeton University
fiz@princeton.edu

 If the Holocaust is not being treated as a sacred mystery and a unique historical event, why would states such as the US and UK, which took no part in perpetrating this crime create memorials, museums and commemorative occasions for it while neglecting atrocities in their own histories, such as the genocide of the native Americans and aboriginal Australians and the enslavement of Africans, not to mention the insistence of the US in the 80s on continuing to recognise Pol Pot's government long after it became known that it had slaughtered 2m Cambodians?

Dr Riadh Abed
Sheffield
abed@globalnet.co.uk

 There is no such thing as a "Holocaust industry". There are only good men and women working hard to educate the public about the Holocaust, so that its horrors shall never be experienced again. These same people are also struggling to provide some measure of justice both to ageing Holocaust survivors and non-Jewish victims against whom the Nazis committed the greatest robbery in the history of mankind. Just one example: Estelle Sapir promised her father before he perished at a concentration camp that she would recover money he deposited at a Swiss bank. Ms Sapir struggled for over 50 years to keep her promise and, in May 1999, finally received the return of her father's funds. Finkelstein aims to shock rather than provide accurate information about the struggle to have corporate wrongdoers disgorge the billions in profits they earned from the suffering of others.

Prof Michael Bazyler
Whittier Law School, USA

 As a Dutch gentile, I helped Jews escape occupied Holland until I had to as well. My mother suffered months in prison as a hostage for the Nazis' failure to capture me.

Three points in support of Finkelstein. Many gentiles suffered as much as Jews, as resisters and as slave labourers. Second, most survivors were compensated shortly after war's end, though no doubt inadequately. The third is the most important. Survivors built new lives for themselves, pulling themselves up by their own bootstraps. It is an insult to those who did so, like my Jewish foster brother, to moan about compensation 60 years later. They confuse money with justice and morality.

Herman Friedhoff
Westcote Barton, Oxon

 The Holocaust Industry contains a number of inaccuracies on the work of the Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany. The Claims Conference has allocated hundreds of millions of dollars to institutions that provide essential social services to survivors of the Shoah. In 1999 alone, in just the former Soviet Union, the Claims Conference funded a programme through which more than 805,000 food packages were delivered and more than 3m hot meals were served. Grants provided nearly 71,000 Nazi victims with fuel to maintain adequate heat through the winter, or with extra blankets, and provided more than 100,000 medical consultations

Ben Helfgott
45 Aid Society

fields.headline: Culture clash
fields.trailText: It would be a relief to think that James Meek's piece on television was only a joke (Campaign now for bad TV, Saturday Reviw, July 15).
fields.body:
It would be a relief to think that James Meek's piece on television was only a joke (Campaign now for bad TV, Saturday Reviw, July 15). If majority television programming sank even lower that would not increase the audiences for books. It would tighten the hold of the commercial, profit-before-everything, tycoons on 85% of the population. Many of the remainder would be confirmed in their sense of superiority and be glad to pull the cultural drawbridge even higher.

The public service principle in British broadcasting has sought to illustrate, at all levels and to all of us, that the world is wider and deeper and richer than we habitually assume. If we fail to understand these things we really will sink even faster into a dumbed-down and divided society. James Meek has not thought other than shallowly about the nature of British modern culture.

Richard Hoggart
Farnham, Surrey

fields.headline: Price check
fields.trailText: In your assessment of the government's annual report (The rhetoric and the reality, July 14), you say that "inflation is still higher than many EU countries".
fields.body:
In your assessment of the government's annual report (The rhetoric and the reality, July 14), you say that "inflation is still higher than many EU countries". If you look at the harmonised index of consumer prices measure of inflation (the standardised EU measure) we have the lowest inflation of any EU country, at 0.5% compared to an EU average of 1.7%. These figures are in the latest consumer prices press release produced by the Office for National Statistics. Also, you say that the number waiting more than 13 weeks for an outpatient appointment, 496,000, doubled since the government came to power. fields.headline: Vivian Bullwinkel
fields.standfirst: Australian nursing sister who was sole survivor of wartime massacre
fields.trailText: At Radjik Beach on Banka Island in the Straits of Sumatra is a plaque marking one of the second world war's atrocities, which might have passed unrecorded but for the determination of its sole survivor.
fields.body:
At Radjik Beach on Banka Island in the Straits of Sumatra is a plaque marking one of the second world war's atrocities, which might have passed unrecorded but for the determination of its sole survivor.

The memorial lists the names of more than 40 nurses who died, including the 21 women who were murdered by Japanese soldiers, machine-gunned in the back on February 16 1942.

Sister Vivian Bullwinkel, who had only recently joined the Australian Army Nursing Service and been posted to Singapore, was the only one of the group to live. "I was towards the end of the line and the bullet that hit me struck me at the waist and just went straight through."

She told the War Crimes Tribunal in Tokyo in 1946 that she had been washed ashore and lay in the sand playing dead for 10 minutes. "All was quiet and then I got up. The Japanese had all disappeared."

Bullwinkel, who has died of a heart attack aged 84, went on to spend three and a half years as a prisoner of war at Palemberg, Sumatra, with other nurses and civilians. She knew that if the Japanese discovered that she was a survivor of the massacre, she would be executed. The Palemberg camp was the basis of Bruce Beresford's 1997 film Paradise Road, starring Glenn Close.

Vivian rarely spoke in detail of the slaughter at Banka Island, but she always epitomised the sacrifice of the wartime nurses and the role of women in that war in her work. She never claimed to be a heroine: others proclaimed that.

Vivian's survival was said to have come as little surprise to those who knew her. After successful school days in outback Broken Hill, where she excelled at sport and became known by the nickname "Bully" which stuck with her for life, she began nursing.

In August 1941 she enlisted with the Australian army's nursing service and was dispatched to Singapore, where she was posted to the 13th Australian General Hospital during the fall of the city to the Japanese. She was one of more than 300 people, including civilians and nurses, who crowded aboard the overloaded coastal freighter Vyner Brooke, which slipped out of Singapore harbour just before the city finally surrendered in February 1942.

Two days later, its dash to Australia ended after the small ship was spotted and bombed by Japanese planes. Most of the survivors clung to wreckage and reached land, where they were captured by the Japanese.

Sister Bullwinkel and 21 other nurses came ashore with 25 British soldiers on Banka Island. The locals urged them to give themselves up to the occupying forces and a merchant navy officer from the ship went off to surrender to the Japanese.

The official history of the incident says that he returned with a party of 15 Japanese soldiers who took the British soldiers, some of whom were badly wounded, around the headland and, without warning, shot them and finished off the job with bayonets. A few still lived, and although none of them survived the war, they told fellow POWs what had happened.

The Japanese then ordered the nurses to wade into the water, before opening fire. "When I was hit I remember thinking. 'It's like the kick of a mule'," Vivian Bullwinkel recalled in 1983. Soon after struggling ashore, she teamed up with a badly wounded British soldier who had survived the massacre, and cared for him. She knew him only as Private Kingsley; for 12 days they hid out in the jungle with the help of villagers. Realising that they might starve to death, they surrendered to the Japanese and both were interned. Kingsley died of his wounds a few days later.

Bullwinkel spent the rest of the war in the Palemberg camp, where she nursed POWs and civilians under appalling conditions and without any basic medicines. She said later that her nurse's training had enabled her to survive the camp. "We were self-reliant people. We certainly had not had any training before we went to war... but we went along and learned how to stay alive," she said.

After the war Sister Bullwinkel, who became Vivian Statham after her 1977 marriage, remained in nursing. In 1975, at a day's notice, she led a team of nurses to Vietnam to recover 80 orphaned babies and children and bring them back to adoptive homes in Australia.

In 1993, in retirement, she returned to Banka Island to dedicate the plaque to her comrades who had been killed; last year she donated her wartime diary to the Australian War Memorial, which already has her uniform (complete with bullet hole) on display.

Sister Bullwinkel was awarded both the Order of Australia and the MBE for her bravery.

Four surviving nurses who had been held captive with her in Palemberg camp flew from around Australia to attend her state funeral.

 Vivian Bullwinkel Statham, nurse, born December 18 1915; died July 3 2000

fields.headline: Antonio Moreira da Silva
fields.standfirst: Rio de Janeiro's loveable rogue, singer and composer of samba
fields.trailText: Always dressed in a white linen suit and panama hat, Antonio Moreira da Silva, who has died aged 98, was Rio de Janeiro's favourite  malandro (lovable rogue). Credited with the invention  of sama do breque, (break samba), in a city where the  malandro is cherished as the epitome of both Brazilian guile and bonhomie, Moreira Da Silva's image was seen as a personification of Rio itself.
fields.body:
Always dressed in a white linen suit and panama hat, Antonio Moreira da Silva, who has died aged 98, was Rio de Janeiro's favourite malandro (lovable rogue). Credited with the invention of sama do breque, (break samba), in a city where the malandro is cherished as the epitome of both Brazilian guile and bonhomie, Moreira Da Silva's image was seen as a personification of Rio itself.

In his sama do breque style, the singer uses the breaks in the melody to tell gags and make commentaries in streetwise slang. Da Silva first became famous in 1937, when he stopped the rhythm during a live performance of the song Jogo Proibido (Forbidden Game) to chat. He continued performing and recording break samba until shortly before his death.

Da Silva recorded more than 100 records, from 78rpm discs in the early 30s to his recent guesting on a young rapper's CD. His oeuvre forms a soundtrack for the malandro lifestyle, a survival manual for canny Cariocas, as the natives of Rio are known. "If you are too malandro you get caught out. I prefer people to think I'm a dupe," goes lesson number one.

Despite his samba success, da Silva kept his day job. He worked as an ambulance driver until he retired in the 50s. In the 60s, he created a performance alter-ego, "Kid Morengueira", a romantic caricature of a Rio gangster, for which he will be best remembered.

But Moreira da Silva was always a "false" malandro. In his private life he hardly drank, hardly got into scrapes and went to bed early. Perhaps this was the secret of his long life. "I was never one for the bottle. My bohemia is soup and eggs, sometimes accompanied with port," he once said.

Born into a middle class family in the Tijuca neighbourhood of Rio, da Silva as a young man was part of that circle of samba composers and singers which emerged in the 20s and 30s, and also included perhaps the greatest of the samba composers, Noel Rosa.

Despite his fame, in later years da Silva lived mostly of a meagre pension from his work as an ambulance driver; just before his death he had to be transferred from a private clinic to a public hospital because his relatives couldn't afford to pay the medical bills.

"With Moreira da Silva a piece of Rio has gone," said the modern samba composer Moacyr Luz. "He created a unique style, transforming Rio into music. Through samba he made people understand daily life in the city, the malandro, the dignity and beauty of the Carioca."

 Antonio Moreira da Silva, singer, born April 1 1902; died June 6 2000

fields.headline: Identification charade
fields.standfirst: Marcel Berlins: Writ large
fields.trailText: Marcel Berlins: Writ large
fields.body:
Yet another barrister involved in a court case has managed to keep his identity secret, courtesy of a judge but against the basic principles of our justice system. Normally, of course, anyone involved in a court action is named, from the start of the proceedings to the court's final decision. That's what open justice is about. It's especially important that a professional (or indeed any provider of goods or services) alleged or judged to have behaved negligently should be identified, in the interests of potential consumers of his or her product.

But a judge does have the power to order that a party should remain anonymous. Mr Justice Ferris did so in the recent case of Green v Hancocks. Broadly, the allegations were that a small firm of solicitors and the barrister whose advice they were following messed up a multi-million pound case on behalf of a client. The exact details don't matter. The client has now sued both the solicitors and the barrister for negligence.

The case hasn't yet reached trial, but in an interim decision the judge has ruled that the barrister should not be named. Apart from the fact that no one objected, he gave no particular reason for allowing him this rare anonymity. It could be argued that it was unfair to advertise the possibility of a lawyer's negligence before a court has actually ruled on the question; but that argument applies to just about every single claim for damages.

We do not, thank goodness, have a system of justice in which litigants are named only if and when they lose in court. The odd thing about this case is that the solicitors' firm which was sued didn't ask for its name to be withheld. Only the barrister did. So here we have two lawyers alleged not to have done their jobs properly, one of whom can be known to the wider public, the other protected.

The judge did say that lawyers had no special status over anyone else when seeking anonymity. Maybe legally that's so, but why is it that one never hears of accountants, doctors or surveyors being allowed secrecy when they're sued for negligence?

About time too. Dame Mary Arden has finally been promoted to the court of appeal, as I've been urging for as long as I can remember. Rumours that she would have got there far sooner had she not been burdened with my support are, of course, wholly inappropriate.

Anyway, her accession creates the first married couple to sit on the appeal court - her husband, Sir Jonathan Mance, got there last year. I wonder whether or not they'll be allowed to sit on the same appeal together.

It's also the first time that the court has had two women at the same time (the other is Dame Brenda Hale). OK, there are around 35 or so men, making the proportion of women a grand 6%, but that's double last week's figure.

Another promotion to the appeal court - and even cynical me believes it to be purely on merit - goes to Tony and Cherie's friend and south-west France holiday host Sir David Keene, at whose house, possibly, young Leo was conceived.

I promised to let you know the result of the lawsuit brought by the former exotic dancer Mary Gale against her New York surgeon who, you will remember, when asked to provide her with a more rounded bottom, did so by inserting ill-fitting breast implants into the relevant buttocks, thus spoiling their shape and obliging her to abandon her chosen career. Well, she won but - and it's a big butt (sorry) - instead of being awarded the usual several million dollars by the jury, she was given a mere £20,000 or so, to her great distress. Let's hope she puts the whole experience behind her.

webTitle: Anyone know what the judge is on about?

fields.headline: Anyone know what the judge is on about?
fields.standfirst: A new study reveals some unsettling facts about the secret world of the juror - they often feel intimidated, scared and confused.  Clare Dyer reports
fields.trailText: A new study reveals some unsettling facts about the secret world of the juror - they often feel intimidated, scared and confused.  Clare Dyer reports
fields.body:
What goes on behind the door to the jury room and how do 12 ordinary mortals reach the verdict which could put a fellow human being behind bars for years? Try asking them and you could face a large fine and a spell in prison yourself.

No one questions the maxim that justice must not only be done but be seen to be done. Yet an impenetrable veil of secrecy hangs over the room where the final act of the criminal justice process - the determination of guilt or innocence - is played out. Researchers are banned from questioning jurors to find out how the system works in practice and how it could be improved. The appeal court has even refused to look into what happened in the jury room when faced with a claim that some irregularity made a conviction unsafe.

Why is the jury so sacrosanct? For centuries the courts have held that the jury room must be inviolate, to make sure decisions are final and to protect jurors from pressure to explain how they came to their verdict.

In 1981, in a surprise ruling, the court of appeal acquitted the publisher of the New Statesman of contempt of court over an article by a juror in Jeremy Thorpe's trial for conspiracy to murder a former lover. The judges decided the piece posed no threat to the finality of jury verdicts or danger of pressure on future jurors. Parliament's immediate response was to pass section 8 of the Contempt of Court Act, a blanket ban on asking for or disclosing details about "statements made, opinions expressed, arguments advanced or votes cast" during jury deliberations.

In 1992 the Mail on Sunday was found guilty of contempt of court and fined £75,000 for publishing interviews with jurors in the Blue Arrow fraud trial about how they reached their verdicts.

The jury, like royalty, is an ancient institution whose survival depends largely on its mystique. In the high-flown words of the late Lord Devlin, it is "the lamp that shows that freedom lives". But the lamp must not be lit too brightly - it could show up the warts and dent public confidence.

The result is that everything we think we know about how real juries operate is the result of anecdote, conjecture and studies of mock juries.

There is pressure to remove juries from fraud cases and replace them with judges and professional assessors. Advocates of the move claim the evidence is too complex for juries to understand. Opponents argue that while the details of abstruse financial transactions may go over juries' heads, they are strong on common sense and have little trouble sussing out the key issue: did the defendant act with dishonest intent?

But now at last a window has been opened into the jury room. For the first time researchers have been able to systematically investigate how real jurors go about their job. It hasn't happened in Britain and the findings have so far gone unnoticed here. But a large-scale research project has been carried out in a criminal justice system so similar to our own that its conclusions shine an unprecedented light into the workings of our own jury system.

In New Zealand there is a convention that jurors may not be questioned about their experiences but not a blanket ban. Judicial approval was granted for the research to be carried out by a team from the Victoria University of Wellington, one of whom, Warren Young, is now deputy secretary for justice in the New Zealand ministry of justice. It was done in collaboration with the New Zealand law commission, the country's official law reform body, which is headed, like our own law commission, by a senior judge.

Jury trials in New Zealand and England follow almost identical procedures. The main difference for the purpose of the jury study is that the 11-1 or 10-2 majority verdicts - introduced in England and Wales to counter jury-nobbling - are not possible in New Zealand. Unless all 12 jurors agree, the result is a hung trial and, usually, a retrial, which means New Zealand jurors are under greater pressure to reach a unanimous verdict.

The research team followed 48 criminal trials and interviewed a total of 312 jurors, an average of 6.5 of the 12 jurors from each trial. The sample included a substantial number of high-profile cases because the researchers wanted to find out whether pre-trial publicity affected jurors' ability to reach their verdicts purely on the evidence in court. Also featured were complex fraud trials, cases with several defendants and multiple charges, drug, sex abuse and rape trials.

The findings explode some long-held myths. They show that while jurors are "overwhelmingly conscientious" in following the judge's instructions, they do have difficulty with the concept of "intent" and whether or not a defendant acted dishonestly.

The research also shows that "some jurors have particular difficulty assessing the credibility of witnesses, challenging the traditional view that juries are particularly adept at assessing credibility".

And juries have problems in fully grasping the law. In four out of the 48 trials, legal errors led to hung juries or questionable verdicts, concluded the researchers.

It was "a great deal to ask" of ordinary lawmen to take on board difficult concepts - such as the burden and standard of proof, the elements necessary to prove an offence, and rules of evidence - when they had heard them only once from the judge and were given no written record.

In 19 trials, one or more jurors misunderstood significant aspects of the ingredients of the offence. "Fairly fundamental" misunderstandings of the law emerged during deliberations in 35 of the 48 cases. Jurors were unsure about the difference between purpose and intent, and sometimes thought intent implied premeditation.

A significant number of jurors had difficulty concentrating on oral evidence, particularly in trials lasting more than two days, and problems in recalling the evidence.

Trial judges, who were also interviewed, would have reached a different verdict from the jury's in 24 of the 48 cases. But in 11 cases where judge and jury disagreed the jury's view "appeared reasonable and supportable on the evidence". In most cases, the disagreement was over the credibility of key witnesses. Of the remainder, the jury was hung in five cases.

There were five "compromise" verdicts where juries agreed to resolve their differences by convicting on some counts and acquitting on others, while the judge and researchers felt conviction was warranted on all counts. The remaining three were "perverse or questionable" verdicts, where the jury reached a unanimous decision on an erroneous basis.

In 22 cases, pressure to reach a verdict came from other members of the jury. Those on their own or in a small minority felt the worst pressure, with the pressure increasing as the other minority jurors changed their minds. In six cases jurors said feeling that time was running out or that people wanted to get home was an important factor in reaching a verdict.

Judges give standard directions to the jury when summing up, but at least some jurors did not realise these were standard. When the judge told them they could draw certain "inferences", some jurors, not knowing this was a standard direction, thought the judge was giving them hints on what the verdict should be. Others had no idea what the judge was talking about.

Jurors experienced considerable stress from serving on the jury. Some found the experience "harrowing", causing them to feel "sick to their stomachs". Some had trouble sleeping or were prone to burst into tears. Some felt they had no business sitting in judgment on their fellow citizens.

For others, the trial brought back experiences in their own lives. In one sex abuse case, four jurors disclosed their own experiences of sexual abuse, one for the first time, in the course of a "lengthy and fraught" deliberation which ended in a hung jury.

Feeling intimidated, like the juror in the trial of Tony Martin, the Norfolk farmer found guilty of murdering a burglar, is not, it seems, unusual. A number of jurors felt intimidated by being stared at by counsel, the accused and his family, and in four cases jurors felt "intimidated and scared" after the trial finished.

In an editorial headlined "Imperfect and all, juries still best", the New Zealand Herald points out that the main result is likely to be more help for juries in carrying out their difficult task.

These include more guidance for jury foremen, providing the jury with a written summary of the judge's summing up on the law, more help with flow charts and other aids in multi-defendant cases, and more encouragement to ask the judge questions - all of which would no doubt help our own juries to reach better verdicts.

fields.bodyText: What goes on behind the door to the jury room and how do 12 ordinary mortals reach the verdict which could put a fellow human being behind bars for years? Try asking them and you could face a large fine and a spell in prison yourself. No one questions the maxim that justice must not only be done but be seen to be done. Yet an impenetrable veil of secrecy hangs over the room where the final act of the criminal justice process - the determination of guilt or innocence - is played out. Researchers are banned from questioning jurors to find out how the system works in practice and how it could be improved. The appeal court has even refused to look into what happened in the jury room when faced with a claim that some irregularity made a conviction unsafe. Why is the jury so sacrosanct? For centuries the courts have held that the jury room must be inviolate, to make sure decisions are final and to protect jurors from pressure to explain how they came to their verdict. In 1981, in a surprise ruling, the court of appeal acquitted the publisher of the New Statesman of contempt of court over an article by a juror in Jeremy Thorpe's trial for conspiracy to murder a former lover. The judges decided the piece posed no threat to the finality of jury verdicts or danger of pressure on future jurors. Parliament's immediate response was to pass section 8 of the Contempt of Court Act, a blanket ban on asking for or disclosing details about "statements made, opinions expressed, arguments advanced or votes cast" during jury deliberations. In 1992 the Mail on Sunday was found guilty of contempt of court and fined £75,000 for publishing interviews with jurors in the Blue Arrow fraud trial about how they reached their verdicts. The jury, like royalty, is an ancient institution whose survival depends largely on its mystique. In the high-flown words of the late Lord Devlin, it is "the lamp that shows that freedom lives". But the lamp must not be lit too brightly - it could show up the warts and dent public confidence. Opponents argue that while the details of abstruse financial transactions may go over juries' heads, they are strong on common sense and have little trouble sussing out the key issue: did the defendant act with dishonest intent? It hasn't happened in Britain and the findings have so far gone unnoticed here. In New Zealand there is a convention that jurors may not be questioned about their experiences but not a blanket ban. It was done in collaboration with the New Zealand law commission, the country's official law reform body, which is headed, like our own law commission, by a senior judge. Jury trials in New Zealand and England follow almost identical procedures. The main difference for the purpose of the jury study is that the 11-1 or 10-2 majority verdicts - introduced in England and Wales to counter jury-nobbling - are not possible in New Zealand. Unless all 12 jurors agree, the result is a hung trial and, usually, a retrial, which means New Zealand jurors are under greater pressure to reach a unanimous verdict. Of the remainder, the jury was hung in five cases. There were five "compromise" verdicts where juries agreed to resolve their differences by convicting on some counts and acquitting on others, while the judge and researchers felt conviction was warranted on all counts. The remaining three were "perverse or questionable" verdicts, where the jury reached a unanimous decision on an erroneous basis. fields.headline: Love in a hot climate
fields.standfirst: US marine falls for Arab princess and smuggles her out of Bahrain to get married ... it must be a movie script, right? Not yet. But as Hollywood's directors queue up to get their hands on the story, the real-life couple awaits the decision today that will seal their fate.  Duncan Campbell reports
fields.trailText: US marine falls for Arab princess and smuggles her out of Bahrain to get married ... it must be a movie script, right? Not yet. But as Hollywood's directors queue up to get their hands on the story, the real-life couple awaits the decision today that will seal their fate. Duncan Campbell reports.
fields.body:
It had everything a film studio could dream of: a clean-cut hero and an exotic heroine, love across the divide, a great escape, desert sands and sinister foreigners. It was Romeo and Juliet meets Desert Storm. It was Runaway Bride meets Lawrence of Arabia. It even has a cliff-hanger ending which is due to unravel today.

He was a clean-cut 25-year-old US marine lieutenant corporal called Jason Johnson serving with the US Navy Fifth Fleet. She was a 19-year-old Bahraini princess called Merian Al-Khalifa who had taught herself English. When their eyes met in a shopping mall in Manama, the capital of the Gulf state Bahrain, last year it was love in a hot climate. Her family discovered the courtship and she was confined to her home, but continued the romance by telephone. Then, finally, the couple decided to flee and make their lives together in the US. It may sound like a treatment for a movie but this one is - more or less - true.

Johnson had used his marine issue, night-vision goggles to suss out security at the airport and discovered that while Bahraini citizens had to show a passport when boarding a plane to leave the country, US marines did not. He forged papers for Al-Khalifa so that she would appear to be a member of the marine corps. Then as the time for departure approached, he got his beloved kitted out in sloppy, baggy American clothes. She hid her long hair under a New York Yankees baseball cap and, last November, they boarded a commercial flight from Bahrain to O'Hare airport in Chicago.

There the hoax was discovered by immigration officials who wanted to deport her immediately as an illegal immigrant. She asked for asylum, claiming that if she returned to Bahrain her life would be in danger. She was eventually paroled into the US, granted a hearing and allowed to remain in the country while a decision was made. After being released by the immigration service, the INS, the princess married the marine in Johnson's home town of Las Vegas. Johnson, the son of a cement truck driver, was duly demoted to the rank of private for bringing an illegal immigrant into the country but is still serving at his unit in Camp Pendleton in southern California, where the couple now live on base.

Today they are due to attend a private hearing with the INS in San Diego, where a decision will be made as to whether or not Al-Khalifa is allowed to stay. Even though she is now married to a US citizen, she still entered the country illegally, the INS will argue. Technically, this means that she could be deported and could then apply to enter either from her home country or another country of her choice.

From the time of their arrival last November until last month, the world was unaware of the couple's story. But when a date was set for the immigration hearing, Johnson decided they needed the media on their side. As decision day approached, so interest increased, although Al-Khalifa has been reluctant to talk to the British press because she believes her family is more likely to see British newspapers and does not want to offend them.

"I did the worst thing possible in my country," she said in one interview. "I fell in love with a non-Muslim. I've ruined the reputation of my family." She said the fact that Johnson was an American only made matters worse. As the daughter of Sheik Abdullah Al-Khalifa, who is the cousin of the head of state, Emir Hamad bin Isa Al-Khalifa, she is part of the ruling elite. For her to marry a non-Muslim and elope to, of all places, Las Vegas, is obviously something of an embarrassment. But is it more than that?

"They'll kill her if she ever returns," Johnson has been quoted as saying. Although there is no suggestion that her family would lift a finger against her, he believes that fundamentalist clerics could threaten her life. Johnson's own family has made sympathetic and supportive noises about the couple while saying they understand how their daughter-in-law's family might well have been upset by her sudden departure.

While the elopement has become big news in the US, it has had minimal coverage in the Middle East. "The Arab press are treating it as something which should be hushed up, or mentioned only as a matter of shame and indignation," says the veteran Arab journalist Abdullah Homouda. "She is considered a disgrace to the family and a political embarrassment."

The Palestinian newspaper, al-Quds, published the story on its back page, with a picture. One of the paper's journalists, who asked not to be named, says: "We didn't see it as a sensational story in the usual way of the American media. We approached it with a different perspective to show that although the Gulf royals are conservative they are not immune to change. The new generation of royals have studied abroad and have been exposed to western views and values.

"We did a similar story a year ago when a princess from the same family discovered she was a lesbian and found friends on the internet. She sought asylum in Britain and changed her identity. We tried to show the impact of the internet on Gulf society."

As the couple fight for the princess's right to stay, the story has also entered the political arena in the US: one of California's two senators, Barbara Boxer, has indicated that she will back the couple's wishes and is due to appear at a press conference today at the time of the INS hearing. She has written a letter supporting the couple and parallels are being drawn with the Cuban Elian Gonzalez case - although so far no public figure has suggested that Al-Khalifa should be sent back to her family. This is a story where everyone wants to be on the happy-ever-after side. Al-Khalifa speaks good English and has been described in the American press as "sounding like Posh Spice".

The story also has implications for the US military, which is particularly sensitive to public opinion because of its recruitment problems. Johnson offended many of his fellow "grunts" and "leathernecks" by saying that his love for his wife comes before his love for the marines. He has been harassed on the camp, where the couple live modestly. She is supposedly discovering the joys of housework. His superiors have publicly allied to support him - the marines do not want to be seen as the bad guys.

As attention focuses on today's hearing, a skilful operation to ensure that the tale receives maximum coverage and makes it to the movie screens has been taking place. A key player in this is Tom Colbert, the president of Industry Research and Development, a company that promotes stories produced in local newspapers by placing them on television and in national newspapers and magazines. He has 45 clients and has handled 6,000 stories since starting up nine years ago. Twenty-one of them have become films, but this one is different.

"I knew it was a gem," said Colbert, who is based in Calabasas in the San Fernando Valley. "It was the Persian Gulf Elian [Gonzalez] story, the biggest story we've ever had." The news item had come out in "dead time" on a Friday evening and no one had followed it up. Colbert decided to track down the couple and found them after calls to 22 Johnsons in the southern California telephone directory. He explained that he could help them. "I said they were about to be in the middle of a firestorm."

He said he had to make sure they could both handle the pressure before he pressed the button, and decided that the princess was well equipped - "she's a sweet gal and she's very smart" - so he went ahead. "They are very much in love," he added.

Colbert then contacted a Beverly Hills associate, Mary Aloe of Proud Mary Entertainment - an independent production company - and told her the story. She wasted no time in meeting the couple and signing up the film rights. Colbert then started planting stories in the press "to fuel the interest" in the film and see if any backers would come out. Already potential directors, writers and producers have emerged. A firm offer for the rights has just been made by Howard Braunstein, who is currently remaking South Pacific with Glenn Close in Australia.

"I fell in love with them," said Aloe. "They are an awesome couple. Their story has everything. It's a thriller and there could be three different endings. They could live happily ever after and find out that her family secretly supported her. Or she could be sent back and he has to let her go. Or she's an independent young woman who realises she loves Jason but now that she's in America she wants to move on." Colbert adds: "no matter what the ending, it's still a movie."

So is it being cast already? Aloe thought Brad Pitt was "a bit too laid back... Jason is a real John Wayne character, a young Steve McQueen all-American renegade, completely without fear." Freddy Prinze Jr has already been suggested and Aloe says they want at least one big star, probably male. For the princess, Selma Hayek has already been mentioned and Aloe reckons that Shannon Elizabeth from American Pie would be ideal.

There will be other attractions for Hollywood than the story itself. It has a potential villain in the shape of cold-hearted Arab clerics wanting the love-struck young woman to return to face punishment. So far the Bahrainis are not playing their part quite right. A statement issued by the Bahrain Embassy in Washington indicated that her family would love her to come home and there would be no punishments or reprisals. Arabs, along with Britons, Germans and Russians, remain popular stock villains in Hollywood so this part of the tale may have to be altered. Arab-Americans have fought a long battle to try to educate their fellow countrymen away from the stereotypical views they hold of Arabs and the Muslim world.

The appetite for "real life" film and television reconstruction remains undimmed. Recent subjects have included Elian Gonzalez (the first television drama appears at the end of this month)and Linda McCartney, while a bundle of recent films - from Erin Brockovich and The Insider to The Hurricane and Boys Don't Cry - have alerted studios to the strength of the genre. As one screenwriter responsible for an Oscar-winning film says: "It's now easier to write a piece for Rolling Stone and then show that to a studio executive than to take in the original idea and pitch it."

Usually a script doctor is brought in if the studio is uncertain about the right ending. Today that task falls to US officials, who will meet in private session in San Diego to decide whether it will be a happy or sad one for the young lovers.

fields.headline: Viaduct view
fields.standfirst: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: A Country Diary
fields.body:
Old Westmorland

At the "back" of the Howgills and just to the west of Kirkby Stephen the Scandal Beck has carved a two-mile gorge through wooded, limestone crags to create the remarkable, little valley of Smardale. Remarkable because of the two massive viaducts that span its narrow gorge and also for the wealth of wild flowers and butterflies that may be found there.

The northern viaduct carries the Carlisle to Settle railway but the other crossing, Smardale Gill viaduct, is on the line of the now disused railway that used to carry coke from the Durham coalfields to Barrow-in-Furness for smelting the haematite iron ore found in those parts. This made possible the establishment of shipbuilding in the new town in the middle of the 19th-century - and the start of the iron-clad era.

Nowadays, the dismantled railway is owned by the Cumbria Wildlife Trust and Smardale has become a national nature reserve. An undemanding round of perhaps six miles north from Ravenstonedale takes you into Smardale, across the impos ing viaduct with its 14 arches about 100 feet high, and along the line of the dismantled railway, more crowded with wild flowers than anywhere else I have ever seen. And butterflies of every colour. The other day, blustery with racing clouds, we had another look at the place and were again amazed at the skill, ingenuity and courage of the workmen, working without modern equipment, who manhandled these enormous blocks into position 140 years ago.

But we were a little disappointed by the flowers along the old railway line. They were interesting, colourful, varied and the best collection we'd seen for some time - but not sensational. Perhaps we were several weeks too soon for I see from my diary that they were almost unbelievably lovely on August 21st two years ago. As you walk back to Ravenstonedale you see, straight ahead, Green Bell, where the River Lune is supposed to have its source. But nearby Newbiggin-on-Lune claims that its own St Helen's Well, which never dries up, is the real source.

The Coniston Tigers - Published by Sigma Press
fields.bodyText: Old Westmorland At the "back" of the Howgills and just to the west of Kirkby Stephen the Scandal Beck has carved a two-mile gorge through wooded, limestone crags to create the remarkable, little valley of Smardale. Remarkable because of the two massive viaducts that span its narrow gorge and also for the wealth of wild flowers and butterflies that may be found there. The northern viaduct carries the Carlisle to Settle railway but the other crossing, Smardale Gill viaduct, is on the line of the now disused railway that used to carry coke from the Durham coalfields to Barrow-in-Furness for smelting the haematite iron ore found in those parts. This made possible the establishment of shipbuilding in the new town in the middle of the 19th-century - and the start of the iron-clad era. Nowadays, the dismantled railway is owned by the Cumbria Wildlife Trust and Smardale has become a national nature reserve. An undemanding round of perhaps six miles north from Ravenstonedale takes you into Smardale, across the impos ing viaduct with its 14 arches about 100 feet high, and along the line of the dismantled railway, more crowded with wild flowers than anywhere else I have ever seen. And butterflies of every colour. The other day, blustery with racing clouds, we had another look at the place and were again amazed at the skill, ingenuity and courage of the workmen, working without modern equipment, who manhandled these enormous blocks into position 140 years ago. But we were a little disappointed by the flowers along the old railway line. They were interesting, colourful, varied and the best collection we'd seen for some time - but not sensational. Perhaps we were several weeks too soon for I see from my diary that they were almost unbelievably lovely on August 21st two years ago. As you walk back to Ravenstonedale you see, straight ahead, Green Bell, where the River Lune is supposed to have its source. But nearby Newbiggin-on-Lune claims that its own St Helen's Well, which never dries up, is the real source. The Coniston Tigers - Published by Sigma Press

fields.headline: No: 1378
fields.standfirst: Not Oscar Wilde
fields.trailText: Not Oscar Wilde
fields.body:
Age: Alive in 1906, unlike Oscar Fingal O'Flahertie Wills Wilde, who had died six years earlier.

Status: Not a playwright, poet, wit, dandy, aphorist, aesthete, or writer of genius.

Sex: Indeed.

Appearance: Fleshy, full-lipped, with flowing hair, and wearing a long skirt, bejewelled brassiere and leather belt. Not dissimilar in face and build to the great man. But look a little closer.

I'm looking. I'm sure I've seen that photograph somewhere before. I've got it. It's in Richard Ellmann's biography of Wilde. It's definitely him. Ellmann certainly thought so and published the photograph in his great book on Wilde in 1987. But the camera can sometimes lie.

You mean ... ? The picture of an Egyptian princess in bondage gear salivating over the severed head of John the Baptist was supposed to be Wilde as Salome in a production of his play in 1893. But it isn't.

A fake? Not exactly. This tubbily elegant Salome bears an uncanny resemblance to Wilde, and it was almost universally accepted as real. Ellmann used the photograph to pinpoint Wilde's suppressed homosexuality and veiled transvestism as the key to his character. If it isn't him, why should we trust the theory?

So who is it? The Marquess of Queensberry? It's a real woman, oddly enough - the Hungarian soprano Alice Guszalewicz, who played Salome in the Richard Strauss opera based on Wilde's play in Cologne in 1906. Her picture was put in the wrong folder in the Roger Viollet archive in Paris, and a sub-genre of Wildean studies was born.

Not to be confused with: Not Aubrey Beardsley, not Dante Gabriel Rossetti, not George Bernard Shaw.

Do say: "How marvellous to see Pass Notes eschewing schoolboy humour and engaging in some proper literary revisionism."

Don't say: "I have nothing to declare except my sparkly bra, fishnet stockings and rhinestone suspender belt."

fields.headline: Wintour warmer
fields.standfirst: As the editor of American Vogue she is the most powerful and feared woman in fashion. But, says Alexander Chancellor, Anna Wintour has shed the ever-present sunglasses and revealed a mellower side to her character
fields.trailText: As the editor of American Vogue she is the most powerful and feared woman in fashion. But, says Alexander Chancellor, Anna Wintour has shed the ever-present sunglasses and revealed a mellower side to her character
fields.body:
The popular image of Anna Wintour is of a cold and terrifying woman. She is often referred to as an "ice queen" - or, more imaginatively, as "nuclear Wintour". At the offices of Vogue in New York, where she has reigned now for 12 years, the junior members of staff tremble in her presence and lose the gift of speech. What is it about Anna Wintour that frightens them so much? According to her friends (and she has many), her character, which is fundamentally amiable, is not to blame. She doesn't do horrible things to people. She isn't even rude to them. As a human being, she is probably less scary than Janet Street-Porter.

But she is very powerful, and that is frightening in itself. Tonight's television documentary about her, in BBC1's Boss Women series, opens with the line: "Anna Wintour is recognised as the most powerful woman in fashion." And this may be true. But her real power resides in her position as the editor of the most profitable magazine in all of the vast Condé Nast publishing empire, which includes Vanity Fair and The New Yorker in America and several publications over here, including Tatler and British Vogue.

Under Wintour, Vogue sells 1.2m copies a month and earns around £100m a year in advertising revenue. It makes by far the largest contribution to Condé Nast's profits, and its multibillionaire chairman, SI Newhouse, is appropriately grateful. It is often alleged that "Si", as he is always called, is slightly in love with Wintour. He was also possibly slightly in love with Tina Brown when she edited Vanity Fair and the New Yorker, although she brought him prestige rather than profits in those jobs. But since Tina abandoned him to start a new magazine, Talk, for the Disney Corporation, Wintour has had no rival for his affection.

Despite the apparent informality of US magazine offices, and the casual use of the first name in all conversations, employees are generally more respectful of hierarchy than they are in Britain. And Wintour, with the assured backing of the all-powerful Newhouse, is worthy of the utmost respect.

On top of that, she has become a huge New York celebrity. The cult of the writer has been replaced by the cult of the editor. People ask for Wintour's autograph in restaurants. Newhouse encourages his editors to behave more like Hollywood studio bosses than the unglamorous drudges they used to be.

Another explanation for Wintour's reputation for coldness could perhaps simply be that she is shy. Her father Charles Wintour, a celebrated editor of the Evening Standard who died last year, was sometimes known, according to Wintour herself, as "Chilly Charlie", and possibly for the same reason. When she was young, before she started wearing dark glasses all the time, she covered as much of her face as possible with a fringe.

A colleague of hers insists that Wintour is not a self-publicist, and that even her dark glasses are not an affectation but are prescribed by an optician to protect her from eye strain. (An editor of Vogue has to spend a lot of time looking at light shows.)

It is noteworthy that in tonight's television documentary she is without her dark glasses for most of the time. This new readiness to cast off their protection and reveal her face to the world has been attributed by some people to her new relationship with Shelby Bryan, a Texas cell-phone millionaire, for whom she has left her husband of many years, the child psychiatrist David Shaffer. They say that the ice queen has finally found romance.

But whether she has found romance or not, she certainly hasn't allowed it to affect her hard-headed approach to her job. Although on Boss Women she says that Vogue aims to give people "something to dream about", this would not appear to be its principal mission. Other fashion magazines, like Harper's Bazaar in New York or even British Vogue in London, do this better.

Wintour's magazine, more successful than either of them, is thoroughly down to earth and practical. Its business is to sell as many copies as possible and to maximise its advertising revenue. This is not achieved by being too imaginative or original. In a lecture in London to the organisation Women in Journalism two years ago, Wintour explained how nearly 25 years of working in New York had weaned her from British creative self-indulgence.

She said she had come to accept that readers preferred "healthy, smiling, energetic girls" to "sad, sick or strange ones". She had also come to recognise the necessity of pleasing advertisers. "If you don't acknowledge your magazine's advertisers, you don't have a magazine," she said.

In an interview last year with New York Magazine, where she got her first job as a fashion editor in the early 1980s, Wintour again made her position clear. "Commercial is not a dirty word to me," she said, adding that in a toss-up between promoting one fashion product or another, she would not hesitate to choose the one of a Vogue advertiser.

Vogue has been through some difficult patches under Wintour, one of the worst being the recent defection of Kate Betts, her trusted chief lieutenant and heir apparent, to become editor of Harper's Bazaar. But Vogue still towers above its traditional rival.

At Vogue, Kate Betts urged Wintour to make the magazine "hipper", to make it "go into the street, cover hip-hop, pop culture and the internet", says New York Magazine. But Wintour resisted, and it looks like she was right. Betts's efforts to steer Harper's towards hipness have yet to be crowned with commercial success. Meanwhile, Wintour has been consistently magnanimous in her public comments on her friend's desertion.

So Vogue sails majestically on, the undisputed flagship of the £100bn American fashion industry, with Wintour's position still seemingly secure as she continues to bask in the favour of the often fickle Newhouse. "I can't think of anything that could give me so much pleasure [as editing Vogue]," she says at the end of tonight's documentary.

Although she and Tina Brown are frequently bracketed together as the two British queens of US journalism, they could not in fact be more different. Now into her fourth editorship since she shook up the Tatler in London 20 years ago, Brown, unlike Wintour, started out as a writer and still apparently hankers after the role.

At a party she gave in New York last month for the launch of Martin Amis's memoir, Experience, Brown told a reporter from the New York Observer: "In my next incarnation, whatever that may be, in my fifth act, I'm going to be a really irresponsible writing journalist. I will write what the hell I want to write. And let 'em publish it as far as I'm concerned, because I've spent the last 10 or 15 years deciding whether something is right to run or not, and I would think it's my time to break out of the box."

Wintour, on the other hand, seems happy in her box. As a woman who has always wanted to be in fashion and has reached the peak, why should she ever want to leave it?

Boss Woman is on BBC1 tonight at 10.40pm

fields.headline: Dinner ladies
fields.standfirst: The age of dissent: Michele Hanson
fields.trailText: The age of dissent: Michele Hanson
fields.body:
On Wednesday I drove my mother to her distant bridge club, wrecking my day. I am prepared to drive for hours out into the backwoods because my mother is desperate for an outing. One more day stuck in the house and she will blow a fuse. I drive home, then back to get her, then back home again. I am a real saint.

"Did you have a good time?" I ask my mother on our return.

"No!" she shouts. "That X gets on my bloody nerves!" Why did I bother with the marathon drive? Why is my Mother not grateful and polite, like Rosemary's Auntie? Auntie would never dream of criticising anyone or anything in such a way. Last month she was grateful and polite in hospital. Unfortunately, she couldn't stretch her injured arm out, reach her food or get it into her mouth, but she was much too polite to bother the nurses. Rosemary was worried she might starve to death in there.

"Why don't you feed her?" I asked. "Because Auntie doesn't want to be spoonfed," said Rosemary. "It's too humiliating." At least that's what everybody thought Auntie thought. Rosemary was too polite to shove spoonfuls of dinner into Auntie's mouth, the nurses weren't spooning in dinner because they didn't have time and nobody asked them to, and if they asked Auntie why she'd hardly eaten a crumb, she would say very politely that she'd had quite enough, thank you.

Anyway, she wasn't very keen on hospital dinners. They weren't worth fighting for and the delicious little snacks her family brought were often lost or spilt in the hospital fridge because none of the visitors liked to shove them into Auntie's mouth. They were all busy pussyfooting around her sensitivities.

Why couldn't everyone be more forthright? Perhaps my mother's method has something to be said for it. I'm beginning to feel like my mother. I want to rush up to the hospital with a big bowl of delicious and nourishing stew, waft it under Auntie's nose and say: "Now look here, Auntie, we know you can't reach your dinner and you're embarrassed about being spoonfed, but it's only till your arm's better, so get this down you!"

Rosemary wouldn't dare speak to her Auntie like that, but I think I know someone who could manage it. It's about time my mother had another outing.

fields.headline: Mummy's girls
fields.standfirst: Luisa Dillner on why all women sooner or later turn into their mothers
fields.trailText: Luisa Dillner on why all women sooner or later turn into their mothers
fields.body:
Sarah Ferguson may not have been invited to the Queen Mother's 100th birthday bash at St Paul's last week but she was there all right, in the form of two miniature replicas of her Ferginess. Newspaper pictures of her daughters show Beatrice (11) with long reddish hair, hand up in ya-ish salutation, smiling broadly, while Eugenie (eight) yawns. Both were apparently irrepressible, curtseying more than was strictly necessary.

Now where did they get that from? If ever one person's genes wiped the floor with another's, it was when Sarah's eggs met Andrew's sperm. These girls haven't waited until their 30s to become their mother, they've got there before puberty.

It was Oscar Wilde who said: "All women become like their mothers. That is their tragedy." Men have translated this into the ultimate insult: "You're getting just like your mother." While they often claim they are chuffed to be getting like their fathers ("He was quite a good bloke," they'll say, even if they hardly knew him), for women the issue is more complex. We may love our mothers but we don't want to become them. Maybe we just don't want to be older women, dyeing away the grey as we saw our mothers do before us. Maybe we think "getting like your mother" is a euphemism for getting fatter, more wrinkled, less desirable.

To be accused (for that's what it is) of being like our mothers makes us think of all the annoying things our mothers do or did, their irritating gestures, and wonder whether we're doing them now. Biologically, we are likely to reach menopause at the same age our mother did. Are we similarly programmed to assume her mannerisms? Will the combined forces of nature and nurture make us unable to find our glasses, fall asleep after one glass of wine, lose our way in shopping malls?

Tell a woman she looks like her mother and she is unlikely to take it as a compliment. Tell her she is behaving like her and she may be inconsolable. "Do you think you're getting like your mother?" I ask a friend in her 30s. There's a screech down the phone. "How can you ask me that? My mother is dysfunctional. She is the world's worst for being negative. I have to work hard not to have a negative mindset. And she has no self-awareness. It's made me so deeply aware that I examine myself in minute detail on a daily basis to make sure none of her character flaws is seeping through."

These "character flaws" are intolerance and being a blame-thrower of Olympic standard. Both have a generational component. Our mothers are likely to be less assertive than we are, slightly more dependent and vulnerable. They were probably mothers in the more traditional sense, choosing children over career, marriage over serial monogamy. How can we bear to think we're getting more like our mothers when we've spent most of our lives trying to rise above them?

Our relationship with her goes through stages, from unconditional childish love, to unconditional teenage hate, to genuine appreciation if you become a mother yourself. "What I do with my child is what my mother did with me," says another friend. "I sing the same songs, comfort him in the same way. I mother like my mother did because I don't know any other way. In that way, I'm more like her than I ever have been."

I ask my partner if I'm getting like my mother and he says no. But I can't hide from the facts. I have her bunions, overspend at Christmas, my hair tends to the frizzy and my mothering is a mix of shouting and hugging. I've always said my mother is a better person than me, kinder, more generous. But my selfishness may be an evolutionary advantage and I don't want to be as selfless as she is. Nor do I want to look like her, though it's nothing personal. I'd rather look like Claudia Schiffer.

I don't want my daughters to look like me (that'll be my mother's self-deprecation) or become like me. But my nine-year-old was touchingly pleased recently to be told we looked alike. "I think it's nice," she said. "I don't mind." In 10 years' time she will.

fields.trailText: Omer Simsek is one of the thousands of drivers in the impoverished south-east of Turkey who try to make a living by breaking the UN sanctions against Iraq. They cross the border to buy diesel fuel, which they resell in their homeland.
fields.body:
Omer Simsek is one of the thousands of drivers in the impoverished south-east of Turkey who try to make a living by breaking the UN sanctions against Iraq. They cross the border to buy diesel fuel, which they resell in their homeland.

As sunset approaches he and his fellow drivers have spent the day crouching in the shade of their lorries, drawn up by the side of the road from the Iraqi border in temperatures approaching 50C.

They have passed the time smoking cigarettes and buying the occasional bottle of water from traders who cycle up and down the queue. They are waiting to sell their cargoes at a new state depot set up late last year by the government.

To a man, they are utterly fed up.

"We can hardly break even any more," said Omer. "There are new expenses, new taxes, and there is nothing else for us to do here."

Everyone knows that the trade takes place, and Turkey's western allies, led by the United States and Britain, have been prepared to turn a blind eye.

Since the end of the Gulf war, Turkey has lost an estimated £25bn in trade because of the UN embargo on Iraq. The heaviest burden has fallen on the border region, which can least afford it.

So, until recently, the unofficial diesel trade has been tolerated because it served as a desperately needed economic lifeline.

But now the government has regulated it, and imposed a strict quota. The amount of diesel fuel the drivers are allowed to bring across the border has been halved, and they have to sell it directly to the state rather than on the open market.

"It's ridiculous - profits have been slashed. What do they expect people to do?" said Kamil Ilhan, of the local chamber of commerce. "If we're not careful, our lorry parks will be turned into graveyards."

Businessmen in the region estimate that nearly 50,000 lorries are involved in the border trade. At one dusty roadside cafe the drivers said some of the lorries parked nearby had not been used for three months.

No one is quite sure why the restrictions have been introduced. Some people say the big oil companies were fed up with having their prices undercut, many suspect that nationalists in the government in Ankara did not want too much unregulated money flowing through this mainly Kurdish region.

The south-east is beginning to emerge cautiously from 15 years of war between the Turkish armed forces and the Kurdish PKK rebel movement. But the conflict has devastated the local economy, and popular frustration is still extremely high.

Raising sheep and cattle used to be the main source of income. But thousands of villages were forcibly evacuated by the army in their fight against the PKK, and farming has been largely destroyed. The diesel trade had become by far the biggest money earner in the region.

"We have to produce alternatives if we're going to restrict the only source of income the people have," said Salih Yildirim, a local MP. "Otherwise even more people will leave this region. They have no other choice."

Mr Yildirim, whose party is in the coalition government, has been working to lift some of the new restrictions, and he hopes to have good news for his constituents soon. If the restrictions are revised rather than abandoned, however, local people will continue to earn less than before.

Reports in the Turkish media suggest that even the military authorities in the south-east are frustrated by the sudden reduction in the border trade. Most of the region is still under quasi-martial law, and security is extremely tight. But the military authorities have been urging the government to launch rapid economic programmes to help restore normal life.

There are plenty of other emotional issues swirling around in south-east Turkey: the fate of the imprisoned Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan, for instance, and the debate on whether the state may relax any of its bans on the expression of Kurdish identity through education or broadcasting.

The border trade, though, is a much more basic necessity. It has been the means by which hundreds of thousands of people have survived from day to day, and they are frightened of losing it.

In an ideal world, the Turkish authorities would like to see the sanctions against Iraq lifted as soon as possible. They have made some moves towards improving their relations with Saddam Hussein's government in Baghdad, but they still allow the US and Britain to fly air patrols over Iraq from Turkish territory.

Caught in the middle of this complicated situation are the ordinary residents of the south-east, who are demanding simple answers.

"The government has to see sense," a driver said. "If they don't want another rebellion to start around here, they have to give us back our livelihood."

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Jacques And Lotka/The Old Lady
fields.body:
In 1966 a student at the French national library was asked by an elderly man who noticed the name on her notebook if she was the daughter of Admiral de Prevaux. When she said her father had been in the army, he exclaimed: "Of course, the truth was always hidden from you". From this chance meeting sprang the Book of the Week, Jacques And Lotka (9.45am, Radio 4), the story Aude Yung-de Prevaux uncovered of her parents' heroic work for the French resistance.

When, between the wars, an MP asked the Bank of England (pictured) governor how he decided about intervening in the markets, a startled Montague Norman tapped the side of his nose. It was, he signalled, a matter of instinct. Though Lesley Curwen gained unprecedented access for her excellent new series on the workings of the bank, plenty of dark corners remain. The operations of The Old Lady (8.0pm, Radio 4) have not changed that much.

fields.headline: Fallen stars
fields.trailText: The possessions which signify a celebrity have changed across the decades.
fields.body:
The possessions which signify a celebrity have changed across the decades. In the 60s and 70s, a Rolls Royce and swimming pool were the badges of fame. In the 80s, charitable activity and friendship with Princess Diana demonstrated separation from the herd. By the 90s, what marked a star was confession to addiction and admission to a rehabilitation clinic.

Channel 4 already has a music show jokily named The Priory after Britain's most famous recovery clinic, but now approaches the subject more seriously in Celebrity Rehab (Wednesday, 8.30pm, C4), a two-part series in which addiction counsellor Beechy Colclough (pictured) addresses one of the most intriguing question about public personalities: are celebrities more likely to become addicts or addicts more likely to become celebrities?

Comedian Jim Davidson (drink), rock star Marc Almond (drugs) and footballer Steve Claridge (gambling) describe their own dependencies. The stories are appalling. Almond describes a pop party at which a plastic intravenous drip-bag containing a pre-med sedative for cancer patients was split open and drunk from champagne glasses. Davidson recalls his nose bleeding into a vodka glass. He scooped out the blood and downed the drink.

This is a sensitive and reflective documentary, but raises two concerns. The first is that the addicts talk about their need to be liked. And, although their anecdotes of degradation appear brave, the interviews sometimes seem another exercise in eliciting public sympathy. And, while Colclough does impressive work with his clients in private, by addressing the subject on TV, he abandons the central point of Alcoholics Anonymous - anonymity.

Colclough's series starts up a branch of Addicts Famous. Whether it's sensible to encourage celebrities to think that even their addiction is special is an intriguing question for psychologists, but Celebrity Rehab is a rewarding programme, as straightforward as its title.
