fields.headline: Syncopated somersaults
fields.trailText: I can still remember the first time I saw the Nicholas Brothers dance. I was 12 years old, watching television after school, having dinner. Bored, I began to flick through the channels. Nothing interested me. Until, on one channel, I saw a choreographer working with a group of dancers from the Alvin Ailey Company. I stopped changing channels and watched.
fields.body:
I can still remember the first time I saw the Nicholas Brothers dance. I was 12 years old, watching television after school, having dinner. Bored, I began to flick through the channels. Nothing interested me. Until, on one channel, I saw a choreographer working with a group of dancers from the Alvin Ailey Company. I stopped changing channels and watched.

One of the company was being interviewed. He talked about his influences, names I didn't know. Next they showed a clip from Orchestra Wives, a 40s black-and-white film. Two black men, brothers, both dressed in white tie and tails, were singing. Suddenly they began to dance. I stopped chewing my food. For the next few moments, as I watched them dance, I didn't even breathe.

I had just seen a jazz routine by the Nicholas Brothers: Fayard, and his younger brother Harold, who died on July 3, aged 79. I love dancing and I've danced since I was six. For a long while after watching them, whenever I danced as a kid, I would try to copy the speed and grace I saw in that clip. But it would be 10 years before I'd see or hear anything more about them.

In early spring 1998, I was at Shepperton Studios talking to Kenneth Branagh about his musical film of Love's Labours Lost. I'd been cast as Dumaine and had gone in to talk about the character. Ken and I were discussing the dance solo for I've Got a Crush on You. He gave me free rein to do what I wanted with the dance but asked if I could incorporate a move from a Fred Astaire film. In the clip that Ken showed me, Astaire stepped on to the seat of a chair, put one foot on the back-rest and, while standing, walked over the chair, tipping it gently to the floor. Ken told me that, for him, it captured the feel of the song. He went on to describe how in love Dumaine is and what the dance signified. Ken's energy and enthusiasm is infectious: I left the room feeling like I could walk on water. As I made my way home I was already thinking about the Nicholas Brothers. During rehearsal, I put in the Fred Astaire steps. That went OK. I also put in my own version of some Nicholas Brothers steps - I nearly broke my leg twice!

Fayard Nicholas was born in 1914; Harold was born in 1921. Segregation was then the way of life in the US. The boys' parents, Ulysses and Viola Nicholas, were musicians in Philadelphia. Fayard spent his first few months lying in his carrycot in an orchestra pit, while his parents played jazz and classical music for silent films and shows. "I never had a babysitter, my parents took me everywhere," he recalls in Brotherhood in Rhythm, Constance Vallis Hill's new biography of the pair. "At the age of three I was hearing music. I'd go to the theatre and hear them play, or be home in the living room listening to music on the radio and just be shakin' in the chair. I'd be moving. I had this rhythm born into me."

Jazz was a new and developing sound in the US in the early 1900s, defining itself from the strongly established blues. In blues, notes were leaned on, stretched and manipulated. Bessie Smith, Ma Rainey and blues singers like them found that one note wasn't enough to convey the feeling in a word. So two or three notes were used, four, five, six, any number as long as the emotion came across to the listener. Jazz, in order to become dance music, needed a syncopated rhythm to sit behind these soaring melodies. Drummers began to speed up their percussion. Bass players also added to the rhythm.

The drums and bass are the engine room of any dance track. They hold on to the beat and the chord structure while other instruments improvise over the top. All over the US, but especially in Harlem, people began to bounce, tap their feet, snap their fingers and clap their hands to jazz. In the 20s, people were beginning to strut, slide and get down to this new music. Lindy-hopping was not far away, and Louis Jordan would soon give birth to rhythm'n'blues. Things were changing fast.

This was the world that Ulysses and Viola worked in, the world into which the Nicholas Brothers were born. They are the only tap dancers I have ever seen who took the basic principles of jazz - passion, delight and inventiveness - and applied them to dance. They were a pair of virtuosos, who made you feel joy and abandonment just watching them.

There are two ways to watch a tap dancer; two ways to appreciate the unique skill and precision that Harold and Fayard had. First, look at the dancing style, the lines of the arms and upper body, the expression in the face and the emotion conveyed with every movement. Many tap dancers don't actually dance: the body is inexpressive while they concentrate on the feet. Sometimes this is a choice, but most of the time it's simply a lack of skill. Second, close your eyes and listen to the rhythm - the taps, stomps and slides - coming from the feet. The tap dancer improvises along with the music, becoming a soloist with the band, using their feet as an instrument to add to the already complicated beat. Very few people could put these two parts of tap dancing together with flair. The usual great dancers come to mind: Fred Astaire, Gene Kelly, Ginger Rogers. But, because tap shoes are slippery and difficult to dance in, many stars performed in dance shoes and would record the sound of the taps after the picture had been shot. With the Nicholas Brothers, the taps you hear are live, recorded at the same time as their dance sequence.

I had thought that writing a book about the Nicholas Brothers' inspirational dancing would be impossible. How do you put into words their brilliant flair and style, their grace and ease, the butterflies you get in your stomach when you watch them do somersaults and backflips? It's a little like doing a radio play about a mime artist. They have to be seen to be believed. And yet, Brotherhood in Rhythm skilfully brings to life their dancing - every flick of the wrist, every step, every movement. It is at once a history of jazz-tap in the US and a touching portrait of Fayard and Harold Nicholas's work together.

Without segregation, without prejudice, what would these two supremely talented dancers have achieved with their careers? When Love's Labours Lost was gearing up for release, a glossy monthly magazine contacted me, asking if I would like to appear in a photo spread with other British actors dressed as our screen idols. I said "yes" and told them I would like to be one of the Nicholas Brothers. The reply was, "Nicholas who?" I explained who they were, but was told that the magazine only wanted to print pictures of people that the readers would recognize. It's the age-old problem: if they're not publicised, the public won't know them. Perhaps, with Hill's book and the various awards and honours Fayard and Harold have received in recent years, we will place them on the same pedestal as other tap dancers from the same era.

They were great singers, phenomenal dancers and always brothers. During the 1992 documentary film Nicholas Brothers: We Sing and We Dance, Fayard was asked if he would trade Harold in for another brother. He answered, "No way! No! We're lucky to be together, and we'll never separate, 'cause we love each other. It's there, you can't hide that - everything is inside." Sitting next to him, Harold replied, "Yeah, right. He's my brother, he's my teacher and we're always together, always brothers. And nothing can split that in half, nobody. 'Cause this is my brother. He needs me, I have to be there."

Brotherhood in Rhythm by Constance Vallis Hill is published by OUP, priced £20.

webTitle: Work experience: The stars before they were famous

fields.headline: Work experience: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: Patrick Stewart in Little Lord Fauntleroy
fields.body:
Patrick Stewart in Little Lord Fauntleroy

(Jack Gold, 1980)

Who? Slaphead Star Trek icon. Stewart started acting in am groups in his native Yorkshire before joining the RSC in 1966. Despite a memorable performance as Sejanus in the acclaimed BBC drama serial I, Claudius, he languished in TV mini-series before heading to LA and Star Trek: The Next Generation in 1987. Despite fears of typecasting, he played Captain Jean Luc Picard until 1994 and continues to play him in the Star Trek movies.

The Next Generation remains the most successful Star Trek franchise, although there have been rumours of late that producers were considering dropping him from future films because his wage demands were becoming too steep. He once said: "My appearance in The Simpsons and on Sesame Street - in praise of the letter B - were perhaps the two most distinguished bits of work that I've done." He'll next be seen playing Professor X in this summer's eagerly anticipated mutant movie X-Men.

The role: Wilkins, horseman to Little Lord Fauntleroy and his grandfather (sadly not called Big Lord Fauntleroy).

Best line: When LLF (Ricky Schroder before he grew up and became Rick) decides to let a poor village boy ride his horse, Wilkins says, in a terribly obsequious manner, "Won't his Lordship give me what for!"

Cringe factor: Moderate. He's still bald, but sports a big moustache and mutton-chop sideburns.

Other wannabes: The aforementioned Rick(y) Schroder. And, unlike most child stars, he's actually made a decent adult career for himself with a role in NYPD Blue.

Also not starring in: I, Claudius in 1976 and Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy in 1980.

Little Lord Fauntleroy, Carlton Cinema, Sat July 22, 5am.

fields.headline: This charming man
fields.standfirst: Weekend TV:  Ian Aitken
fields.trailText: News From Number Ten
fields.body:
Well, bless my soul, what's all the fuss been about? That handsome Mr Alastair Campbell, the PM's press secretary, isn't a horrid, foul-mouthed brute after all. As News From Number Ten (BBC2, Saturday) showed, he is really a nice, cuddly, loyal servant of Tony Blair whose misfortune is that he is endlessly tormented by beastly lobby correspondents who are determined to do down this best of all possible governments.

And I can be quite confident about that judgement, for the simple reason that I have seen it with own eyes on the television. As we all know, the cameras cannot lie in the way that the written word can lie. It is the truth, pure and unvarnished, brought to us by that paragon among television presenters, Michael Cockerell.

That, indeed, is the reason why Ali and his boss agreed to let the BBC cameras into 10 Dowing Street to film the secret Masonic rituals of the parliamentary lobby. Mr Campbell just wanted to let honest, ordinary folk like you and me see what a foul lie it is to suggest that he is a Machiavellian master of spin. And it worked. Well, nearly.

As Mr Campbell himself declares, in a scene which must have pleased him greatly, it isn't he who is the purveyor of spin. He just tells it like it is. The trouble is that those pesky journalists won't report it the way he says it. They are the barrier to getting the government's voice heard in the land. In fact, they are the spin doctors, not him.

There was, however, just one tiny doubt gnawing at me as I watched Mr Campbell charm his way through the show with scarcely a single scowl and (by my count) only one use of the word "garbage" and two "guffs". Virtually everything he said to the assembled journalists was so bland and un-newsworthy that one wondered how on earth said hacks ever managed to get a story out of it at all.

Moreover, I asked myself how those big exclusive stories - usually describing some splendid new government initiative on the NHS or whatever - manage to get into the newspapers. They can't come from Mr Campbell, because we see him talking to the hacks, and he doesn't tell them anything like that. Is someone else talking to them, away from Mr Cockerell's cameras? Or, perish the thought, is it Mr Campbell in the gents' toilet?

I am not here talking about those scurrilous stories Mr Campbell complains about so much - the ones attributed to unnamed "senior ministers" or "friends of the chancellor". Oh no, no, no. I mean straight-up "good news" stories about the wonders the government has in store for us. Maybe those quotes from "senior ministers" really were were made up, as Mr Campbell claims. But the "good news" stories aren't made up. They must come from somewhere, and somewhere official.

So perhaps I should let you into a secret which Mr Cockerell doesn't share with his audience. These big splash stories don't just come from official sources - their distribution around Fleet Street is used as a ministerial weapon. The underlying message to the hacks is: "Keep your noses clean and you, too, will have stories like this. Misbehave and you're out."

I'm not saying that this practice is unique to the Blair/Campbell regime. All governments have done it. But the fact that it happens casts some doubt on the idea that "fly on the wall" programmes about politics can ever be truthful.

I mean, damnit, would you behave normally if there were a TV camera pointing up you right nostril? Of course not, and neither does handsome, smiling Mr Campbell. Personally I'd sooner have seen a few characteristic scowls from him, not to mention a four-letter word or two. It would have made it easier to believe the rest of the show.

Yet Alastair really is a nice chap, though a rather different sort than Mr Cockerell's bloodless version. Moreover, no sensible journalist expects an official spokesman to tell him the unvarnished truth. Ali just has a bigger pot of varnish than most of his predecessors.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Jackie Brown/Klute/Ordinary People/The Music Of Chance
fields.body:
Jackie Brown

(Quentin Tarantino, 1997)

10pm, Sky Premier

Pulp punk Tarantino's coming-of-age movie. An adaptation of Elmore Leonard's Rum Punch, it's an assured account of Pam Grier's middle-aged heroine, a stewardess with a past, trying to make a living, then a killing, in a meticulously recreated 70s LA gangsterland. The music's soulful, the characters (Samuel L Jackson's deadly arms dealer, Bridget Fonda his stoned girlfriend, Robert De Niro's dim hood) are right on the money; some (Grier, Robert Forster as the bail bondsman who falls for her) we actually care for.

Klute

(Alan J Pakula, 1971)

10pm, Sky Cinema

Along with The Parallax View and All The President's Men, part of Pakula's trilogy of darkly paranoid 70s thrillers. Donald Sutherland (currently on the London stage in Enigmatic Variations) as a smalltown detective in the big city may have the title role, but the film belongs to Oscar-winning Jane Fonda as the assured but needy hooker, Bree. She's being stalked by a violent client, and unwittingingly holds the key to the murder case Klute is investigating. Shadowy, taut and intelligent, all the way to the clenching climax.

Ordinary People

(Robert Redford, 1980)

11.55pm, Sky Cinema

Redford's directorial debut is a decent, slightly dull account of an affluent middle-class US family in crisis. Mary Tyler Moore, TV epitome of the capable mum, is here an emotionally battered semi-wreck, who, with husband Donald Sutherland, is trying to come to terms with a son's drowning. Timothy Hutton won an Oscar playing the suicidal second son.

The Music Of Chance

(Philip Haas, 1993)

2.30am, FilmFour

The presence of diffident James Spader (pictured) usually denotes something odd afoot. Here he's a card sharp, picked up bloodied at the roadside by a man in a limo with a proposition: to fleece a pair of old fools in a poker game. But the two come a cropper, and the old boys set them to work rebuilding a medieval castle wall. Kafkaesque, with no escape, and astutely performed.

webTitle: Struggle over for Italy's radical daily

fields.headline: Struggle over for Italy's radical daily
fields.trailText: The Rome offices of L'Unita are lined with front pages that spurred generations to join the fight against capitalism. But yesterday's edition is unlikely to be framed.
fields.body:
The Rome offices of L'Unita are lined with front pages that spurred generations to join the fight against capitalism. But yesterday's edition is unlikely to be framed.

Instead of defiance, it spoke of sadness and farewells - the historic Italian daily has been put into receivership. Nearly 80 years of championing the left is ending in a fight against market forces: it may not survive the week.

Once a symbol of radical chic, L'Unita weathered fascism and gave a voice to the west's largest Communist party, railing against the Christian Democrat hegemony.

Yesterday a funereal air wafted through its four-storey office on the Via Due Macelli.

The collapse is blamed on strong competition and faltering ideological certainty, but it is a failure that journalists who were once an important part of the Italian political landscape find hard to accept.

The paper modernised to fight the resurgent centre-right led by the media magnate Silvio Berlusconi.

"If we close it will have a psychological impact on our readers and the left. We are a symbol, a badge, when people lose that they become disoriented," said Umberto De Giovannangeli, head of the paper's union.

The shareholders, a group of entrepreneurs and the Democratic Left, the biggest party in the coalition government, appointed three receivers to evaluate proposals to buy the paper, and to restructure it. If that fails, the paper will be declared bankrupt and fold.

The Democratic Left, heir to the Italian Communist party, is unwilling to go on absorbing monthly losses of £640,000, and a debt estimated at £22.5m

Even if a new owner is found, redundancies are expected to halve the staff of 124 journalists and 75 support workers.

Circulation has plunged to 50,000 from 268,000 in the mid-70s, when headlines hailed the left's electoral advance and America's humiliation: "Vietnam's victory illuminates May day."

Founded in 1924 by the ideologue Antonio Gramsci, L'Unita grew to be one of Italy's only truly national papers, sold by party members and carried as a status symbol.

It surfaced from the underground after Rome's liberation from fascism to influence the 1947 referendum which ended the monarchy and gave birth to the republic.

The emergence in 1978 of the leftwing daily La Repubblica cost it readers. But worse came with the fall of the Berlin wall in 1989.

The paper shed its ideological baggage, opened its pages to diverse opinion, allowed criticism of the party leadership, and ran sport and satire. But its influence dwindled and it was bought only for its comment, if at all.

Its closure would deny the ailing centre-left government an ally as it prepares for the general election due by April, which Mr Berlusconi is expected to win.

fields.headline: Bonded workers bid for freedom
fields.trailText: Mano escaped from his Pakistani landlord last month. The 65-year-old is weak, his skin is weathered from a lifetime working the fields of Sind, and he is very angry.
fields.body:
Mano escaped from his Pakistani landlord last month. The 65-year-old is weak, his skin is weathered from a lifetime working the fields of Sind, and he is very angry.

"I hate that landlord deeply and if I meet him again I will beat him," he said.

Mano is finally a free man. For the past 36 years he was forced to work day and night tending the sugar cane and cotton crops of a landlord, a zamindar, in southern Pakistan.

The zamindar said Mano owed him money and the loan was increasing. Armed guards patrolled the fields to make sure that he and 1,000 others like him did not escape.

"We are not educated. We don't know about accounts. We were just told we had a loan and it was increasing. We were not allowed to leave," he said.

Some took the offer of loans from the zamindar. Others like Mano never understood how they came to owe money. But all were bonded labourers, or haris, poorly educated farmers forced to work the land for years to pay off debts with interest rates as high as 10% a month.

Bonded labour was made illegal in Pakistan under the 1973 constitution. Yet an estimated 2m men, women and children are still forced to work in the farms of Sind and the Punjab. They are victims of the feudalism that still generates the wealth of the country's elite.

"By the end my loan grew to 250,000 rupees (£3,125 )," Mano said. A farm labourer would barely earn that much in 20 years. "We were given only flour and chillies to eat. We were beaten. Many of our women were raped."

Mano and 60 others escaped when the landlord's family was away at a funeral. Now he lives in Kotri camp, one of four refuges set up by Pakistan's independent Human Rights Commission near Hyderabad.

Like most other haris, Mano is a low-caste Hindu, an "untouchable," from the Thar desert, near the border with India. Even in Pakistan, a society which likes to boast it is free of caste divisions, few people will even shake his hand.

For the women, life in the farms is often worst. The lucky ones work in the fields. Mira did not. From the age of 16 she was used as a sex slave.

"I was kept in the landlord's house for 15 years and I had two children by the landlord," said Mira, 36, also a low-caste Hindu from the Thar desert.

"I was 16 years old when it started. We were beaten and we were afraid. Five girls were permanently kept for him in the landlord's house and we were raped again and again," she said.

"I want the zamindar to be hanged."

Five years ago she was one of a large group of haris released by a court order. Since then she has married Shahu, another former hari .

Human rights workers gather information on families known to be working on particular farms and press the high court to order their release.

There have been some successes. The courts have ordered the release of more than 300 haris in the past two months. Others have escaped. Now more than 12,000 free haris live in the commission's four camps.

But the number of bonded labourers is rising. After Partition in 1947 around 1% of the workforce was in bonded agricultural labour. Now the figure has risen to 15%, according the National Commission for Justice and Peace, a Catholic human rights body.

Many zamindars blame bonded labour on rawaj, centuries-old local customs.

"We don't like to be called zamindars, that is so feudal. We are growers," said Mahfooz Ursani.

"Bonded labour is a problem that has been there for years. But I cannot afford to tackle all the problems of the poor. You cannot swim against the flow of the river."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
Spain hit by ETA attack

The Basque separatist organisation ETA stepped up its wave of violence yesterday with the car bombing of a civil guard headquarters in Agreda, northern Spain.

A woman was hit by flying glass and metal in the blast, which happened just before the funeral of a local councillor, Jose Maria Martin Carpena, who was shot dead in Malaga on Saturday. Adela Gooch, Madrid

UN halts work in southern Iraq

The UN has suspended the work of its international observers in southern Iraq for security reasons, a spokesman for its oil-for-food programme said.

It comes less than three weeks after an Iraqi took hostages in the Food and Agriculture Organisation office in Baghdad, leading to a shootout with Iraqi guards in which two people died. Other UN work in Iraq will continue. AP, Baghdad

Police acquittal angers students

Iranian student leaders staged a sit-in outside parliament this weekend in protest against the acquittal of police officers charged with the bloody suppression of a campus protest last July.

Officials say at least one student died, but student leaders say around six were killed. Reuters, Tehran

40,000 watch elephants race

Europe's first modern elephant races were held in Berlin yesterday, despite protests by animal rights activists, watched by around 40,000 spectators. Reuters, Berlin

webTitle: Russia and China open new chapter

fields.headline: Russia and China open new chapter
fields.trailText: President Vladimir Putin arrives in Beijing today for a visit which will set a new course for Sino-Russian relations after 50 years of sharp twists and turns.
fields.body:
President Vladimir Putin arrives in Beijing today for a visit which will set a new course for Sino-Russian relations after 50 years of sharp twists and turns.

"The visit will be a complete success," China's foreign minister, Tang Jaixuan, declared at the weekend after talks with his Russian counterpart, Igor Ivanov. Mr Ivanov said that it would "determine the strategic development of bilateral relations in the 21st century".

The mood of unqualified optimism reflects a significant warming of relations between Moscow and Beijing, spurred by a common concern about US foreign policy and a revived Russian interest in Asia.

The Sino-Soviet dispute in the 1960s which ended the two countries' cold war alliance is officially regarded as ancient history.

"Mr Putin and President Jiang Zemin are in agreement on a lot of issues," a senior Chinese diplomat, Cui Tiankai, said. "They will reaffirm the strategic relationship and discuss US plans for a national missile defence system (NMD), security in Asia and extension of Nato."

The two leaders are expected to sign joint statements condemning NMD and pledging themselves to strengthen bilateral relations in the future.

Asia plays a significant role in the new Russian foreign policy doctrine announced by Mr Ivanov last week. His statement shared China's opposition to a "unipolar world" dominated by the US and said that Russia would seek to establish a multi-polar system.

Closer relations with China are also seen as essential to reverse the erosion of Russian power in its Asian territories.

Russia and China have common security interests in central Asia, both being anxious to promote stability in the former Soviet republics there, and deter terrorism.

Relations between China and the former Soviet Union have followed a helter-skelter path since the Chinese communist victory of 1949.

In the early 1950s Mao Zedong urged his people to "learn from the Soviet Union" - although in private he suspected Stalin of seeking to isolate China.

Improved relations between the US and the Soviet Union led to the Sino-Soviet split in the 1960s. To fierce ideological polemics, the two countries almost went to war along their 2,500-mile border.

The US seized the opportunity to reopen the door to China in the 1970s and 1980s, in a strategic partnership directed against Moscow. It has taken time since the collapse of the Soviet Union for Russia and China to overcome the residual suspicion.

"Our relations with Russia are always important for China," said Mr Cui, "whether in a good sense or a bad sense. But in the early 1990s, when the Soviet Union was dismantled, the Russians were at a loss in what direction they were going."

A series of summits between the then Russian president, Boris Yeltsin, and Mr Jiang was based on a new policy of "strategic partnership" agreed in 1996. But the vital stimulus only came last year when the countries found common ground in opposing the US-led Nato bombing of Yugoslavia.

Their mutual trade, running at an annual two-way total of $6bn, lags far behind the goal of $20bn set by Mr Jiang and Mr Yeltsin.

Russia provides China with a supply of relatively cheap military hardware. The summit may finalise agreement on some pending contracts, including the building of two new destroyers for the Chinese navy.

Although diplomats on both sides insist that their new stable relationship will last well into this century, some analysts believe the legacy of history is not so easily overcome.

In a report last year for the Carnegie Endowment, the Russian expert Dmitri Trenin described Sino-Russian relations as looking "sterile and shallow". Subconscious fears, he argued, still lingered in Russia about the "yellow peril" loudly proclaimed by earlier Soviet propaganda.

Chinese memories of high-handed Soviet behaviour are perpetuated in widely sold books and magazines. Beijing's fear of Russian expansionism was finally dispelled only by the obvious decline of Moscow's military strength and economic power in the 90s.

Relations between China and the former Soviet Union have followed a helter-skelter path since the Chinese communist victory of 1949. In the early 1950s Mao Zedong urged his people to "learn from the Soviet Union" - although in private he suspected Stalin of seeking to isolate China. Improved relations between the US and the Soviet Union led to the Sino-Soviet split in the 1960s. To fierce ideological polemics, the two countries almost went to war along their 2,500-mile border. The US seized the opportunity to reopen the door to China in the 1970s and 1980s, in a strategic partnership directed against Moscow. It has taken time since the collapse of the Soviet Union for Russia and China to overcome the residual suspicion. "Our relations with Russia are always important for China," said Mr Cui, "whether in a good sense or a bad sense. But in the early 1990s, when the Soviet Union was dismantled, the Russians were at a loss in what direction they were going." A series of summits between the then Russian president, Boris Yeltsin, and Mr Jiang was based on a new policy of "strategic partnership" agreed in 1996. But the vital stimulus only came last year when the countries found common ground in opposing the US-led Nato bombing of Yugoslavia. Their mutual trade, running at an annual two-way total of $6bn, lags far behind the goal of $20bn set by Mr Jiang and Mr Yeltsin. Russia provides China with a supply of relatively cheap military hardware. The summit may finalise agreement on some pending contracts, including the building of two new destroyers for the Chinese navy. Although diplomats on both sides insist that their new stable relationship will last well into this century, some analysts believe the legacy of history is not so easily overcome. In a report last year for the Carnegie Endowment, the Russian expert Dmitri Trenin described Sino-Russian relations as looking "sterile and shallow". Subconscious fears, he argued, still lingered in Russia about the "yellow peril" loudly proclaimed by earlier Soviet propaganda. Chinese memories of high-handed Soviet behaviour are perpetuated in widely sold books and magazines. Beijing's fear of Russian expansionism was finally dispelled only by the obvious decline of Moscow's military strength and economic power in the 90s.

webTitle: US sunbathers fight for right to bare all

fields.headline: US sunbathers fight for right to bare all
fields.trailText: The nudists of Rincon Point beach were discretion itself. There were the families playing the traditional naturist sport of volleyball and men of all ages sunbathing behind shelters built from driftwood washed in from the Pacific on to this stretch of coast south of Santa Barbara.
fields.body:
The nudists of Rincon Point beach were discretion itself. There were the families playing the traditional naturist sport of volleyball and men of all ages sunbathing behind shelters built from driftwood washed in from the Pacific on to this stretch of coast south of Santa Barbara.

But now this beach, like many others in California and Florida which allow nude swimming and sunbathing, is coming under attack in what is seen as a new wave of puritanism.

Next month Korina Jochim, 25, will appear in court in Santa Barbara charged with breaking a bylaw which prohibits women from "showing any portion of her breasts below the areolas".

Ms Jochim has been campaigning for the right of women to sunbathe topless on beaches and is contesting the charge to challenge the growing number of bylaws closing down nude beaches around the US.

"We are fighting this as a gender equality issue," said Ms Jochim, who was arrested with a friend on nearby Summer land beach. "There are topless bars and porn videos around everywhere and our argument is that it would be much healthier for people not to see women's bodies in this sexualised way."

Ms Jochim said there had been an attempt to stop topless and nude sunbathing along the coast. She is being backed in her campaign by naturist organisations, which argue that designated beaches traditionally used for nude sunbathing should not be shut down.

"These are mostly pretty remote beaches," Ms Jochim said yesterday. "It's not as if you are suddenly going to stumble upon them."

She will be defended by Robert Harris, who represented topless dancers in freedom of expression cases in the 70s and who has come out of retirement for the trial.

He will cite the 1992 case of the People v Santorelli, in which an appeal court in New York ruled that Ramona Santorelli was entitled to be topless in a state park since she had the same protection under the law as men.

The campaign to reverse the bylaws forbidding topless and nude bathing on beaches where where the practice is traditional is led by a group called Top Freedom, which was formed last year after local sheriffs started arresting sunbathers. The sheriffs have stepped up their activity this summer.

Earlier this year Tecopa hot springs near Death Valley, believed to be the only area in the US where bathing is compulsorily nude, was also under threat after some tourists objected to stripping off.

Nudity is insisted on to prevent contamination by bathing suit materials. Residents fought off local council plans to make bathing suits compulsory but said they feared their victory was only temporary.

Officials and police in the Santa Barbara area say that nude beaches attract voyeurs and sex offenders, and that nudity can make family groups uncomfortable.

But campaigners argue that beaches could be designated away from populous areas, zoned, and sign-posted with warnings.

Korina Jochim says she hopes the attention generated by the case will raise awareness of the issue and allow Californians to retain their bathing habits without fear of arrest.

fields.headline: Picasso minotaur finds appropriate setting
fields.trailText: A stunning masterpiece by Pablo Picasso has at last found a setting worthy of its splendour after the £15m conversion of Toulouse's abattoirs into one of the most impressive art galleries in Europe.
fields.body:
A stunning masterpiece by Pablo Picasso has at last found a setting worthy of its splendour after the £15m conversion of Toulouse's abattoirs into one of the most impressive art galleries in Europe.

La Dépouille du Minotaure en costume d'Arlequin - the Minotaur's body dressed as Harlequin - was painted in 1936 as the stage curtain for Romain Rolland's play Le 14 Juillet .

The painter was so attached to the work that he kept it in his Paris atelier throughout the war, and only donated it to Toulouse, a southern city with a strong bullfighting tradition, in 1965.

The curtain needed extensive renovation before it was given its own gallery in the Espace d'Art Moderne et Contemporain, which has just been opened to the public on the banks of the Garonne.

The work, which stands about nine metres (30ft) high and more than 12 metres (40ft) across, has little direct reference to the play and was apparently hurriedly completed as an enlargement from a small gouache - an opaque watercolour - which had been finished long before the commission.

"The subject is a strange choice, because there is no iconographic or narrative link to Romain Rolland's enthusiastic play," Gilles Barabant, a Picasso specialist, said. "There is evidence, though, that the artist did try a Revolutionary design but did not have the time to complete it. There is a curious drawing dated June 13 1936 which shows a joyful crowd with what looks like a symbolic reference to the taking of the Bastille.

"On the other hand, Picasso was obsessed by personal allusions at the time with reference to mythology and bullfighting. You can see in the curtain the confrontation of good and evil, the victory of youth, and beauty conquering menace, which was a logical rapprochement of the epic themes of both Picasso and Rolland."

Most of the influential European painters of the second half of the 20th century are represented in the converted slaughterhouse, built in the 1830s. Its collection of 2,000 works by nearly 700 artists is dominated by Mediterranean names.

The museum claims to be a leader in representing movements such as Art brut, Arte Povera and Trans-Avant-Garde.

The renovation of the abattoirs, which were closed in 1988, is part of a programme to revitalise the area, which was once an industrial centre.

fields.headline: Neo-Nazis attack refugee hostel
fields.trailText: Neo-Nazis are suspected of carrying out an arson attack on a refugee hostel in the western German city of Ludwigshafen early yesterday in which an 11-year-old Kosovan girl was seriously burned.
fields.body:
Neo-Nazis are suspected of carrying out an arson attack on a refugee hostel in the western German city of Ludwigshafen early yesterday in which an 11-year-old Kosovan girl was seriously burned.

Two other children and a woman were injured in the attack, which coincided with a warning by the head of Germany's Jewish community about growing neo-Nazi violence by young people.

The attack was the latest of several assaults by far-right groups on foreigners and vagrants in Germany.

Kosovan refugees at the hostel in the Ludwigshafen suburb of Oppau said a birthday party was interrupted at 1.30am by the sound of breaking glass and an explosion of fire "like a big rocket".

One of the refugees, an 11-year-old girl, suffered severe burns to her legs and two other children aged 12 and 14 were injured by flying glass.

All three and a woman resident who suffered scalp burns after her hair caught fire were taken to hospital.

"We came to Germany to escape being attacked. We cannot understand what is going on," one of the refugees said in a radio interview.

Police said the hostel residents put out the fire, which was started by a homemade petrol bomb. They said far-right extremists were suspected of carrying out the attack.

The head of Germany's 85,000-strong Jewish community, Paul Spiegel, said in an interview published yesterday that he was "greatly concerned" by an increase in extreme rightwing violence among young Germans.

"Today the violence is directed against foreigners, tomorrow it will be against the handicapped and the day after tomorrow against sexual minorities. In the end it will be against democratic society. It was like that in Weimar times," he told Welt am Sonntag newspaper.

Yesterday's attack was the latest of several unprovoked assaults. On Friday five skinheads aged 19-22 confessed to killing a 52-year-old vagrant man in the east German city of Wismar. His body was discovered by the police on Wednesday.

Last month a 39-year-old Mozambican man was kicked to death by three skinheads after he boarded a bus in the eastern city of Dessau.

The head of Germany's domestic intelligence services, Heinz Fromm, admitted in an interview at the weekend that rightwing extremism was on the increase.

"It seems to me that its attraction is growing among young people," Mr Fromm said. "The far right seems to think that its philosophy is accepted by a large part of the population, because there is no reaction when something bad happens."

fields.headline: Stealth bombers destined for Britain
fields.standfirst: Pentagon's choice of Fairford could revive cold war debates
fields.trailText: The US is planning to use Britain as a base for long-range stealth bombers in a move likely to revive the cold war debate about the UK's role as America's "unsinkable aircraft carrier".
fields.body:
The US is planning to use Britain as a base for long-range stealth bombers in a move likely to revive the cold war debate about the UK's role as America's "unsinkable aircraft carrier".

The Ministry of Defence confirmed yesterday that the Pentagon had chosen Fairford in Gloucestershire - nominally an RAF station - as a possible base for the bombers, America's most expensive warplane, when they were needed to be "deployed forward".

Washington has yet to discuss the plan with the British government, an MoD spokesman said. He denied Fairford would be a "permanent" base for the stealth bomber and insisted its use by the US airforce would have to be cleared with Britain in advance.

Fairford was used by giant US B52 bombers during the Kosovo war last year when stealth bombers flew 30-hour strike missions on Belgrade directly from their Wightman base in Missouri.

Fairford is undergoing a £60m upgrading of its runway and fuel bunkers in the largest single military construction project within a Nato country since the end of the cold war.

"Fairford is the only place in Europe we can realistically use for the heavy bombers," a US 3rd Air Force headquarters official said at Mildenhall, Suffolk, said last month.

Alternatives, such as Moron and Zaragoza in Spain, could face local opposition, the Pentagon believes. According to US sources, Fairford has also been chosen as an emergency landing strip for the US space shuttle.

Fairford is one of several bases the Pentagon wants to deploy long-range bombers. Another - which the US has used for B52 bombers, notably in the 1991 Gulf war - is Diego Garcia, in the Chagos archipelago which forms the British Indian Ocean Territory.

Harold Wilson's Labour government handed over the base to the US in the 1960s for a £5m discount on the Polaris nuclear missile system. The deal was never disclosed to parliament.

In the high court today, Chagos islander who were banished to Mauritius will fight for their right to return home.

In a separate developemnt yesterday, it was disclosed that shells being tested for the Challenger 2 - the British army's new battle tank - have a serious fault that could endanger their crews.

Leaked documents from royal ordnance engineers carrying out the trials show that problems have been detected in ammunition produced by the German company, Nitrochemie, which might cause the tanks' gun barrels to jam.

"A major improvement is required. The risk of some degree of programme delay might thus be significant," the engineers say.

Jack Dromey, national organiser of the TGWU, who has seen the documents, blamed the problem on the MoD's decision to close the royal ordnance factory at Bishopton, Renfrewshire, the only British plant producing propellant for shells.

"Test-firing at the Ridsdale range [Northumberland] has left soot and debris in the gun barrel, demonstrating fatal flaws in the Nitrochemie propellant," he said. "The specialist engineers who trialled the German product have warned that its use might incinerate tank crews."

An MoD spokesman said the trials were part of an assessment programme. "There is no question of the MoD allowing or royal ordnance supplying unsafe propellants to be used in service."

He added: "We can categorically say we have no problems with any in-service propellant charge supplied by the royal ordnance."

The Challenger 2, now with British forces in Bosnia and Kosovo, was years late because of problems with the turret.

 The Foreign Office said yesterday it was investigating a report that a planned £5m sale of military equipment to the Gulf state of Qatar was actually destined for Algeria.

It said it was checking a Sunday Times report that rapid deployment vehicles and pickup trucks, as well as night vision sights, would end up in the hands of Algerian forces fighting Islamist rebels.

fields.headline: The low down: Paternity leave
fields.trailText: Paternity leave came in with a bang at the end of last year and enjoyed a revival of interest with the birth of Leo Blair. But apart from the prime minister has anyone taken any? The short answer is that nobody seems to know.
fields.body:
Paternity leave came in with a bang at the end of last year and enjoyed a revival of interest with the birth of Leo Blair. But apart from the prime minister has anyone taken any? The short answer is that nobody seems to know. Even the pressure groups that monitor the issue closely admit no satisfactory information is available. What is clear is that the biggest obstacle is financial worry.

A survey by online bank Virgin One found a good deal of enthusiasm for the theory at least. Overall, 61% of fathers "welcomed" the introduction of paternity leave; among younger fathers, this rose to 71%. Enthusiasm fades, though, in the face of the financial consequences, 45% saying they won't be taking paternity because they can't afford to. A further 23% would be reluctant to do so because work commitments preclude it.

The survey reflects the experience of the charity Parents At Work. A spokeswoman says that since the change in the law, it has had many enquiries about paternity leave but callers lose interest on learning that there will be no financial support. Financial expectations are generally modest. The charity suggests that just £125 would make some paternity leave viable for low-income families. And, it says, paternity leave should be paid on the same basis as maternity leave, with government provision to help small businesses.

It would also like to see more flexibility, with perhaps one day a week over several weeks being an option rather than one week here or there. As yet this is available only to the fathers of children with disabilities. But it is early days. As recently as 1992, Parents At Work was known as the Working Mothers Association. It seems it will take some time to establish that the issue affects both sexes.

fields.headline: Have skills, will travel
fields.standfirst: In Europe's business centres, UK secretaries are highly valued and much in demand. Bill Saunders reports
fields.trailText: If money talks, as the saying has it, these days it prefers to speak English. A side effect of the global economy is that English-speaking secretaries are much in demand in Europe's business centres. So much so, that some London secretarial consultancies are recruiting secretaries to work overseas
fields.body:
If money talks, as the saying has it, these days it prefers to speak English. A side effect of the global economy is that English-speaking secretaries are much in demand in Europe's business centres. So much so, that some London secretarial consultancies are recruiting secretaries to work overseas.

There is more to this trend than the spread of English, however. While Europe finds itself doing more business in English, British secretaries are in demand for their professionalism. So indeed are British secretarial consultancies, since secretarial recruitment is an emerging skill in Europe and the few local agencies there are cannot meet the demands of multinational companies.

Typing is becoming something of a lost art in France, while British secretaries tend to shine with their key board skills and their grasp of new technology. But there is more to the job than typing. David Mele, head of Angela Mortimer's international division, says attitude is also important. "British secretaries are more willing to take the initiative and expand their job descriptions," he says.

Angela Mortimer has a Paris office with 18 staff, which includes a training division for its clients. A Brussels office which opened last year now has eight staff, and there are plans to open in Frankfurt within a year.

So what lures British secretaries to Paris? The 35-hour week is about to become law in France and, as Mele says, 9am-4pm is an immediately more attractive proposition than 9am-5pm (especially when it includes an hour off for lunch, in a city where lunch means lunch, rather than a 20-minute scramble for a tuna bap). The short working day was introduced originally as a strategy to keep down unemployment, but in the course of bringing it onto the statute books the problem has solved itself. After seven years of recession, Paris is thriving.

While London is a magnet for the ambitious, Paris, says Mele, attracts people who are looking for a lifestyle. Brussels is also popular, offering the same international activity as London, especially in its law firms, but in a smaller, more intimate city.

Regardless of how fast you type, you do need to speak French to work in Paris. Although you won't have to be bilingual, you will need to be fluent, stresses Mele. You will probably have to have studied the language to degree-level, and the ability to write in French and make yourself understood will satisfy employers.

The situation can be different in European countries whose languages are less widely spoken. Crone Corkill's language division is recruiting secretaries to work in Amsterdam for companies which do not require knowledge of Dutch. As yet, this is an unusual instance, but it may become more common now that some European companies conduct their internal business in English.

Amsterdam apart, the shift to another city where, whatever happens at the office, the people outside it speak another language, is always going to be difficult. Angela Mortimer holds open days in London which allow would-be émigrés to explore every aspect of the move. As well as interviews with Paris and Brussels consultants, with the possibility of acquiring a job before you set off, advice is also given on the problems of finding somewhere to live. The open days particularly appeal to recent language graduates keen to experiment with a couple of years abroad before settling down.

In Mele's experience many who have tried the experiment like it so much they make the move permanent.

Angela Mortimer has a Paris office with 18 staff, which includes a training division for its clients. A Brussels office which opened last year now has eight staff, and there are plans to open in Frankfurt within a year. So what lures British secretaries to Paris? The 35-hour week is about to become law in France and, as Mele says, 9am-4pm is an immediately more attractive proposition than 9am-5pm (especially when it includes an hour off for lunch, in a city where lunch means lunch, rather than a 20-minute scramble for a tuna bap). The short working day was introduced originally as a strategy to keep down unemployment, but in the course of bringing it onto the statute books the problem has solved itself. After seven years of recession, Paris is thriving. While London is a magnet for the ambitious, Paris, says Mele, attracts people who are looking for a lifestyle. Brussels is also popular, offering the same international activity as London, especially in its law firms, but in a smaller, more intimate city. Regardless of how fast you type, you do need to speak French to work in Paris. Although you won't have to be bilingual, you will need to be fluent, stresses Mele. You will probably have to have studied the language to degree-level, and the ability to write in French and make yourself understood will satisfy employers. The situation can be different in European countries whose languages are less widely spoken. Crone Corkill's language division is recruiting secretaries to work in Amsterdam for companies which do not require knowledge of Dutch. As yet, this is an unusual instance, but it may become more common now that some European companies conduct their internal business in English. Amsterdam apart, the shift to another city where, whatever happens at the office, the people outside it speak another language, is always going to be difficult. Angela Mortimer holds open days in London which allow would-be émigrés to explore every aspect of the move. As well as interviews with Paris and Brussels consultants, with the possibility of acquiring a job before you set off, advice is also given on the problems of finding somewhere to live. The open days particularly appeal to recent language graduates keen to experiment with a couple of years abroad before settling down. In Mele's experience many who have tried the experiment like it so much they make the move permanent.

fields.headline: Desktop icons No 28: The answerphone
fields.trailText: "I'm sorry I can't take your call at the moment, I'm either away from my desk or on another line. But if you leave your name and number after the tone I'll get back to you as soon as I can . . ." Sorry, dozed off for a minute there. Why are answerphone messages so dull?
fields.body:
"I'm sorry I can't take your call at the moment, I'm either away from my desk or on another line. But if you leave your name and number after the tone I'll get back to you as soon as I can . . ." Sorry, dozed off for a minute there. Why are answerphone messages so dull? It's a mantra we could intone to send us to sleep at night, so often do we hear the same old line repeated during the day while that very important person we really need to speak to just blinking well refuses to take the call.

The answer, of course, is that the alternative is just too dreadful to contemplate. There may be a few - a very few - workplaces where it's appropriate to make a stab at wackiness in greeting your callers electronically, but if there are I can't think of any. Little is guaranteed to make a caller hang up more swiftly, gagging into the nearest wastebin, than being confronted with unregulated voicemail comedy at ten past nine in the morning. Disney theme tunes, silly voices, Blair Witch spoofs - you know who you are. Now stop it.

The only thing worse than "comedy" voicemail is returning from holiday (or, if you're fantastically important, from lunch) to be greeted with a little red flashing light and the message "you have... 45... new messages". Such a difficult decision - plough your way through them? Or kill yourself?

It was all downhill for the answerphone once someone - they probably got their hair done at Klipz 'n' Kurlz - decided to spell it "ansaphone". This may have been based on an admirable desire to simplify spelling, phoneticise nomenclature, but if so, why baulk at the "ph"? No, I think we know the answer. It was the first sign of workplace wackiness, and telephone messages have been particular victims of this menace ever since. Make a stand against such office ogres. Call them lots of times and clog up their mail. Oh, and speak really quickly, and never repeat your number.

fields.headline: The sec's files
fields.trailText: Fancy yourself as a top PA? Why not enter the new Executive PA of the Year Award and prove it?
fields.body:
 GET TO THE TOP

Fancy yourself as a top PA? Why not enter the new Executive PA of the Year Award and prove it? Judged by PAs themselves, the winner will receive £1,000, plus a free place at the Executive PA in Business conference (worth £1,000), and a year's membership to the Executive PA network (worth £95). Send an outline of your achievements and a letter of endorsement from your boss to organisers IIR by August 25, 2000. Contact Elise Cole on 020 7915 5038 or email ecole@iir-conferences.com.

 KNOW YOUR INTERNET

One new internet start-up launches every 29 minutes, but it is not just those who work in new media who need to be well versed in internet skills. Recruitment agency Office Angels has found that those who are familiar with the net are a third more likely to be offered a job than those who still fear email. In some parts of the country, such as "Silicon Fen" in Cambridge, 75% of employers say they are interested only in staff who know their way round the internet.

 TECHNO TROUBLE AT TOP

How techno-literate are bosses? Not very, according to the Secretarial Consulting Group in Manchester. The recruitment firm set up a range of training courses for secretaries this year, but has found that their managers are now knocking on the door for IT courses. "Some cannot open and send emails, or get to grips with Windows, while others just use their computer as a glorified typewriter," says MD Sue Williams. "When they see what their assistants have learned, they see the need to catch up." For more details call 0161 839 2309.

 ONE-STOP PA SHOP

Launched in April to coincide with National Secretaries' Day, Secretary1 is a new website for admin staff that claims to offer a one-stop shop for everything a PA needs, from advice on filing to contacts for arranging conferences. The site, which already boasts a quarter of a million hits, has now joined with internet stationery supplier Stationery-Store to make ordering paperclips even easier online. See www.secretary1.com for more information.

 HAPPY IN OUR WORK

According to a new survey, from training company Eden Brown having friendly colleagues is the most important element of a happy workplace. Second comes job security, while several factors - money, comfortable working conditions and equality of opportunity - share third place. Last year, job security held the top spot, which suggests that we may be feeling slightly more safe in our jobs at the moment.

Compiled by Penny Cottee, editor of Executive PA magazine

webTitle: Sick, or just sick of work?

fields.headline: Sick, or just sick of work?
fields.standfirst: As the government threatens stricter medicals for public-sector workers taking early retirement because of ill-health, Diane Taylor considers its motives
fields.trailText: If you are middle-aged and work in the public sector, you're probably trying to pull a long-term sickie that will allow you to enjoy retirement with an enhanced pension while you're still young enough to make the most of it. At least, that's what a new report from the Treasury believes.
fields.body:
If you are middle-aged and work in the public sector, you're probably trying to pull a long-term sickie that will allow you to enjoy retirement with an enhanced pension while you're still young enough to make the most of it. At least, that's what a new report from the Treasury believes.

The year-long inquiry, which was leaked to the press last week, found that the rate of ill health among workers on the state payroll is a third higher than among their private-sector colleagues. Firefighters scored lowest in the long-term employment stakes with 68% retiring early on ill-health grounds, closely followed by almost half of police officers and more than a third of local government employees. Figures for teachers and NHS workers were only slightly lower, with a 25% and 23% early exodus respectively.

The government has responded by saying it will clamp down on skivers who have until now conned sloppy medical officials. In future, medical checks will be more rigorous, and only those who are utterly incapable of work will be waved off into the sunset patting a pension tucked securely into their back pocket. Those with minor ailments will have to stay in their jobs and, if necessary, will be assigned less physically demanding duties.

Predictably, the report has sparked fury among public-sector workers, some of whom say they have appealed against medical decisions to retire them early and begged to be allowed to remain in the jobs they love. Unison, the largest union for those working in public services, suspects a disingenuous political motive on the part of the government.

"It is no coincidence that the government is trying to make the most of this story just in advance of the comprehensive spending review where we are asking for more resources to be pumped into our public services," says Unison general secretary-elect Dave Prentis.

"We don't think the government should be allowed to get away with whipping up this hysteria and dumping blame on public-sector workers in this way. If there is an abuse of the system, it should be dealt with. But those people who have been retired are not only the victims of stress, violence or injury, but are now the victims of a whispering campaign to portray them as swinging the lead."

Prentis proposes that, instead of pointing an accusing finger, government ministers should call on employers to introduce good occupational health schemes along with safer working practices, and offer advice and redeployment to prevent ill health in the first place.

Nick Page, adviser on pay and employment conditions to the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development, warns that emotion from both sides can cloud a very complex issue which is about much more than how well or ill an employee may be. While he acknowledges that those who are perfectly well should not abuse the system because they'd rather potter round the garden, he says that any perception among employees that the clampdown is merely a cost-cutting exercise will breed huge resentment.

"If there are cases of people who are using the excuse of ill health to progress their retirement, we need to find ways of making public-sector managers manage better so that this doesn't happen," he says. "I think one of the reasons early retirement on ill-health grounds is lower in the private sector is because often they have better managers who keep employees motivated so that they want to stay in their jobs. As an employer, the government is not always good at providing back-up to employees nor does it say to staff very often, 'well done, congratulations, we value you'.

"Teachers and other public-sector workers are political footballs in a way that private-sector workers are not. Often they find that control of their job is out of their hands."

Even if the stampede for the exit marked early retirement is motivated by a desire to put your feet up, there's nothing so wrong with that, according to Carolyn Jones, director of the Institute of Employment Rights. "In the 70s, in the heyday of new technology, we were all promised shorter working hours and more leisure. Today, people in this country work much longer hours than our European neighbours. In a civilised society, we should be encouraging people to take early retirement at a time that they can enjoy it rather than being forced to work until they drop."

fields.headline: A woman of many words
fields.standfirst: Known as 'the secretary with languages', Rosemary Graham takes an unusual interest in the euro. Dolly Dhingra finds out why
fields.trailText: Known as 'the secretary with languages', Rosemary Graham takes an unusual interest in the euro. Dolly Dhingra finds out why
fields.body:
The debate continues as to whether the UK will become part of Euroland, but for Rosemary Graham the controversial currency is already a large part of her working day. "Our first euro payment was made at 9am on January 4, 1999, so it's already part of business. It's really not about us having a view for or against the euro, but having to deal with changes," she says.

As PA both to Barclays' head of corporate banking Robert Robson and his deputy Andrea Teeew, Graham has taken a keen interest in the debate surrounding the currency. If introduced, the euro will call for an enormous public education programme, the likes of which have not been implemented since the introduction of decimalisation.

Europe is a subject close to Graham's heart in more ways than one - having taken a degree in German and French at Manchester University she has worked abroad, and is getting married to her German partner in September. "I do keep up with the issues surrounding the euro. I have long debates with my other half who says that we've got to join. I've still got savings in Germany and I'm never quite sure what to do with them," she says.

Her love of things European began during her degree placement in Germany. "For my first job I went to the interview and said, 'I can't type and I can't use the computer but I promise I will be able to in three months time.' They gave me the job and I taught myself to type on a German typewriter, using a German book - so I was kind of confused when I came back to the UK and tried to use a typewriter here."

Known by customers and staff alike as "the secretary with languages", Graham says, "I have to do all sorts of things at work that involve translations, correspondence in German, taking minutes and speaking to different countries. I act as a central contact point in the middle for nine countries and languages, including France, Germany, Italy, Ireland, Spain, Portugal, Greece and the Netherlands. I do what I can to get by in the languages that I'm not so good at, but if I get desperate we have a very multinational, multilingual, team who will help me out. We've got people who are half-German, half- Italian, half-Spanish, half-French - it's really useful!" she says.

Both her bosses spend a lot of time abroad dealing with business customers throughout Europe and this increases Graham's responsibilities in the office, which she relishes. "When they're on their travels, I have to make sure they know exactly what is going on. Monitoring all their emails, getting all messages to them, routing information to them that they need to know because they'll be speaking to customers or other members of staff. I have to ensure that I keep them involved in what's going on here - acting as a sort of bridge."

Keen to broaden her experiences as much as possible, she says, "I've actually been lucky because I've had a very varied job: both my bosses give me a lot of things to do which are perhaps not your bog-standard secretarial work. If the auditors are coming over, they'll delegate it to me as a project to sort out, so I'll get us prepared and make sure that things get done.

"We've also had a programme called the Culture Busters, which was all about spreading cultural diversity and I was involved in setting that up. It was a way to make Barclays truly diverse, which is not something a secretary would normally be required to do." As well as the usual perks that a career in banking offers, there are added bonuses in her job: "What I particularly appreciate about this job is that they are very supportive of language training: the bank pays for and encourages staff. I'm currently doing a German translation course so I could eventually become a German translator."

With an aptitude for languages and a Dutch boss, Graham has managed to pick up the language. "Dutch is even more difficult to pronounce than German. I tend to go for the guttural languages! Working with different people and languages here I think I've found my home job-wise."

fields.headline: The office gossip
fields.trailText: "Working on a magazine means that your job pretty much revolves around when each issue goes to print," says Rachel Lewis, editorial assistant on Later magazine.
fields.body:
"Working on a magazine means that your job pretty much revolves around when each issue goes to print," says Rachel Lewis, editorial assistant on Later magazine. "My job consists of two very different aspects - administration and writing. In the run-up to the magazine going to print, I tend to focus heavily on the writing, and the week after I concentrate on the admin and secretarial side ."

Ultimately she wants to be a writer, "and a job as an editorial assistant gives you a foot in the door", she says candidly. "I provide all the admin support for the writers, do research for any articles that are being written, and look after the editor - which usually just involves reminding him about meetings."

Lewis admits that it can be difficult balancing what are really two different jobs, particularly as she has a strong preference for one of them. The administrative demands of the job can mean constant interruptions when she is trying to write. "Sometimes I can spend all day trying to start a piece and never get it finished," she says. "People will come up and tell me the fax is out of paper, or their computer isn't working, and it's up to me to sort it out. Or they'll ask me to research some facts for a particular piece, and I have to put aside what I'm doing.

"I have learnt that it is important to try to do the admin tasks first," she says, "because although I'm happy to stay late to write, I resent it if I have to stay on to sort out invoices or order stationery. In the week after the issue goes out, I concentrate totally on the admin side. I have to ensure all the invoices from the magazine's contributors have been dealt with and sent to accounts. It's a huge job and the only way to get it done quickly is to put aside everything else."

As well as all her other work, Lewis has to deal with a constantly ringing telephone. "I get all sorts of calls. Often PRs phone, trying to sell an idea, or recommending that we cover something totally unsuited to the magazine. Readers also ring up with queries about the magazine. Or sometimes guys call to ask if they can have shots of a model we've used. Phone calls can take ages to deal with because often it's a matter of listening to the person, rather than passing the problem on to someone else."

So is it difficult to remain organised when juggling two jobs? "I always used to be a very organised person, but in this job its hard to keep focused on what you're doing. I love the writing, but I have learnt that if I ignore what needs doing on the admin side, I just get into a mess. If someone calls with an enquiry I try to deal with it straight away, and if a writer asks me to something, I try to sort it out. Otherwise my desk ends up covered in yellow stickies. I am a bit of a Post-it queen, but I'm trying to curb my addiction!"

webTitle: Don't be bullied by a big bad boss

fields.headline: Don't be bullied by a big bad boss
fields.standfirst: Working for a malevolent manager can be a devastating experience. Sadly, there are plenty of them around, so it pays to know how to respond. Hilary Whitney reports
fields.trailText: How do you become a good manager? Judging by the abundance of information, from books to CD-roms to residential courses, on how to become a better boss, one might suppose that there was no reason for anyone to suffer from bad management any longer. Ah, if only.
fields.body:
How do you become a good manager? Judging by the abundance of information, from books to CD-roms to residential courses, on how to become a better boss, one might suppose that there was no reason for anyone to suffer from bad management any longer. Ah, if only.

The unfortunate reality, according to a recent survey, is that you are as likely to encounter a bad boss as a good one. The study, carried out by the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology (Umist), surveyed 5,000 employees from public, private and voluntary sectors, almost half of whom said they had experienced or witnessed bullying in the past five years. And the perpetrators? Surprise surprise, in three-quarters of cases it was the boss who was to blame.

Everyone would like to work for a focused and dynamic boss who is secure enough to encourage the careers of colleagues without feeling threatened in his or her own career. Unfortunately, many employees have to deal with a lesser breed of managers who use bullying and manipulative methods to get their own way and show themselves in the best light.

This is where incompetent management becomes actively malevolent. Take your pick from a catalogue of sins: criticising competent staff, taking away responsibilities and assigning trivial tasks instead, shouting at staff, picking on people in front of colleagues, blocking promotion, setting impossible deadlines, and regularly making the same person the butt of jokes.

Sound familiar? If so, you are likely to appreciate the devastating effect this kind of behaviour can have on employees - both physically and psychologically. A demotivated workforce simply does not perform as effectively, and there is the risk of a huge loss of resources as experienced staff leave the organisation in despair.

Angela Holmes recognises this behaviour all too well. An experienced PA, she had worked for her boss, a senior member of a multi-national corporation, for six years before his arrogant manner became too much to bear. "He was very demanding and I'd seen him behave appallingly to other people, but he was generally OK with me. I think he knew that he was difficult to work for, and as I was good at my job he didn't want to risk losing me.

"Then one day, when he was on holiday, another colleague asked me to do something for him. Normally I would have been happy to help, but I wasn't able to on that occasion as I was about to go on a computer course. When my boss returned from his holiday, this colleague informed him that I'd been uncooperative. My boss went absolutely ballistic and threw a can of soft drink at me which hurt me quite badly."

Fortunately for Holmes, this incident was witnessed by several other members of staff and she went straight to the human resources department to lodge a complaint. There was such animosity between Holmes and her boss that it was decided she should go on sick leave until the matter was sorted out. "I had a lot of support from my colleagues," says Holmes, "but to be honest I felt that HR was very much on the management's side. They kept trying to find fault with me even though I'd done nothing wrong, and went back through all my old appraisal records, which were all glowing. It was extremely stressful."

She eventually agreed to leave the company with a fairly substantial financial compensation. "It was a very high-profile company and they were terrified about this getting out. It reflected very badly on them."

Depressing? Rob Phillips's experience was even worse. For more than two years he has been seeking recompense for psychiatric injuries inflicted by his former boss. "From the beginning he was a difficult man to get along with. His confrontational attitude was aggressive and disconcerting. He had many unpleasant habits that he displayed as a demonstration of his authority. He took a perverse pleasure in distressing people, and justified it by the notion that this kept people stretched so they could give their best. In fact, this was nothing short of brutal bullying."

Although Phillips felt suited to his job and was enjoying a certain amount of success, his boss made him feel so incompetent and worthless that in July 1997 he was diagnosed with a "mixed anxiety and depressive disorder" and has since been under the care of a psychiatrist.

"The company continues to deny that there was such a regime, although my boss was sacked within days of my bringing the situation to the notice of the chief executive. Nothing can prepare you for working with a serial bully. It is the most devastating, draining, misunderstood and ultimately futile experience imaginable."

Perhaps surprisingly, unless you can prove that the motivation behind the behaviour is sexually or racially motivated, there is no law against bullying. But that doesn't mean you should give in without standing your ground. A new book, Where Egos Dare, by Dean B McFarlin and Paul D Sweeney (Kogan Page, £17.99), argues that while ignoring the problem may seem the easiest solution, in the long term it may not be the wisest way to proceed.

The book is packed with depressing examples of atrocious managers, but the authors - both academics - offer plenty of constructive advice on how to handle them, ranging from getting the support of colleagues to making contingency plans and, in particular, putting everything in writing. You may ultimately decide you will be happier elsewhere, but making a positive decision to move is at least preferable to being signed off sick because of stress and depression.

Angela Ishmael from the Industrial Society stresses that, however malevolent your manager, it is important not to lose your personal power. She agrees that it is important to keeping a diary of aggressive incidents and suggests confiding in a colleague you trust who might be able to help you develop a strategy to cope. Don't be afraid to contact your HR department or another manager, she says - that's what they are there for after all - but if you still feel unsupported it might be worth talking to Citizens Advice or a solicitor.

If the all else fails and you feel you really must move on, don't let it shake your own self-esteem, say McFarlin and Sweeney. "Seize the moral high ground on your way out - demand exit interviews with top managers and tell anyone who will listen about what has happened. Doing so will be cathartic and allow you to leave with a clear conscience." And you'll probably feel a lot better for it.

Where to get advice

* Andrea Adams Trust: 01273 704900

* TUC: 020 7636 4030

* Women Against Sexual Harassment (Wash): 020 7405 0430

Further reading

* Where Egos Dare: The Untold Truth about Narcissistic Leaders - and How to Survive Them, by Dean B McFarlin and Paul D Sweeney, Kogan Page, £17.99

* Harassment, Bullying and Violence at Work: A Practical Guide to Combating Employee Abuse, by Angela Ishmael, The Industrial Society, £16.99.

* Bullying at Work: How to Confront and Overcome It, by Andrea Adams, Virago Press, £8.99.

* Adult Bullying: Perpetrators and Victims, by Peter Randall, Routledge, £45.
