fields.headline: Exercise your mind
fields.standfirst: Forget Einstein, there are other ways to stimulate your brain. Or so says the company behind the UK's first mind gym. Merope Mills reports
fields.trailText: Who needs gyms? Too much effort, too much sweat and way too much guilt over unused membership fees manifesting themselves in ever-expanding waistlines. Still, beauty is only skin-deep - as mother used to say, it's not what's on the outside but what's on the inside that matters.
fields.body:
Who needs gyms? Too much effort, too much sweat and way too much guilt over unused membership fees manifesting themselves in ever-expanding waistlines. Still, beauty is only skin-deep - as mother used to say, it's not what's on the outside but what's on the inside that matters.

It's no surprise then to see the innovation of the UK's first "mind gym", the latest offering from Regus, Europe's largest operator of fully serviced business centres. This is a new gimmick for people who think it pays to get out of the office once in a while, and a bit of stimulation wouldn't go amiss either.

But don't get too excited. This is not a place where you go in barely articulate and come out versed in Tolstoy. There is no Einstein, no Kant and no Nietzsche here. Instead, it is a place where some of the 5m workers estimated to be suffering from high levels of stress can come to "relax their minds and gather their thoughts," according to its creators.

The gym is intended to improve focus and perspective and aid productivity. Specialist design consultants have created two zones - one for relaxation and one for stimulation. "Workers can either 'chill out' or get an adrenaline burst," promises the breathless publicity. For those nearing boiling point, the relaxation area tempts with massages, soothing music and projections of moving shapes and colours. By contrast, the stimulation zone presumes you're already well on the way to losing the plot and so is kitted out with padded walls and a punch bag.

The gym was the brainchild of Regus's UK managing director, Sean Morgan, who admits he came up with the idea "after a particularly stressful week at work when all I wanted was to find a quiet room where I could let off steam and vent my frustrations". After 10 years working in the US and losing a lot of staff man-hours to stress-related illnesses, Morgan set up "a think-tank" with some of the blue-chip companies based in Reading and decided this was "another way we could give something worthwhile to our customers".

At the moment the Mind Gym is available only in the Reading business centre as the company assesses how the prototype is fairing with the 50-odd businesses in the building. Morgan admits most of them were sceptical at first, but argues that even the cynical are coming round to the idea. A variety of small businesses use the facilities, he says, and some users have said they enjoy having a common space for networking and socialising with other people in the building.

Among those who frequent the gym are the workers at FTSN, a company that provides high-speed internet access to the hotel industry. Andrew Travers is particularly enthusiastic about the massage bed. "It sort of makes funny noises and sends pulses through your body. After 20 minutes you could easily doze off. In fact, if I weren't so self-conscious I'd probably spend the day there."

Another unsurprising winner with the predominantly male company is the Sony Playstation. The Formula One game, says Travers, is the best training for any of their sales team who have a less than successful record on real roads. But isn't it a distraction? Not at all, says Travers. "Nipping out for five minutes on the Playstation is the ideal way to relax after you've been discussing contracts for an hour."

Regus has promised that if the Mind Gym continues to be successful in Reading it will roll out the concept regionally. But as challenging as going four rounds on Gran Turismo might be, if you want to flex your grey matter in a real mind gym, a trip to your local library during your lunch break will probably stand you in better stead.

webTitle: Net millionaires are raring to go

fields.headline: Net millionaires are raring to go
fields.trailText: Two aspiring internet tycoons will today begin developing their website ideas with the help of £1m each after winning Channel 4's E-Millionaire show.
fields.body:
Two aspiring internet tycoons will today begin developing their website ideas with the help of £1m each after winning Channel 4's E-Millionaire show.

The pair beat off competition from more than 7,000 applicants to triumph in last night's final.

Charity worker Joe Rajko, 37, from Leeds can now set up his dream site - yourable.com - which allows disabled people to buy specialised equipment online.

The site also provides information and travel guides for disabled holidaymakers.

The other victorious website - schoolsforschools.com - was the brainchild of Colin Robinson, 37, from Slough, Berkshire.

The site allows schools to save money when buying equipment by letting them group together to maximise purchasing power.

After claiming his prize Mr Rajko, a wheelchair user, said he was eager to get to work on his project.

He said: "I am elated. I am going out for a few beers but only a few because I have got to keep a clear head.

"I want to start work on the site as soon as I can."

Despite recent fears that the internet bubble could be bursting, Mr Rajko said he was confident he could make his idea succeed.

"Our profit targets are all within easy reach and I am sure we will do well.

"And I hope it will benefit disabled people enormously," he said.

Mr Robinson also expressed confidence in his idea. The technical support manager said: "It still hasn't sunk in yet. It's all a bit of a blur. But I know I have the passion and vision to make it succeed."

Out of 7,000 original ideas, 15 contestants made it through to last week's televised heats.

The winners from each show met in last night's final which was hosted by Channel 4 News presenter Jon Snow.

The £2m prize money was put up by a consortium of venture capitalists who decided on the final winners. The consortium was made up of Oxygen, Bright Station, Andersen Consulting, Skill Capital and BM Investments.

webTitle: Porn, pop, and five minutes of fame

fields.headline: Porn, pop, and five minutes of fame
fields.standfirst: As Big Brother kicks off in the UK, the German version has just finished its run, and the inmates have become the most unlikely stars. Ruth Elkins reports
fields.trailText: As Big Brother kicks off in the UK, the German version has just finished its run, and the inmates have become the most unlikely stars. Ruth Elkins reports
fields.body:
It all seemed so improbable when 13 ordinary Germans were locked in a prefab on in Cologne for 100 days. And then Germany became insanely devoted to them. But the Big Brother production company, GMG Endemol (part-owned by the Guardian Media Group), was confident from the start that it could turn them into stars. And RTL2, the commercial channel that broadcast the show, now uses them as brand builders and quota boosters. Is this the fate awaiting the UK participants?

John - the tattooed new dad with communist leanings and the eventual winner of the reality show - was once an unemployed carpenter from east Germany. Now he's a pop star and is in talks to become a radio DJ. His imaginatively titled song, Gewinner (Winner), will hit German record-store shelves in a few weeks. There's little doubt that it will be a hit. The four other singles released by ex-Big Brother inmates have been.

But John wasn't the biggest star to come out of the show. That was Zlatko. He was booted out of the house in week six, but not before he had asked the now legendary question: "Who is Shakespeare?" Pre-Big Brother, he was an unemployed industrial mechanic from the depths of southern Germany; a stocky man with hoop earrings, a gold chain round his neck and alleged violent tendencies. But he makes his Macedonian mother proud. He, too, has a pop career, had his own (rather banal) six-episode show, called Zlatkos Welt (Zlatko's World), and his new-found fame even seems to have turned him into a bit of an altruist. He declared recently: "If I were king of Germany I'd want to follow in the footsteps of Princess Di."

Sabrina left behind a world of massive debts and missed court appearances when she entered the BB house as a Zlatko's replacement. Her sister worried that her return to the real world might drive her to suicide, but she needn't have worried. A millionaire fell in love with Sabrina, a 32-year-old Cologne-born roofer with a bad perm. Michael Leicher, the self-styled "German Liberace", now wants to marry her and improve her credit rating. "The debts aren't as high as has been alleged," he said, telling Berlin tabloid BZ that he planned to pay them off and that he would have fallen in love with Sabrina even if she hadn't been on Big Brother.

Alex, last seen waving at fans from a lorry at Berlin's Love Parade 2000, has also struck it lucky. The 27-year-old Teutonic starlet Jenny Elvers allegedly left veteran German actor Heiner Lauterbach for him. Berlin tabloid BZ now respectfully uses his full name, Alex Jolig, when he "reports" for them.

But not all of the German BB inmates wanted to be stars. Kerstin is the budding actress whose suspiciously bobbing head underneath a duvet certainly gave Alex, if not the rest of Germany, something to smile about. She refused all promotional opportunities offered to her, including one to pose for Playboy, and has had a minor role in a prison soap. "All I want to do now is work on my acting career, starting from the very bottom," she said recently.

Manu - reduced to tears by fans outside the house shouting, "Manu's a slut" - was an obvious wannabe, however, and the results speak for themselves. Most weekdays, the 23-year-old law student from Hamburg can be found asking the questions on possibly the least challenging gameshow on German television - RTL2's call-and-win-cash show, Call-TV.

 Ruth Elkins writes for Die Welt (ruthelkins@berlin.com)

webTitle: Why ITN is taking the BBC to court

fields.headline: Why ITN is taking the BBC to court
fields.standfirst:
ITN chief executive Stewart Purvis on why the BBC should not be allowed to distribute online content free of charge to commercial operators
The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: ITN chief executive Stewart Purvis on why the BBC should not be allowed to distribute online content free of charge to commercial operators
fields.body:
A leading regulator told a recent gathering of senior media executives: "I had wanted to talk about the BBC, but I didn't want to be told off by Sir Christopher Bland." Fortunately the potential lash of the headmaster's tongue didn't frighten the regulator, but many in the room knew what he meant.

Campaigning for the BBC to be more defined in its remit and more transparent in its practices risks the wrath of not just Sir Christopher but of all loyal supporters of the BBC. ITN is doing things that "chaps" in broadcasting never used to do, like seeking intervention from the regulators, from government, from parliament and - if necessary - from European institutions to get fair competition in new media services.

The websites bbc.co.uk and itn.co.uk happily slug it out for "hits" with sky.com and newspaper sites like theguardian.com. Unlike many commercial operators, ITN has never had any difficulty with this. After all, we've been competing with BBC News for 45 years. ITN news programmes are now broadcast on ITV, Channel 4, Channel 5 and IRN - and from August 1 the competition hots up with the ITN News Channel going live across all digital platforms against BBC News 24.

But we do have one major problem. Most licence-fee payers already know that some of their money is spent on internet services. What they probably don't realise is that the content which is generated for bbc.co.uk at some considerable expense is then offered to a whole series of commercially funded operators for free. From the American internet portal Yahoo! to Vodafone, from BT OpenWorld to Cellnet, valuable content from the BBC News website is pumped out across all of these commercial platforms with absolutely no financial return.

Who cares? Well, for a start, the BBC should try to explain to licence payers how it can afford to be quite so generous to wealthy private sector companies when it can't even afford to buy the rights to sporting events for BBC1 and BBC2. Perhaps more importantly, if the BBC continues to offer online news content "free-to-air" on these commercial platforms, all the other news providers who have traditionally kept the BBC on its toes through vigorous competition will be crowded out of the market.

What possible incentive is there for mobile telephone companies to pay ITN - or Sky or Reuters or small, independent, content providers - when the BBC plies its wares free of charge to all-comers? A budding British creative industry is threatened with strangulation at birth. The equivalent might have been the BBC responding to the creation of ITN (in 1955) by supplying the ITV companies with free television news.

If the BBC continues this distribution strategy unimpeded by regulatory or government intervention, it will establish a monopoly "news voice" across a whole series of new platforms - mobile phones, commercial internet portals, broadband interactive services. The same services that were supposed to deliver more consumer choice, not less.

Rather than bleating from the sidelines, ITN tried the polite approach first, writing to the chairman of the governors to ask which part of the BBC charter or agreement allowed the BBC to distribute online content free-of-charge to commercial operators. We've had polite replies telling us that the provision of free content to mobile operators is a "technical trial". Our answer is that technically the service works, so why does the trial need to continue?

Now we're forced to take a rather more direct approach. ITN has put together a complaint to the office of fair trading. If it takes up our case, we could stop this practice and lots of content providers - big and small - would benefit. If the OFT doesn't, this should at least prove to government that the existing regulatory framework can't prevent market distortions, let alone ones that undermine the public good.

ITN also has an excellent case to bring before the European competition authorities - something we intend to pursue just as soon as we know whether or not the OFT will take up the case. And we're seeking legal advice on whether or not ITN can take the BBC board of governors to judicial review for failure to abide by their own charter and agreement.

This whole episode tells us all we need to know about the malaise at the heart of the BBC's self-regulatory structure. Is it any wonder that nearly every submission to government in its Communications Reform white paper consultation calls for the abolition of the board of governors? Roll on independent regulation. If nothing else, it's less expensive.

fields.headline: 'People were walking out with i-Macs under their arms'
fields.standfirst: Worldsport.com bit the dust last week. An anonymous insider tells us what happens when a dot.com dies
fields.trailText: Worldsport.com bit the dust last week. An anonymous insider tells us what happens when a dot.com dies
fields.body:
It should have been a historic meeting in the marketing of sport. In the event, it was to spell the demise of one of the most prestigious sports dot.com companies.

Until recently, worldsport.com was a website with offices in London, Monte Carlo and Florida. It boasted contracts to provide websites for dozens of international sports federations, and was negotiating for the rights to webcast their world championship events. But this was not enough for Worldsport's founder and CEO, Alan Callan. What Callan had always desperately wanted was a foot in the door of the Olympic movement. And earlier this year, he finally got his chance when Juan Antonio Samaranch, the all-powerful head of the International Olympic Committee, agreed to meet him in Lausanne.

Callan was only a couple of minutes into his presentation, sources say, when Samaranch, in his gentle, patrician manner, leant forward and said: "Alan, that is all very well, but how will you make your money?" Samaranch could not have known how pertinent this question was. Around 180 of Worldsport's employees have not received their salaries since the beginning of June, and 10 days ago, the London-registered company went into voluntary arbitration.

Half the London staff were made redundant on July 7, but had to wait for another week to find out whether they would get any of the money they were owed. They say that the buzz you get from working on a new launch cannot be matched. But after weeks of 12-, 14- and 16-hour days throughout January, February and March, in the lead-up to the relaunch of the Worldsport site, few of the editorial staff had much energy left to appreciate any buzz.

Three months later, still battling with inadequate server capacity and a main computer that could be down for up to five hours a day, the staff were not surprised when the management finally announced that the company had an uncertain future. Several employees immediately boxed up their i-Macs and took them home. Six more computers had disappeared while the announcement was being made. Other machines were later discovered to have been stripped of their memory chips. "But you know the really sad thing," one of my colleagues said, turning to me over a glass of wine on Black Friday, as we tried to work out what to do next, "there were just so many really nice people there." Indeed there were. There were also several major hitters involved: people such as Brendon Parsons, the former Daily Mirror executive responsible for the "Achtung Surrender" Euro '96 front page who famously pulled the plug on the Sporting Life; Mike Miller, headhunted from BBC Sport; and Adrian Metcalfe, the Olympic silver medallist who later became an ITV sports commentator and the first head of Channel 4 sport.

In June, four months after the relaunch, the site still had no source of revenue: no ads, no subscriptions, no pay-per-view charges to see the jerky webcast of the European indoor tug-of-war, or the Dutch junior korfball championships. And it was impossible to tell whether anyone would pay to watch such esoteric sporting lowlights, since for a long time Callan hadn't allowed anything like a counter on the site, to gauge the number of daily hits. The best estimate before the relaunch was that the site was getting just 1m visits each month, but some thought even this might be optimistic. That would have been entirely in keeping with Callan's approach to the project: optimistic and expansionist.

Yet it was also vastly over-extended. The monthly salary bill for the London office was reckoned to be close to £600,000. It was clear that there were money problems almost as soon as boo.com happened. Suddenly, Callan could no longer find venture capitalists to pour more money into his brainchild, staff were told. Robert Harding, the financial director, much respected in the City for his career in the IMF, described it in a staff meeting in May as "probably the worst situation in the market I have ever known". In fact, the situation was so bad that salaries for May were delayed.

In April, Callan was diagnosed as having a form of bone cancer, forcing him to stand down as CEO a month later and to say that he would reduce his involvement in the day-to-day running. When accountants from the Texan venture capitalists Hicks Muse swaggered through the offices at the end of June, they were greeted by many on the staff like the Seventh Cavalry coming to the rescue. Yet somehow even that deal managed to fall through. Speculation as to why was rife: some said Callan wanted £100m; Hicks Muse offered amounts varying between £20m and £40m; Hicks Muse could not see a way of turning things around quickly enough.

Whatever, a "due diligence" procedure that was supposed to take two weeks ended after seven days. Four days before the staff in London were given the news of redundancies, the Monte Carlo office had begun the process of filing unemployment claims with the French social security system. The business theory behind Worldsport was brilliant. Produce a series of websites for a host of sports federations. Pay them a modest rights fee (about £50,000 each a year) and give them a slice of the webcasting action, and then watch the millions roll in as people click on the site to watch the quarter-finals of the women's doubles at the badminton world championships or the triathlon world cup. Or not.

Because ultimately, what Worldsport lacked was a really big-name federation - the sort of deal that Sportal managed to secure with Euro 2000. Too often, Worldsport's unique selling point was that it was "dull but worthy". Where else would you see a site's news page led by a report on the qualifying competition for the Olympic women's water polo? Yet Callan had succeeded before, from equally unpromising beginnings. The Bernie Ecclestone lookalike and one-time business manager for Led Zeppelin had become a Monte Carlo tax exile after securing the marketing rights to the first two rugby world cups. He then sold his company to International Management Group, reportedly ensuring he was paid millions annually in residual rights fees. Likewise, while the World Student Games in Sheffield in 1991 may have been a commercial disaster for the city - which is still paying off the debts incurred - Callan reportedly received agency fees worth £2m.

But Callan will not be coming out of this venture a richer man. Plans to float the company on the stock market, with lucrative share options, have long been forgotten. Ten days ago, Robert Harding walked out of the office for a final time, saying that he could no longer work with Callan. A few hours later, in a conference call on a speakerphone, Callan fired Norman Howell, the managing editor. Then, last Thursday, the remaining staff were told that Callan had made a payment to the receivers to cover their salaries. Unsurprisingly, Callan was never invited back to sign a deal for the Olympics. As sports pundits are always so keen to point out, no one ever remembers the losers.

fields.headline: Car-crash television
fields.standfirst: We will be able to watch the contestants on Big Brother 24 hours a day, seven days a week for the next three months - even in the toilet. But what does our need for voyeuristic TV say about us, and what does it say about the people taking part? By Dr Raj Persaud
fields.trailText: We will be able to watch the contestants on Big Brother 24 hours a day, seven days a week for the next three months - even in the toilet. But what does our need for voyeuristic TV say about us, and what does it say about the people taking part? By Dr Raj Persaud
fields.body:
Producers of the Channel 4 TV series Big Brother claim the filming of 10 contestants night and day for nine weeks is not simply voyeuristic entertainment, but "a serious experiment in human interaction".

That mainstream TV is now offering the previously secret pleasures of the peeping Tom to millions - hidden cameras ensure every inch of the Big Brother home (including the toilets) is in view at all times - raises serious questions about why we watch.

Is this just TV trying to keep pace with the internet now that webcams can show you a couple losing their virginity or a woman giving birth? The advantage of reality TV is that it permits spying on actual social interaction.

But unlike participants in the BBC1's Castaway 2000, contestants on Big Brother have been intensively psychologically screened by a professional psychotherapist. The main criterion was their ability to get on with other people. "If we put in nine people and a lunatic, it would be great television for a day and they'd all want to leave," Conrad Green, the series editor, explains.

Yet this new TV genre owes its huge popularity to precisely the same phenomenon that makes people watch motor racing: we secretly want to see a crash, even if we are in denial about our motivation (as the Big Brother producers seem to be). We tune in to watch in the hope of seeing conflict - if everyone turns out to like each other and nothing happens, just watch the ratings plummet.

What's more, the participants are likely to be motivated to stir something up to ensure that they attract an audience. At first glance, the motivation for taking part appears even more mysterious than why anyone would want to watch. However, 40,000 people applied to be on the show. Since most people fervently believe that they lead lives of undeserved obscurity, reality TV is a vehicle for them to right that wrong. More often than not, however, it is the conviction that you are fascinating that renders you boring, hence the relatively large army of psychological professionals that the producers of Big Brother have hired to select the perfect contestants.

Voyeur TV is certainly evolving rapidly. Recent examples of the trend that began with MTV's The Real World include Fox's Who Wants to Marry a Multi-Millionaire?, and Survivor, CBS's answer to Castaway, in which 16 people were marooned and filmed on an island in the South China sea.

But the latest twist - having to win a popularity contest with fellow contestants, voted on by viewers - means these programmes are becoming ever more Darwinian. So the old psychological explanation - because we are now too busy to have relationships, we experience them instead vicariously through TV - no longer quite fits this latest mutation of reality TV.

Participants are now contestants pitted against each other to survive until the end and win a prize of £70,000. This raises disturbing questions about the psyche of the programme and of its audience. After all, the hook behind Castaway was apparently the lure of seeing a new community being constructed from nothing, giving an optimistic new-age feel to TV - even if everyone was taking side bets on who would break first and decamp to the comfort of the nearest hotel.

But survival in Big Brother is not about coping with physically adverse conditions, but socially competitive ones. So will it be more popular because it is closer to the audience's own experience? Do we want to see who will win because we want to learn something about how to succeed in our own lives?

The cash prize at the end is in fact a device to keep us diverted from the real psychology of the situation - to the exhibitionist, the actual reward is in staying on camera for longer than all the rest.

Either way, Big Brother is designed to engender competition between those sharing intimate space. This means that contestants are bound to try to double-bluff each other. They will be busy appearing indispensable and keen to be seen as allies. But behind backs, the knives will be flying. Only the audience gets to see which contestants are voting to dump each other.

Is part of the attraction of this kind of reality TV therefore that it offers a microcosm of real life in the rest of society? Do the 11 million who switch on daily for the Spanish version of Big Brother enjoy witnessing, in starker terms than is apparent around us, what we basically suspect about our friends and colleagues - that everyone plays office politics, and sleeps their way to the top, so that behind the veneer of cooperation with our neighbours only the Machiavellian survive?

This is a far more pessimistic view of relationships than has been pandered to on television before. It could well be the case that programmes like Big Brother end up revealing more about their audience than about their dissected stars.

Jacques Lacan, the late French psychoanalyst, argued that the real motivation behind the voyeur was to see everything, because of the belief that important things are constantly hidden from him. So perhaps the popularity of voyeur TV reveals how conscious we have become of the artifice behind the media. Ironically, TV is constantly attempting to re-seduce us by offering to strip away the next layer of artifice and show us the reality beneath.

The actual lesson of the original Dutch version would appear to be that Big Brother is most successful as television when it evolves into mimicking the plot dynamics of a good soap. All soaps need an irritant to which other characters must react, and the eventual winner of the Dutch Big Brother, Bart Spring, was so unpopular with his fellow contestants that they continually elected him to be the one ejected from the house.

It was only the fact that the public kept voting for him to remain that kept him in play. Also, while the sexual tension between Bart and fellow contestant Sabine was apparent from the beginning of the series, they contrived to sleep with each other only in the sixth week of filming. This presumably kept the audience voting for them both to stay, just to see what would happen.

So another tip to contestants on the British version, due to start tomorrow, is that if you are going to sleep with someone, don't do it too early on - make everyone think it could be on the cards, but keep them guessing. If you have no future twists to offer, why should the public want you to stay?

I met Bart Spring last week, and tried as fruitlessly as every other interviewer to date to ask him for his own analysis of the secret of his success. Either he is one of the most un-analytic people I have ever met - as he tried to appear by whiling our time together away telling awful knock-knock jokes - or he is just very good at keeping his personal cards close to his chest.

Indeed, maybe his lack of need to unburden himself is the key quality you need to win Big Brother. His enigmatic aloofness kept the public wanting to find out more about him, so they kept voting to keep him in while his fellow contestants could get no purchase on him at all. Bart, an ex-soldier who served in Bosnia, did eventually confess that the loss of privacy never really concerned him, because, as he said: "I am private in my head. As long as they don't know what you think, you give them nothing. There is a brick wall in my head!"

John Millz, a tattooed carpenter, won the German version of Big Brother, perhaps by bursting into tears whenever fellow housemates were booted out, maybe by making the audience anxious about how he would cope with being chucked himself. But he hasn't been seen crying since picking up his £80,000 prize.

Bart was enough of an exhibitionist to sleep with Sabine on camera, but not sharing enough with his emotions to need to continue the relationship exclusively after the show. He gave the public what they wanted, but he didn't really give himself.

It is precisely this ability to keep your personality secret and to fail to connect with those around you, thereby keeping your personal vulnerabilities to yourself, that is what the Big Brother society breeds. After all, you never know who could be watching.

 Dr Raj Persaud is a consultant psychiatrist at the Maudsley Hospital in London

This is a far more pessimistic view of relationships than has been pandered to on television before. It could well be the case that programmes like Big Brother end up revealing more about their audience than about their dissected stars. Jacques Lacan, the late French psychoanalyst, argued that the real motivation behind the voyeur was to see everything, because of the belief that important things are constantly hidden from him. So perhaps the popularity of voyeur TV reveals how conscious we have become of the artifice behind the media. Ironically, TV is constantly attempting to re-seduce us by offering to strip away the next layer of artifice and show us the reality beneath. The actual lesson of the original Dutch version would appear to be that Big Brother is most successful as television when it evolves into mimicking the plot dynamics of a good soap. All soaps need an irritant to which other characters must react, and the eventual winner of the Dutch Big Brother, Bart Spring, was so unpopular with his fellow contestants that they continually elected him to be the one ejected from the house. It was only the fact that the public kept voting for him to remain that kept him in play. Also, while the sexual tension between Bart and fellow contestant Sabine was apparent from the beginning of the series, they contrived to sleep with each other only in the sixth week of filming. This presumably kept the audience voting for them both to stay, just to see what would happen. So another tip to contestants on the British version, due to start tomorrow, is that if you are going to sleep with someone, don't do it too early on - make everyone think it could be on the cards, but keep them guessing. If you have no future twists to offer, why should the public want you to stay? I met Bart Spring last week, and tried as fruitlessly as every other interviewer to date to ask him for his own analysis of the secret of his success. Either he is one of the most un-analytic people I have ever met - as he tried to appear by whiling our time together away telling awful knock-knock jokes - or he is just very good at keeping his personal cards close to his chest. Indeed, maybe his lack of need to unburden himself is the key quality you need to win Big Brother. His enigmatic aloofness kept the public wanting to find out more about him, so they kept voting to keep him in while his fellow contestants could get no purchase on him at all. Bart, an ex-soldier who served in Bosnia, did eventually confess that the loss of privacy never really concerned him, because, as he said: "I am private in my head. As long as they don't know what you think, you give them nothing. There is a brick wall in my head!" John Millz, a tattooed carpenter, won the German version of Big Brother, perhaps by bursting into tears whenever fellow housemates were booted out, maybe by making the audience anxious about how he would cope with being chucked himself. But he hasn't been seen crying since picking up his £80,000 prize. Bart was enough of an exhibitionist to sleep with Sabine on camera, but not sharing enough with his emotions to need to continue the relationship exclusively after the show. He gave the public what they wanted, but he didn't really give himself. It is precisely this ability to keep your personality secret and to fail to connect with those around you, thereby keeping your personal vulnerabilities to yourself, that is what the Big Brother society breeds. After all, you never know who could be watching.  Dr Raj Persaud is a consultant psychiatrist at the Maudsley Hospital in London

fields.headline: Cachet, not crochet
fields.standfirst: Forget the magazines your mother read, a new breed of women's publications aims to capture the more mature - but still modern - mind. As the BBC launches Eve, the latest, in August, Jessica Hodgson studies form
fields.trailText: Forget the magazines your mother read, a new breed of women's publications aims to capture the more mature - but still modern - mind. As the BBC launches Eve, the latest, in August, Jessica Hodgson studies form
fields.body:
Gill Hudson has compiled a comprehensive list of women's magazine cliches from her years in publishing. In the editorial offices of Eve - which attempt to recreate a W1 publishing house amid the austerity of BBC Worldwide - you can be shot for using the following phrases: "Shop 'til you drop", "The gold standard", "Back to basics", "Step out in style", "On your bike", "Get up and glow" and "Shape up for summer". They head a long list to which Hudson has enthusiastically added, "Other classic cliche suggestions welcome".

Hudson is editing the BBC's biggest consumer magazine to date which launches on August 3 with a marketing budget of more than £2m and an editorial team that reads like a Who's Who of women's publishing. Fiona Hayes, who launched Russian Vogue, Harriett Jagger, former fashion director at Tatler and Harpers, and Justine Southall, previously IPC's ad director across fashion and beauty, bring blue-chip fashion credentials. There's an art team with alumni from i-D and Scene, and a panel of associate editors raided from everything from broadsheets to parenting mags.

Consumer marketing research company Mintel published a report in 1998 predicting the impact of changing demographics on the women's magazine market. Women would become older, richer and less housebound. Between 1994 and 1998, all growth in the female population came from women aged between 35 and 65. Mintel said that the twentysomething population - the largest market for women's magazines - would decline sharply by 2002. The constituency of the market would also polarise, with growth in the numbers of affluent ABC1s, and decline among the C2s and Ds.

After the launch of Red in 1998, and the highly successful revamp of older women's magazine staple Woman's Journal (circulation rose 29% in the six months since the relaunch), publishers are avidly chasing this market. Earlier this year, Dennis Publishing launched PS, Eve Pollard's Parkhill launched Aura and IPC relaunched 60s style magazine Nova. Grüner and Jahr has delayed publication of "Project Florence" for six months amid rumours that IPC is in talks to buy the company, but the magazine is now scheduled to launch shortly after Eve. John Brown Publishing's Bare is also due for a late summer launch.

A generation weaned on Cosmopolitan and Elle is maturing, and it no longer wants to lurch abruptly from orgasms to origami. The "how to get four family meals out of a shank of lamb" school of women's journalism seems a sudden jolt for affluent mothers versed in the black arts of childcare and the Marks & Spencer ready meal.

Helena Jaworski-Lang, launch editor of G+J's Project Florence, says: "Women still grow up but they don't buy the same magazines their mothers buy. I wouldn't want to buy the same magazines my mother bought."

It's not just about lifestyle. Hudson and others believe there's a widening gap between the "breathy kind of girliness" that speaks through the standard crop of older women's magazines and the increasingly diverse babble of real women over the age of 35. If the traditional older women's magazine suppressed the raucous joy of the freedom years in a rictus of self-denial, modern mature women speak in a style that is "very direct and self-revelatory", she says.

Having overseen the launch of Dennis Publishing's Maxim and Stuff, Hudson felt stultified by the contrast offered by women's mags. "We don't talk to each other like this and haven't done for years. It's a kind of disease infecting women's magazines and even good writers think, 'Women's magazine piece - the gold standard' and they're off. And you're thinking, 'Hang on, you wrote a brilliant piece for the Observer last week. Why are you writing like this for me?'

"What seems extraordinary to me is that, given that humour is the prime way women communicate, this is not reflected in women's magazines at all. You do get the odd funny slot but it's always either Maureen Lipman or Vanessa Feltz and it's always relegated to the back page."

Hudson is unwilling to spill the beans on why Eve is going to make us laugh, but think Christine and Neil Hamilton doing a Mr and Mrs, both grilled for hours in airtight rooms about everything from life in the public eye to their sex lives. ("Is your sex life vanilla, raspberry ripple or knickerbocker glory? Read on.")

Eve will also be different in that it will call on the BBC's resources for editorial support. Hudson is cagey about how this will work in practice, but drops names such as Alan Yentob, director of drama, entertainment and children's programming, and BBC2 chief Jane Root as examples of people who've promised to keep her in the loop. Hudson says that Eve will benefit from the BBC's global infrastructure and that she will have no compunction about raiding it for "sociology, sexuality, global politics, the environment, anything that will make you go, 'Ooh, well I never' when you hear it at a dinner party".

It will also feature a "mythbusters" section, designed, according to Hudson, to give people the "confidence to go, 'Well that's a load of ...' to some of the stuff you read in the Daily Mail." And look out for sexy older women modelling grown-up fashion.

But isn't a sexy, aspirational women's magazine from the BBC a contradiction in terms? One women's magazine journalist says: "The BBC is fundamentally unsexy and Eve risks becoming the Dome of women's publishing - a kind of Blairite manifesto for the modern woman." Clearly Hudson isn't going to let this happen without a fight, but for women who equate the BBC with Biddy Baxter and John Birt, it's going to be a tough sell.

If TV is any yardstick, Eve could also face censure from commercial publishers wary of it cross-fertilising its editorial from the corporation's considerable resources. Although BBC Worldwide has commercial guidelines to prevent cross-promotion or subsidising of commercial operations from licence-fee funding, senior figures are keeping a beady eye on events. Good Housekeeping's editor-in-chief Lindsay Nicholson (who presided over a relaunch that increased GH's sales to just below 400,000) notes that "Being part of the BBC is a huge commercial advantage. If it's a good magazine we welcome decent competition. If it's a bad magazine and it distorts the market we will be concerned."

Privately, journalists on other women's glossies admit they are treating Eve as a real threat. But many warn that it risks making the same mistake as Frank - launched in 1997 by Wagadon as an "alternative" women's mag and now awaiting its fate at the hands of Emap, which bought the group last year.

Elsa McAlonan, editor of Woman's Journal, is sceptical about the readers' readiness for such a broad remit. "Current affairs and architecture?" she wonders. "I think I'd read a newspaper or look at the internet for that. A good magazine should be a treat, like an expensive bubble bath or a box of chocolates. You've got to make the most of the glossy, visual format."

Others say the market has more to fear from US-style magazine formats such as Condé Nast's Glamour, due for a spring launch, and Time Warner's In Style. One observer notes: "The beauty of In Style is that it doesn't pretend to be anything other than what it is, which is a frothy women's magazine. There are so many women's launches that are supposed to be different and we've heard it all before."

Nicholson says identifying the niche is only half the battle. "The market is undeniably there. It's just that women in this age group have well-formed opinions. It's a mistake to assume you can just come in and talk to them in the way you can in a younger market."

Jane Reed, News International's outgoing communications chief and a former editor of Woman and Woman's Own, agrees: "I think the 30s and 40s are quite separate from the 50s. Going from 35 to 45 is fine. Once you get over 45 you've got to face up to it." Reed thinks magazines in the "post-childrearing sector" (over 45) have an opportunity to re-engage women in debates and interests they may not previously have had time for, so there is a new diversity. "But a successful magazine should always have that 'Mars Bar on a wet Saturday afternoon' factor. You've got to think carefully, not just about what women want to read, but when and why they read a magazine."

Upmarket advertisers are naturally keen to tap into a market of wealthy, liberated and aspirational women. But if Girl Power was an insecure, malleable adolescent, Woman Power is a more mercurial force. The planners and buyers know it's a vast, uncharted territory, but it's much harder to pin down.

Eve Pollard recalls going to buy her first convertible: "The young man in the showroom was staring at me and I went up to him and said, 'You think I'm too old for this, don't you?' And he said, 'No, Ms Pollard, you're just the sort of customer we want,' but he was a bit scared by this point. I think some of the kids in ad agencies can't believe there are women alive after the age of 35."

And as the market diversifies, titles will have to make do with smaller circulations, according to Bryony Brampton, press buying director for media agency Universal McCann. "The market will support these launches up to a point but they will go for lower circulations than the Marie Claires and Cosmopolitans." This in turn creates a need for magazines to attract higher-end advertising.

But Caroline Baker, formerly fashion editor on the old Nova and now fashion director at the Mail on Sunday's You magazine, believes this may be wishful thinking. "The British magazine publishing establishment is hard to break into because of the relationship between publishing houses and the fashion industry," she says. "The fashion industry hasn't traditionally been large enough to support that many glossier, smaller circulation magazines, and with British manufacturing in decline, the situation isn't going to improve."

Advertisers are privately worried about Aura, which has seen two sales directors and an editor depart since its launch. John Brown's Bare - which targets women (and advertisers) interested in natural health, is also said to be a worry because of the "very nichey" nature of its pitch.

But in spite of favourable demographic predictions, there are more general worries about the future of women's glossies. The last ABCs - to December 1999 - show a growth in the total audited market of 15%. But the four largest new launches in the period were customer loyalty magazines. Magazines set up by big consumer goods companies or marketing organisations to create loyalty or boost databases are eating into the territory of the consumer women's magazine. However, consumer women's magazine publishers are confident that readers still want editorial objectivity and something that customer loyalty titles can't give them - a "voice", according to G+J's Jaworski-Lang.

"The fundamental thing is that if you get the voice of the magazine right you can write about pretty much anything," says Jane Reed, and she should know. "That's why Wallpaper works so well. It travels through all sorts of subjects, some quite obscure, but because its voice is so strong it can accommodate them." Eve, Aura, Nova and all the others are trying to invent a voice for a new and fragmented generation.

But Caroline Baker of You offers a warning to publishers not to shy away from confronting the age problem. "Women of my generation - and younger - have seen some fantastic changes in their lifetime. Where is the magazine for the Germaine Greers? Where is the mag for the woman who wants to wear leather and hang out with Mick Jagger? You can't get away with describing something as ageless. We're all tribes and we are - like it or not - defined by age. But we shouldn't be afraid to confront it."

webTitle: A caravan on the back of a Ferrari

fields.headline: A caravan on the back of a Ferrari
fields.standfirst: Simon Waldman on the gap between fantastic theory and the clunky reality when it comes to Wap
fields.trailText: Simon Waldman on the gap between fantastic theory and the clunky reality when it comes to Wap
fields.body:
Wap is crap. You might have heard this already, but what was once simply a neat rhyme - and a reminder that it is not pronounced "wop" - has now become something of a mantra among the digerati. It takes its place alongside "the banner is dead" and "content is king".

Jakob Nielsen, the internet usability guru - he charges $35,000 for a one-day seminar, so he must be a guru; up to $15,000 you are merely a consultant, more than $50,000 and you are a visionary - long ago declared that Wap stands for 'Wrong Approach to Portability'.

Last week he was back on the Wap attack. In his influential Alertbox column (find it at www.useit.com) he wrote: "Wap has miserable usability for many reasons: ridiculously small screens, slow bandwidth, and the need to place a new call every time the device needs to connect. The digits-only keypad is a laughable input device... Also, the actual telephones vary in their design and sometimes have poor human factors that don't deliver as good a user experience as would be possible under the given constraints."

He had been visiting the UK NetMedia 2000 conference where he found: "Most speakers... proclaimed Wap a temporary aberration that delivers sub-standard services."

As the proud owner of a Nokia 7110 for the past few months, I can indeed confirm that it really is rather frustrating. The most fun I have had has been downloading the theme to Mission Impossible as my ringtone - although that can be done on any phone so it doesn't count. I have found it useful a couple of times for picking up news or sports results and about once a week have a click around in pursuit of something wonderful, but on the whole it is just too fiddly to be truly useful.

My initial sense of wonderment at Wap still remains; it is amazing that you can access information anywhere. It's just that the gap between the fantastic theory and the clunky reality is vast.

Wap suffers even further because this clunkiness sits inside one of the most useful inventions of the past century. The combination of a global roaming mobile phone with SMS messaging (why does anyone need email on their phone when they have SMS?) makes for a rather excellent communication tool - which is why more than 50% of us now own one. Adding Wap to this mix is like attaching a caravan to the back of a Ferrari.

In contrast to this, however, on the other side of the hand-held forest, we have experienced something of a resounding success with the launch of a Guardian Unlimited channel on AvantGo (www.avantgo.com). This allows the ever-growing number of handheld users to download almost the entire copy of the day's paper whenever they synch with their PC.

Suddenly this thing in which you used to store your diary and phone numbers suddenly becomes a news medium. In contrast to the Ferrari/ caravan combination above, this is more like putting rocket fuel in a VW Beetle.

I stopped using it ages ago. But we have been attracting around 100 new subscribers a day to the service for the past three months. And the feedback is tremendously positive. We have had a number of people overseas becoming confirmed readers because of the service and others in the UK switching their choice of paper because they can now get ours on their Palm Pilot and read it on the way into work.

There are two things that are important here. Whether on Wap or Palm or GPRS or whatever, the mobile platform is going to be huge. Portability is a potent offering (it has stood newspapers in good stead for centuries), and media owners are mad if they do not realise that they will have to make themselves available on it in some form or other if they want to have any mass appeal in the future.

For this reason we are quite happy to put these temporary glitches to one side and carry on with our Wap trials with the likes of BT Cellnet and Orange, just to find out what is going to work both for us and for users and advertisers.

The second point is a bit of context. Great technological innovations always tend to start out rather uselessly. It was not so long ago that friends of mine were nipping round to my flat to witness this new internet thing and then going off to write features about how slow/rubbish/generally pathetic it was. Now, they sit in their own flats and write business plans in a belated rush to become dot.com millionaires.

The greatest example of this is the first PC, the Altair 8800. To the casual observer, it was little more than a box with some lights and switches on it - no monitor, no keyboard, not even a built-in solitaire game. Had you or I seen it, we would quickly have pointed out that it did absolutely nothing at all and dismissed the whole phenomenon. But a young undergraduate thought it was rather cool and started to develop a programming language for it. His name, of course, was Bill Gates.

My initial sense of wonderment at Wap still remains; it is amazing that you can access information anywhere. It's just that the gap between the fantastic theory and the clunky reality is vast. Wap suffers even further because this clunkiness sits inside one of the most useful inventions of the past century. The combination of a global roaming mobile phone with SMS messaging (why does anyone need email on their phone when they have SMS?) makes for a rather excellent communication tool - which is why more than 50% of us now own one. Adding Wap to this mix is like attaching a caravan to the back of a Ferrari. In contrast to this, however, on the other side of the hand-held forest, we have experienced something of a resounding success with the launch of a Guardian Unlimited channel on AvantGo (www.avantgo.com). This allows the ever-growing number of handheld users to download almost the entire copy of the day's paper whenever they synch with their PC. Suddenly this thing in which you used to store your diary and phone numbers suddenly becomes a news medium. In contrast to the Ferrari/ caravan combination above, this is more like putting rocket fuel in a VW Beetle. I stopped using it ages ago. But we have been attracting around 100 new subscribers a day to the service for the past three months. And the feedback is tremendously positive. We have had a number of people overseas becoming confirmed readers because of the service and others in the UK switching their choice of paper because they can now get ours on their Palm Pilot and read it on the way into work. There are two things that are important here. Whether on Wap or Palm or GPRS or whatever, the mobile platform is going to be huge. Portability is a potent offering (it has stood newspapers in good stead for centuries), and media owners are mad if they do not realise that they will have to make themselves available on it in some form or other if they want to have any mass appeal in the future. For this reason we are quite happy to put these temporary glitches to one side and carry on with our Wap trials with the likes of BT Cellnet and Orange, just to find out what is going to work both for us and for users and advertisers. The second point is a bit of context. Great technological innovations always tend to start out rather uselessly. It was not so long ago that friends of mine were nipping round to my flat to witness this new internet thing and then going off to write features about how slow/rubbish/generally pathetic it was. Now, they sit in their own flats and write business plans in a belated rush to become dot.com millionaires. The greatest example of this is the first PC, the Altair 8800. To the casual observer, it was little more than a box with some lights and switches on it - no monitor, no keyboard, not even a built-in solitaire game. Had you or I seen it, we would quickly have pointed out that it did absolutely nothing at all and dismissed the whole phenomenon. But a young undergraduate thought it was rather cool and started to develop a programming language for it. His name, of course, was Bill Gates.

webTitle: Black market now open for business

fields.headline: Black market now open for business
fields.standfirst: Websites for and by British Afro-Caribbeans are belatedly acquiring users, says Chantal Benjamin. But they are desperately short of advertising from blue-chip companies
fields.trailText: Websites for and by British Afro-Caribbeans are belatedly acquiring users, says Chantal Benjamin. But they are desperately short of advertising from blue-chip companies
fields.body:
A few years ago, black people in the UK used to dub the internet the "world white web". Cyberspace was an ethnically-cleansed environment aside from a few black American sites.

"The mainstream media have let us down," says Caroline Joseph of Blacknet. "Even when broadcasters like the BBC or Channel 4 run black stories on the web they are from a white perspective."

Things are changing now, with a plethora of UK-based Afro-Caribbean websites making their own impact. Blacknet, Blink, Blackbritain and Voice-online are all news and information sites attracting hundreds of thousands of page views daily. But why did black British people take so much longer than their white counterparts to get online?

Karl Wilson of Blacknet.co.uk thinks there were two key reasons: "First, the internet was an invisible status symbol. It wasn't like a mobile phone or a new car or the latest gizmo which you can physically show off. Of course that's all changing now with Wap technology. In the early days, in the mid-90s when my brother and I used to leaflet the night clubs to promote our new site, most of the black people leaving the club had never heard of the internet. Secondly, black people weren't being given job opportunities in the IT sector and therefore didn't see it as a career."

Launched in February 1997, Blacknet is now one of the UK's favourite black community sites, with thousands of discussions and forums taking place on its site every week. The site also offers news and information, a dating agency, soul food recipes and a monthly community networking event which attracts a range of people, from senior managers to students and the elderly.

However, in the early days just using the word "black" for your website was considered risky. Advertisers seemed not to like anything with the word in it.

But Blacknet was clear that its goal was not to make its founders dot.com millionaires. It was determined to be a grassroots community networking group with close personal links to the people the site serves.

The strategy has paid off. Channel 4 turned to Blacknet for promotional support when it launched the Richard Blackwood series. An upmarket, formal ball for black professionals held at the City of London's Mansion House attracted more than 1,000 people who were accessed through Blacknet's massive database. "We are close to our users and we contact them regularly with offers of events and opportunities to meet, so they really trust our brand. We're not just a faceless software package," says Wilson.

It's true that the black websites offer far more specific and targeted information than mainstream news sites. You can read a history of homosexuality in Africa, find out where in Birmingham to get extensions put in your hair, and discover more about sickle cell anaemia, a condition that specifically affects black people.

But despite the claims of all the webmasters that their sites are attracting anything from 100,000 to 200,000 page views a day, blue-chip companies like British Airways, Marks & Spencer and BMW are conspicuously absent from any banner advertising. Part of the reason may be that many black websites are not properly audited for usage and that their webmasters are keen to promote their own sites. Each one I spoke to claimed to be both the first black British information site and the most accessed.

None the less, it is obvious that many of these sites are attracting large groups of people who are hard to reach through mainstream advertising campaigns. In addition, their users spend longer on the sites than users of more popular mainstream sites - and they tend to be educated and well-off.

The commission for racial quality estimates that in 10 years' time, 40% of people in urban Britain under the age of 25 will be black or Asian. It's a young market that few companies can afford to ignore - and yet they do ignore it. Is it racism or short-sightedness that has kept black British websites a virtually ad-free zone?

Blackbritain.co.uk is a news and information site that, like Blacknet, also aims to be a portal for other black websites. But while Blacknet is community-based, Blackbritain is concerned with making money out of the web. Its managing director, Kofi Kusitor, laughs about the lack of interest from corporate Britain.

"To be honest, I don't think it's racism," he says. "They just don't realise how much spending power and influence the black middle classes now have in this country. A recent survey put the power of the black and brown pound as high as £15bn a year. Half of that is in London alone."

Kusitor has managed to attract a limited amount of sponsorship from Virgin. He is damning, however, about the lack of support from the black press when he started.

"I remember having meetings with the black press in the late 90s when I was starting up this website and they just were not interested in coming in with me then. I was trying to get them to understand that the world is moving faster now and people don't want to wait seven days for news from their weekly black paper. But in October 1997 Tony Sewell, leader writer at the Voice, wrote an article saying the internet was dead and advised readers to steer clear of it."

The Voice now runs its own website for readers and promotes its subscriptions on Kusitor's site. Blackbritain now has seven permanent staff and uses 22 freelances across the country to generate stories and content. Kusitor is now a paper millionaire. But unless he can create a cash flow from blue-chip advertisers then it seems likely that virtual millions are all he will reap.

Perhaps the real problem is that there is so little accredited research about black internet users. This week a new report becomes available from Peoplescience.com, a company specialising in Afro-Caribbean and Asian lifestyles research. In its sample, 56% were single - which perhaps suggests that you need to be single to spend lots of time in chat rooms. More surprising, perhaps, 50% had one PC at home, 27% had two and 10% had three or more PCs at home. This flies in the face of received wisdom, which has black internet users logging on gratefully from their schools, universities or places of work. The sample's primary reasons for using the internet were to connect with other black people, to do research, to find products and as an educational or business tool.

New black sites are coming on stream daily. But to survive they need the support of advertisers and sponsors. When huge companies like boo.com fail and even the mighty Amazon.com is deemed a dodgy investment, is there any hope at all for the black websites?

webTitle: I want it cheaper, and I want it now

fields.headline: I want it cheaper, and I want it now
fields.standfirst: John Sutherland: On the death of retailShopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: John Sutherland: On the death of retail
fields.body:
What do the following have in common: Mark Z Danielewski's horror novel, House of Leaves; the John Cusack-starring movie, High Fidelity and Vinnie Jones's latest excursion into the world of film, Gone in 60 Seconds?

All of them are (or will be) hot-button topics in the British press in summer 2000. And all of them were ditto in the American press in spring 2000. Danielewski's book, published last week in the UK, came out in the US in March. It's The Blair Witch Project in print; grungy, low-gloss, amateur-night Stephen King but clever with it. Like the movie it will be big - first there, then here.

High Fidelity, Nick Hornby's cosy lament for vinyl, has been relocated to Chicago. The film came out in April in the US. Probably not one in a 100 of the audience knew or cared about its alien origin. America bought the British product, repackaged it and, when it is good and ready, it'll sell it back to Britain. Sheep that we are, we will queue up patiently and buy.

British villains are flavour of the month in Hollywood. Gone in 60 Seconds is a carjack thriller. The bad guys (very, very bad) all have Italian names and south-London accents. Vinnie Jones is recruited as the good bad guy. Unfortunately, American audiences can't be trusted to understand his accent so he has to act dumb (literally) throughout (there's a nice twist at the end). The movie came out in late May. We'll get the scratched prints when it drops off American screens sometime soon. Or perhaps not. We'll be patient and grateful.

Product sequencing suits the merchandisers. It is convenient to have your main markets lined up like dominoes and your consumers patient as sheep. British distributors and publishers know, ahead of time, what the big items will be and can allocate advertising budgets accordingly. The stars and bestselling authors, having fulfilled their US schedules, are available for a UK tour - if they can be bothered to make the trip.

The future of British fiction, as Martin Amis put it, is American. And film, and television. We follow our (American) leader. But it's more complex than that. Harry Potter's latest instalment, for instance, was simultaneously released in the US and UK on July 8. It is number one in both markets, was originated here and is ultra-English. Norman G Finkelstein's The Holocaust Industry, a book aimed directly at American readers and interests, has been available in the UK marginally earlier than in the US. That's because it is published - here and there - by a small left-wing British press, Verso (perhaps because the big publishing houses, on both sides of the Atlantic, were terrified of Jewish-American backlash).

If one stands back a bit one can see the imminent convergence of two vast cultural forces: globalisation and e-commerce. British customers could, for example, have ordered House of Leaves from Amazon.com (but not its British subsidiary, Amazon.co.uk) in March. Doubtless some did. In a year or two's time you will be able to download the latest movie releases as easily as you can now get chart-toppers on Napster. Sequencing, in either direction, will soon be irrelevant. Customers will go round it.

This leads to the fundamental question: why have retailing, or e-tailing, at all? Americans are just waking up to the fact that (like us) they are royally ripped off when they buy cars. You go online and do research and decide what model you want. But, having done your research, you must go to a dealer (or its website) to buy your vehicle. Every American state has laws that make it illegal to buy cars direct from the manufacturer. What is the dealer doing - other than raking in a 40% commission? So too with books and movies. You cannot buy from the publisher or the studio. You have to go to a bookseller (walk-in or virtual), a cinema, or a video store and pay a whopping middleman commission. Customers will, quite soon, find a web-route round him as well.

I think Amazon is doomed - at least as an e-tailer. Who wants electronic bookshops? What one wants is a cataloguing or finding service (charging a lot less than the 40% bookseller's mark-up) that will direct one to the manufacturer. No wait, no surcharge. I've seen the future, and it's impatience.
